University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Whan that Aprill with
The droughte of Marche hath ꝑperced to
And bathed euery veyne / in such licour
Of which vertue / engendred is þᵉ flour
And zephirus eke / with his swete brethe
Enspired hath in euery holt and hethe
The tendre croppes / and the yonge sonne
Hath in the Ram / his half cours yronne
And smale fowles maken melodie
That slepen al the nyght with open eye
So priketh hem nature / in here corages
Than longen folk / to gon in pilgrimages
And palmer forto seke / straunge strondes
To ferne halwes / cowthe in sondry londes
And specialy / from euery shires ende
Of Englond to Cauntirbury they wende
The holy blisful martir / forto seke
That hem hath holpen / whan that they were seke
Byfell that / in that sesoıı̄un on a day
In Suthwerk at the Tabard as I lay
Redy to wenden / on my pilgrimage
To Cauntirbury with ful devoute corage
At nyght was come / into that hostelrie
Wel nyne and twenty in a companie
Of sondry folk / by auenture yfalle
In felshuppe / and pilgrimes were they alle
That towarde Cauntirbiry wolde ryde
The chambres and the stables weren wyde
And wel were esed at the beste
And shortly whan the sonne was to reste
So hadde I spoken with hem euerychon
That I was of her felashuppe anon
And made forward erly forto rise
To take oure way there as I you deuise
But nathalees / whil I have tyme and space
Er that I ferther in this tale pace
Me thinkith it accordaunt to resoıı̄un
To telle you al the condicio
Of eche of hem / so as it semed me
And whiche they were / and of what degre
And eke in what aray / that they were Inne
And at a knyght / than wol I first bygynne
A knyght therwas / and that a worthy man
That fro the tyme / that he first bigan
To riden out / he loued chiualrie
Trouthe and honoᵘur / fredam ⁊and curtesie
Ful worthi was he / in his lordes werre
And therto hadde he ryden / no man ferre
As wel in cristendome / as in hethenesse
And ever honoured / for his worthinesse
At Alisaundre he was / whan it was wonne
Ful often tyme / he hadde the bord bygonne
Above all nacions / in Pruce
In lettow had he reised and in Ruce
No cristen man / so ofte of his degree
In Genade at the seege / eek had he bee
Of Algezir / and riden in Belmarie
At leyes was he / and at Satalie
Whan they were wonne / and in the grete see
At many a noble arme / had he be
At mortall batailes / hadde he be fiftene
And foughten for oure faith at Tramissene
In lystes thries / and ay slayn his fo
This ilk worthy knyght / hadde ben also
Sumtyme with the lorde of Palatye
Ageyn another hethen / in turkye
And evermore / he had a souerayn pris
And though that he was worthy / he was wys
And of his port / as meke as is a mayde
He never ȝit / no vilenie ne seide
In al his lyf / vnto no manere wight
He was a verray ꝑparfit gentil knyght
¶ But forto telle you / of his aray
His hors were goode / but he was not gay
Of fustian / he wered a Gipou
Al bysmotered / with his habirgeou
For he was late ycome / from his viage
And went forto done / his pilgrimage
With hym ther was / his sone / a yonge squyer
A louier a lusty bacheler
With lokkes crulle / as they were leide in presse
Of xxᵗⁱ yere of age / was he as I gesse
Of his stature / he was of euene lengthe
And wonderly deliuer / and grete of strengthe
And he hadde ben somtyme / in chiuachie
In Flaundres in Artoys / and in picardie
And born hym self / as of so litel space
In hope to stonden / in his lady grace /
Enbrawded was he / as it were a mede
All ful of fressh floures / white and rede /
Syngynge he was / or flowtynge al the day
He was as fressh as is the monthe of May
Short was his gowne / with sleves longe and wyde
Wel couthe he sitte on hors / and fayre ryde /
He couthe songes make / and wel endite
Iust and eke daunce and wel portroye and write
So hote he loued that by nyghter tale
He slepe no more / than doth a nyghtyngale
Curteys he was / lowely and seruisable
And carf bifore his Fader atte table
A yeman hadde he / and ʆseruᵃntes no mo
At that tyme / for hym lust to ride so
And he was clad in coote and hood of grene
A sheef of pecok arwes / brighte and kene
Vndir his belte / he bar ful thriftily
Wel couthe he dresse / his takel yomanly
His arwes drouped nought / with fethers lowe
And in his hande / he bar a myghty bowe
A not heed hadde he with a brou visage
Of wodecraft / wel couthe he al the vsage
Vpon his arme / he bar a gay bracer
And by his syde / a swerd and a bokeler
And on that other syde / agay daggere
Harneised wel / and sharpe as poynt of spere
A xpofre on his brest / of syluer shene
An horne he bar / the bawdrik was of grene
A Forster was he / sothely as I gesse
Ther was also / a Nonne a prioresse
That of hir smylynge was ful symple and coy
Her grettest othe / was but by seynt Loy
And she was cleped / ma dame Englentyne
Ful wel she songe / the seruice deuyne
Entuned in hir nose / ful semely
And frenssh she spak / ful faire and fetisly
After the scole of Stratford atte Bowe
For frenssh of Paris / was to hir vn knowe /
At mete wel y taught was she with alle
She lett no morsell / fro hir lippes falle
She wette hir fyngers in hir sauce depe
Wel couthe she carie a morsel / and wel kepe
That no drope / ne fille vpon hir breste
In curteisie was sette / ful moche hir leste
Hir ouerlippe / wyped she so clene
That in hir cuppe / ther was no ferthing sene /
Of grece whan she dronken hadde hir draught
Ful semely / after hir mete she raught
And sikerly she was of grete disport
And ful plesant / and amyable of port
And peyned hir / to counterfete chere
Of court / and to ben estately of manere
And to ben holden / digne of reuerence
But forto speken of hir conscience
She was so charitable / and so pitous
She wolde wepe / if she sawe a mous
Kaught in a trappe / if it were ded or bledde
Of smale houndes / hadde she / that she fedde
With rosted flessh / or mylk or wastel brede
But sore wepte she / if eny of hem were dede
Or if men smote it with a yerde smerte
And al was conscience / and tendernesse of herte
Ful semely hir wympel / pinched was
Hir nose was streight / hir eyen grey as glas
Hir mouthe ful smale / and therto softe and rede
But sikerly she hadde a faire forhede
It was almost a spanne brode I trowe
For hardely / she was not vndergrowe /
Ful fetys was hir cloke / as I was war
Of smale coral / a boute hir arme she bar
A peire of bedys / gauded al with grene /
And theron henge / a broche of gold ful shene
On which ther was first wreten a crowned A
And after / amor vincit omia .
Another nonne with her hadd she
That was hir Chapeleyn and prestes thre /
A Monk ther was / a fair for the maistrie
An out Rider / that loued venerie
A manly man / to ben an Abbot able
Ful many a deynte hors / hadde he in stable
And whan he rode / men myghte his bridell here
Chinkynge in a whistelynge wynde / as clere
And eke as lowde / as doth the chapel belle
Ther as this lorde / was keper of the celle
The rewle of seynt Maure or of seynt beneit
By cause / that it was old / and somdel streit
This ilke monke / leet olde thynges pace
And heeld after the newe world the space
He ȝaf nought of the text / a pulled hen /
That seith / that hunters / be nought holy men
Ne that a monk / whan he is recheles
Is likned til a fissh / that is waterles
This is to say / a monk out of his cloystre
But thilk text / heeld he nought worth an oystre
And I seide / his opiniou / was right good
What shulde he studie / or make hym self wood
Vpon a book / in cloystre / alwey to poure
Or swynke with handes / or laboure
As Austeyn bid / how shal the world be ʆserued
Lat Austeyn have / his swynk to hym reʆserued
Therfore he was a prikasour aright
Grehoundes he hadde / as swifte as foul in flight
Of prikyng / and of huntyng for the hare
Was al his lust / for no coste wolde he spare
I sigh his sleves ypurfiled at the honde
With grys / and that the fynest of a londe
And forto festene his hood / vnder his chynne
He hadd of gold ywrought / a ful curious pynne
A loue knotte / in the gretter ende ther was
His heued was balled / that shon as eny glas
And eke his face / as he hadd ben anoynt
He was a lord ful fat / and in good poynt
His eyen stepe / and rolled in his hede
That stremed / as a furneys of lede
His botes souple / his hors in grete astate
Now certeynly / he was a faire prelate
He nas not pale / as a forpyned gost
A fat swan loued he / best of eny rost
His palfrey was as brou / as aberie
A Frere ther was a wantou and a merye /
A lymytour a ful solempne man
In alle the ordris foure / is ther noght oon that can
So moche of daliance / and faire langage
He had made ful many a mariage
Of yong women / at his owne cost
Vnto his ordre / he was a noble post
Ful wel biloued / and famuler was he
With Frankeleyns / ouer al in his countre
And with worthy women of the tou
For he had power of confessiou
As seide hym self / more than a curat
For of his ordre / he was licenciat
Ful swetely / herde he confessiou
And plesant / was his absoluciou
He was an esy man / to yeve penance
¶ There as he wiste to have a good pitance
For vnto a pouere ordre forto yeve
Is signe that a man is wel yshryve
For yif he ȝaf he dorste make auaıı̄unt
He wiste that a man was repentant
For many a man so hard is of his herte
He may not wepe / al though hym sore smerte
Therfore in stede of wepynge / and praiers
Men moste yeve syluer / to the pore freres
His typet was ay farsed ful of knyves
And pynnes / forto yeve faire wyues /
And certeynly he hadde a mery note
Wel couthe he syngen / and pleyn on a rote /
Of ȝeddynges / he bar vtterly the pris
His nekke whyt / as is the flour delys
Therto he was stronge / as is a Champioıı̄un
He knewe the tauerners / wel in euery toıı̄un
And euery hostiler / and Tapster
Bet than a lazar / or a begger
For vnto suche / a worthy man as he
Accorded nought / as by his faculte /
To have with suche sike lazares acquyntaıı̄unce
It is noght honest it may noght avaıı̄unce
For to dele with such porayle
But al with riche / and sellers of vitayle
And over al there / as ꝓprofite shulde arise
Curteis he was / and lowely of ʆseruise
Ther nas no man / nowher so vertuous
He was the best begger / in his hous
For though a widewe / hadde noght a sho
So plesant was his In principio
Ȝit wolde he have / a ferthyng or he wente
His purchas was wel better / than his rente
And rage he couthe / as it were a whelpe
In louedaies / there cowde he moche helpe
For there was he noght lyk a cloystrer
In a thredbare cope / lyk is a poủere scoler
But he was lyk / a Maister or a pope
Of double worstede / was his semycote
That rounded was as a belle / out of the presse
Sumwhat he lipsed / for his wantownesse
To make his englissh / swete vpon his tonge
And in harpyng / whan he hadde ysonge
His eyen twynkled in his hede a right
As don the sterres / in the frosty nyght
This worthy lymytoᵘur / was cleped huberd
A Marchaunt with a forked berd
In motle / and high on hors he sat
Vpon his heued a flaundrissh beuere hat
His botys clasped faire and fetisly
His resons he spak / ful solempnely
Shewyng alway / the encres of his wynnynge
He wolde the see / were kept / for eny thynge
Bitwixt Middelburgh and Orwelle
Wel couthe he in eschaunge sheeldes selle
This worthy man / ful wel his witte bisette
Ther wiste no wight / that he was in dette
So estately was he / of his gouernaıı̄unce
What with his bargeynes / and his cheuissaıı̄unce
For sothe / he was a worthy man with alle
But sothely to seien / I not how men hym calle
A Clerk ther was of Oxenforde also
That vnto logyke / longe tyme hadde ygo
As lene was his hors / as is arake
And he nas not right fat I vndertake
But loked holwe / and therto soberly
Ful thredbare was his oủerest courtepy
For he hadde geten hym no benefice
Ne was so worldly / forto have office
For hym was leuere / have at his beddeshede
Twenty bokes clad in blak and rede
Of Aristotil and his philosophie
Than robes riche / fithel or gay sawtrie
But al be that / he was a phylosophre
Yit hadde he but litel golde in his cofre
But al that he myght / of his frendes hente
On bokes / and on lernynge / he it spente
And besely gan / for the soules preye
Of hem / that hym yave werwith to scoleye
Of studie toke he most cure and hede
Nought oo word spak he / more than was nede
And that was saide in forme and reuerence
And short and quyk and ful of high sentence
Sownyng in moral vertue / was his speche
And gladly wolde he lerne / and gladly teche
A Sergeant of the lawe war and wys
That ofte hadde ben at Parvys
That was also ful riche of excellence
Discrete he was / and of grete reuerence
He semed such / his wordes were so wise
Iustice he was / ful ofte in assise /
By patent / and pleyn cōmmyssiou
For his science / and for his high renou
Of fees and robes / hadde he manyon
So grete a purchasour was nowher non
Al was fe symple / to hym in effecte
His purchasynge / myght not ben infecte
Nower so besy a man / as he / ther nas
And yet he semed besier than he was
In termes hadde he caas / and domes alle
That fro the tyme / of kyng William were falle
Therto he couthe endite / and make a thing
Ther cowde no wight pynche at his writynge
And euery statute / cowde he pleyn by rote
He rode / but homely / in a medly cote
Girt with a seint of silk / with barres smale
Of his aray / telle I no lenger tale /
A Frankeleyn was in his companie
White was his berde / as is the dayes eye
Of his complexiou / he was sangwyne
Wel loued he by the morowe a sop in wyne
To leuen in delite / euere was he wone
For he was epitures owne sone
That heelde opiniou / that pleyn delite
Was verray felicite ꝑparfite
An housholder / and that a grete was he
Seynt Iulian / he was in his Cuntre
His breed his ale / was alwey after oon
A better envyned man / whas nowher noon
Withoute bake mete / was neuer his hous
Of fissh and flessh / and that so plenteuous
It snewed in his hous / of mete and drynke
Of alle deyntes / that men cowde thenke
After the sondry sesons of the yere
So chaunged he his mete / and his sopere
Ful many a fat partrich / hadde he in mewe
And many a breme / and many a pike in stewe
Wo was his cook / but his sauce were
Poynant and sharp / and redy all his gere
His table dormant / in his halle alway
Stode redy coủered / al the longe day
At sessions / ther was he lorde and sire
Ful ofte tyme / he was knyght of the shire
An anlas / and a gipser all of silk
Heeng at his girdell / white as morne mylk
A shereue hadde he ben / and accomptoᵘur
Was nowher such a worthy vauasoᵘur
An haberdassher / and a Carpenter
A Webbe a dyer and a Tapicer
And they were cloded alle in o lyuere
Of a solempne and a grete fraternyte
Ful fressh and newe her gere ypiked was
Hir knyves were nought chaped with bras
But al with siluer wrought ful clene and wel
Her gurthels and her powches eủerydel
Wel semed eche of hem / a faire burgeys
To sitten in a yildehalle on a deys
Euerich for the wisdam that he can
Was shaply forto ben an alderman
For catel they hadde ynowe and rente
And eke her wyves wolde it wel assente
And ellis receyue they were to blame
It is ful fair to be cleped ma Dame
And gon to vigilies al bifore
And have a mantel rialliche ybore
A Cook they hadde with hem for the nones
To boyle chekenes with the maribones /
And pouder marchant / tart and galingale
Wel knewe he a draught of londou ale
He cowde roste / boyle and frie
Maken mortreux and wel bake a pie
But grete harme was it / as it thought me
That on his shyne / a mormal hadde he /
For blank manger / that made he with the beste
A Shipman was there / wonynge fer by weste
For ought I wote / he was of Dertemouthe
He rood vpon a Rouncy / as he couthe /
In a gowne of faldyng / to the kne
A dagger hangynge in a lace hadde he
Abovte his nekke / vnder his arme a dou
The hote sonne / hadde made his hewe albrou
And certeynly / he was a goode Felawe
Ful many a draught of wyn hadde he drawe
Fro Burdeuxward / while the Chapmen slepe
Of nyce conscience / toke he noo kepe
Ȝif that he faught / and hadde the higher hande
By water he sente hem home to euery lande
But of his craft / to rekne wel his tydes
His stremes / and his daungers hym bysides
His herberwe his mone / and his lodemenage
Ther nas no suche / fro hull vnto Cartage
Hardy he was / and wys to vndertake
With many a tempest / hadde his berd ben shake
He knewe all the havenes / as they were
Fro Guthlond to the cape of fynystere
And euery cryke in Brytayne and in Spayne
His barge ycleped was the Mawdelayne
With hym ther was a Doctour of phisik
In alle the worlde / ne was ther non hym lyk
To speke of phisik and of surgerie
For he was grounded in astronomie
He kepte his pacient / a ful gret dele
In houres / by his magik naturelle
Wel cowde he fortune the ascendent
Of his ymages / for his pacient
He knewe the cause of euery maladye
Where it of hoot or cold / or moyst or drye
And where engendred / and of what humoᵘur
He was a verray ꝑparfit practisour
¶ The cause yknowe / and of his harme the roote
Anon he yaf the seke man his boote
Ful redy hadde he his apothecaries
To sende hym his drugges and his letuaries
For eche of hem / made other forto wynne
Her frenshipe nas nought newe to bygynne
Wel knewe he the olde Esculapius
And diascorides / and eke Rufus
Olde ypocras / haly and Galien
Serapiou Razie / and auicen
Auerois Damascien and constantyn
Bernard and Gatesden / and Gilbertyn
Of his diete / mesurable was he
For it was / of noo suꝑparfluite
But of grete norisshinge and digestible
His studie / nat but litel in the bible
In sangwyn / and in perse / he clad was all
Lyned with taffata / and with sendall
And yet he was / but esy of dispense
He kepte / that he wan in pestilence
For gold in phisik is a cordial
Therfore he loued gold in special
A goode wyf ther was of biside bathe
But she was somdel deef and that was scathe
Of cloth makyng / she hadde suche an haunt
She passed hem of Ipris / and of Gaunt
In al the parissh /wyf wyf ne was ther noon
That to offring / bifore here shulde goon
And ȝif ther dide certeyn / so wroght was she
That she was out / of alle charite /
Hir couerchiefs ful fyne were of grounde
I dorste swere they weyed ten pounde
That vpon a sonday were vpon here hede
Hir hosyn were of fyne scarlet rede
Ful streit ytied / and shoos ful moiste and newe
Bolde was hir face / and faire / and reed of hewe
She was a worthy woman al hir lyve
Husbondes atte chirche dore / hadde she had fyve
Withoute other company in yowthe
But herof nedeth nought forto speke as nowthe /
And thries hadde she ben at Ierusalem
She hadde passed many a strange streem
At Rome hadde she ben / and at Boloyne
In Galice at seynt Iame and at Coloyne
She couthe moche of wrandryng by the weye
Greed tothed was she / sothely forto seye
Vpon an ambler al esely she sat
Ywympled wel and on her heed an hat
As brood as is a bokeler or a targe
A foot mantel abovte hir hipes large
And on hir feet / a paire of spores sharpe
In felawshipe wel cowthe lawghe and carpe
Of remedies of lowe / she knewe ꝑperchaunce
For she cowthe of that art the olde daunce
A goode man was there of Religioıı̄un
And was a poor ꝑpersou of a toıı̄un
But riche he was of holy thought and werk
He was also a lerned man / and a Clerk
And cristes gospell trewely wolde preche
His parisshens deuoutely wolde he teche
Benigne he was / and wonder diligent
And in aduersite ful pacient
And suche he was preved ofte sithes
Ful looth were hym to curse for his tithes
But rather wolde he yeven out of doute
Vnto his poor parisshens aboute
Of his offryng / and of his substance
He cowthe in lytel thing / have suffisance
Wyde was his parissh / and houses fer assonder
But he ne lefte nought / for reyn ne thonder
In sekenes nor in meschief to visite
The ferthest in his parissh / moche and lite
Vpon his /feet and in his hande a staf
This noble ensample / vnto his sheep he yaf
That first he wroughte / and after ward he taughte
Out of the gospel / he thoo wordes kaughte
And this figure he added therto
That yef gold ruste / what shal Iren do /
For yef a preest be foul in whom we truste
No wonder is a lewed man to ruste
And shame it is ȝif a preest take kepe /
A shite sheꝑ parde and a clene shepe
Wel oughte a preest ensample forto ȝiue
By his clennes / howe his sheep shulde liue
He set noght his benefice to hire
Ne lett his sheep acombred in the myre
And ren to londou vnto seynt paules
To seke hym a chauntry for soules
Or with a bretherhede to ben witholde
But dwelled at home / and kepte wel his folde /
So that the wolf / ne made it not miscarie
He was a Shepperde / and not a mcernarie /
And though he holy were / and vertuous
He was not to synful men dispitous
Ne of his speche / daungerous ne digne
But in his speche / discreet and benigne
To drawen folke to heuene by fayrnesse
By good ensample / this was his besynesse
But it were ony ꝑpersone obstinate
What so he were of lowe or high estate
Hym wolde he snybbe / sharpely for the nones
A better preest I trowe / that nowher non ys
He wayted after / no pompe ne reuerence
Ne maked hym a spiced conscience
But cristes lore / and his appostels twelue
He taught but first he vsed it hym selue
With hym ther was a ploughman was his brother
That hadde ylad of dong ful many a fother
And a trewe swynker / and a good was he
Lyvynge in pees / and ꝑparfite charitee /
God loued he best / with al his herte
At all tymes / though hym gamed or smerte
And than his neghbour / right as hym selue
He wolde dresshe / and therto dyke and delue
For cristes sake / for euery pore wight
Withoute hire / ȝif it lay in his myght
His tithes paied he / ful faire and wel
Bothe of his propre swynke / and his catel
In a tabbard he rode vpon a mere
Ther was also a Reve and a Millere
A sompnoᵘur and a pardoner also
A maunciple / and my self / ther were no moo /
The Millere was a stout carle for the nones
Ful big he was of brawn and eke of bones
That preved wel / for ouer al ther he cam
At wrastlyng / he wolde have a wey the ram
He was short shuldred a thikke knarre
Ther ne was no dore / that he ne wolde heue of harre
Or breke it at a rennynge with his heed
His berd as any sowe or fox was reed
And therto brood as though it were a spade
Vpon the cop right of his nose he hade
A werte and ther on stode / a tuft of heres
Rede as the bristelles of a sowes eres
His nose thrilles / blake were and wide
A swerde and a bokeler / bar he by his syde
His mouthe was asgret as a gret furneys
He was a iangeler and a golyardeys
And that was most of synne / and of harlotries
Wel couthe he stele corn / and tollen thries
And yet he hadde a thombe of golde parde
A whyte cote and a blewe hood wered he
A bagge pipe wel couthe he blowe and sowne
And ther with al he broughte vs oute of towne
A gentil maunciple was there of a temple
Of which achatoᵘurs myghte take exemple
For to ben wise in beynge of vitayle
For wheither that he paied / or toke by tayle
Algate he wayted so in his achat
That he was ay biforn in good astat
Now is not that of god a ful faire gᵃce
That suche a lewde mannes wit shal pace
The wisdam of an heep of lerned men
Of maistres hadde he / mo than thries ten
That were of lawe / expert and curious
Of whiche ther were a doseyn in that hous
Worthy to ben stywardes / of rent and lond
Of eny lorde / that is in Englond
To make hym leve / by his ꝓpropre good
In honoᵘur dettelees / but ȝif that he were wood
Or leve as scarcely as hym list desire
And able for to helpen al a shire
In eny caas that myght falle or happe
And ȝit this Maunciple sette he alther cappe
The Reue was a slender colrik man
His berd was shave / as nygh as ever he can
His her was by his eres ful rounde yshorne
His top was dokked / lyke a preest biforn
Ful longe were his legges and ful lene
Y lyke a staf / ther was noo calf ysene
Wel couthe he kepe / a gerner / or a bynne
Ther was noon auditoᵘur / couthe on hym wynne
Wel wiste he / by the draughte / and by the reyne
The yeldenge of his seed and of his greyne
His lordes sheep / his neet / his dayerie /
His swyn / his hors / his store and his pulletrie
Was holy in this Reves gouernynge
And by his couenᵃnt ȝaf he his rekenynge
Syn that his lorde was twenty yere of age
Ther couthe no man / brynge hym in arrerage
Ther nas bayly / heerde ne other hyne
That he ne knewe his sleighte and his covyne
They were a drad of hym / as of the deth
His wonynge was ful faire vpon an heth
With grene trees shadwed was his place
He couthe better than his lorde purchace
Ful riche he was / astored pryvely
His lorde he cowthe plesen wel subtily
To yeve and lene / hym his owne good
And have a thanke / and yet a coote and a hood /
In youthe he hadd lerned a good mystere
He was a wel goode wrighte a Carpyntere
This Reve sat vpon a ful good stoot
That was al pomely grey / and highte scoot
A longe surcote of peers bliwe he hadde
And by his side / he bar a rusty bladde
Of Norfolk was this Reve / of whiche I telle
Biside a tou / men clepe Baldeswelle
Tukked he was / as is a frere aboute
And ever he rode / the hynderest of oure route
A Sompnoᵘur was there wᵗith vs in that place
That hadde a firy cherubynnes face /
For sawceflem he was / with eyen narwe
And as hoot he was / and lecherous as a sparowe
With scalled browes / blaak and peled berd
Of his visage childern weren afferd
Ther nas quik syluer / litarge nor brimston
Borace ceruse ne oyle of trarter non
Ne oynement that wolde clense and byte
That hym myght helpe / of his whilkes whyte
Nor of the knobbes syttynge in his chekes
Wel loued he garlyk oynons and leekes
And forto drynke strong wyn red as blood
Than wolde he speke / and crie / as he were wood
For whan that he wel dronken hadde the wyn
Than wolde he speke no word but latyn
A fewe t̉ermes hadde he / twoo or thre
That he hadde lerned out of som decre
No wonder is / he herde it al the day
And eek ye knowen wel / how that a Iay
Can clepe watte / as wel / as can the pope
But who so couthe / in other thinges hym grope
Than hadde he spende / al his philosophie
Ay questio / quid iuris wolde he crye /
He was a gentil harlot / and a kynde
A better felawe shulde men not fynde
He wolde suffre / for a quart of wyn
A good felawe to have his concubyn
A twelf monthe / and excuse hym atte fulle
Ful priuely eke / a fynche couthe he pulle
And if he fonde owher a good felawe
He wolde techen hym to have non awe
In suche caas / of the Erchedekens curs
But if a manes soule were in his purs
For in his purs he shulde punysshed be
Purs is the Erchedekens helle seide he
But wel I wote / he lyed right in dede
Of cursyng oughte ech gilty man to drede
For curs wol sleen / right as assoilyng saueth
And also war hym of a signyficauit
In daunger hadde he / at his owne gyse
The yonge gerles / of the diocise
And knewe her counsaill / and what was al her rede
A garland hadde he / sette vpon his hede
As grete as it were / for an ale stake
A bokeler hadde he / made hym of a cake
With hym ther rode / a gentil ꝑpardoner
Of Rouncyvall / his frende and his comper
That streght was come / fro the court of Rome
Ful lowe he song / come hider loue to me
This sompnoᵘur bar to hym / a stif burdou
Was never trompe / of half so grete a sou
This ꝑpardoner hadde heer / as yelwe as wax
But smothe it henge / as doth a strike of flax
By ounces henge his lokkes / that he hadde
And ther with he / his shulders ouerspradde
But thynne it lay / bi culpus oon and oon
But hood for iolyte / wered he non
For it was trussed vp in his walet
Hym thought he rode / al on the newe Iet
Discheuele saaf his cappe / he rode al bare
Suche glaringe eyen / hadde he as an hare
A vernicle hadde he / sewed vppon his cappe
His walet lay bifore hym / in his lappe
Bretful of pardou / comen fro Rome al hoot
A voys he hadde / as smale as a goot
No berde ne hadde he / ne never shulde have
As smothe it was / as it were late shave
I trowe he were / a geldyng or a mare
But of his craft / fro Berwik into ware
Ne was ther such / another ꝑpardoner
For in his male / he hadde a peliwber
Which that he seide / was oure lady veyl
He seide he hadde / a gobet of the seyl
That seynt petir hadde / whan that he wente
Vpon the see / til Ihu Crist hym hente
He hadde a croos of latou / ful of stones
And in a glas / he hadde pigges bones
But with thise relikes / whan that he fond
A poủere ꝑpersone / dwellynge vpon lond
Vpon a day / he gat hym more moneye
Than the ꝑpersou gat / in monthes tweye
And thus with fayned flateringe and iapes
He made the ꝑpersou / and the peple his apes
But trewly to tellen / at the laste
He was in churche / a noble ecclesiaste
Wel couthe he rede / a lessou or a storie
But altherbest / he song an offretorie
For wel he wiste / whan that songe was songe
He muste preche / and wel affile his tonge
To wynne syluer / as he wel couthe
Therfore he song / so merily and lowde /
Now have I tolde you / sothely in a clause
The estate the array / the nombre and eke the cause
Why that assembled was / this companye
In southwerk / at this gentil hostelrie
That highte the tabbard / fast by the belle
But now is tyme / to you forto telle
How that we baren vs / that ilke nyght
Whan we weren / in that hostelrie a lyght
And after wol I tellen / of oure viage
And al the remenant of oure pilgrimage
But first I pray you / of youre curtesie
That ye ne rette it / noght my vilenie
Though that I pleynly speke in this matere
To tellen you her wordes / and here chere
Ne though I speke / her wordes proꝑperly
For this ye knowen / as wel as I .
Who so shal telle / a tale after a man
He moot reherse / as neght as eủere he can
Euery word / yf it be in his charge
Al speke he neuere / so rudely or large
Or elles he moot telle / his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thinges / or fynde wordes newe
He may not spare / al though he were his brother
He moot as wel say / oo worde as another
Crist spak hym self / ful brode in holy writte
And wel ye wote / no vilenie is it
Eke plato seith / who so can hym rede
The wordes / mote be cosyn to the dede
Also I pray yow / foryeve it me
Al have I nought sett folk in her degre /
Here in this tale / as they shulde stonde
My wit is short / ye may wel vnderstonde
Gret chere made oure host vs euerichon
And to the souper / set he vs anon
He ʆserued vs / with vitaylls / at the best
Stronge was the wyn / and wel to drinke vs leste
A semely man / oure host was with alle
For to ben a marchal / in a lordes halle
A large man he was / with eyen stepe
A fairer burgeys / ys ther non in chepe
Bolde of his speche / and wys / and wel ytaught
And of manhode / hym lakked right nought
¶ Eke therto he was / right a mery man
And after soper / to pleien he bigan
And spak of merthe / amonge other thinges
Whan that we hadde made oure rekenynges /
And seide thus / now lordinges trewely
Ye ben to me / welcome right hertely
For by my troughe / yf that I shal not lye
I sawgh nought this yere / so mery a companye
At ones in this herberwe / as is nowe
Fayne wolde I done you / merthe wiste I howe
And of merthe / I am right now bithought
To don you ese / and it shal coste nought
¶ Ye gon to Cauntirbury / god you spede
The blisful martir / quyte yow / youre mede
And wel I wote / as ye gon by the weye
Ye shapen you / to talken / and to pleye
For trewely confort / ne myrthe is non
To ryde by the weye / dombe as eny ston
And therfore wole I maken you disport
As I seide arst / and don you som confort
And if yow liketh alle / by oon assent
Forto stonden / at my Iugement
And forto wirken / as I shal you seye
¶ To morowe / whan we ryden by the weye
Now by my Faders soule / that is ded
But ye be merye / I wol yeve you myn hed
Holdeth vp youre handes / withoute more speche
Oure counseill / was nought longe forto seche
Vs thoughte it was not worth / to make it wys
And graunted hym / withoute more avys
And bad hym say / his verdite as hym lyste
Lordinges qd he / now herkeneth for the beste
But take it nought I pray you in disdeyn
This is the poynt to speke short and pleyn
That eche of you / to short with oure weye
In this viage / shal telle tales tweye
To Cauntirbury ward I mene it so
And homward / he shal tellen other two
Of auentures / that whilom have bifalle
And whiche of you / that bereth hym best of alle
That is to seyn / that telleth in this caas
Tales of best sentence / and of moost solas /
Shal have a soper / at oure alther cost
Here in this place / sittyng by this post
Whan that we comen ageyn fro Cauntirbury
And for to make you / the more mery
I wol my self / goodely with you ryde
Right at myn owne cost / and be youre gyde
And who so wole / my iugement withseye
Shal paie for al / we spende by the weye
And if ye vouchesauf / that it be soo
Tel me a non / withoute wordes moo
And I wol erly / shape me therfore
This thyng was graunted / and oure othes swore
With ful glad herte / and prayen hym also
That he wolde vouchesauf / forto done so /
And he wolde ben oure gouernour
And of our tales / Iuge and reportour
And sette a soper / at a certeyn pris
And we wol rewled ben / at his devys /
In hight and lowe / and thus by oon assent
We ben accordet / to the iugement
And ther vpon / the wyn was fet a non
We dronke / and to reste wente echon
Withoute eny / lenger tariynge
A morowe / whan the day bygan to sprynge
Vp roos oure host and was oure alther cok
And gedered vs / to geder in a flok
And forth we reden / a lytel more than a pas
Vnto the waterynge of seynt Thomas
And than oure host / gan his hors a reste
And seide lordinges / herkenith if you leste
Ye wote youre forward and I it recorde
Ȝif euensong / and morow song accorde
Lat se now / who shal telle the firste tale
As euere mote I drynke wyn or ale
Who so be rebel / to my iugement
Shal paie for al / that by the way is spent
Now draweth cut / or that we ferther twynne
Which that hath the shortest / shal first bygynne /
¶ Sire knyght qduod he / my maist̉er and my lord
Now draweth cut / for that is myn acord
Cometh ner qduod he / my lady prioresse
And sire Clerk / lat be youre shamefastnesse
Ne studieth nought / ley hand to eủery man̄
Anon̄ to drawe / euery wight bigan̄
And shortly forto tellen / as it was
Were it by auenture / or sort or cas
The sothe is this / the cut fel to the knyght
Of whiche ful blithe / and glad was euery wight
And tellen he muste his tale / as was resoıı̄un
¶ By forward and by composiciıı̄un
As ye han̄ herd / what nedeth wordes mo /
And whan this good man / saugh that it was so
As he / that wys was / and obedient
To kepen̄ his forward / by his fre assent
He seide sithen / I shal begynne the game
What welcome / be the cut / in godes name
Now lat vs ride / and herkeneth what I seye
And with that word / we riden̄ forth oure weye
And he began̄ / right with a mery chere
His tale anon̄ / and seide as ye may here /

¶ Iamqȝue domos patrias Scithice post asꝑpera gentis
Prelia laurigero ¶ In Stacio thebaⁱdes
Whilom as olde stories / tellen vs
Ther was a duk / that highte Theseus
O Athenes / he was lord and gouernour
And in his tyme / such a conquerour
That gretter was non̄ / vnder the sonne
Ful many a riche countre / hadde he wonne
What with his wysdam / and his chiualrie
He conquered / al the Regne of Femynie
That whilom was called Scithia
And wedded / the queen ypolita
And brought hir home / with hym in his cuntre
With moche glorie / and grete solempnite
And eke hir yonge suster Emelye
And thus with victorie / and with melodye
Late I this noble Duk / to Athenes ride
And al his host / in armes hym beside
And certes / ȝif it nere to longe to here
I wolde have tolde / fully the manere
How wonnen was / the Regne of Femynie
By Theseus / and by his chiualrie
And of the grete batyle / for the nones
Bitwixt Athenes / and amazones
And how biseged was ypolita
The faire hardy queen of Scithia
And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
And of the tempest / at hir home comynge
But al that thyng / I mote as now forbere
I have god wote / a large felde to ere
And wayke ben̄ / the Oxen / in my plough
The remanent of the tale / is longe ynow
I wol note lette / eke non̄ of this route
Lat eủery felawe / telle his tale aboute
And lat see now / who shal the soper wynne
And ther I lefte / I wol ageyn̄ bigynne
This duk / of whom I make mencioıı̄un
Whan he was comen / almost to the toıı̄un
In al his wele / and his most pride
He was ware / as he cast his eye asyde
Where that there kneled / in the high weye
A company of ladies / tweye and tweye
Eche after other / cladde in clothes blake
But such a crye / and such a wo they make
That in this worlde / nys creature lyuynge
That herde such another waymentynge
And of this crie / they nolde never stynte
Tyl they the Reynes of his bridel hente
What folk ben ye / that at myn̄ home comynge
Perturben̄ so my feste / with criynge
Quod Theseus / have ye so grete envie
Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crie
Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
And telleth me / ȝif it may be amended
And why that ye / ben clothed thus in blak /
¶ The oldest lady / of hem aƚƚ spak
Whan she hadde swowned / with a dedly chere
That it was rowthe / forto seen and here
She seide lorde / to whom fortune hath yeven̄
Victorie / and as a conquerour to lyuen̄
Not greveth vs / youre glorie / and youre honour
But we biseche / mercy and socour
Have mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
Som drop of pite / thurgh thy gentilnesse
Vppon vs / wrecched women / lat thow falle
For certes lorde / ther is non̄ of vs alle
That she ne hath ben̄ / a duchesse or a queen̄
Now ben̄ we caytives / as it is wel seen̄
Thanked be fortune / and her fals wheel
That noon̄ estate / ensureth to be weel
Now certes lorde / to abide youre p̉resence
Here in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
We have ben waytynge / al this fortenyghte
Helpe vs lorde / sitthe it is in thy myghte
I wrecche whiche / that wepe and wayle thus
Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
That starf at Thebes / cursed be that day
And alle we / that ben̄ in thus array
And maken / al this lamentacioıı̄un
We losten / aƚƚ oure husbondes at that toıı̄un
While that thassege / ther aboute lay
And ȝit nowe / the olde Creon̄ weleaway
That lorde is nowe / of Thebes the Citee
Fulfilled of ire / and of iniquite
He for despite / and for his tirannye
To done the dede bodyes / vylanye
Of alle oure lordes / whiche that ben̄ slawe
Hath alle the bodies / on an heep ydrawe
And wol nought suffre hem / by noon̄ assent
Neither to ben / yburied / nor ybrent
But maketh houndes / to eten̄ hem in despite
And with that withoute more respite
They fallen gruf / and criede pitousely
Have on vs wrecched women / som mercy
And lat oure sorowe / synke in thyn herte
This gentil duk / doıı̄un from his courser sterte
With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
Hym thoughte that his herte / wolde breke
Whan he saugh hem / so pitouse / and so mate
That whilom were / of so grete astate
And in his armes / he hem aƚƚ vp hente
And conforted hem / in ful good entente
And swore his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
He wolde done so ferforthly / his myght
Vpon̄ the tyraunt Creon̄ / hem to wreke
That al the peple / of Grece sholde speke
How Creon̄ was / of Theseus serued
And he that hadde / his deth wel deserued
And right anon̄ / withoute more abood
His baner he displayed / and forth rood
To Thebes ward / and al his host beside
No ner Athenes / wolde he go ne ride
Ne take his ese / fully half a day
But onward on his way / that nyght he lay
And sent anon̄ ypolyta / the queene
And Emelye / hir faire Sust̉er shene
Vnto the toıı̄un / of Athenes to dwelle
And forth he ritte / ther nys no more to telle
¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
So shyneth / in his white baner large
That al the felde glitereth / vp and doıı̄un
And by his baner / born̄ was his pynoıı̄un
Of golde ful riche / in whiche ther was ybete
The Mynotaur / that he wan̄ in Crete
Thus ritte thus duke / thus ritte this Conqueroᵘur
And in host / of chiualrie the flour
Til that he come / to Thebes / and a lighte
Faire in a felde / there as he thought to fighte
But shortly forto speken / of this thyng
With Creon̄ which / that was of Thebes kyng
He faught / and slough hym manly as a knyght
In pleyne bataile / and put the folk to flyght
And by assaut / he wan̄ the Cite after
And rente adoıı̄un / bothe wall and sparre and rafter
And to the ladies / he restored ageyn̄
The bones of hir lordes / that were slayn̄
To done obsequies / as was the gise
But it were al to longe / forto deuise
The grete clamoᵘur / and the waymentynge
That the ladies made / at the brennynge
Of the bodies / and the grete honour
That Theseus / the noble conquerour
Doth to the bodies / whan they from hym wente
But shortly to tellen / is myn̄ entente
Whan that this worthy duk / this Theseus
Hath Creon̄ slayn̄ / and wonne Thebes thus
Stille in that felde / he toke al nyght his reste
And dide with al the cuntre / as hym leste
To ransake in the chaas / of the bodies dede
Hem forto strepe / of harneys and of wede
The pilours diden / besines and cure
After the bataile / and discomfiture
And so bifel / that in the caas they founde
Thurgh girt / with many a greuous blody wounde
Two yonge knyghtes / liggyng by and by
Bothe in oon̄ armes / wrought ful richely
Of whiche two / Arcite hight that oon̄
And that other knyght / hight palamon̄
Not fully quik / ne fully ded they were
But by here cote armours / and by here gere
The heraudes knewe hem / best in special
That they were / of the blood roial
Of Thebes / and of two susters yborn̄
Out of the chaas / the pilours han hem torn̄
And have hem caried / softe vnto the tente
Of Theseus / and ful sone hem sente
To Athenes / to dwellen in prisoıı̄un
ꝐPerpetuely / he nolde no raunsoıı̄un
And whan this worthy duke / hath thus ydon̄
He toke his host / and home he rit anon̄
With laurer corouned / as a conquerour
And there he lyueth / in ioye and in honoᵘur
Terme of his lyf / what nedeth wordes mo
¶ And in a tour / in angwissh and in wo
Dwellen this palamon̄ / and eke Arcite
For evermore / ther may no golde hem quite
This passeth yere by yere / and day by day
Til it fel ones / in a morwe of may
That Emelye / that faire was to sene
Than̄ is the lilie / vpon his stalke grene
And fressher than the Maij / with floures newe
For with the rose coloᵘur / strof hir hiewe
I noot which was the fairer / of hem two
Er it were day / as was hir wone to do
She was arisen / and al redy dight
For may wol have / no slogardye a nyght
The sesoıı̄un priketh / euery gentil herte
And maketh it / out of his sleep to sterte
And seith arise / and do May obseruance
This maketh Emelye / to have remembrance
To don̄ honour to May / and for to rise
Yclothed was she / fressh for to deuise
Hir yelwe heer / was breyded in a tresse
Be hynde hir bak / a yerde longe I gesse
And in the gardyn̄ / at the sonne vprist
She walketh vp and doıı̄un / and as hir list
She gedereth floures / patie white and rede
To make a subtile / garland for hir hede
And as an aungel / heuenishly she songe
The tour that was / so grete thikke and stronge
Which of the castel / was the chief dongeoıı̄un
Ther as the knyghtes / weren in prisoıı̄un
Of whiche I tolde you / and telle shal
Was euene ioynant / to the gardeyn̄ wal
Ther as this Emelie / hadde hir pleyinge
Bright was the sonne / and clere in that mornynge
And palamon / this woful prisoner
As was his wone / by leue of his gailer
Was risen / and romed / in a chambur an high
In which / he al the noble Cite sigh
And eke the gardeyn / ful of branches grene
There as the fresshe Emelie / the shene
Was in hir walk / and romed vp and doıı̄un
This sorweful prisoner / this palamoıı̄un
Goth in the chambre / romyng to and fro
And to hym self / compleynynge of his wo
That he was born̄ / ful ofte he seide allas
And so bifel / by auenture or caas
That thurgh a wyndowe / thikke of mony a barre
Of iren̄ grete / and square as eny sparre
He caste his eyen / vpon̄ Emelia
And ther with al / he bleynte / and cried A .
As thoughe he stongen were / vnto the herte
And with that cry / Arcite anon̄ vp sterte
And seide cosyn̄ myn̄ / what eyleth the
That art so pale / and dedly onto se
Why criedestow / who hath the done offence
For godes loue / take al in pacience
Oure prison̄ / for it may non other be
Fortune hath yeven vs / this aduersite
Som wikke aspect / or disposicioıı̄un
Of saturne / by som constellacioıı̄un
Hath yeven vs this / al though we hadde it sworn̄
So stood the heuene / whan wan whan that were born̄
We mote endure / this is short and pleyn̄
¶ This palamon̄ / answered and seide ageyn̄
Cosyn̄ for sothe / of this opinioıı̄un
Thou hast a wronful / ymaginacioıı̄un
This prison̄ / caused me noght to crye
But I was hurt right nowe / thurgh out myn̄ eye
Into myn̄ herte / that wol my bane be
The fairenesse of that lady / that I se
Yonder in the gardeyne / romen to and fro
Is cause / of al my cryinge / and my wo
I noot whether she be / woman or goddesse
But venus is it / sothely as I gesse
And ther with al / on knees doıı̄un he fil
And seide venus / yf hit be thy wyl
You in this gardeyne / thus to tᵃransfigure
Bifore me sorweful / wrecched creature
Out of this prison̄ / helpe that we may scape
And ȝif so be / my destine be shape
By et̉erne worde / to dyen in prisoıı̄un
Of oure lynage / have som compassioıı̄un
That is so lowe ibrought / by tirannie
And with that worde / Arcite gan aspie
Where as this lady / romed to and fro
And with that sight / hir beaute hurte hym so
That ȝif that palamon̄ / was wounded sore
Arcite is hurte / as moche as he or more
And with a sike / he seide pitously
The fresshe beaute / sleeth me sodeinly
Of hir that rometh / in the yonder place
And but I have / hir m̉ercy / and hir gᵃrace
That I may seen hir / atte leste way
I ne am but ded / ther is no more to say
¶ This palamon̄ / whan he thise wordes herde
Dispitousely he loked / and answerde
Whether seystow thus / in ernest or in pley
Nay quod Arcite / in ernest by my fey
God helpe me so / me luste ful euely to pleye
This palamon̄ / gan knette his browes tweye
It were to the / quod he no grete honour
For to be fals / ne forto be traitour
To me that am / thy cosyn̄ and thy brother
Ysworn̄ ful depe / and eche of vs tyl other
That neủere / forto dyen in the peyne
Til that the deth / departe shal vs tweyne
Neither in loue / to hyndere other
Ne in noon other caas / my leve brother
But that thou sholdest / trewely forther me
In euery caas / and I shal forther the
This was thyn̄ othe / and myn̄ also certeyn̄
I wote right wel / thou darst nought withseyn̄
Thus art thou of my counsel / out of doute
And now thou woldest / falsly ben̄ aboute
To loue my lady / whom I loue and serue
And ever shal / vntil myn herte sterue
Now certes fals Arcite / thou shalt not so
I loued her first / and tolde the my wo
As to my counseill / and my brother sworn
To forther me / as I have tolde biforn̄
For whiche thou art ybounden as a knyght
To helpe me / ȝif it lay in thy myght
Or ellis artow fals / I dar wel sayn̄
¶ This Arcite ful proudly / spak agayn̄
Thou shalt qduod he / ben rather fals than I
And thou art fals / I telle the vtterly
For ꝑparamour / I loued hir first or thou
What wiltow seyn̄ / thou wist it noght ȝit now
Wheither she be a woman / or a goddesse
Thyn is affeccioıı̄un / of holynesse
And myn̄ is loue / as a creature
For whiche I tolde the / myn̄ auenture
As to my cosyn̄ / and my brother sworn̄
I pose that thou / louedest hir biforn̄
Wostow nought wel / the olde clerkes sawe
That who shal yeue / a louer eny lawe
Loue is a gretter lawe / by my pan
Than may be yeven / to eny erthely man
And therfore posityf lawe / and such decree
Is broke alday / for loue in eche degree
A man moot nedes loue / mawgre his hede
He may not fleen it / though he shulde be ded
Al be she mayde / widewe / or ellis wyf
And eke it is not / likly al thy lyf
To stonden in hir gᵃrace / no more shal I
For wel thou wost / thy self verraily
That thou and I / ben dampned to prisoıı̄un
ꝐPerpetuely / vs gayneth no raunsoıı̄un
We stryue as dide / the houndes for the bon̄
They foughte alday / and ȝit her part was non̄
Ther come a kyte / while that they were so wrothe
And bar away the bon̄ / atwixt hem bothe
And therfore atte kynges court / my leue brother
Eche man̄ for hym self / ther is non other
Loue ȝif thou list / for I loue and ay shal
And sothely leue brother / this is al
Here in this prison̄ / mote we endure
And eủerich of vs / take his auenture
¶ Greet was the strif / and longe bitwixe hem tweye
Ȝif that I hadde / leyser forto seye
But to this effect / it happed on a day
To tellen it you / as shortly as I may
A worthy duk / that hight ꝑparotheus
That felawe was / to duk Theseus
Syn thilke day / that they were children̄ lyte
Was comen to Athenes / his felowe to visyte
And for to pleye / as he was wont to do
For in this world / he loued no man so
And he loued hym / as tenderly agayn̄
So wel they loued / as olde bokes sayn̄
That whan̄ that on̄ was ded / sothely to telle
His felawe wente / and sought hym doıı̄un in helle
But of that story / list me nought to write
Duk ꝑparotheus loued wel Arcite
And hadde hym knowe / at Thebes yere by yere
And finally / at request and prayere
Of ꝑparotheus / withoute eny raunsoıı̄un
Duk Theseus / hym let out of prisoıı̄un
Frely to gon̄ / wher that hym list ouerall
In swiche a gise / as I you telle shall
This was the forward / pleynly for tendite
Betwixe Theseus / and hym Arcite
That ȝif so were / that Arcite were founde
Euer in his lyf / by day or nyght or stounde
In any countre / of this Theseus
And he were caught / it was a corded thus
That with a swerd / he shulde lese his hede
Ther nas non other / remedie ne rede
But taketh his leve / and homward he hym spedde
Lat hym be war / his nekke lyeth to wedde
¶ How grete a sorowe / suffreth now arcite
The deth he felith / thurght his herte smyte
He wepeth wayleth / and crieth pitously
To sleen hym self / he wayteth pryuely
He saide allas / the day / that I was born̄
Now is my prison̄ worse than biforn̄
Now is my shape / et̉ernally to dwelle
Nought in purgatorie / but in helle
Allas that euere / I knewe ꝑparotheus
For ellis hadde I dwelled / with Theseus
Yfetered in his prison̄ euermo
Than hadde I ben̄ in blisse / and not in wo
Only the sighte of here / whom that I serue
Though that I never / hir gᵃrace may deʆserue
Wolde have suffised / right ynogh for me
O dere cosyn̄ palamon̄ quod he
Thyn̄ is the victorie / of this auenture
Ful blisfully in prison̄ / maystow dure
In prison̄ certes nay / but in ꝑparadys
Wel hath fortune / ytorned the / the dys
That hast the sight of hir / and I the absence
For possible is / syn thou hast hir p̉resence
And art a knyght / a worthy and able
That by som caas / syn fortune is chaungeable
Thou maist som tyme / to thy desire atteyne
But I that am / exiled and bareyne
Of alle gᵃrace / and in so grete despeire
That ther nys erthe / watir fyre ne eire
Ne creature / that of hem maked is
That may me helpe / or don̄ confort in this
Wel ought I sterue / in wanhope and distresse
Fare wel my lyf / my lust and my gladnesse
Allas why pleyne / men̄ so in cōmmune
On purueance of god or of fortune
That yeveth hem ful ofte / in many a gise
Wel bet than̄ they can / hem self deuise
Som man̄ desireth / forto have richesse
That cause is of his mordre / or greet siknesse
And som man̄ wolde / out of prison̄ fayn̄
That in his owne hous / is of his meyne slayn̄
Infinite harmes / ben in this matere
We wote not what thyng / that we prayen here
We faren as he / that dronken is as a mowys
A dronken man̄ woot wel / that he hath an howys
But he noot which / the right way is thider
And to a dronken man̄ / the way is slyder
And certes in this worlde / so faren we
We seken̄ faste / after felicite
But we goon̄ wrong / ful ofte trewely
Thus may we seyn̄ alle / and namely I
That wende / and hadde / a grete opinioıı̄un
That ȝif I myght / escape fro prisoıı̄un
Than hadde I ben in ioye / and ꝑparfite hele
Ther now I am / exiled fro my wele
Syn that I may nought / seen you Emelie
I am but ded / ther is no remedie
¶ Vpon̄ that other syde palamon̄
Whan that he wyste / that Arcite was a goon̄
Swich sorowe he maketh / that the grete tour
Resowneth of his yollyng / and clamour
The pure feters / on his shynes grete
Were of his bittre / salte teres wete
Allas quod he / Arcite cosyn̄ myn̄
Of al oure strif / god wote the fruyt is thyn̄
Thow walkest now / in Thebes at thy large
And of my woo / thow yeuest lytel charge
Thow mayst syn̄ thow / hast wysdam and manhede
Assemble al the folk / of oure kynrede
And make a werre / so sharp̄ on this Cite
¶ That by som auenture / or som trete
Thow maist have here / to lady and to wyf
For whom that I mooste / nedes lese my lyf
For as as by weye of possibilite
Sith thou art / at thi large of prison̄ free
And art a lorde / greet is thyn̄ auᵃauntage
More than̄ is myn̄ / that sterue here in a cage
For I moste wepe / and wayle that I leve
With al the woo / that prison̄ may me yeve
And eke with peyne / that loue me yeveth also
¶ That doubleth al my toᵘurment and my wo
Therwith the fire of ialousie vpsterte
Withyn his brest / and hent hym by the herte
So woodly that he / lyke was to be holde
The boxtre / or the asshen / dede and colde
¶ Than seide he / O cruel goddes / that goủerne
This worlde / by youre byndynge et̉erne
And writen in the table of athamaunt
Youre ꝑparlement / and youre et̉erne graunt
What is mankynde / more vnto you holde
Than is the sheep / that rouketh in the folde
For slayn is a man̄ / right as a nother beste
And dwelleth eke in prison̄ / and in arreste
And hath sikenes / and grete adủersite
And ofte tymes / gilteles parde
¶ What gouernance is in this p̉rescience
That gilteles / tormenteth innocence
And yit encresith this / al my penance
To man is bounde to his obseruance
For godes sake / to letten of his wille
Ther as a beste / may al his lust fulfille
And whan a beste is ded / he hath no peyne
But after his deth / man̄ mot wepe and pleyne
Though in this world / he have care and wo
Withoute doute / it may stonde so
¶ The answere of this / lette I to diuinis
But wel I wote / that in this worlde grete peyne is
Allas I see / a serpent or a theef
That many a trewe man̄ / hath doon mescheef
Gon at his large / and where hym lust may turne
But I mot ben̄ / in prison̄ thurgh saturne
And eke thurgh Iuno / ialous and eke wood
That hath destroied / welnygh al the blood
Of Thebes / with his waste walles wyde
And venus sleeth me / on that other syde
For ialouse / and fere of hym Arcite
Now wol I stynte of palamon̄ a lyte
And late hym in prison̄ stille dwelle
And of Arcite / forth I wil yow telle
¶ The somer passeth / and the nyghtes longe
Encresen double wise / the peynes stronge
Bothe of the lover / and the prisoner
I noot which hath / the wofuller myster
For shortly forto seyn̄ / of this palamon̄
ꝐPerpetuely is / dampned to prison̄
In cheynes and fetters / to the ded
And Arcite is exiled / vpon̄ his hed
For euermore / as out of that cuntre
Ne neuer more / shal his lady se
¶ Yow louers aske I / now this question̄
Who hath the worse / Arcite or palamon̄
That on̄ may se his lady day by day
But in prison̄ mot he dwelle alway
That other / where hym list may ride and go
But seen his lady / shal he never mo
Now diuineth ye / that list þat ye can
For I wil telle forth as I bigan
¶ Whan that Arcite to Thebes comen was
Ful ofte a day he / swelte / and seide allas
For seen his lady / shal he never mo
And shortly / forto concluden al his wo
So moche sorowe / hadde never creature
That is or shal / while that the worlde may dure
His sleep his mete / his drynke / is hym birafte
That lene he wax / and drye as is a shafte
His eyen holwe / and grisly to byholde
His hewe falwe / and pale as asshen colde
And solitarie he was / and ever allone
And waylyng al the nyght makyng his mone
And if he herde songe or instrument
Than wolde he wepe / he myght not be stent
So feble eke were his spirites / and so lowe
And chaunged so / that no man couthe hym knowe
His speche nor his voys though men it herde
And in his gere / for al the worlde he ferde
Not comonly lyk / to louers maladye
Of heres / but rather lyk manye
Engendred of humour malencolik
Biforn̄ his celle fantastyk
And shortly turned was al vp and doıı̄un
Bothe habite / and disposicioıı̄un
Of hym this woful louer daıı̄un Arcite
What shulde I al day / of his wo endite
Whan he endured hadde a yeer or two
This cruel torment / and this peyne and wo
At Thebes in his cuntre / as I seide
Vpon̄ a nyght / in slepe as he hym leide
Hym thought how that wenged god mercurie
Bifore hym stood / and bad hym to be merie
His slepy ȝerde / in honde he bar vpright
An hatte he wered vpon his heres bright
Arraied was this god / as he toke kepe
As he was / whan that argus toke his slepe
And seide hym thus / to athenes shalt thou wende
Ther is the shapen / of thy wo an ende
And with that worde / Arcite awook and sterte
Now trewely how sore / that men smerte
Quod he to Athenes / right now wol I fare
Ne for the drede of deth / shal I noght spare
To see my lady / that I loue and serue
In hir p̉resence / I ricche nought to sterue
And with that worde / he caughte a gret Mirour
And saugh that chaunged was / al his colour
And saugh his visage / al in another kynde
And right a non̄ / it ran hym in hys mynde
That sithen his face / was so disfigured
Of maladie / the which hadde endured
He myghte wel / ȝif he bar hym lowe
Lyue in athenes / euermore vnknowe
And seen his lady / wel nygh day by day
And right anon / he chaunged his array
And cladde hym as a poủere labourer
And al allone sauf only a squyer
That knewe his priuite / and al his caas
Which was disgised pouerly as he waas
To Athenes is he gon̄ / the next way
And to the court he wente vpon a day
And atte gate he profred his seruise
To drugge and drawe / what so men wol deuise
And shortly of this matier forto seyn̄
He fil in office / with a chamburleyn̄
The whiche that was dwellynge with Emelie
For he was wys / and sone couthe espie
Of euerich seruᵃaunt / whiche that serued here
Wel couthe he hewen wode / and water bere
For he was yonge / and myghty for the nones
And therto he was stronge / and bigge of bones
To done / that eny wight / can him deuise
A yer or two / he was in this seruise
Page of the Chambre / of Emelie the brighte
And philostrate / he seide / that he highte
But half so wel biloued a man̄ as he
Ne was ther never in Court of his degre
He was so so gentil of condicioıı̄un
That thourgh out al the court was his renoıı̄un
They seide / that it were a charite
That theseus wolde enhauncen his degre
And putten hym / in worshupful seruise
There as he myghte / his vertue excercise
And thus withyne a while / his name is spronge
Bothe of his dedes / and his goode tonge
That theseus / hath taken hym so ner
That of his Chambre / he made hym a Squyer
And ȝaf hym golde / to mayntene his degre
And eke men broughte hym out of his countre
Fro ȝere to ȝere / ful pryuely his rente
But honestly / and slighly he it spente
That no man wondred / how that he it hadde
And iij yere in this wise / his lyve he ladde
And bar hym so in pees / and eke in werre
Ther was no man / that Theseus hath derre
And in this blisse / lete I now Arcite
And speke I wol / of palamon̄ alite
¶ In derknesse orrible / and stronge prison̄
This seuene yere hath seten̄ palamon̄
For pyned what for wo / and for distresse
Who feleth double sorowe / and heuynesse
But palamon̄ that loue distreyneth so
That wood out of his witte he goth for wo
And eke therto / he is a prisoner
ꝐPerpetuely / nought only for a yer
Who couthe ryme in englissh ꝓproprely
His martirdome / forsoth / it am not I
Therfore I passe / as lightly as I may
It fele that in the seuenethe yere of May
The thridde nyght / as olde bokes seyn̄
That al the storie / telleth more pleyn̄
Were it by auenture / or by destyne
As whan a thynge is shape / it shal be
That sone after the mydnyght palamon̄
By helpyng of a frend / brak prison̄
And fleeth the Cite faste / as he may go
For he hadde ȝeue his gailer drynke so
Of clarre made of a certeyn̄ wyn̄
With nercotikes / and opie of thebes fyn̄
That al that nyght / though men wolde hym shake
The gailer sleep / he myght not a wake
And thus he fleeth / as faste as eủere he may
The nyght was short / and fast by the day
That nedes / he muste him self hyden
And til a groue faste ther bysiden
With dredful foot / than stalketh palamoıı̄un
For shortly / this was his oppinioıı̄un
That in þᵗat greve he wolde hym hyde al day
And in the nyght / than wolde he take his way
To thebes warde / his frendes to pray
On theseus / to helpe hym to werray
And certes outher / he wolde lese his lyf
Or wynnen Emelie his lady / to his wyf
This is the effecte and his entent pleyn̄
¶ Now wol I turne vnto Arcite ageyn̄
That litel wiste / how nygh than was his care
Til that fortune / hadde caught him in the snare
¶ The besy larke / messager of day
Salueth in hir songe / the morow gray
And firy phebus / risith vp so bryght
That al the orient / lawgheth of the light
And with his stremes dryeth in the greues
The syluer dropes / hangynge on the leves
And Arcita / that in the Court roial
With theseus / his Squyer principal
Is risen and loketh on the mery day
And forto don̄ / his obseruᵃaunce to May
Remembrynge on the poynt of his desire
He on a courser / stertynge / as the fire
Is riden into the feldes / hym to pleye
Out of the Court / were it a myle or tweye
And to the grove / of whiche / that I you tolde
By auenture / his way he gan to holde
To maken him a garland of the greues
Were it of wodebynde / or hawethorn̄ leves
And lowde he songe / ageyn̄ the sonne shene
May with alle thy floures and thy grene
Welcome be thou / faire fressh May
In hope / that I som grene gete May
And from his courser with a lusty herte
Into the groue ful hastely he sterte
And in a path / he rometh vp and doıı̄un
There as by auenture / this palamoıı̄un
Was in in a bussh / that no man̄ myght hym see
For sore afferd / of his deth was he
No thynge ne knewe he / that it was arcite
God wote / he wolde have trowed it ful lite
But soth is seide / gon̄ sithen many yeres
That felde hath eyen̄ / and the wode hath eres
It is ful faire / a man̄ to bere hym euene
For al day meten̄ men / at vnsette stevene
Ful litel woot arcite / of his felawe
That was so nygh to herken of his sawe
For in the bussh / he sitteth now ful stille
¶ Whan that Arcite hadde romed al his fille
And songen al the Rondel lustily
Into a studie he fel sodeinly
As done thise louers / in here queynte geres
Now in the crop / now doıı̄un in the breres
Now vp now doıı̄un / as boket in a welle
Right as the friday sothely forto telle
Now it sheneth / now it rayneth faste
Right so can gery venus ouercaste
The hertes of here folk / right as hir day
Is gerful / right so / chaungeth she array
Selde is the friday / al the wyke yleke
¶ Whan that Arcite hadde ysonge / he gan to syke
And sette hym doıı̄un / withoute eny more
Allas quod he / that day that I was bore
How longe Iuno thurgh thy cruelte
Wiltow werrey thebes / the Cite
Allas ybrought is to confusioıı̄un
The blood roial of Cadme and Amphioıı̄un
Of Cadmus / which that was the ferste man̄
That Thebes bulte / or first the toıı̄un bigan̄
And of the Cite / first was crowned kyng
Of his lynage am I / and of his ospryng
By verray ligne / as of the stok royal
And now I am so caityf / and so thraƚƚ
¶ That he that is my mortal enemy
I serue hym / as a squyer poủerly
And yet doth me Iuno wel more shame
For I dar not biknowe myn̄ owne name
But ther as I was wont to highte Arcite
Now highte I Philostrate / not worth a myte
Allas thou felle Mars / allas thou pluto
Thus hath youre ire / oure lynage al forto
Saf onely me / and wrecched palamon̄
That theseus martireth in prison̄
And ouer al thus to sleen me vtterly
Loue hath his firy dart so brennyngly
Ystiked thurght my woful and trewe careful herte
That shapen was my deth / er than̄ my sherte
Ȝe sleen me with youre eyen / Emelie
Ȝe ben̄ the cause / wherfore that I dye
Of al the remanant / of myn̄ other care
Ne sette I nought / the montance of a tare
So that I coude don ought to youre plesance
And with that worde / he fel doıı̄un in a trance
A longe tyme / and afterward vpsterte
¶ This palamon̄ / thoughte that thurgh his herte
He felde a colde swerde / sodeinly glyde
For Ire he quoke / no lenger wolde he bide

rdg.seg: And whan he hadde herde a

app.rdg: And whan he hadde herde a

div.note: Line 719 is supplied in the margin and is cut off in the gutter.
div.l: As he were wood / with face ded and pale
He sterte hym vp / out of the buskes thikke
And saide Arcite fals traitoᵘur wikke
Now art thou hent / that louest my lady so
For whom that I have / al this peyne and wo
And art my blood / and to my counsel sworn̄
As I ful ofte have tolde the / here biforn̄
And hast by iaped here duk Theseus
And falsly chaunged hast thy name thus
I wol be ded / or elles thou shalt dye
Thou shalt not loue / my lady Emelye
But I wol loue hir only and no mo
For I am palamon̄ / thy mortal fo
And though that I / no wepyne have in this place
But out of prison̄ amastert by grace
I drede nought / that outher thou shalt dye
Or thou ne shalt noght loue Emelye
Chese whicħ thou wilt / or thou shalt not asterte
¶ This Arcite witħ ful despitous herte
Whan he hym knewe / and hadde his tale herd
As feers as a lyon̄ pulled out his swerd
And seide thus / by god that sittetħ a boue
Ne wene it that / thou art sike / and wood for loue
And eke that thou no wepene haste in this place
Thou sholdest neuer out of this groue pace
That thou ne sholdest dyen of myn̄ honde
And I diffye the surete of thy bonde
Whiche that thou saist / that I have made to the
What verray fool / thenke wel / that loue is fre
And I wol loue hir / maugre al thy mygħt
But for as moche / thou art a worthy knygħt
And wilnest to darreyne hir by batayle
Haue here my trougħ / to morowe I wol not fayle
Withoute wetynge of eny other wygħt
That here I wol be founden as a knygħt
And bryngen harneys / rigħt ynow for the
And chese the beste / and leve the worste for me
And mete and drynke / ¶ this nygħt wol I brynge
Ynowe for the / and clothes for thy beddynge
And ȝif so be that thou my lady wynne
And sle me in this wode / there I am ynne
Thou mayst wel have / thy lady as for me
This Palamon̄ answered I graunted the
And thus they departed / til on morowe
Whan eche of hem had leyd his feitħ to borowe
O Cupide out of al charite
O Regne / that wolde no felawe have to wᵗith the
Ful soitħ is seide / that loue ne lordeshipe
Wol not his thankys / haue no felaweshipe
We fynde that of Arcite / and of Palamon̄
Arcite is riden / anon̄ into the ton̄
And on the morowe / er it were dayes ligħt
Ful priuely / two harneys / hatħ he digħt
Bothe suffisant / and mete to darreyne
The bataile in the felde / betwexe hem tweyne 22
And on his hors / allone as he was born̄
He carietħ al this harneys hym biforn̄
And in the groue / at tyme and place ysette
This Arcite / and Palamon̄ be mette
To chaungen gan the colour in here face
Rigħt as the hunters in the regne of trace
That stondetħ atte gappe / witħ a spere
Whan̄ hunted is the lyon̄ / or the bere
And heretħ hym come russhinge in the greues
And breketħ bothe / the bowes and the leves
And thenketħ / here cometħ my mortal enemy
Withoute faile / he mot be ded or I
For either I moot sleen hym atte gappe
Or he mote sleen me / ȝif that me myshappe
So ferthen they / in chaungynge of her hewe
As fer / as euericħ of hem / other knewe
Thernas no good day / ne no saluynge
But streigħt withoute worde / or rehersynge
Euericħ of hem halp to armen̄ other
As frendely as he were / his owne brother
And after that witħ sharpe speres stronge
They foynen ecħ to other / wonder longe
Thow myghtest wene / that this Palamon̄
In his fightyng / were a wood lyon̄
And as a cruel tygre was Arcite
As wylde bores / gonne they to smyte
That frothen white as foom / for ire wood
Vp to the ancle / foughten they / in her blood
And in this wyse / I late hem fightinge dwelle
And fortħ I wol / of Theseus you telle
¶ The destine / ministre general
That executitħ in the world ouer al
The purueance / that god hatħ seen bifore
So stronge it is / that thougħ / the world had it swore
The contrarie of a thing / be it ȝe or nay
Ȝit somtyme / it shal fallen on a day
That falletħ nougħt eft wᵗith ynne a thousand yere
For certeinly oure appetites here /
Be it of werre / or pees / or hate or loue
Al is this ruled / by the sigħt aboue
This mene I now / by myghty theseus
That for to hunte / is so desirous
And namely atte grete herte in may
That in his bedde / ther dawetħ hym no day
That he nys clad and redy forto ride
Witħ hunte and horn̄ / and houndes him beside
For in his huntynge / hatħ he suche delyte
That it is al his hope / ioye and appetyte
To be hym self / the grete hertes bane
And after mars / he seruetħ now dyane
Clere was the day / as I have tolde or this
And Theseus witħ al ioye / and blis
Witħ his ypolita / the faire quene
And Emelie cloded al in grene
On huntyng ben they riden̄ rially
And to the groue / that stood ful fast by
In whiche ther was an herte / as men hym tolde
Duk Theseus / the streighte way hatħ holde
And to the launde / he ridetħ hym ful rigħt
For thider was the hert wont to have his fligħt
And over a brook / and so fortħ on his wey
This duk wol have / a cours at hym / or twey
Witħ houndes / suche as that hym list cōmmande
And whan̄ this Duk was come vnto the launde
Vnder the sonne / he loked / and anon̄
He was war of Arcite / and Palamon̄
That foughten breme / as it were boles two
The brighte swerdes / wenten to and fro
So hidously / that witħ the lest strook
It semetħ / that it wolde felle an ook
But what they were / no thyng he ne woot
This Duk / his courser / witħ his spoores smoot
And at a stert / he was bitwene hem two
And pulled out a swerd / and cried ho
No more vp peyne of lesyng of youre hed
By myghty mars / he shal a non̄ be ded 23
That smytetħ eny stroke / that I may seen
But telletħ me / what myster men ye been
That ben so hardy / forto fighten here
Withoute Iuge / or other officere
As it were / in lystes rially
¶ This Palamon answered hastyly
And saide sire / what nedes wordes mo
We have the detħ / deserued bothe two
Two wofuƚƚ wrecches be we two caytyues
That ben encombred / of oure owne lyues
And as thou art a rightful lorde and Iuge
¶ No yeve vs neyther mercy / ne refuge
But sle me furst / for seynt charite
But sle my felawe eke / as wel as me /
Or sle hym first / for thougħ thou knowe it lite
This is thy mortal fo / this is Arcite
That fro thy londe / is banysshed on his hed
For whiche / he hatħ / deserued to be ded
For this is he / that come vnto thy gate
And seide / that he highte Philostrate
Thus hatħ he iaped thee / ful many a yeer
And thou hast maked hym / thy cheef squier
And this is he / that louetħ Emelie
For sotħ the day / is come that I shal die
I make pleinly my confessioıı̄un
That I am thilke woful Palamon̄
That hatħ thy prison̄ / broken wikkedly
I am thy mortal fo / and it am I
That louetħ so hote / Emelie the brigħt
That I wol dye / present in hir sigħt
Wherfore I aske detħ / and my Iuyse
But sle my felawe / in the same wise
For bothe we haue deserued / forto be slayne
¶ This worthy Duk / answered anon̄ agayn
And seide / this is a short conclusioıı̄un
Youre owne moutħ / by youre confessioıı̄un
Hatħ dampned you / and I it wol it recorde
It nedetħ nogħt / to peyne you witħ the corde
Ye shul be ded / by myghty Mars the rede
¶ The quene anonn / for verray womanhede
Gan to wepe / and so dide Emelie
And al the ladies / in the companie
Greet pite was it / as thougħt hem alle
That ever sucħ a chaunce / sholde falle
For gentil men / they were of greet estate
And nothyng / but for loue / was this debate
And saugħ her blody woundes / wyde and sore
And alle cried / bothe lasse and more
Have mercy vpon̄ vs women alle
And on her bare knees / don̄ they falle
And wolde have kist his feet / there as he stood
Til atte laste / a slaked was his mood
For pite / rennetħ sone / in gentil herte
And thougħ he first / for Ire quook and sterte
He hatħ considered / shortely in a clause
The trespas of hem bothe / and eke the cause
And al thougħ his Ire / her gilt accused
Ȝit in his reson̄ / he hem bothe excused
And thus he thoghte wel / that euery man̄
Wol helpe hym self in loue ȝif that he can̄
And delyuer hym self / out of prison̄
And eke hym self / hadde compassioıı̄un
Of women / for they wepen euer in oon̄
And in his gentil herte / he thoughte anoon̄
And softe to hym self / he seide fy
Vpon̄ a lorde / that have wol no mercy
But ben a lyon̄ / bothe in worde and dede
To hem / that ben / in repentance and drede
As wel as to a proude dispitous man̄
That wol mayntene / that he first bigan̄
That lord / hatħ litel / of discrecioıı̄un
That in suche caas / can no diuisioıı̄un
But weyetħ pride / and humblesse after oon̄
And shortly / whan his Ire is was thus agon̄
He gan to loken vp / witħ eyen ligħt
And spak thise same wordes / al on higħt24
The god of loue / O benedicite
How myghty / and how grete a lorde is he
Agayn̄ his mygħt / ther gaynetħ none obstacles
He may be cleped a god / for his myracles
For he can̄ maken / at his owne gise
Of euery herte / as that he can̄ deuise
¶ Lo here is this Arcite / and this Palamon̄
That quitely were / out of my prison̄
And myghte have lyued in Thebes rialy
And wite I am her mortal enemy
And that her detħ / is in my mygħt also
And ȝit hatħ loue / maugre her eyen two
Brougħt hem hider / bothe for to dye
Now loketħ / is not this a greet folye
Who may be a fool / but ȝif he loue
Biholde for godes loue / that sittetħ aboue
Se how they blede / be they not wel arrayed
Thus hatħ her lord / the god of loue hem payed
Her wages and her fees / for her seruise
And ȝit they wenen / for to ben ful wise
That seruen loue / for ougħt that may bifalle
¶ But ȝit is this the beste game of alle
That she for whom / they have this iolyte
Can hem therfore / as moche thank as me
She woot no more / of al this hote fare
By god than woot a cukkow / or an hare
But al mot ben̄ assaied / hoot and colde
A man̄ mot ben̄ a fool / or yonge or olde
I wote it by my self / ful yore agon
For in my tyme / seruaunt was I oon̄
And therfore sitħ I knowe of loues peyne
And woot how sore / it can a man̄ distreyne
As he that hatħ ben ofte / caugħt in his laas
I you foryeve al holy / this trespaas
Atte request of the quene / that kneletħ here
And eke of Emelie / my suster dere
And ye shal bothe / anon̄ vnto me swere
¶ That neuer more / ye shal my contre dere
Ne make werre vpon̄ me / nygħt ne day
But ben my frendes / in al that ye may
I you foryeve / this trespas euerydel
And they hym swore / his askyng faire and wel
And hym of lordeshupe / and of m̉ercy prayde
And he hem grauntetħ gᵃrace / and thus he sayde
To speke of royal lynage / and richesse
Thougħ that she were a quene / or a princesse
Eche of you bothe / is worthy douteles
To wedden whan̄ tyme is / but nathales
I speke for my suster Emelie
For whom / ye have this stryf and ialosye
Ȝe woote youre self / she may not wedden two
Atones / thougħ ye fighten euermo
That oon of you / be he lothe / or leef
He mot go pipen / in an Iue leef
That is to saie / she may not now have bothe
Ne be ye never so ialouse / ne so wrothe
And for thy / you putte in this degre
That eche of you / shal have his destine
As hym is shape / and herkenetħ in what wyse
Loo / here youre ende / of that I shal deuyse
¶ My wil is this / for plat conclusioıı̄un
Withouten eny replicacioıı̄un
Ȝif that you liketħ / take it for the beste
That eche of you / shal goon̄ where hym leste
Frely withoute raunson̄ or daunger
And this day fifty wykes fer ne ner
Euericħ of you / shal brynge an hundred knygtes
Armed for lystes vp alle rightes
Al redy to darreyne hir by batayle
And this bihete I you withoute fayle
Vpon my trouthe and as I am a knygħt
That wheither of you bothe / that hath mygħt
This is to seyne that wheither he or thow
May witħ his hundred as I have spoke of now
Slee his contᵃrarie or out of listes dryue 25
Than shal I yeve hym Emelye to wyue
To whom that fortune hatħ yeven so faire a grace
The lystes shal I done make in this place
And god so wisly on my soule rewe
As I shal euene Iuge ben̄ and trewe
Ye shul non̄ other ende witħ me make
That oon of you / ne shal be ded or take
And ȝif you thenke / this is wel ysaide
Say youre auys and holdetħ you apaiede
This is youre ende and youre conclusioıı̄un
¶ Who looketħ lightly / now but Palamon̄
Who springetħ vp for ioye but Arcite
Who couthe telle / or couthe endite
The ioye that is made in that place
Whan Theseus hatħ done so faire a gᵃrace
But don̄ on knees went euery man̉er wigħt
And thanken hym / witħ al herte and mygħt
And namely thise thebanes many sithe
And thus witħ hope / and herte blithe
They take hir leue / and homward gon they ryde
To Thebes warde / witħ olde walles wyde
I trowe men wolde deme it necligence
Ȝif I foryete to telle the dispence
Of Theseus / that gotħ so bysyly
To maken vp the listes rially
That suche a noble theatre as it was
I dar wel say in al this worlde ther nas
The circuite a myle was a boute
Walled witħ stoon / and diched al withoute
Round was the shap / in maner of a compaas
Ful of degrees / the higħt of sixty paas
That whan a man / was set on oo degree
He letted nougħt / his felawe for to see
¶ Estward ther stood a gate of marbyl white
Westward rigħt sucħ another in the opposite
And shortly to conclude / swiche a place
Was non̄ in erthe / as of so lytel space
For in the londe / ther was no crafty man̄
That gemetrie / or ars metric can /
Ne portrayour / ne keruer of ymages
That Theseus ne yaf hym mete and wages
The theatre for to make / and to deuise
And forto done his rite / and his sacrifise
¶ He estward hatħ vpon the gate aboue
In worshupe of venus goddes of loue
Done maken an auter / and an oratorie
And westward also in memorie
Of Mars / he hatħ done maked suche another
That coste largely of gold a fother
And northward in a touret on the wal
Of alabastre white / and reed coral
And oratorie / riche forto see
In worshupe of dyane of chastite
Hatħ Theseus done wrougħt in noble wise
But ȝit hadde I forȝete to deuyse
The noble keruynges / and the portraytures
The shap / the countenance / and the figures
That weren in thise oratories thre
¶ Furst in the temple / of Venus maistow see
Wrougħt on the wal / fuƚƚ pitous to beholde
The broken slepes / and the sikes colde
The sacred teres / and the waymentynge
The firy strokes / of the desirynge
That loues seruances / in this lyf enduren
The othes / that here couenantes assuren
Plesance and hope / desire fool hardynesse
Beaute and thougħt / bawdrie richesse
Charmes and force / lesynges and flaterie
Dispense besynes / and ialousie
¶ That wered of ȝelwe gooldes a garlonde
And a cukkow sittynge on hir honde
Festes instrumenteȝ caroles daunces
Luste and array and alle the circumstaunces
Of loue / whiche I rekned / and rekne shal
By ordre were ypeynted on the wal
And mo than I can of make mencioıı̄un 26
For sotħly al the Mount of Citharon̄
There venus hatħ hir principal dwellynge
Was shewed in the walle in portrayinge
With al the gardyne / and the lustynesse
Nougħt was forȝeten̄ / the porter ydelnesse
Ne Narcisus the faire of ȝore agoon
Ne ȝit the folye of kyng Salomon̄
Ne ȝit the grete strengthe of hercules
The enchauntementes of Medea a Circes
Ne of Turnus witħ the hardy feers corage
The riche Cresus / caitif in seruage
Thus may ye seen̄ / that wysdam ne richesse
Beaute ne sleighte / strengthe / hardynesse
Ne may witħ venus holde champartie
For as hir list / the world / than may she gie
Lo alle this folke so caugħt were in hir laas
Tyl they for wo / ful ofte seide allas /
Suffisetħ hire on ensample / or two
And thougħ there cowde I rekne a thousand mo
The stature of venus glorious forto see
Was naked fletynge / in the large see
And fro the nauel don̄ / al couered was
Witħ wawes grene / and brigħt as eny glas
A citole / in hir rigħt honde / had she
