And on hire hede / ful semely for to se
A rose garland / fressħ and wel smellynge
A boue hire hede / hir dowues flaterynge
Bifore hir stood / hir sone Cupido
Vpon his shulders / wynges hadde he two
And blynde he was / as it is ofte sene
A bowe he bar / and Arwes brighte and kene
Why sholde I not eke / as wel telle you al
The portrayture / that was vpon the wal
Withynne the temple / of myghty Mars the rede
Al peynted was / the wal in lenghte and brede
Lyke to the estres of the grisely place
That highte the grete temple of mars in trace
In thilke colde frosty region̄
There as mars / hatħ his soueraigne mansioıı̄un
First on the wal was peynted a forest
In whiche / ther wonetħ / neither man ne beest
Witħ knotty knarry / bareyne trees olde
Of stubbes sharpe / and hidous to beholde
In whiche ther ran̄ / a rombil and a swougħ
As thougħ a storme shulde breken euery bougħ
And donward from an hil vnder a bent
There stood the temple of Mars Armypotent
Wrougħt al of burned steel / of whiche the entre
Was longe and streyt / and gastely forto see
And ther out com a rage / and suche a veȝe
That it made alle the gates forto rese
The Northerne ligħt / in at the dore shon̄
For wyndowe / on the wal ne was ther non̄
Thurgħ whiche men myghte any ligħt discerne
The dore was al / of athamant eterne
Yclenched ouerthwart and endelong
Witħ Iren towgħ / and forto make it strong
Euery piler / the temple to sustene
Was tonne greet / of Iren brigħt and shene
¶ Ther saugħ I ferst the derke ymagenynge
Of felonye / and aƚƚ the compasynge
The cruel Ire / reed as eny glede
The pykepurs / and eke the pale drede
The smyler / witħ the knyf vnder the cloke
The shepene brennynge / witħ the blake smoke
The treson̄ of the mortheryng / in the bed
The open werre / witħ woundes al bybled
Contek witħ blody knyf / and sharpe manace
Al ful of chirkynge / was that sory place
¶ The sleer of hym self / ȝit saugħ I there
His herte blood / hatħ bathed al his here
The mayl y dryuen / in the shode a nygħt
The colde detħ / witħ mouthe gapynge vprigħt
A myddes of the temple / sat meschaunce
Witħ disconfort / and sory contenaunce
¶ Ȝit saugħ I woodnes / laughynge in his rage 27
Armed compleynt othes and feers corage
The careyne in the busshe / witħ throte ykorve
A thousand slayn̄ / and not oon of qualme ystorve
The tyrant witħ the pray / by force yraft
The ton̄ destroyed / ther was no thyng ylaft
¶ Ȝit saugħ I brenne the shippes vpsteres
The hunte strangled witħ the wilde beres
The sowe fretynge the childe / rigħt in the cradel
The cook yscalled / for al his longe ladel
Nougħt was forgeten / by the infortune of marte
The carter ouerryden witħ his carte
Vnder the wheel / fuƚƚ lowe he lay adon̄
There were also / of martes diuisioıı̄un
The barbour / the boucher and the Smytħ
That forgetħ sharpe swerdes on the stitħ
And al aboue depeynted in a tour
Saugħ I conquest / sittynge in grete honour
Witħ the sharpe / swerde ouer his heed
Hangynge by a sotyl twynes threed
Depeynted was / the slaughter of Iulius
Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
Al be that thilke tyme / they were vnborn̄
Ȝit was her detħ / depaynted ther biforn̄
By manasynge of Mars / rigħt by figure
So was it shewed / in the purtrayture
As is depeynted in the certres above
Who shal be ded / or elles slayn̄ for love
¶ Suffisetħ oon ensample / in stories olde
I may not rekne hem alle / thougħ I wolde
The Statue of Mars / vpon̄ a cart stood
Armed and loked grym / as he were wood
And over his hede / ther shynen two figures
Of sterres / that ben cleped in scriptures
That oon Puella / that other rubeus
This god of armes / was arraied thus
A wolf ther stood / byfore hym at his feet
Witħ eyen reed / and of a man̄ he eet
Witħ sotil pensel / was depeynted this storie
In redoutynge of Mars / and his glorie
Now to the temple / of dyane the chaste
As shortely as I can / I wil me haste
To telle you al the discripsioıı̄un
Depeynted was the wal / vp and don̄
Of huntenge / and shamefast chastite
Ther saugħ I / how woful Calistopete
Whan̄ that diane / greued was wᵗith here
Was torned fro a woman / to a bere
And after was she made / the lode sterre
Thus was it peynted / I can seye you no ferre
Hir sone is eke / a sterre as ye may see
Ther saugħ I dane turned vnto a tree
I mene not the goddesse dyane
But Peneus doughter / whicħ that highte dane
Ther saugħ I Attheon / an hert ymaked
For vengeance / that he saugħ dyane al naked
I saugħ how that his houndes have hym caugħt
And freten hym / for they knywe hym naugħt
Ȝit peynted was / a lytel further more
How that athelant / hunted the wilde bore
And meliagre / and many other mo
For whiche dyane / wrougħte hym care and wo
¶ Ther saugħ I many another wonder storie
Whiche me lust not / to drawe memorie
This goddesse / vpon̄ an hert / ful wel she seet
Witħ smale houndes / al aboute here feet
And vnder nethe here feet / she had a mone
Wexinge it was / and shulde wanye sone
In gaude grene / his statue clothed was
Witħ bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas
Hire eyen caste she / ful lowe adon̄
There Pluto hatħ his derke regioıı̄un
A woman̄ travelynge / was hir biforn̄
But for hir childe / was so longe vnborn̄
Ful pitously / lucyna gan she calle
And seide helpe / for thou mayste best of alle
Wel couthe he peynte / lyfly that it wrouħte 28
Witħ many a floreyne / he the coloures boughte
Now ben thise lystes made / and Theseus
That at his grete coste / arrayed thus
The temples / and the theatre euerydeƚƚlle
Whan it was don̄ / hym lyked wonder weƚƚlle
But stynte I wol / of Theseus a lyte
And speke of palamon̄ and Arcite
¶ The day approched / of her retourynge
That euericħ shulde / an hundred knyghtes brynge
The bataille to darreyne / as I you tolde
And to Atthenes her couenaᵃaunt forto holde
¶ Hatħ euericħ of hem / brougħt an hundred knygħtes
Wel armed for the werre / atte alle rigħtes
And sykerly / there trowed many a man̄
That sithe the worlde first bigan̄
That forto speke / of knyghthode witħ her honde
As feer as god hatħ maked see or londe
Nas of so fewe / so noble a companye
For euery wigħt / that loued chiualrie
And wolde his thankys / have a passant name
Hatħ prayed / that he mygħte be of that game
And wel was hym / that therto chosen was
For ȝif ther felle to morowe sucħ a caas
Ye knowen̄ wel / that euericħ lusty knygħt /
That louetħ paramours / and hatħ mygħt
Were it in Englond / or ellis where
They wolden fayne / wilne to be there
To fighte / for a lady / a benedicite
It were a lusty sigħt forto see /
Rigħt so ferden they witħ Palamon̄
Witħ hym there wente knyghtes manyon̄
Some wol ben armed / in an habirgeon̄
And a brest plate / and a ligħt gypoun̄
And some wol have / a paire of plates large
And some wol have / a pruce plate / sheeld or targe
Some wil ben̄ armed / on his legges wele
And have an ax / and some a mace of stele
Ther nas no newe gyse / that it nas olde
Armed were they / as I have you tolde
Euericħ after his opinion̄
Ther maistow seen / comynge wᵗith Palamon̄
Lygurge hym self / the grete kyng of trace
Blak was his visage / and manly was his face
The cercles of his eyen / in his heed
They gloweden̄ / bitwixe ȝelwe and reed
And leke a lyon̄ / loked he aboute
Witħ kempe heres / on his browes stoute
His lemes grete / his brawnes stronge
His shulders brode / his armes rounde and longe
And as the gise was / in his cuntre
Ful higħ / vpon̄ a chare of gold stood he
Witħ mi white boles / in the trays
In stede of cote armure / ouer his harneis
Witħ nayles ȝelwe / and brigħt as eny golde
He had a beres Skynne / col blak for olde
His longe heer was kempt behynde his bak
As eny ravenes fether / it shoon̄ for blak
A wrethe of golde / arme grete of huge wigħte
Vpon hede set ful ofte stones brigħte
Of fyne rubies / and of diamautȝ
Aboute his chare / ther wente white alauntȝ
Twenty and moo / as greet as eny steer
To hunten atte lyon̄ / or the deer
And folwed hym / witħ mosel faste ybounde
Witħ colers of golde / and turrettes fyled rounde
An hundred lordes / had he in his route
Armed ful wel / witħ hertes sterne / and stoute
¶ Witħ Arcite / in stories / as I fynde
The grete Emetrius / the kynge of ynde
Vpon a stede bay / trapped in steel
Cỏuerd witħ a clotħ of golde dyapred weel
Com rydynge / lyke the god of arme Mars
His cote armure / was of clotħ of tars
Cowched witħ ꝑperles / white rounde and grete
His sadel was / of brent golde newe ybete
A mantelet vpon̄ his shulder hangynge 29
Bretful of rubies / reed as fyres sparkelynge
His crispy heer / lyke Rynges was yronne
And that was ȝelwe / and glyterynge as the sonne
His nose was higħ / his eyen brigħt citryn̄
His lippes rounde / his colour was sangwyn̄
A fewe frakenes / in his face spreynt
Betwext ȝelwe / and somdel blak ymeynt
And as a lyon̄ / he his eyen caste
Of fyve and twenty ȝere / his age I caste
His berde was wel bigonne for to sprynge
His voys was lyk a trompet / thonderynge
Vpon̄ his heed / he wered of laurer grene
A garland fressħ / and lusty for to sene
Vpon his hande he bar for his delyte
An egle tame / as eny lilye white
An hundred lordes / had he witħ hym there
Al armed saf her hedes / in al here gere
Ful richely in aƚƚ maner thynges
For trustetħ wel / that dukes Erles kynges
Were gadred in this noble companye
For loue / and for encrees of chiualrie
Aboute this kynge / ther ran on euery part
Ful many a tame lyon̄ / and leopard
And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
Ben on the sonday / to the Cite come
Aboute prime / and in the ton̄ aligħt
This Theseus / this duk / this worthy knygħt
Whan he had brougħt hem / into his cite
And Inned hem / after here degre
He festetħ hem / and dotħ so grete labour
To esen hem / and done hem alle honour
That ȝet men wenen / that no mannes wit
Of noon estate / ne cowde amenden it /
The mynstralcie / the s̉eruice at the feste
The grete ȝiftes / to the meste and leste
The riche array of Theseus paleys
Ne who sat first / or last vpon̄ the deys
What ladyes fayrest ben / or best daunsynge
Or whiche of hem / can best daunce or synge
Ne who moste felyngly / speketħ of loue
What hawkes sitten on perche aboue
What hondes liggen / on the flore adon̄
Of al this now / make I no mencioıı̄un
But al to the effecte / that thenketħ me the beste
Now cometħ the poynt / herkenetħ ȝif you leste
The sonday nygħt / or day bigan̄ to sprynge
Whan̄ palamon̄ / the lerke herde synge
Al thougħ it nere not day by houres two
Ȝit songe the larke / and palamon rigħt tho
Witħ holy herte / and witħ an higħ corage
He roos hym vp to done his pilgrymage
Vnto the blisful Cithera benigne
I mene venus honorable and digne
And in hir houre / he walketħ fortħ a paas
Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple waas
And don̄ he kneletħ / and witħ humble chere
And herte soor he seide / as ye shul here
Fairest of fayre / o lady myn̄ Venus
Doughter of Ioue / and spouse to welcanus
Thow glader of the mount of Citheron̄
For thilke loue / thou haddest to adon̄
Have pite of my bitter teres smerte
And take myn humble prayer at thyn herte
Allas I have no langage to telle
The effecte / ne the torment of myn helle
Myn̄ herte / my harmes not biwreye
I am so confuse / that I can̄ not seye
But mercy lady brigħt / that woost weel
My thougħt / and seest what harmes I feel
Considre al this / and rewe vpon̄ my sore
As wisly / as I shal for eueremore
Enforce / my mygħt thy trewe seruᵃauant to be
And holde werre / alwey witħ chastite
That make I myn̄ avowe / so ye me helpe
I kepe not of armes for to ȝelpe
Ne I ne aske not / to morowe to have victorie 30
Ne renon̄ in this caas / ne veyne glorie
Of pris of armes / blowen vp and don̄
But I wolde have fully possessioıı̄un
Of Emelye / and dye in hir seruise
Fynde ye maner / how and in what wise
I recche not / but it may other be
To have victorie of hem / or they of me
So that I have my lady in myn̄ armes
For thougħ so be / that mars is god of armes
Youre vertue is so grete in heuene above
That ȝif you list I shal wel have my love
Thy temple shal I worshipe eủere mo
And on thyn auter / where I ride or go
I wol done sacrifice / and fires bete
And ȝif ye wol not so / my lady swete
Than pᵃray I you / to morowe witħ a spere
That Arcita me thurgħ the herte bere
Than rekke I nougħt / whan I have lost my lyf
Thougħ Arcita / than̄ wynne hir to his wyf
This is theffecte and ende / of my prayere
Yeve me my lady / thou blisful lady dere
¶ Whan̄ the orison̄ was done of palamon̄
His sacrifice he dide / and that anon̄
Ful pitosely / witħ alle circumstances
Al tel I not as now / his obseruances
But atte laste / the Statue of Venus shook
And made a signe / wherby that he took
That is prayer / accepted was that day
For thougħ the signe / shewed a delay
Ȝit wist he wel / that graunted was his bone
And witħ glad herte / he went away ful sone
The thridde houre in equal that palamon̄
Bigan to venus temple forto gon̄
Vp roos the sonne / and vp roos Emelye
And vnto the temple / of dyane gan hie
Hir maydenes / that she thider / wᵗith her ladde
Ful redely / witħ hem the fire they hadde
The encens / the clothes and the remenaᵃaunt al
That to the sacrifice longen shal /
The hornes ful of methe / as was the gise
Ther lakked nogħt to done hir sacrifise
Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
This Emelie / witħ herte Debonaire
Hir lady wossħ / witħ water of a welle
But how she dide / hir rite I dar not telle
But it be eny thyng in generalle
And ȝit it were / a gamen to heren alle
To hym that menetħ wel / it were no charge
But it is good / a man be at his large
Hir brigħt heres / were vntressed al
A Corone of a grene ooke serial
Vpon̄ hir hede / was set ful faire and mete
Two fires / on the auter gan she bete
And dide hir thynges / as men̄ may be holde
In stace of thebes / and thise bokes olde
Whan kyndeled was / the fire / wᵗith pitous chere
Vnto dyane / she spak as ye may here
O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
To whom bothe heuene / and erthe ⁊and see is sene
Queen of the regne of pluto derk and lowe
Goddesse of maydenes / that myn hert hast knowe
Ful many a Ȝere / and wost what I desire
As kepe me fro thy vengeance / and thyn Ire
That attheon̄ aboughte cruelly
Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
Desire to be a mayde al my lyf
Ne neủere wol I be loue ne wyf
I am thou wost / ȝit of thy companie
A mayde and loue huntyng and venerie
And for to walke / in the wodes wilde
And not to be a wyf / and be witħ childe
Nat wol I knowe / company of man̄
Now helpe me lady / sitħ ye may and can̄
For tho thre formes / that thou hast in the
And Palamon̄ / that hatħ sucħ loue to me
And eke Arcite / that louetħ me so sore 31
This gᵃrace I pray the / withoute more
To sende loue / and pees bitwexe hem two
And fro me turne / a way / hertes so
That al hir hote loue / and hir desire
And al hir besy torment / and hir fire
Be queynt or torned / in another place
And ȝif so be / thou wilt do me no grace
Or ȝif so be / my destyne ben shapen so
That I shal nedes / have oon of hem two
As sende me hym / that most desiretħ me
Bihold godesse / of clene chastite
The bitter teres that on my chekes falle
Syn thou art mayden / and keper of vs alle
My maidenhode thou kepe / and wel conserue
And while I leve / a mayde I wol the serue
¶ The fires brēnne / vpon the Auter clere
While Emelie / was this in hir prayere
But sodeinly she saugħ a thyng queynte
For rigħt anon̄ / oon of the fires queynte
And quiked ageyn̄ / and after that anoon
That other fire / was queynt and al agoon̄
And as it queynte / it made a whistelynge
As don̄ thise wete brondes / in her brennynge
And at the brondes ende / out ran anon̄
As it were blody dropes / manyon̄
For whiche so sore agast was Emelie
That she was welnygħ mad / and gan to crie
For she ne wiste / what it signified
But only for the fire / thus she cried
And wept / that it was pite for to here
And there witħ al / dyane gan̄ appere
Witħ bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
And seide doughter / stynte thy heuynesse
Amonge the goddes higħ / it is affermed
And by et̉erne worde / wreten and confermed
Thou shalt be wedded / vnto oon of tho
That have for the / so moche care and wo
But vnto whiche of hem / I may not telle
Fare wel / for I ne may no lenger dwelle
The fires / whiche on my Auter brenne
Shul the declaren / er that thou go henne
Thyn auenture of loue / as in this caas
And witħ that worde / the arwes in the caas
Of the goddes / clateren faste and rynge
And fortħ she wente / and made a vanisshynge
For whiche this Emelie / astoned was
And saide / what amountetħ this allas
I putte me in thy ꝓproteccioıı̄un
Dyane and in thy disposiciıı̄un
And home she gotħ anon̄ the next way
This is the effecte / ther is no more to say
The next houre of mars folwynge this
Arcite vnto the temple y walked is
Of feerse mars / to done his sacrafice
Witħ alle the rites / of his paien wise
Witħ pitous herte / and higħ deuocioıı̄un
Rigħt thus to Mars / he saide his orison̄
O stronge god / that in the Regnes colde
Of Tharse honoᵘured art / and lorde yholde
And hast of euery Regne / and euery londe
Of armes / al the bridel in thyn honde
And hem fortunest / as the list deuise
Accepte of me / my pitous sacrifice
Ȝif so be my thougħt may deserue
And that my mygħt be worthy to serue /
Thy godhede / that I may be oon̄ of thyne
Than pray I the / to rewe vpon̄ my pyne
For thilke peyne / and that hote fire
In which thou brentist whilom for desire
Whan thou vsedest the beaute
Of faire yonge fresshe venus fre
And haddest hir in armes at thy wille
Al thougħ the ones / on a tyme mysfille
What wlcanus had caugħt the in his laas
And fond the liggenge / by his wyf allas
For thilke sorwe / that was than in thyn herte 32
Have routhe as wel / vpon my peynes smerte
I am yonge / and vnkonnynge as thou wost /
And as I trowe / witħ loue offended most
That euere was / eny lyues creature
For she that dotħ me / al this wo endure
Ne recchetħ never / wher I synke or flete
And wel I wote / or she me mercy hete
I mot witħ strengħte / wynne hir in this place
And wel I woot / withoute other gᵃrace
Of the / ne may my strengthe nougħt avayle
Than̄ helpe me lorde / to morowe in my bataile
For thilke fire / that whilom brent the
As wel as that fire now brennetħ me
And do that to morowe have victorie
Myn be the travaile / and thyn the glorie
Thy souereyne temple / wol I most honouren
Of eny place / and alwey most labouren
In thy plesaıı̄unce / and in thy craftes stronge
And in the temple / I wol my baner honge
And al the armes / of my companye
And euermo vn til that day I dye
Et̉erne fire / I wol bifore the fynde
And eke to this avow / I wol me bynde
My berde / myn̄ heer / that hongetħ have a don̄
That never ȝit / felte offensioıı̄un
Of rasour / ne of shere / I wil the yeve
And ben thy trewe seruant / while I lyve
Now lorde have rought my soro was sore
Ȝeve me the victorie / I aske the no more
¶ The prayer stinte / of arcita the stronge
The rynges on the temple dore that honge
And eke the dores / clatered ful faste
Of whiche Arcite / som what hym agaste
The fires brenne / vpon̄ the auter brigħte
That it gan al the temple forto lighte
A swete smel / anon̄ the grounde vp ȝaf
And Arcita anon̄ his hand / vp haf
And more encense / in to the fire he caste
Witħ other rites mo / and atte laste
The statue of Mars / bigan his hawberk rynge
And witħ that son̄ / he herde a murmurynge
Ful lowe and dym / that seide thus victorie
For whiche / he ȝaf to Mars / honoᵘur and glorie
And thus witħ ioye / and hope wel to fare
Gotħ Arcite home / ylissed of his care
As fayn as foul is / of the brigħt sonne
And rigħt anoon̄ sucħ stryf ther is bigonne
For thilke gᵃrauntyng in the heuene aboue
Bitwixe venus / the goddesse of loue
And mars the sterne god / armipotent
That Iubit̉er was besy it to stent
Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde
That knewe so many of auentures olde
Fond in his olde exꝑperience an art
That he ful sone hatħ plesed eny part
As sotħ is seide / elde hatħ grete auantage
In elde is bothe wisdam and vsage
Men may the olde at atrenne / but not at rede
Saturne anoon̄ / to stynte strif and drede
Al be it that it is / ageyn̄ his kynde
Of al this stryf he gan remedie fynde
My dere doughter Venus / quod Saturne
My cours that hatħ so wyde forto tourne
Hath more power / that woot eny man̄
Myn is the drenchinge / in the see so wan
Myn̄ is the prison̄ / in the derke cote
Myn̄ is the strangelyng / and hongeng by the throte
The murmur / and the cherles rebellynge
The groynyng / and the pryue empoysonynge
I do vengeance / and pleyne correccioıı̄un
While I dwell in the signe of lyon̄
Myn̄ is the Reuyne / of the higħ halles
The fallyng of the toures / and of the walles
Vpon̄ the Mynoᵘur or vpon the Carpynter
I slougħ sampson̄ / shakynge the pyler
And myn̄ ben̄ the maladies colde
The derke tresons / and the castes olde
My lokynge is the Fader of pestilence
Now wepe no more / I shal do my diligence
That Palamon̄ that is thyn̄ owene knygħt
Shal have his lady / as thou hast hym higħt
Thougħ Mars shal helpe / his knygħt / ȝit nathalees
Bitwixe you tweyne / ther mote somtyme be pees
Al be ye not of oon complexiıı̄un
That causetħ alday suche diuisioıı̄un
I am thyn ael / redy at thy wille
Wepe no more / I wil thy lust fulfille
Now I stynte wol / of thise goddes aboue
Of mars and of venus goddesse of loue
And playnly telle I wol / as I can̄
The grete effect / for whicħ that I bigan̄
Greet was the feste / in athenes that day
And eke the lusty seson̄ in may
Made euery wigħt / to be in sucħ plesance
That al that day / Iusten̄ they and daunce
And spenden it / in Venus higħ seruice
But by the cause / that they shulde rise
Erly for to seen / the grete sigħt
Vnto here reste / wente they at nyght
And on the morowe / whan day bigan to sprynge
Of horses and harneyes / noyse and claterynge
Ther was in the hostelries aboute
And to the lyftes / rood there many a route
Of lordes vpon stedes / and palfreys
Ther maistow see / deuisyng of harneys
So vncoutħ and so riche / and wrought so wele
Of goldsmythrie / of broudyng / and of stele
The sheldes brighte / testers and trappures
Gold hewen helmes / hauberkes / and cote armures
Lordes in paramentȝ / on her coursers
Knyghtes of retenue / and eke Squiers
Naylynge the speres / and helmes bokelynge
Gigyng of sheldes / witħ layners lasynge
There as nede was / they were no thyng ydel
The fomynge stedes / on the golden brydel
Gnawynge / and fast the armurers also
With file and hamour / rykynge to and fro
Yomen on fote / and cōmmuns manyon̄
Witħ short staves / as faste as they may gon̄
Pipes trumpes / nakers and clariones
That in the batayle / blowe blody sownes
The paleys ful of peples vp and don̄
Here thre / there ten̄ / holdynge her questioıı̄un
Diuinynge of thise theban / knyghtes two
Som̄ seide thus / some seide it shal be so
Some heelde witħ hym / witħ the blake berd
Some witħ the balled / some wᵗith the thikke hered
Some seide he loked grym / and he wolde figħte
He hatħ a spartħ / of twenty pound of wighte
Thus was the halle / ful of diuinynge
Longe after the sonne / gan to sprynge
¶ The grete Theseus / of sleep gan awake
Witħ mynstralcie / and noyse that they make
Heeld ȝit his chambre / of his paleys riche
Til that the Thebane knyghtes bothe yliche
Honoᵘured weren / into the place fet
Duk Theseus / is at a wyndowe set
Arrayed rigħt as he were / a god in trone
The peple presed / thiderward sone
Hym for to seen / and done hym reuerence
And eke to herken his heste / and his sentence
¶ An herawde / on a scaffold made an oo
Til al the noyse / of the peple was doo
And whan he saugħ / the peple of noyse al stille
Thus shewed he / the myghty dukes wille
The lord hatħ / of his higħ discrecioıı̄un
Considred / that it were destruccioıı̄un
To gentil blood / to fighten in this gise
Of mortail bataile / now in this emprise
Wherfore to shapen / that they shul not dye
He wol his firste purpos modyfie 34
No man therfore / vp peyne of los of lyf
No maner shot / ne pollax ne short knyf
Into the listes sende / or thider brynge
Ne short swerd for to stoke wᵗith poynt bitynge
No man it drawe / ne bere it by his side
Ne no man shal / vnto his felawe ryde
But o cours / witħ a sharpe grounde spere
Foyne ȝif hym liste on fote / hym self to were
And he that is at mescheef shal be take
And nougħt slayn̄ / but brougħt vnto a stake
That shal be ordeyned / on either side
But thider he shal be force / and there abide
And ȝif so falle / the Chieftayn̄ be take
On either side / or elles slayn̄ his make
No lenger / shal the tornement laste
God spede you / go and ley on faste
Witħ swerdes / and longe maces fightetħ youre fille
Go now youre way / this is the lordes wille
¶ The voys of peple / touched the heuene
So lowde cryed they / witħ mery steuene
God save sucħ a lorde / that is so good
That wilnetħ / no destruccioıı̄un of blood
Vp gon̄ the trompes / and the melodie
And to the listes / rit the companye
By ordynance / thurgh out the cite large
Honged witħ clotħ of gold / and not wᵗith sarge
Ful lyke a lorde / this noble duk gan ride
Thise two Thebanes / vpon either side
And after rood / the queen and Emelie
And after that / another companye
Of oon and other / after her degre
And thus they passed / thugħt oute the Cite
And to the listes / come they by tyme
It was not of the day / ȝit fully pryme
Whan sett was Theseus / ful richely and hie
Ypolita the queen / and Emelye
And other ladies / in degrees aboute
Vnto the setes / presetħ al the route
¶ Westward thurgħ the gates vnder Mart
Arcite and eke the hundred of his part
Witħ baner rede / is entred rigħt anoon
And in that self moment palamon
Is vnder venus / estward in that place
Witħ baner white / and hardy chere and face
And in al the world / to seken vp and don̄
So even withoute variacioıı̄un
Ther nere suche companyes tweye
For ther was noon so wys / that couthe seye
That eny hadde of other avantage
Of worthines / ne of estate ne age
So even were they chosen forto gesse
And in two reenges / faire they hem dresse
Whan that her names / rad were eủerichon̄
That in hir nombre / gile was ther noon
Tho were the gates shette and cried was loude
Do now youre dever / yonge knyghtes provde
The herawdes lefte / her prikyng vp and don̄
Now ryngen trompes / lowde and clarioıı̄un
Ther is no more to say / est ne west
In gon̄ the sharpe speres / ful sadly in arrest
In gotħ the sharpe spore / into the side
Ther may men seen / who can iuste or ride
Ther shyueren shaftes / vpon sheeldes thikke
He fileth thourgħ / the herte spon the prikke
Vp springen speres / twenty fote on higħt
Out gon the swerdes / as the syluer brigħt
The helmes they to hewe / and to shrede
Out brest the blood / with sterne stremes rede
Witħ myghty maces / the bones they to breste
He thurgħ the thikkest / of the throng gan threste
Ther stomblen stedes stronge / and don̄ gotħ al
He rolletħ vnder fote / as dotħ a bal
He foynetħ on his fote / witħ his tronchon̄
And he hym hurtetħ / witħ his hors adon̄
He thurgħ the body is born / and sithe ytake
Maugre his heed / and brougħt vnto the stake 35
As forward was / and there he muste abide
Another lad is / on that other side
And somtyme dotħ hem / Theseus forto reste
He to refresshe / and doynke ȝif hem leste
Ful oft a day / have thise Thebanes two
To gider met / and wrougħt eche other wo
Vnhorsed hatħ / eche other of hem tweye
Ther was no tigre / in the vale of galgepheye
Whan hir whelp is stole / whiel it is lyte
So cruel on the hunte / as is arcite
For ialous herte / vpon̄ this palamon̄
Ne in Belmary / is non̄ so fel lyon̄
That hunted is / or for hunger wood
Ne of his pray / desiretħ so the blood
As Palamon to sle his fo Arcite
The ialouse strokes / on her helmes bite
Out rennetħ the blood / of bothe her sides rede
Sometyme an ende / there is of euery dede
For or the sonne / to the reste wente
The stronge kynge Emetrius gan hente
This palamon / as he faugħt wᵗith Arcite
And made his swerd / depe in his flessħ to bite
And by force of twenty / is he take
Vnȝolden / and drawen vnto the stake
And in the rescous / of this palamon̄
The stronge kynge / lygurge is born̄ adon̄
And kyng Emetrius / for al his grete strengthe
Is born out of his Sadeƚƚ / his swerdes lengthe
So hitte hym palamon / or he were take
But al for nogħt / he was brougħt to the stake
His hardy herte / may hym helpe naugħt
He muste abide / whan̄ that he was caugħt
By force / and eke by composicioıı̄un
¶ Who sorwetħ now / but woful Palamon̄
That mot no more gon / ageyn̄ to figħ
And whan that Theseus / had seen that sigħt
He cried hoo / no more for it is doon̄
Ne noon shal lenger / to his felawe goon̄
I wol be trewe Iuge / and not ꝑpartie
Arcite of Thebes / shal have Emelie
That by his fortune / hatħ hir faire ywonne
Anon̄ ther is / a noyse of peple bigonne
For ioye of this / so lovde and higħ with alle
It semed / that the lystes shulde falle
¶ What can now faire Venus done aboue
What saitħ she now / what dotħ this queen of loue
But wepetħ so for wantyng of hir wille
Til that the teres / in the lystes fille
She saide I am ashamed douteles
Saturnus saide / dogħter holde thy pees
Mars hatħ his wille / his knygħt hatħ al his bone
And by my heed / thou shalt ben esed sone /
¶ The trompours witħ the lowde mynstralsie
The herawdes / that ful lowde ȝelle and crie
Ben in here wele / for ioye of dan̄ Arcite
But herkenetħ me / and stynte voys alyte
Whiche a myracle / ther bifel anon
Ther fiers Arcite / hatħ of his helme ydoon
And on a courser / for to shewe his face
He priketħ endelong the large place
Lokynge vpward / vnto Emelie
And she ageyne hym caste a frendely eye
For women as to speken the cōmmune
They folwen al the fauour of fortune
And was al his chere / as in his herte
Out of the grounde / a furie infernal sterte
Fro pluto sent at request of saturne
For whicħ his hors / for fere can to turne
And leep a syde / and foundred as he leep
And or that Arcite / may taken keep
He pighte hym on pomel on his hed
That in the place / he lay as he were ded
His brest to brosten̄ / witħ his Sadeƚƚ bowe
As blak he lay / as eny cole or crowe
So was the blood yronnen in his face
Anoon̄ he was brougħt / out of the place 36
Witħ herte sore / to Theseus paleys
Tho was he coruen / out of his harneys
And in a bed ybrougħt / ful faire and blyue
For he was ȝit / in memorie / and on lyue
And alway criynge / after Emelie
Duk Theseus / witħ al his companye
Is comen home / to Athenes his Cite
Witħ al blisse / and grete solempnite
Al be it / that this auenture was falle
He wolde not discomforte hem alle
Men seide eke / that Arcite shulde not dye
He shal be heled / of his maladie
And of another thyng they were as fayn̄
That of hem alle / ther was noo man slayn̄
Al were they sore beten / and namely oon
That witħ a Spere / was thirled the brest boon̄
Two other wondes / and two broken armes
Some hadde salue / and some hadde charmes
Femacies of herbes / and eke save
They dronken / for they wolde her lyues have
For whiche this noble duk / as he wel can
Conforteth and honouretħ euery man
And made Revel al the longe nygħt
Vnto the straunge lordes as it was rigħt
Ne ther was holden / no discomfiture
For fallynge / is but an auenture
Ne to be lad / by force vnto a stake
Vnȝolden / and witħ twenty knyghtes take
A ꝑpersone allone withoute moo
And haried fortħ / by arme foot and too /
And eke his stede / dryven fortħ wᵗith staves
Witħ footmen / bothe yemen and knaves
It was arretted hym / no velenye
Ther may no man / clepe it cowardie
For whiche anon̄ / duke Theseus leet crie
To stillen al the rancour and enuye
The gree as wel of o syde as of another
And either side lyke / as otheres brother
And ȝaf hem ȝiftes / after here degre
And fully heeld / a feste dayes thre
And conueied the kynges worthily
Out of his ton̄ / a iourne largely
And home wente euery man̄ / the rigħt way
Ther was no more / but fare wel have good day
Of this bataile / I wol no more endite
But speke of palamon̄ / and Arcite
¶ Swellitħ the brest / of arcite and the sore
Encresetħ at his herte / more and more
The clotered blood / for eny lechecraft
Corruptetħ / and is in his body laft
That neyther veyne blood ne ventusyng
Ne drenke of herbes / may ben his helpyng
By vertue expulsif / or anymal
Fro thilke vertue / cleped Natural
Ne may the venym / voide ne expelle
The pipes of his lunges / gan to swelle
And euery lacerte in his body don̄
Is shent / witħ venym and corrupcioıı̄un
Hym gaynetħ nother for to kepe his lyf
Vomyte vpward / ne dounward laxatif
Al is to brosten / thilke regioıı̄un
Nature hatħ no dominacioıı̄un
And certeinly there nature wol not werche
Fare wel Phisik lat bere the man̄ to cherche
This al and some / that Arcita mot dye
For whicħ / he senditħ after Emelie
And Palamon̄ his cosyn dere
Than seide he thus as ye shal after here
Nougħt may the woful spirite in my herte
Declare oo poynt of my sorwes smerte
To you my lady / that I love most
But I biquethe the seruise of my gost
To you / aboven euery creature
Syn that my lyf / may no lenger dure
Allas the woo / allas the peynes stronge
That I for you have suffred and so longe 37
Allas the detħ / allas myn̄ Emelye
Allas departynge / of youre companie
Allas myn hertes queen / allas my wyf
My hertes lady / ender of my lyf
What is this worlde / what aske men to have
Now witħ his love / now in his colde grave
Allone / withoute / eny companie
Fare wel my foo / fare well myn̄ Emelye
And softe taketħ me / in youre armes tweye
For loue of god / and herkenetħ what I seye
¶ I have here witħ my Cosyn̄ Palamon̄
Had strif and rancour / many day agon̄
For love of you / and for my ialowsie
And Iupit̉er so wis my soule gye
To speken of a seruᵃaunt ꝓproprily
Witħ circumstances alle trewely
That is to say / trouthe honoᵘur and knyghthede
