Fredome and al that longetħ to that art
So Iupiter have on my soule part
As in this world / rigħt now knowe I noon
So worthy to be loued / as Palamon̄
That seruetħ you / and wol done al his lyf
And ȝif that ye / shal euer ben̄ a wyf
For yete not Palamon̄ / the gentil man̄
And witħ that worde / his speche faile gan̄
And from his feet / vnto his herte was come
The colde detħ / that had hym ouercome
And ȝit more over / for in his armes two
¶ The vital strengthe / is lost and al ago
Only the intellecte / withoute more
That dwelled in / the herte sike and sore
Gan faylen / whan therte felte detħ
Dusked his eyen two / and fayled bretħ
But on his lady / ȝit caste he his eye
His last word / was mercy Emelie
His spirite chaunged hous / and wente there
As I cam neuer / I can̄ not tellen where
Therfore I stynte / I am no diuinistre
Of soules fynde I / not in this registre
Ne me ne liste / thilke opinions to telle
Of hem thougħ that they writen where they dwelle
Arcite is colde / thet mars his soule gye
Now wol I speken fortħ of Emelye
¶ Shrighte Emelie / and halowen Palamon
And Theseus / his suster toke anoon̄
Swownynge / and bar hir fro the corps away
What helpetħ it vs / to tarien fortħ the day
To tellen yow / how she wepte bothe eve and morowe
For in suche caas / women have suche sorwe
Whan that her husbondes / ben from hem ago
That for the more part / they sorwen so
Or elles fallen / in suche a maladie
That atte laste / certeynly they die
Infinite harmes ben / and eke the teres
Of olde folk / and folk of tendre ȝeres
In al the ton̄ / for detħ of this theban̄
For hym ther wepen / bothe child and man̄
So grete wepyng / was ther nougħt certayn̄
Whan Ector was ybrougħt / al fressħ newe yslayn̄
To Troye / allas the pite that was there
Cracchyng of chekes / rentyng eke of here
Why woldesthow be ded / thise women crie
And haddest golde ynow / and Emelie
No man mygħt gladen Theseus
Sauynge / his olde Fader Egeus
That knewe this worldes tᵃransmtacioıı̄un
As he hadde seen it / vp and don̄
Ioye after wo / and wo after gladnesse
And shewetħ hym / ensample and lyknesse
Rigħt as ther dyed / neuer man quod he
That he ne lyued / in erthe in some degre
Rigħt so ther lyued never man he seide
In al this world / that some tyme he ne deide
This world is nougħt / but a thurghfare ful of wo
And we ben pilgrymes passynge to and fro 38
Detħ is an ende / of euery worldely sore
And ouer al this / ȝit seide he moche more
To this effecte / ful wisely to enhorte
The peple / that they hem shul recomforte
¶ Duk Theseus / witħ al his besy cure
Castetħ now where / that the sepulture
Of good Arcite / may best ymaked be
And eke most honurable of degre
And atte laste / he toke conclusioıı̄un
That there as first Arcite and palamon̄
Hadde for loue / the batayle hem bytwene
¶ That in the sylue groue / swete and grene
There as he hadde / his amerous desires
His compleynt for loue / and his hote fires
He wolde make a fire / in whicħ the office
Funeral / he mygħt al complice
He let anoon̄ cōmmaunde / to hakke and hewe
The okes olde / and ley hem on a rewe
In culpons wel arrayed forto brenne
His offic̉ers / witħ swift foot / they renne
And rigħt anoon̄ / at his cōmmaundement
And after Theseus hatħ ysent
After a beer / and it al over spradde
Witħ clotħ of gold / the richesse that he hadde
And of the same sute / he clothed Arcite
Vppon his handes / a pure of gloves white
Eke on his heed / a crowne of laurer grene
And on his honde / a swerde ful brigħt and kene
He leide hym bare / the visage on the bere
Ther witħ he wepte / that pite was to here
And for the peple / shuld seen hym alle
Whan it was day / he brougħt hym to the halle
That roretħ of the cry / and the son̄
Tho gan this woful theban palamon̄
Witħ flotry berd / and roggy asshi heres
In clothes blake / dropped al witħ teres
And passynge othere / of wepyng Emelie
Was rewefullest / of al the companie
¶ In asmoche as the seruice shulde be
The more noble / and riche in his degre
Duk Theseus / leet fortħ the stedes brynge
That trapped were / in steel al gliterynge
And couered witħ the armes of dan̄ Arcite
Vpon̄ thise stedes / grete and white
Ther seten folke / of whicħ oon bar his sheeld
Another his spere / in his hondes heeld
The thridde bar witħ hym / his bowe turkeys
Of brent gold was the caas / and eke the harneys
And riden fortħ a paas / witħ sory chere
Toward the grove / as ye shul after here
The noblest of the grekes / that there were
Vpon her shuldres / carieden the bere
Witħ a slow paas / in drie and in wete
Thourgħ out the Cite / by the maister strete
That sprad was / al witħ blak and wonder hie
Rigħt of the same / is the strete ywrie
Vpon the rigħt honde / wente olde Egeus
And on that other syde / Duk Theseus
Witħ vesseles in her hond of gold ful fyne
Al ful of hony mylke / blood and wyne
Eke Palamon / witħ ful greete companie
And after that / come woful Emelie
With fire in honde / as was that tyme the gise
To don̄ the office / of funeral seruise
Higħ labour / and ful grete apparailynge
Was atte seruise / and atte fire makynge
That witħ his grene top / the heuene caughte
And twenty fadme of brede / the armes raughte
This is to seyn̄ / the bowes were brode
Of stre first was leyd many a lode
But how the fire was maked vpon higħt
And eke the names / how the trees higħt
As oke fir birche asp / alder elme popeler
Wilugħ holmme plane assħ box chesteyn̄ bynde laurer
Mapil thorn̄ beche ew hasil whipultre
How they were feld / shal not be told for me 39
Ne how the goddes / ronnen vp and don̄
Disherited of her habitacioıı̄un
In whiche they woned / in reste and pees
Nymphes fawnes and amadries
Ne how the bestes / ne the briddes alle
Fledden for fere / whan this was falle
Ne how the grounde / agast was of the ligħt
That was not wont to see / the sonne brigħt
Ne how the fire / was couched first wᵗith stre
And than witħ drie stikkes / clouen on thre
And than witħ grene wode / and specerie
And than witħ clotħ of gold / and wᵗith perrie
And garlandes hangynge / witħ many a flour
The mirre / the encense / witħ the swete odour
Ne how Arcite lay among al this
Ne what richesse / aboute his body is
Ne how Emelie / as was the gise
Putte in the fire of funeral seruise
Ne how she swowned / whan made was the fire
Ne what she spak / ne what was hir desire
Ne what ieweles / men in the fire caste
Whan that the fire was greet / and brente faste
Ne how some caste her sheld / and some here spere
And of her vestymentes / whiche they were
And cuppes ful of mylke / and wyn̄ and blood
Into the fire / that brente as it were wood
Ne how the grekes / witħ an huge route
Thries riden al the fire / aboute
Vpon the lift honde / witħ a loude showtyng
And thries / wᵗith here speres clateryng
And thries / how the ladies gonne crie
Ne how that lad was homward Emelie
Ne how Arcite is brente to asshen colde
Ne how the licħ wake was yholde
Al that nygħt / ne how the grekes pleye
Þe the wake pleyes / kepe I not to seye
Who wrasteletħ beste naked / wᵗith oyle anoynt
Ne who bar hym best in no disioynt
I wol not telle / al how they goon
Home tyl Athenes / whan the play is doon
But shortly to the point / than wol I wende
To make / of my longe tale an ende
By processe / and by lengthe of yeres
Al stynt is / the mournyng and the teres
Of grekes by oon gen̉eral assent
Than̄ semed me / ther was a ꝑparlement
At Atthenes / vpon certeyn̄ poynt and caas
Amonge whiche poyntes / spoken waas
To have wᵗith certeyne / cuntres alliance
And have of Thebes / fully obeisance
For whicħ this noble Theseus anoon̄
Let senden after gentil Palamon̄
Vnwist of hym / what was the cause and why
But in his blake clothes / sorwefully
He come at his cōmmaundement in hie
Tho sende Theseus / for Emelie
Whan they were sette / and hussht was al the place
And Theseus abiden hatħ a space /
Er eny worde / come fro his wise brest /
Hys eyen sette he / there hym lest
And with a sad visage / syked stille
And after that / rigħt thus / he saide his wille
¶ The first mouer / of the cause aboue
Whan he first made / the fayre cheyne of loue
Greet was the effecte / and higħ was his entente
Wel wist he why / and what therof he mente
For witħ that faire cheyne / of loue he bonde
The fire / the aier / the water / and the londe
In certeyne boundes / that they may not fle
That same Prince / a that same mover quod he
Hatħ stablisshed / in this wrecched world adon̄
Certeyne daies / and t̉ermynacioıı̄un
That al that ben̄ engendred in this place
Over the whiche day / they may not pace
Al mowe they ȝit / tho dayes abregge
Ther is non̄ auctorite ther ageyn̄ to legge 40
For it is proved / by exꝑperience
But that me lust declare my sentence
Than may men / by this ordre discerne
That thilke mouer / stable is and eterne
Wel may man̄ knowe / but it be a fool
That euery part / darreyued from his hool
For nature hatħ nougħt / taken his bigynnyng
Of eny part / or cantel of a thyng
But of oo thyng / that ꝑparfit is and stable
Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
And therfore / for his wise purueance
He hatħ so wel biset his ordinance
That specise of thynges / and progressions
Shul endure by successions
And not et̉erne withoute eny lie
This maistow / vnderstonde / and seen at eye
Loo the ooke / that hatħ so longe a norisshynge
Fro tyme that first / it begynnetħ sprynge
And hatħ so longe a lyf as ye may see
Ȝit atte laste / wasted is the tree /
Consideretħ eke / how that the harde stoon̄
Vnder oure fete / on whiche we trede and goon̄
Ȝit wastetħ it / as lietħ in the weye
The brode Ryuer / some tyme wexeth drye
The grete townes so wyde / wane and wende
Than ye see / that alle thynge hatħ ende
And man̄ and woman̄ / see we wel also
That endetħ in oon / of the t̉ermes two /
That is to seyne / in youthe other elles age
He mote be deed the kynge / as shal a page
Som in his bed / some in the depe see
Som in the large feeld as ye may see
Than helpetħ nogħt / al gotħ / that ilke weye
Than may I say / that aƚƚ thynge shal deye
What maketħ this / but Iupiter the kynge
That is Prince / and cause of al thynge
Conuertynge aƚƚ vnto his ꝓpropre wille
Fro whicħ it is darreyued / sootħ to telle /
And her agayn̄ / no creature on lyue
Of no degre / avayletħ forto stryue
Than it is wysdome /as thenketħ me
To maken vertue / of necessite
And take it wel / that we may not eschewe
And namely that / that to vs is due
And who so grucchetħ ougħt he doitħ folie /
And rebel is to hym / that al may gie
And certeynly a man̄ hatħ most honour
To dyen in his excellence and flour
Whan he is siker / of his goode name
Than hatħ he done / his frende / ne hym no shame
And gladder ogħte / his frende / ben of his detħ
Whan witħ honoᵘur / yolden is vp the bretħ
Than whan his name / appalled is for age
For al foryeten is than his vassalage
Than is the beste / as for a worthy fame
To dyen / whan he is best of name
The contᵃrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
Why grucche we / why have we heuynesse
That good Arcite / of Chiualrie flour
Deꝑparted is / witħ duete and honour
Out of the foule prison̄ / of this lyf
Why grucchen here / his cosyn and his wyf /
Of his welfare / that louetħ hem so wel
Can he hem thanke nay god woot neủere adel
That bothe his soule / and eke hem self offende
And ȝit they may not / her lustes amende
What may I conclude / of this longe serie
But after wo / I rede vs to be merie
And thanke Iupiter / of al his grace
And er we departen / fro this place
I rede we make / of sorwes two
Oon ꝑparfit ioye / lastyng euer mo
And loke now where / most sorwe is here ynne
Ther wol I first amende / to bygynne
Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
Witħ al the avise here / of my ꝑparlement 41
Than gentil palamon / youre owne knyghte
That servetħ you / witħ wille herte and myghte
And ever hatħ done / sithen ye first hym knewe
That ye shal of youre womanhode vpon̄ hym rewe
And take hym / for husbonde and lorde
Lene me youre honde / for this is oure accorde
Lat se now / of youre womanly pite
He is a kynges brother sone parde
And thougħ he be a poủere bacheler
Syn he hatħ serued you / so many a yere
And had for you / so grete aduersite
It mut be considered levetħ me
For gentil mercy / ougħt to passen rigħt
Than seide he thus / to palamon the knygħt
I trowe ther nede litel sermonyng
To make you / assente to this thyng
Cometħ nere / and taketħ youre lady by the honde
Bitwexe hem two / was made anon̄ the bonde
That higħt matrimoyne / or mariage
By al the conseƚƚ / and the baronage
And thus witħ al blisshe / and melodie
Hatħ palamon̄ / ywedded Emelie
And god that al this world hatħ wrougħt
Sende hym his loue / that hatħ it dere bougħt
For now is palamon̄ / in al his wele
Lyuynge in al blisse / in richesse and in hele
And Emelie / hym louetħ so tenderly
And he hir seruetħ / so gentilly
That was ther no word hem bitwene
Of ialousie / or eny other tene
Thus enditħ palamon̄ and Emelie
And god save al this faire companye
¶ Thus endetħ the knyghtes tale

¶ And here
Bigynnetħ the prologe of the Miller et cetera
Whan that / þᵗat the knygħt had thus his tale tolde
In al the company / nas ther yonge ne olde
That he ne seide / it was a noble storie
And worthy to be drawen / in memori
And namely the gentilnes of euerichon̄
Oure host lowgħ / and swore so mote I gon̄
This gotħ a rigħt / vnbokeled is the male
Lat see now / who shal telle a nother tale
For trewely the game / is wel bygonne
Now telletħ ye / ʆsir monke ȝif ye konne /
Somwhat to quiten witħ the knyghtes tale
The Miller / that for dronke was al pale
So that vnnethe / vpon his hors he sat
He wolde avale / neither hood ne hat
Ne abide no man̄ / for his curtesie
But in pilates vois / he gan to crie
And swore by armes and by blood and bones
I can a noble tale / for the nones /
Witħ whicħ I wol now / quite the knyghtes tale
Oure host saugħ / that he dronke was of ale
And seide abide Robyn leue brother
A beter man / than thou / shal telle vs first another
Abide and lete vs werke thriftily
By godes soule / quod he / that wol not I ·
For I wol speke or ellis go my way
Oure host answered telle on a deuelway
Thou art a fool / thy witte is ouercome
Now herkenetħ / quod the Miller alle and some
But first I make a protestacion̄
That I am dronke / I knowe it by my son̄
And therfore ȝif I / myspeke or say
Wyte it the ale of soutħwerke I you pray
For I woll telle a legende / and a lyf
Bothe of a Carpenter / and of his wyf
How that a Clerk / sette the wrightes cappe
The Reue answered / and saide stynte thy clappe
Let be thy lewed dronken harlotrie
It is a synne / and eke a grete folie
To apeyren eny man̄ / or hym diffame
And eke to brynken wyfes in suche name
Thou maist ynow of other thynges sayn
This dronken Miller / spak ful sone agayn̄
And seide / leve brother Oswold
Who hatħ no wyf / is no cokewold
But I say not therfore / that thou art oon
Ther ben ful goode wyues / many oon
Why art thou angry wᵗith my tale now /
I have a wyf / parde as wel as thow
Ȝit nolde I / for the oxen in my plougħ
Take vp on me / more than ynougħ
As demen of my self / that I were oon
I wol bileuen / that I am noon
An husbonde / shal not ben inquisityf
Of godes pryuete / ne of his wyf
So he may fynden / godes foysen there
Of the remanent / nedetħ not to enquere
What shulde I more saie / but the Millere
He nolde his wordes for no man̄ forbere
But tolde his cherles tale / in his manere
Me forthenketħ that I shal reherse it here
And therfore eủery gentil wigħt I preye
Demetħ not for goddes loue / that I seye
Of euel entente / but for I mot reherse
Here tales alle / be they bet or werse
Or elles falsen some of my matere
And therfore who so list not to here
Turne over the leef and chese another tale
For ye shul fynde ynowe / grete or smale
Of historial thynge / that touchetħ gentilnesse
And eke moralite / and holynesse
Blame not me / ȝif that ȝe chese amys
The Millere is a Cherl ȝe know wel this
So was the Reve eke / and other mo
And harlotrie / they tolde bothe two
Auyse yow / and putt me out of blame
And eke men shal not make ernest of game /
¶ Here endetħ the ꝓprologe /
and bigynnetħ the tale
Whilom thewas dwellynge in Oxenforde /
A riche gnof / that gestes heelde to borde
And of his craft / he was a Carpenter
Witħ hym ther was dwellynge a pore scoler
That lerned art / but al his fantasie
Was turned for to lerne astrologie
And coude a certeyne of conclusions
To demen / by interrogacions
Ȝif that men asked hym / in certeyne houres
Whan that men shulde have droughte or shoures
Or ȝif men asked hym what shulde byfalle
Of euery thyng / I may not rekne hem alle
This clerk was cleped hende Nicholas
Of derne loue / he coude and priue solas
And therto he was slygħ and ful priue
And lyke a mayde / meke for to see
A chambre hadde he / in that hostelrie
Allone withoute eny companie
Ful fetisly digħt / witħ herbes swote
And he hym self / as swete as is the rote
Of licoris / or eny seduale
His almagist / and bokes grete and smale
His astrolabie / longynge for his art
His augryme stones / lay ful faire part
On shelues couched / at his beddes heed
His presse ycouered / witħ a faldyng reed
And al aboue ther lay / a gay sautrie
On whiche he made / on nygħt melodie
So swetely / that al the chamber ronge
And angelus ad virginem he songe
And after that he songe the kynges note
Ful ofte yblessed was / his mery throte
And thus / this swete Clerk / his tyme spente
After his frendes fyndyng / and his rente
This carpynter hadde wedded newe a wyf
Whiche he loued / more than his owne lyf
Of xviij yere / she was of age
Ialous he was / and kepte her streit in cage
For she was wylde / and yonge / and he was olde
And demed hym self / to ben̄ a cokewold
He knewe not Caton̄ / for his wit was rude
That bad men / sholde wedden her similitude
Men shulde wedde / after her astate
For youthe and elde / are ofte atte debate
But sitħ he was fallen / in the snare
He must enduren / as other folk / his care
¶ Fair was this yonge wyf / and ther witħ aƚƚ
As eny wesil / hir body gent and smaƚƚ
A seynt she wered / barred al of sylke
A barme clotħ / as white as morne mylke
Vpon here lendes / ful of many a gore
White was her smok / and enbraided al bifore
And eke bihynde / on hir coler aboute
Of colblak silk / witħynne and eke withoute
The tapes / of here white voluper
Were of the same suyte of her coler
Her felet brood of silke / and sett ful heye
And sikerly / she hadde a lykerous eye
Ful smale ypulled / were here browes two
And tho were bent / and blak as eny slo /
She was ful more blisful / forto see
Than ys the newe pereionet tree
And softer / than the wolle is of a wether
And by hir gyrdel / henge a purs of lether
Tasseled with silke / and ꝑperled witħ laton̄
In al this worlde / to seken vp and don̄
Ther is no man / so wys / that couthe thenche
So gay a popelot / or swiche a wenche /
Ful brighter was shynyng / of hir hewe /
Than in the Toure / the noble yforged newe /
But of hir songe / it was as lowde and yerne
As eny swalwe syttenge on a berne
Therto she couthe skippe and make game
As eny kide / or calfe / folwynge his dame
Hir mouthe was swete / as braget or methe
Or horde of apples leyd / in hey or hethe /
Wynsyng she was / as is a ioly colt
Longe as a mast / and vp ward as a bol
A broche she bar / on hir loue coler
As brood / as is the boos of a bokeler
Hir shoos were lased / on hir legges hie
She was a prymerole / a piggesnye
For eny lorde / to liggen in his bedde
Or ȝit / for eny good ȝeman to wedde
Now sire and eft sire and so bifel the caas
That on a day / this hende Nicholas
Fil witħ this yonge wyf / forto rage and pleye
While that hir husbonde / was at Oseneye /
As clerkes ben ful subtile / and ful queynte
And priuely he caught / her by the queynte
And seide ywis / but ȝif I have my wille
For derne loue / of the leman I spille
And heeld hir fast / by the haunche bones
And seide lemman / loue me wel attones
Or I wol dye / also god me save
And she sprong as a colt in the traue
And witħ her hede / she wryed faste awey
She seide / I wol not kisse the / by my fey
Whi lat be quod she / lat be Nicholas
Or I wol crie out / harrow and allas
Do way youre handes / for youre curtesie
This Nicolas / gan mercy forto crie
And spak so faire / and profred hym so faste
Til she hir loue graunted hym atte laste
And swore hir othe / by seint Thomas of kent
That she wolde ben / at his cōmmaundement
Whan that she may / hir leyser wel aspie
My husbonde is so ful of ialousie
That but ye wayte wel / and be priue
I woot rigħt wel / I nam but ded quod she
Ye mote be ful derne / as in this caas
Nay therof care yow nougħt qduod Nicolas
A clerk hadde lytherly / biset his while
But ȝif he coude a carpenter begile
And thus they were accorded / and isworne
To a wayte a tyme / as I have saide biforn
Whan Nicholas hadde done this euerydel
And thakked hir aboute the lendes wel
He kissetħ hir swete / and taketħ his sautrie
And pleyetħ faste / and maketħ melodie
¶ Than fil it thus / that the parissħ chirche
Cristes owne werkes / forto wirche /
This good wyf wente vpon̄ an haliday
Hir forhede shon̄ as brigħt as eny day
So was it wasshen̄ / whan she leet hir werk
Now was therof the chirche a parisshe clerk
The whiche that was cleped Absolon̄
Crulled was hir heer / and as the golde it shoon̄
And strouted as a fanne / large and brood
Ful streigħt and euene / lay his ioly shood
His rody was rede / his eyen gray as goos
Witħ paules wyndowe / coruen on his shoos
In hosen rede / he wente fetisly
Y clad he was ful smal and propirly
Al in a kirtel of ligħt waget
Ful faire and thikke / were the poyntes set
And ther vpon̄ / he hadde a gay surplys
As white / as is the blosme on rys
A mery childe / he was so god me saue
Wel couthe he lett blood / clippe and shaue
And a chartre of londe make / or a quytance
In twenty manere couthe he trippe and daunce
After the scole of Oxenforde tho
And witħ his legges / casten to and fro
And pleyen songes / on a smal ribible
Some tyme he songe / a lowde quynyble
And as wel coude he play on a giterne
In al the toıı̄un / nas brewhous ne tauerne
That he ne visited / witħ his solas
There eny gaylard tapster was
But soth to say / he was somwhat squaymous
Of fartyng / and of speche daungerous
¶ This absolon / that was ioly and gay
Gotħ witħ a sencer on the sonda
Sensynge / the wyues / of the parissħ faste
And many a louely look / on hem he caste
And namely / on the carpynters wyf
To loke on hir / hym thoughte a mery lyf
She was so proper / swete and likerous
I dar wel say / and she hadde ben a mous
And he a cat / he wolde hir hente anoon
This parissħ clerk this ioly absolon
Hatħ in his herte / suche a loue longynge
That of no wif / toke he noon offrynge
For curtesie / he seide he wolde noon
The mone / whan it was nygħt brighte shoon̄
And absolon̄ / his git̉erne hatħ ytake
For ꝑparamours / he thoughte forto wake /
And fortħ he gotħ Ialous and amerous
Til he come / to the Carpenters hous
A lytel after / the cok hadde ycrowe
And dressed hym / vnder a short wyndowe
That was vpon̄ the Carpenters waƚƚ
He syngetħ / in his vois / gentel and smaƚƚ
Now dere lady / ȝif thy wille be
I pray you / that ye wol rewe on me
Ful wel accordynge / to his git̉ernynge
This Carpenter a wook and herde hym synge
And spak vnto his wyf / and seide anon
What Alison̄ / herest thou not Absolon
That chauntetħ thus / vnder oure bowres waƚƚ
And she answered hir husbonde ther witħ aƚƚ
Ȝis god woot Ioħn / I here it eủerydel
This passitħ fortħ / what wol ye bet than wel
Fro day to day / this ioly Absolon̄
So wowetħ hir / that hym was wo bigon̄
He waketħ al the nygħt / and al the day
He kembetħ his lokkes brode / and made hym gay
He wowetħ hir / by menes / and brocage
And swoor he wolde ben hir owne page
He syngetħ / brokkynge as a nyghtyngale
He sente hir piement metħ and spiced al
And wafres pipynge hoote / out of the glede
And for she was of ton̄ / he profred mede
For sōmme wole be wonne for richesse
And for strokes / and some for gentilnesse
Somtyme to shewen̄ his lightnes and maistrye
He playetħ herodes / on a scaffold hye
But what auayletħ it hym / as in this caas
So louetħ she / this hende Nicholas
That Absolon̄ may blowe / the bukkes horn
He ne hadde / for his labour but a scorn
And thus she maketħ / Absolon hir ape
And al his ernest / tornetħ to a iape
For sotħ this prouerbe is no lie
Men seyn thus alwey / the nygħ slye
Maketħ the fer leef / to be lotħ
For thougħ / that Absolon be wood or wrotħ
By cause that he / fer was from hir sigħt
This nygħ Nicolas / stood in his ligħt
Now bere the wel / hende Nicolas
For Absolon̄ may wayle / and synge allas
¶ And so bifel it on a saterday
This Carpenter was goon to Osnay
And hende Nicolas / and Alison
Accorded were / to this conclusion̄
That Nicolas shal shapen hym wyle
This sely ialous husbonde / to be gyle
And ȝif so be / the game wente arigħt
She shulde slepen in his armes al nygħt
For this was his desire and hir also
And rigħt anon̄ woute wordes mo
This Nicolas no lenger wolde tarie
But dotħ ful softe vnto his chambre carie
Bothe mete and drynke / for a day or tweye
And to hir husbonde / bad hir forto seye
Ȝif that he aske after Nicolas
She shulde say / she nyst where he was
Of al that day / she say hym not witħ eye
She trowed that he was malady
For no crie / hir mayde coude calle
He nolde answere / for nought that myght befalle
¶ This passeth forth al the saterday
That Nicolas stille in his bed lay
And eet and slept / and dide what hym leste
Til sonday / that the sonne goth to reste
This sely Carpenter / hath grete meruayle
Of Nicolas / or what thyng myght hym ayle
And seide / I am a drad by seynt Thomas
It stondeth nought a right with Nicolas
God shilde / that he deyed sodeynly
This world is now ful tikel sikerly
I saugh to day a corps / bore to chirche
That now a monday last / I saugh hym wirche
Go vp quod he / to his knaue anoon
Clepe at his dore / or knokke with a stoon
Loke how it is / and telle me boldely
This knave wente hym vp ful sturdily
And atte chambre dore / while that he stood
He cried and knokked / as though he were wood
What how / what do ye maister Nicolay
How may ye slepen / al this longe day
But al for nought / he herde never a word
An hole he founde / ful lowe vpon a bord
There as the cat / was wont in forto crepe
And at the hole / he loked in ful depe
And atte laste he hadde of hym a sight
This Nicolas / sat euere gapynge vpright
As he hadde kyked in the newe Mone
A dou he goth / and tolde his maist̉er sone
In what aray / he saugh this ilke man
This Carpenter / to blissen hym bigan
And seide helpe vs / seint Frideswyde
A man wote litel / what hym shal betyde
This man is fallen / with his astronomye
In som woodnes / or in som agonye
I thoughte wel / how it shulde be
Men shulde not knowe goddes priuit
Ȝe blessed be ȝit / the lewed man
That nought / but only his bileue can
So ferde another clerk with astronomye
He walked in the feeldes forto prye
Vp on the sterres / to wite what shulde befalle
Til he was in a marle pitte yfalle
He saugh noght / that / but ȝit by seint Thomas
Me reweth sore / heende Nicolas
He shal be rated of his studyng
Ȝif that I may / by Ihus heven kyng
Gete me a staf that I may vnderspore
While that thou Robyn / hevest vp the dore
He shal out of his studyng as I gesse
And to the Chambre dore / he gan hym dresse
His knave was a strong carl for the nones
And by the haspe / he haf it vp at ones
Into the flore / the dore fel anon
This Nicolas / sat ay stille as stou
And euere gaped vpward into the eyre
This Carpenter / wende he were in dispeyre
And hente hym / by the shulders myghtily
And shook hym harde / and cried spitously
What Nicolas / what how loke adou
Awake and thenke on cristes passiou
I crouche the from elues / and fro wightes
Ther with the nyght spell / he seide anon rightes
On foure halfes / of the hous aboute
And on the thresshfold on the dore withoute
Ihu Crist and seint Benedight
Blesse vs / from euery wikked wight
For the nyghte uerye the white pat̉er noster
Where wentest thou seint petres suster
And atte laste / this heende Nicolas
Gan sore forto sike / and oft seide allas
Shal al the worlde be lost / eft sones nowe
This Carpenter answered / what saist thowe /
What thenke on god as we done / men that swynke
This Nicolas answered / fecche me drynke /¶
And after wol I speke in priuite
Of certeyne thyng / that toucheth the and me /
I wol telle it noon other man certeyn
This Carpenter goth dou / and cometh ageyn
And brought of myghty ale / a large quart
And whan that eche of hem / hadde dronke his part
This Nicolas / his dore faste shette
And dou the Carpenter / by hym he sette
And seide Iohn / my host leef and dere
Thow shalt vpon thy trouthe swere me here
That to no wight / thou shalt this conseill biwreye
For it is cristes conseill that I seye
And ȝif thou telle it man / thou art forlore
For this vengeance / thou shalt have / therfore
That ȝif thou biwreye me / thou shalt be wood
Nay crist forbede it for his holy blood
Quod this sely man / I am no blabbe
Ne though I seye / I nam not leef to gabbe
Sey what thou wilt I shal it neuer telle
To childe ne wyf by hym / that harwed helle
¶ Now Iohn qd Nicolas I wol nought lye
I have yfounde / in myn astrologye
As I have loked in the Mone bright
That now a monday next after quarter nyght
Shal falle areyn / and that so wilde and wood
That half so grete was never Noes flood
This world he seide / in lasse than an hour
Shal al be dreynt / so hidous is the shour
Thus shal mankynde drenche / and lese her lyf
This Carpenter answered / allas my wyf
And shal she drenche / allas my Alisou
For sorowe of this / he fel almost adou
And seide is ther no remedie in this caas
Why ȝis for gode / quod heende Nicolas
Ȝif thou wilt wirche / after lore and reed
Thou maist nought wirchen after thyn owne heed
For thus seith Salomon / that was ful trewe /
Wirche by conseill / and thou shalt never rewe ¶¶
And ȝif thou wirche wil by good consaill
I vndertake withoute mast or saill
Ȝit shal I save her / and the and me
Hastow nought herde / how saved was Noe
Whan that oure lorde / hath warned hym biforn
That al the worlde / with water sholde be lorn
Ȝis qd this Carpenter / ful ȝore ago
Hastow noght herde / qd Nicolas also
The sorowe of Noe / with his felaship
Or that he myghte gete his wyf to ship
Hym hadde lever I dar vndertake
At thilke tyme / than all his wetheres blake
That she hadde / had a ship hir self allone
And therfore wostow what is best to done
This asketh haste / and of an hasty thynge
Men may nought preche / ne make tariynge
Anou go gete vs faste ynto this Inne
A knedyng trough / or a kemelynne
For eche of vs / but loke that it be large
In whiche we may swymme as in a barge
And have therynne vitailles suffisant
But for a day / fy on the remenant
The water shal a slake / and goon away
Aboute Prime / on the nexte day
But Robyn may not wite of this that is thy knave
Ne eke thy mayde gille / I may nought save
Aske not why / for though thou aske me
I wol not tellen goddes priuite
Suffiseth /the but ȝif thy wittes madde
To have as grete a grace / as Noe hadde
Thy wyf shall I wel saven out of doute
Go now thy wey and spede the here aboute
But whan thou hast / for hir the and me
Ygeten vs thise knedyng tubbes thre
Than shalt thou hange hem / in the roof ful hye
That no man of our purueance espye .
And whan thou thus hast done / as I have sayd /
And hast oure vitayle / faire in hem ylayd . ¶
And eke an axe to smyte the corde a two
Whan that the water cometh / that we may go
And broke an hole / on high vpon the gable
Vnto the gardeynward ouer the stable
That we may frely passen / forth oure way
Whan that the grete shour / is gon away
Than shalt thou swymme as mery I vndertake
As doth the mallerd after the drake
Than wol I clepe / how Alisou how Iohn
Be mery / for the flood wil passe anou
And thou wilt say / heyle maist̉er Nicolay
Good morow / I se the wel / for it is day
And than shal we be lordes al oure lyf
Of al the world / as Noe and his wyf
But that of o thyng / I warne the ful right
Be wel avised on that ilke nyght
That we ben entred in to the shippes bord
That noon of vs / ne speke nought a word
Ne clepe ne crie / but be in his prayere
For it is goddes owne heste dere /
Thy wyf and thou mot hange fer a twynne
For that bitwixt you / shal be no synne
No more in lokyng / than ther shal in dede
This ordinaıı̄unce is said / go god the spede
To morow at nyght / whan men been alle in slepe
Into oure knedyng tubbes wol we crepe
And sitten there / abydeng goddes grace
Go now thy way / I have no leger space
To make of this / no lenger sermonynge
Men seyn thus / sende the wyse / and say no thyng
Thow art so wys / it nedeth the noght to teche
Go save oure lyf and that I the biseche
This sely Carpenter / goth forth his way
Ful ofte he saide allas and wele away
And to his wyf / he tolde his priuite
And she was war / and knewe it bet than he
What al this queynte cast was forto seye
But natheles / she ferde as she wolde deye /¶¶
And seide allas go forth thy weye anoou
Helpe vs to scape / or we be dede echoon
I am thy trewe verray wedded wyf
Go dere spouse / and helpe to save oure lyf
¶ Lo whiche a greet thyng / is affecciou
Men may deye of ymaginaciou
So depe may impressiou be take
This sely Carpenter / bigynneth quake
Hym thenkith veraily / that he may see
Noes flood / come walwynge in the see
To drenchen Alison his hony dere
He wepeth wayleth maketh sory chere
He siketh with ful many a sory swough
And goth / and geteth hym a knedyng trowgh
And after a tubbe / and a kymelyn
And priuely / he sente hem to hys In
And heeng hem in the roof in priuite
His owne hand / he made eke laddres thre
To clymbe by the ronges / and the stalkes
Vnto the tubbes / hangenge in the balkes /
And hem vitailed / bothe trough and tubbe
With brede and chese / and good ale in a Iubbe
Suffisynge right ynow / as for a day
But er that he hadde made al this array
He sente his knave / and eke his wenche also
Vpon his nede / to londou forto go /
¶ And on the monday / whan it drought to nyght
He shette his dore / withoute candel light
And dressed al thyng / as it shulde be
And shortly vp they clomben al thre
They saten stille / wel a forlong way
Now Pater noster / clum seide Nicolay
Clum qd Iohn / and clum seide Alison
This Carpenter seide his devocion
And stille he sitte and biddes his prayere
Awaytenge on the reyn ȝif he myght it here
The dede slepe / for wery besynesse
Fil on this Carpenter / right as I gisse ¶¶
Aboute corfew tyme / or lytel more
For trauayle of his goost / he groned sore
And eft he routeth / for his hede myslay
Done of the ladder / stalketh Nicolay
And Alisou a done ful softe she spedde
Withoute wordes moo they gou to bedde
Ther as the Carpenter / is wont to lye
There was the Reuel / and the melodye
And thus lyth Alisou and Nicolas
In besynesse in merthe / and in solas
Til that the belle of laudes / gan to rynge
And freres in the Chauncell gonne synge
¶ This Parissh Clerk amerous Absolou
That is for loue / alwey so wo bygou
Vpou the monday was at Osenay
With companie / hym to desporte and play
And asked vpon caas a Cloystrer
Ful priuely after Iohn the Carpenter
And he drough hym a part out of the chirche
And seide I not / I saugh hym here noght wirche
Sithe saterday / I trowe / that he be went
For tymber there oure Abbot hath hym sent
For he is wont for tymber for to go /
And dwellen atte graunge a day or two
Or elles he is at his hous certeyn
Where that he be I can nought seyn
This Absolou ful ioly was and light
And thought now ys tyme / to wake al nyght
For sikerly / I saugh hym nought sterynge
Aboute his dore / syn day bigan to sprynge
So mote I thryue / I shal at cokkes crowe
Ful priuely knokke at his wyndowe
That stant ful lowe / vpon his bowre wall
To Alisoıı̄un now / wol I tellen all
My loue longynge / For ȝit I shal not mysse
That atte leste wey / I shall here kisse
Som maner confort / shal I have Parfay
My mowth hath icched / al this longe day /¶¶
This is a signe of kissynge atte leste
Al nyght me mette eke / that I was at a feste
Therfore I wol go slepe an houre or tweye
And al the nyght / than wil I wake and pleye
Whan that the first cok hath crowe anou
Vp rist this ioly louer Absolou
And arrayeth hym / gay at poynt devys
But first he cheweth greyns and licoris
To smellen swote / or he hadde kempt his here /
Vnder his tunge / a trewe loue he bere
For therby wende he to be gracious
He rometh to the Carpenters hous
And stille he stant vnder the shorꝭes wyndowe
Vnto his breste . it raught / it was so lowe
And softe he koughed with a semy soıı̄un
What do ȝe hony combe / swete Alisou
My faire brid / my swete synamome
Awaketh lemman myn / and speketh to me
Wel lytel thenke ye / vpon my woo
That for youre loue / I swelte as I goo /
No wonder is though that I swelte and swete
I morne as doth a lambe after the tete
Ywys lemman / I have suche loue longeng
That lyke aturtel / trewe / is my morneng
I may not ete / namore than a mayde
Go fro the wyndowe / Iakke fool she sayde
As helpe me god / it wil not be compame
I loue a nother / and ellis I were to blame
Wel bet than the / by Ihus Absolou
Go forth thy weye / or I wil caste a stou
And lete me slepe / atwenty deuelway
Allas qd Absolou / and weleaway
That trewe loue / was eủere so evel biset
Than kisse me / syn it may be no bet
For Ihus loue / and for the loue of me
Wiltow than go thy way / ther with qd she
Ȝe certes lemman / qd this Absolon
Than make the redy / qd she I come anou ¶
This Absolon don sette hym on his knees
And seide I am a lorde / at alle degrees
For after this I hope ther shal come more
Lemman thy grace / and swete brid thyn ore
The wyndowe she vndoth and that in haste
Have do qd she / come of / and spede the faste
Lest that oure neghebores the espie
This Absolou gan wype his mouthe ful drie
Derke was the nyght / as piche or as the cole
And at the wyndowe out she putte hir hole
And Absolon hym fil / no bet ne wers
But with his bare Mouthe / he kiste hir naked ers
Ful sauoᵘurly / or he was ware of this
A bak he sterte / and thoughte it was amys
For wel he wiste / a woman hath no berd
He felte a thyng al rough and longe yhered
And seide allas / fy what haue I do
Te he qd she / and clapte the wyndowe to
And Absolon goth forth a sory paas
A berde a berde / seide hende Nicolas
By godes corpus / this goth faire and wel
This sely Absolon / herde it euery del
And on his lippe / he gan for anger byte
And to hym self seide / I shal the quyte
Who rubbeth now / who froteth now his lippes
With dust with sande / wᵗith strawe / wᵗith cloth wᵗith chippes
But Absolon / that seith ful ofte allas
My soule bitake I vnto Sathanas
But me were leuer / than al this tou qd he
Of this despite / a wroken forto be /
Allas qd he / allas I ne hadde ybleynt
His hote loue was colde / and al yqueynt
For fro that tyme / that he hadde kyst hir ers
Of ꝑparamoᵘurs / he sette nought a kers .
For he was heled / of his maladie
Ful ofte ꝑparamours / he gan to diffie
And weep as doth a childe that is ybete
A softe pas he wente ouer the strete /
Vn tyl a smyth / men cleped daıı̄un gerueys
That in his forge / smythieth plough harneys /
He sharpeth share / and culter bisily /
This Absolon knokketh al esely
And seide vnto Gerveys / and that anou
What who art thou / It am I / Absolou
What Absolon / what crestes swete tre
Why rise ye so rathe / ey benedicite
What eyleth you / som gay gerl god it woot
Hath brought you / thus on the viritoot
By seint Note / wete wel what I mene
This Absolon ne roughte nought a bene
Of al his pley / ne word ageyn he gaf
He hadde more tow / on his distaf
Than Gerveys knewe / and seide frende so dere
The hote culter / in the chymyne here
As lene it me / I have therwith to done
I wol brynge it ageyn ful sone
Gerveys answered / certes were it gold
Or in a poke / nobles all vntold
Thou sholdest have it / as I am trewe smyth
Ey cristes fo / what wole ye done ther with
Therof qd Absolou / be as be may
I shal wel tellen it / the to morow day
And caughte the culter / by the colde stele
Ful softe / out atte dore / he gan stele
And wente vnto the Carpenters wal
And koughed first / and knokked ther with al /
Vpon the wyndowe / right as he dide ere
This Alisou answered / who is there /
That knokketh so / I warante it is a theef
Why nay qd he / god woot my swete leef
It am I Absolon / thy dere derlynge
Of gold qd he / I have the brought a rynge
My moder ȝaf it me / so god me save /
Ful fyn it is / and therto wel ygrave
This wel I yeve the / ȝif thou me kisse
This Nicolas / was risen for to pisse /¶¶
And thought he wolde amende al the iape
He sholde kisse his ers / or that he scape
And vp the wyndowe /dide he hastely
And out his ers / he putte priuely
Ouer the buttok / to the haunche bou
And therwith spak this clerk / this Absolou
Speke swete brid / I noot were thou art
This Nicolas / anoou lete fleen a fart
As greet as it hadde ben a thonder dent
That with the strook he was almost yblent
And he was redy with his iren hoot
And Nicolas in the ers he smoot
Of goth the skyn / an hanbrede aboute
The hote culter / brenned so his toute
And for the smert / he wende for to dye
As he were wood / for wo he gan to crye
Helpe water water / helpe for godes herte
This Carpenter / out of his slomber sterte
And herde oon cryen water / as he were wood
And thought / allas now cometh Noes flood
And sette hym vp / withoute wordes mo
And with an axe / he smote the corde a two /
And dou goth al / he fonde neither to selle
Bred nor ale / til he come to the selle
Vpou the flour / and there a swou he lay
Vp stirte hire Alisou and Nicolay
And cried out / and harrow in the strete
The neghebores / bothe smale and grete
In ronne forto gauren on this man
That a swou lay / bothe pale and wan
For with that fal / he brosten hadde his arme
But stonden he muste / vnto his owne harme
For whan he spak / he was anou bore dou
With hende Nicolas and Alisou
They tolde euery man / that he was wood
He was agast so / of Noes flood
Thurgh fantasie / that of his vanyte
He hadde ybought hym / knedyng tubbes thre ¶¶
And hadde hem hanged / in the roof above
And that he prayed hem / for godes loue
To sitte in the roof ꝑpar companie
The folk gan laughen at his fantasie
And to the roof they kyken / and they gape
And torned al his harme vnto a iape
For what so this Carpenter answerde
It was for nought / no man his resou herde
With othes grete / he was so boru adou
That he was holden wood in al that tou
For euery Clerk / anoon right heeld wᵗith other
They saide the man / is wood my leve brother
And euery wight gan laughen at this stryf
Thus swyved was the Carpent̉ers wyf
For al his kepyng and his ialousie
And Absolon / hath kist hir nether eye
And Nicolas is scalded in his toute
This tale is dou / and god save al this route /
¶ Thus endeth the mellers tale /

l.hi:
And here bigynneth
the prologe of the Reve ⁊et c̉etera

div.l: Whan folk han laughen / at this nyce caas
Of Absolon̄ and heende Nicolas
Diủerse folk dyủersely they seide
But for the more ꝑpart / they lowh and pleide
And at this tale / I saugh no man hym greue
But it were only Oswald the Reve
By cause he was of Carpenters craft
A lytel ire is in his herte ilaft
He gan to grucche / and blamed it a lyte
So the ik quod he / wel I couthe the quyte
With bleryng of a prowde Mellers eye
Ȝif that me liste / to speke of rebaudye
But ik am olde / me list not pleye for age
Gras tyme is done / my fodder is forage
This white top / writeth myn olde ȝeres
Myn herte is also mowled as myn̄ heres
But ȝit I fare / as doth an open ers
That ilke fruyt is eủere lenger the wer
Til it be roten in mullok or in stree
We olde men I drede / so fare we
Til we be roten / can we not be rype
We hoppen alwey / while the world wol pipe
For in oure wil / ther stiketh eủere a nayle
To haue an hoor heed / and a grene tayle
As hath a leek / for though oure myght be goon
Oure wille desireth folye eủere in oon
For whan̄ we may noȝt done / than wol we speke
Ȝit in oure asshen olde / is fire yreke
Foure gledes have we / whiche I shal deuise
Auᵃauntyng lying / anger and couetise
Thise foure sparkles longen vnto elde
Oure olde lymes / may wel ben vnwelde
But wille shal not faylen / that is soth
And ȝit have I alwey / a coltes toth
As many a ȝere / as it is passed henne
Syn that my tappe of lyf bygan to renne
For sikerly / whan I was born̄ anoon̄
Deth drough the tappe of lyf and let it goon̄
And euer sithen / hath the tappe yronne
Til that almost / al empty is the tonne
The streme of lyf now droppeth on the chymbe
The sely tonge may wel rynge and clymbe
Of wrecchednes / that passed is ful yore
With ode folk / saue dotage is more
Whan that oure host / hadde herde this ʆsermonyng
He gan forto speke / as lordly as a kyng
He seide what amounteth al this witte
What shal we speke al day of holy writte
The devel made a Reve / forto p̉reche
Or of a Souter a Shipman or a leche
Sey forth thy tale / and tarie nouȝt the tyme
Lo depford / and it is almost pryme
Lo Grenewich / that many a shrewe is ynne
It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne
Now sires / qduod this Oswold / the Reve
I pᵃray you all / that ye nouȝt you grev
Though I answere / and somdel sette his howe
For leeful it is wᵗith force / force of showe
This dronken Miller / hath ytolde vs here
How that bigyled was a Carpentere
Par aun̄ter in scorne / for that I am oon̄
And by youre leue / I shal hym quyte anoon̄
Right in his cherles t̉ermes wol I speke
I pray to god his nekke mote to breke
He can wel in myn̄ eye seen a stalke
But in his owne / he can not seen a balke
¶ Explicit ꝓprolog͗e /
et Incipit fabula
At Trumpyngton̄ nouȝt fer fro Caumbrigge
Ther goth a brook / and over that a brigge
Vpon̄ the whiche brook / ther stant a mylle
And this is verray soth / that I you telle
A meller was ther dwellynge many a day
As eny pecok he was proud and gay
Pipen he couthe / fisshen and nettes bete
And turne cuppes / and wel wrastle and shete
Ay by his belte / he bar a long panade
And of a swerd / ful trenchant was the blade
A ioly popper bar he in his powche
Ther was no man for ꝑperile durste hym touche
A Shefeld thwytel / bar he in his hose
Round was his face / and camuse was his nose
As peled as an ape /was his sculle
He was a market beter atte fulle
Ther was no wight / that durst hande on hym legge
But ȝif he swoor / he shulde anoon̄ abegge
A theef he was / for soth of corn and mele
And that a slight / and vsant forto stele
Hys name was hoten̄ / Deynous Symkyn̄
A wyf he hadde / comen of noble kyn̄
The ꝑperson̄ of the toıı̄un / hir fader was
With hir he ȝaf ful many a panne of bras
For that Symkyn̄ / sholde in his blood allie
She was yfostred / in a Nonnerie
For Symkyn wolde no wyf as he said
But she were wel ynorsshed / and a mayde
To saven his estate of yomanrie
And she was proud / and pert as is a pie
A ful faire sight / was it vppon hem two
On halydies / biforn hir wolde go
With his tipet / wounden aboute his heed
And she cam after / in a gyte of reed
And Symkyn̄ / hadde hosen of the same
Ther durst no wight / clepen her but dame
Was noon̄ so hardy / that went by the way
That with hir durste / rage or ones play
But ȝif he wolde be slayn̄ of Symkyn̄
With panade or wᵗith knyf or boydekyn̄
For ialuose folk ben ꝑperilous euere moo
Algate they wolde hir wyves wende soo
And eke for she was somdel smoterliche
She was as digne / as water in a diche
And ful of hoker / and of bismare
Hir thoughte / that a lady sholde hir spare
What for hir kynrede / and hir nortelrie
That she hadde lerned in the nonnerie
A doughter hadde they / bitwixt hem two
Of twenty yere / withoute eny mo
Sauynge a childe / that was of half yere age
In cradel it lay / and was a proper page
This wenche thikke / and wel ygrowen was
With camuse nose / and eyen grey as glas
With buttokkes brode / and brestes rounde and hye
But right faire was hire face / I wil nouȝt lye
The ꝑperson̄ of the toıı̄un / for she was faire
In purpose was / to maken hir / his heyre
Bothe of his catel / and of his mesuage
And straunge he made it / of hir mariage
His purpos was / to bestowe hir hye
Into some worthy blood / of Auncetrye
For holy chirches good /moot ben dispended
On holy chirche blood / that is descended
Therfore he wolde / his holy blood honour
Though that he holy chirche shulde deuoure
¶ Grete soken hath this meller out of doute
With whete and malt / of al the londe aboute
And namely / ther was a grete college
Men clepen the Soler halle of Caumbrigge
There was her whete / and hir malt ygrounde
And on a day / it happed in a stounde
Syk lay the manciple / on a maladye
Men wende wisly / that he shulde dye
For whiche the Miller / stale bothe mele and corn̄
An hundred tyme more / than biforn̄
For ther biforn̄ he stale but curteisly
But now he was a theef outrageously
For whiche the wardeyn̄ chidde and made fare
But thereof sette the Miller nouȝt a tare
He craked bost / and it was nouȝt so
Than were there yonge scolers two
That dwelte in the halle / of whiche I seye
Testif they were / and lusty forto pleye
And only for her merthe / and her reuerie
Vpon̄ the wardeyn̄ / besily they crie
To yeve hem leve but a lytel stounde
To goon to mylle / and seen her corn ygrounde
And hardely they durste leie her nekke
The meller sholde not stele hem half a pekke
Of corn / ne by sligthe / ne by force hem reve
And at the laste / the wardeyn̄ yaf hem leve
Iohn highte that oon / and Aleyn highte the other
Of oo toun were they born̄ / that highte Strother
Fer in the north / I can not tellen where
This Aleyn̄ maketh redy / al his gere
And on an hors / the sak he caste anoon
Forth goth Aleyn̄ / the clerk and also Iohn
With goode swerde / and bokeler by his syde
Iohn knewe the weye / hym nedeth no gyde
And atte melle / the sak adoıı̄un he layeth
Aleyn̄ spak first al helye Symond in fayeth
How fares thy fayre doughter and thy wy
Aleyn welcome qduod Symkyn by my lyf
And Iohn also / how now / what do ye here
By god qduod Iohn / Symond nede has no pere
Hym byhoues to serue hym self / that has na swayn̄
Or ellis he is a fool / as clerkes sayn̄
Oure Manciple / I hope wil be ded
Swa werkes hym ay / the wanges in his hed
And therfore is I come / and eke Alayn̄
To grynde oure corn̄ / and carie it ham agayn̄
I pray you / spedes vs hethen that ye may
It shalbe done qduod Symkyn by my fay
What wol ye done / while it is in hande
By god right by the hoper wol I stande
Quod Iohn / and see how gates / the corn gas inne
Ȝit saugh I neuer by me Fader kynne
How that the hoper wagges til and fra
Aleyn̄ answered Iohn / wil ye swa
Than wil I be bynethe by my croıı̄un
And see how gates / the mele falles doıı̄un
In til the trough / that sal be my disport
Quod Iohn in faith / I is of youre sort
I is as ille a meller / as are ye
This meller smyled of her nycete
And thought al this nys / done but for a wyle
They wene / that no man / may hem begyle
But by my thrift / ȝet shal I blere her eye
For al the sleighte / in her philosophie
The more queynte that thise Clerkes make
The more wil I stele / whan I take
In stede of flour / ȝit wol I ȝeve hem bren
The grettest Clerkes / be nought wysest men̄
As whilom to the wolf spak the mare
Of al her art / ne counte I nouȝt a tare
Out at the dore / he goth ful priuely
Whan that he saugh his tyme softely
He loketh vp and doıı̄un / til he hath founde
The Clerkes hors / there as it stood ybounde
Behynde the melle / vnder a leuesel
And to the hors he goth faire and well
He strepith of the bridel / right anoon̄
And whan the hors was loos he bigynneth to goon̄
Toward the fen̄ / there wilde mares renne
And fortwith we hee / thurgh thikke and thenne
This meller goth agayen̄ / no worde he seyde
But doth his note / and with these clerkes pleyde
Til that her corn was faire and wel ygrounde
And whan the mele is sakked and ybounde
This Iohn goth forth / and fynde his hors away
And gan to crie harow / and weleaway
Oure hors is lost Aleyn̄ / for goddes banes
Stepe on thy feet / come of man al attanes
Allas oure wardeyn̄ / has his palfray lorn
This Aleyn̄ al forgat / bothe mele and corn
Al was out of his mynde / his housbonderie
What whilke way is he goon̄ he gan to crie
The wyf come lepyng in at a ren
She saide allas / youre hors goth to the fen
With wilde mares / as fast as he may go
Vnthank come on his hande / that band hym so
And he that bet sholde have knet the reyne
Allas qduod Iohn Aleyn̄ for cristes peyne
Lay doıı̄un thy swerd / and I wil myn̄ alswa
I is ful swift / god wat as is a ra
By goddes herte / he shal nought scape vs bathe
Why ne hadde thou putte the capel in the lathe
Il hayel by god Aleyn̄ thou is a fonne
Thise sely clerkes / han ful faste yronne
Toward the fen / bothe Aleyn and eke Iohn
And whan the Meller saugh that they were goon̄
He half a busshel of here mele hath take
And bid his wyf gon knede it in a cake
And seide I trowe / these Clerkes were aferd
Ȝit can a meller make a clerkes berd
For al here art / ȝe lat hem goon here weye
Lo where they goon̄ / ȝe lat the children pleye
They gete hym nouȝt so lightly by my croıı̄u
Thise sely clerkes / rennen vp and doıı̄un
With kepe kepe / stand stand / iosa · warderere
Ga whistle thou / and I shal kepe hym here
But shortly tyl it was verray nyght
They couthe not / though they dide her myght
Her capil cacche / he ranne awey so faste
Til in a diche / they caughte hym atte laste
Wery and weet as bestes ben̄ in the reyn̄
Cometh sely Iohn / and with hym cometh Aleyn̄
¶ Allas qduod Iohn / the day that I was born̄
Now ere we drevyn / tyl hethyng and til scorn̄
Oure corn is stole / men wol vs fooles calle
Bothe the wardeyn̄ / and oure felawes alle
And namely the meller / wele away
Thus playneth Iohn / as he goth by the way
Toward the Melle / and bayhard in his hande
The meller sittynge by the fyre he fonde
For it was nyght / and ferther myght they nought
But for the love of god / they hym bisought
Of herberwe and of ese / as for her peny
The meller seide ageyn̄ / ȝif ther be eny
Swich as it is / ȝit shal ȝe have youre part
Myn̄ hous is streit / and ȝe have lerned art
Ye can by argument make a place
A myle brood / of twenty fote of space
Lat se nowe / ȝif this place may suffice
Or make it rowmer / wᵗith speche as is youre gise
¶ Now Symond seide this Iohn by seint Cuthberd
Ay is thou mery / and that is faire answerd
I have herde say / men sal taken of twa thynges
Swilk as ye fyndes or take swilke as ye brynges
But specialy / I pray the hoost dere
Gete vs some mete and drynke and make vs chere
And we wol paie trewely atte fulle
With empty handes / men may nane haukes tulle
Lo here oure syluer redy forto spende
This Meller to the toıı̄un his doughter sende
For ale and breed / and rosted hem a goo
And bonde her hors / it sholde no more go loos
And in his owne chambre he made a bed
With shetes ⁊and wᵗith chalons fayre yspred
Nought from his owne bed ten fote or twelue
His doughter hadde a bed al by her selue
Right in the same chambre by
It myght be no bet and cause why
Ther was no rowmer herberwe in the place
They soupen and they speken hem to solace
And drynken ever stronge ale atte beste
Aboute mydnyght wente they to reste
Wel hath this Meller / vernysshed his heed
Ful pake he was for dronken / and noght reed
He ȝixeth and he speketh thurgh the nose
As he were on the quakke / or on the pose
To bed he goth and with hym goth his wyf
As eny iay she light was and iolyf
So was hir ioly whistel wel ywette
The cradel atte hir beddes feet is ysette
To rokken / and to yeve the childe to souke
And whan that dronken was al in crouke
To bedde wente the doughter right anoon̄
To bedde goth Aleyn̄ and also Iohn
Ther was no more hem neded no dwale
The meller hath so wysely bibbed ale
That as an hors / he snorteth in his sleep
Ne of his tayle ende / ne taketh he no keep
His wyf bar hym a burdon̄ a ful strong
Men myghte her routyng here a forlong
The wenche routeth eke ꝑpar companie
Aleyn the Clerk / that herde this melodye
He powked Iohn / and seide slepistow
Herde thou ever slyk a sang as now
Lo swilk a couplyng is amonges thaym alle
A wylde fyre / on thayre bodyes falle
Who herked eủere swilk a ferly thyng
Ȝe they sal have the floure of ille endyng
This lange nyght ther tides me na rest
But ȝit na force al sal be for the beste
For Iohn seide he as ever mote I thryue
Ȝif that I may / yonder wenche wol I swyue
Som esement has lawe shapen vs
For Iohn / ther is a lawe / that saith thus
That ȝif a man in oo point be a greued
That in another he shal be releved
¶ Oure corn̄ is stolen / sothly it is no nay
And we have hadde / an ille fitte to day
And syn I shal have nan amendement
A gayn̄ my losse / I wil have esement
By goddes soule / it shal nan other be
This Iohn answered Aleyn̄ avise the
The meller is a ꝑperilous man he seide
And ȝif he out of his sleep abreide
He myght done vs bothe a vylenye
Aleyn̄ answered I counte hym not a flye
And vp he riste / and by the wenche he crepte
The wenche lay vpright / and faste slepte
Til he so nygh was / or she myght aspie
That it hadde ben / to late forto crie
And shortely forto seyn̄ / they were at on
Now pley Aleyn̄ / for I wol speke of Iohn
¶ This Iohn lieth stille a forlong way or two
And to hym self / he maketh routhe and wo
Allas qduod he / this is a wikked iape
Now may I say / that I is but an ape
Ȝit hath my felawe / somwhat for his harm
He hath the mellers doughter / in his arm
He auntred hym / and hath his nedes spedde
And I ligge as a draf sak in my bed
And whan this iape / ys tolde another day
I shal be holde a daffe / a cokenay
I wol aryse and auntre it by my faith
Vnhardy is vnsely thus men saith
And vp he roos / and softely he wente
Vnto the cradel and in his hand it hente
And bar it softe vnto his beddes fee
Sone after the wyf hir routyng leet
And gan to wake / and wente hir out to pisse
And come ageyn̄ and gan hir cradel mysse
And groped here and there / but she founde non̄
Allas qduod she / almost I hadde mysgon̄
I hadde almost goon / to the clerkes bed
Ey benedicite / than hadde I foule ysped
And forth she goth til she the cradel fond
And gropeth alwey ferther with hir hond
And fond the bed / and thoughte nought but good
By cause that the cradel by it stood
And nyste where she was / for it was derk
But faire and wel / she crepte into the clerk
And lyth full stille / and wolde have caught a sleep
Withynne a while / this Iohn the clerk vp leep
And on this goode wyf / he leyth on sore
So mery a fitte / ne hadde she nought ful ȝore
He priketh harde / and depe as he were mad
This ioly lyf / han thise clerkes lad
Til that the thridde cok bigan to synge
¶ Aleyn wex wery / in the dawenynge
For he hadde swonken / al the longe nyght
And seide fare wel Malyn swete wyght
The day is come / I may no lenger byde
But euere mo / where so I go or ryde
I am thyn owne clerk / so have I hele
Now dere lemman qduod she go farewele
But or thou go / oo thyng I wol the telle
Whan that thou wendest / homward by the melle
Right at the entre / of the dore behynde
Thou shalt a cake / of half a busshell fynde
That was ymaked of thyn owne mele
Whiche I halpe my Fader forto stele
And good lemman god the save and kepe
And with that worde / almost she gan to wepe
Aleyn vprist and thoughte / or that it dawe
I wol go crepen in by my felawe
And fonde the cradel with his honde anoon
By god thoughte he al I have mysgoon̄
Myn̄ heed is toty of my swynke to nyght
That maketh me / that I go nought aright
I wote wel by the cradel / I have mysgo
He lyth the Meller / and his wyf also
And forth he goth / a twenty devel way
Vnto the bed ther / as the Meller lay
He wende have cropen in by his felawe Iohn
And by the Meller / in he crepe anon̄
And caughte hym by the nekke / and softe spake
And seide thou Iohn / thou swyneshed awake
For cristes soule and here a noble game
For by that lorde / that called is seynt Iame
As I have thries in this shorte nyght
Swyued the mellers doughter / thries bolt vpright
While thou has as a Coward ben agast
Ȝe false harlot quood the Meller hast
A fals traytoᵘurr / fals clerk quod he
Thou shalt be ded by goddes dignyte
Who durste be so bolde to disparagedispargedisparage
My doughter / that is comen of swiche lynage
And by the throte bolle / he caught Aleyn̄
And hente hym dispitousely ageyn̄
And on the nose / he smote hym with his fist
Doun ran the blody streme vpon his brist
And in the flore wᵗith nose and mouthe to broke
They walwe as done / two pigges in a poke
And they gon̄ and doıı̄un ageyn̄ anon̄
Till that the Meller sporned at a ston̄
And doıı̄un he fil bakward vpon his wyf
That wyste no thynge / of this nyce stryf
For she was falle a slepe / a lytel wight
With Iohn the Clerk that waked hadde al nyght
And were fal out / of hir slepe she brayde
Helpe holy Cros of bromholme she sayde
In manus tuas lorde to the I calle
Awake Symond the fende is on me falle
Myn herte is broken holpe I nam but dee
The lyth oon vpon my wombe / and vpon̄ myn heed
Helpe Symkyn̄ for the false clerkes fighte
This Iohn sterte vp / as faste as euere he myghte
And grasped by the walles to and fro
To fynde a staf / and she sterte vp also
And knewe the estres bet than dide Iohn
And by the wal / a staf she founde anoon̄
And saugh a lytel shymeryng of a lyght
For at an hole / in shoon the mone bryght
And by that lyght / she saugh hem bothe two
But sikerly / she nyste who was who
But as she saugh / a white thyng in hir eye
And whan she gan this white thyng aspye
She wende the clerk / hadde wered a volupere
And with the staf / she drough eủere nere and nere
And wende han hitte / this Aleyn̄ atte fulle
And smote the Meller / on the piled sculle
That doıı̄un he goth / and cried harrow I dye
Thise clerkes beten hym wel / and lete hym lye
And greythen hem / and token her hors anoon
And eke here mele / and on her way they goon̄
And atte Melle ȝit they toke her cake
Of half a busshell whete / ful wel ybake
Thus is the proude Meller wel ybete
And hath ylost / the gryndyng of the whete
And paied for the soper eủerydell
Of Aleyn̄ and of Iohn / that beeten hym well
His wyf is swyued / and his doughter als
Lo swich is it a Meller to be fals
And therfore the ꝓprouerbe is seid ful soth
Hym thar not wel wene / that evel doth
A gylour shal hym self begiled be
And god that sitteth highe in mageste
Save al this company grete and smale
This have I quytte the Millere his tale
¶ Explicit fabula ⁊et c̉etera

¶ And in the next leyf
Bygynneth the prologe of the Cook ⁊et c̉eter
The Cook of london̄ / while the Reve spak
For ioye hym thoughte / he clawed hym on the bak
A ha quod he / for cristes passion̄
This meller hath a sharp conclusion̄
Vpon his argument of herbergage
Wel seide Salamon / in his langage
Ne bryng not eủery man / into thy hous
For herberwyng by nyght is ꝑperilous
Wel ought a man / avysed for to be
Whom that he broughte into his pⁱriuyte
I pray to god / so yeve me sorowe and care
Ȝif euere suthen I highte hogge of ware
Herde I meller bet yset a werke
He hadde a iape of malice in the derke
And therfore ȝif ye vouchesauf to here
But god forebede / that we stynte here
A tale of me that am a pore man̄
I wol you telle / as wel as euere I can̄
A lytel iape / that fil on oure Cite
Oure oost answered / and seide I gᵃraunte it the
Now telle on Rogger / loke that be good
For many a paste hast thou laten blood
And many a Iakke of douere hast thou sold
That hath been twyes hoot and twyes cold
Of many a pilgryme hast thou cors
For of thy ꝑpersyle / ȝit they fare the wors
That they have eten with thy stubbil goos
For in thy shoppe is many a flye loos
Now telle on gentil Roger by thy name
But ȝit I pray the / be not wroth for game
A man may say ful soth / in game and pley
Thou seist ful soth quod Roger by my fey
But soth pley / quade pley / as the flemyng seith
And therfore / herry Bayly by thy feith
Be thou nought wrouth / er we departen here
Though that my tale / be of an Ostellere
But nathales I wol not telle it ȝit
But er we parte ywys / thou shalt be quy
And ther with al / he lough / and made good chere
And seide his tale / as ye shal after here
¶ Thus endeth the prologe
¶ And now bygynneth the tale
A prentys whilom dwelled in oure Cite
And of a craft of vitaillers was he
Gaylard he was / as goldfynche in the shawe
Bron as a berie / a ꝓpropre short felawe
With lokkes blake / ykempt ful fetisly
Daunce he couthe / so wel and iolyly
That he was cleped perkyn Reuelour
He was as ful of loue / and paramour
As is the hyue / ful of hony swete
Wel was the wenche / wᵗith hym myghte mete
At eủery bridale / wolde he synge and hoppe
He loued bet the tauerne / than the shoppe
For whan ther eny rydyng was in chepe
Out of the shoppe / thider wolde he lepe
Til that he hadde / al the sighte yseyn
And daunced wel / wolde he not come ageyn̄
He gadered hym a meyne of his sort
To hoppe and synge / and make such disport
Ande there they sette stevene forto mete
To pleyen atte dys / in suche a starte
For in the toıı̄un was ther no prentys
That fairer couthe caste a peyre of dys
Than p̉erkyn̄ couthe / and ther to he was fre
Of his dispence / in place of pryuyte
That founde his maist̉er / ful wel in his chaffare
For ofte tyme he fonde his box ful bare
For sikerly a p̉rentys reuelour
That haunteth dys / riot or ꝑparamour
His maister shal it in his shoppe abye
Al have he no part / of the mynstralcie
For theft and riot they ben inconủertible
Al can he pleye / on git̉erne or ribible
Revel and trouthe / as in lowe degree
They ben ful wrothe / alday as men may se
This ioly prentys / with his Maister bood
Tyl he were nygh out of his prentishood
Al were he snybbed / erly and late
And somtyme lad / wᵗith revel to Newgate
But atte laste / his maist̉er hym bithoughte
Vpon a day / whan he / his paper soughte
Of a prouerbe / that seith this same worde
Wel bet is roten appil out of horde
Than that that it rote al the remenant
So fareth by a riotous seruant
It is fulle lasse harme / to late hym pace
Than he shende alle the seruᵃauntes in the place
Therfore his Maist̉er / ȝaf hym a quytance
And bad hym goon with sorowe and meschance
And thus this ioly p̉rentys hadde his leve
Now let hym /riote / al the nyght or leve
And for ther is no theef withoute a lowke
That helpeth hym / to wasten and to sowke
Of that he bribe can̄ / or borwe may
Anoon he sente his bed / and his aray
Vnto a conpere of his owne sort
That loved dys revel / and disport
And hadde a wyf that heeld for countenᵃaunce
A shoppe / and swyued for hir sustenᵃaunce
But here of I wol passe as now
And of yonge Gamelyn I wol telle yow
(base) Lithen and lesteneth and herkeneth aright
(base) And ȝe shul here of a doughty knyght
(base) Sir Iohn of Boundes was his name
(base) He coude of norture and moche game
(base) Thre sones þe knyght hadde ⁊and with his body hem wan
(base) The eldest was a moche shrewe ⁊and sone he bigan
(base) His bretheren loued wel her fader ⁊and of hym were a gast
(base) The eldest deserued his fader cors ⁊and had it atte last
(base) The goode knyght his fader lyued so ȝore
(base) That deth was comen hym to ; and handeled hym ful sore
(base) The goode knyght cared sore sike there he lay
(base) How his children shulde lyue ; after his da
div.note: ¶ Cook
div.l: He hadde ben wyde where but non husbonde he was
Al the londe / that he hadde / it was purchas
Fayn he wolde it were dressed / among hem alle
That eche of hem hadde his part / as it myght falle
Tho sente he in to contre / after wyse knyghtes
To helpe delen his londes ⁊and dressen hem to rightes
He sente hem worde / by łletre / they shulde hye blyve
Yif they wolde speke wᵗith hym / while that he was on lyve
Tho the knyghtes herde syke / that he lay
Hadde they no reste by knyght nor by day
Til they come to hym / þere he lay stille
On his deth / bed to abide goddes wille
Than saide the goode knyght / syke there he lay
Lordes I you warne / forsothe withoute nay
I may no lenger leven here in this stounde
For thurgh goddes wille deth draweth me to grounde
Ther nas noon of hem alle that herde hym a right
That they ne hadde ruthe / of thilke knyght
And seide sire / for goddes loue ne dismay yow nought
God may do bote of bale / that is now ywrought
Than spak the good knyght syk there he lay
Bote of bale god may sende / I woot it is no nay
But I biseche you knyghtes / for the love of me
Goth and dresseth my londes / among my sones thre
And for the love of god / deleth hem not amys
And forȝeteth not. Gamelyn / my yonge sone that is
Taketh heede to that oon as wel as to that other
Seelde ye seen eny heir helpen his brother
Tho lete they the knyght lyn / that was not in hele
And wenten to counsell his londes to dele
Forto delen hem alle to oon that was her thought
And for Gamelyn was yongest / he shulde have nought
Al the londe that ther was they deled it in two
And lete Gamelyn the yonge withoute londe go
And eche of hem saide to other ful lowde
His bretheren might yeve hym lond / whan he good cowde
Whan they hadde deled the landes at her wille
They come to the knyght / there he lay stille
And tolde hym anoon / how they hadde wrought
And the knyght there he lay / liked it right nought
Than seide the knyght by seynt martyn
For al that ye have done / ȝit is the lond myn
For goddes loue / neighbores stondeth alle stille
And I wol dele my lond / right after my wille
Iohn myn eldest sone / shal have plowes fyve
That was my Faders heritage / while he was on lyve
And my myddellest sone / fyve plow lond
That I halp for to gete wᵗith my right hond
And al myn other purchas / of londes and ledes
That I bequethe Gamelyn / and alle my goode stedes
And I biseche you goode men / that law conne in londe
For Gamelyns love / that my quest stonde
This delte the knyght his londe by his day
Right on his deth bed / sik there he lay
And sone after / he lay ston stille
And dyed whan tyme come / as it was cristes wille
Anon as he was ded / and vnder gras grave
Sone the elder brother / giled þe yonge knave
He took into his hond his lond and his lede
And Gamelyn hym selue to clothen and to fede
He clothed hym and fedde hym / euele and eke wrothe
And leet his londes forfare and his houses bothe
His parkys and eke his wodes / and dede no thyng wel
And sitthe he it abouȝte on his owne fel
So longe was Gamelyn in his brother halle
For the strengest of good wil they douted hym alle
Ther was noon ther in / nother yong ne olde
That wolde wratthe Gamelyn / were he neủere so bolde
¶Gamelyn stood on a day / in his brother ȝerd
And bigan with hond / to handel his berd
He thoughte on his londes / that lay vnsawe
And his faire okes don were ydrawe
His parkys were broken / and his dere reued
Of alle his good stedes / noon was hym bileued
His houses were vnheled / and evel ydight
Tho thoughte Gamelyn / it wente nought a right
Afterward cam his brother walkynge there
And seide to Gamelyn / is oure mete ȝare
Tho wratthed hym Gamelyn / ⁊and swoor by goddes book
Thow shalt go bake thy self / I wil not be thy cook
Now brother Gamelyn / how answerest thou now
Thow spakest neuere suche a worde / as thow dost now
By my feith seide Gamelyn / now me thenketh nede
Of alle the harmes / that I have I toke neủere ȝit hede
My parkes ben broken / and my deer be reued
Of myn armes / and my stedes nought is me byleued
Al that my Fader me biquath al goth to shame
And therfore have thou godes curs / brother by the name
Than spak his brother / that rape was of rees
Stand stille gadelyng / and hold thy pees
Thou shalt be fayn to have / thy mete ⁊and thi wede
What spekest thou gadelyng of lond or of leede
Than seide Gamelyn / the child so ying
Cristes curs mote he have / that clepeth me gadelyng
I am no worse gadelyng ne worse wight
But born of a lady / and geten of a knyght
Ne durst he not to Gamelyn / neủere a fote go
But cleped to hym his men / and saide to hem tho
Goth and beteth this boy / and reveth hym his wit
And lat hym lerne another tyme to answere me bet
Than saide the child yonge Gamelyn
Cristes curs mote thou have / brother art thou myn
And ȝif I shal algate / be beten anoon
Cristes curs mote thou have / but thou be þᵗat oon
And anoon his brother in þᵗat grete hete
Made his men to fette staves / Gamelyn to bete
Whan eủery man hadde a staaf ynomen
Gamelyn was war / tho he seigh hem comen
Tho Gamelyn saugh hem comen / he loked oủer all
And was ware of a pestel / that stood vnder the wall
Gamelyn was light / and thider gan he lepe
¶ And drof alle his brother men / sone on an hepe
And loked as a wylde lyon / and layde on good woon
Tho his brother saugh that / he bigan to goon
He fley vp into a loft / and shette the dore fast
Thus Gamelyn with the pestel / made hem alle agast
Sōmme for Gamelyns love / and sōmme for eye
Alle they drowen hem to halues / tho he gan pleye
What now saide Gamelyn / evel mote ye thee
Wol ye bigynne contek and so sone flee
Gamelyn soughte his brother / whider he was flowe
And saugh where he loked out at a wyndowe
Brother saide Gamelyn / come a litel neer
And I wol teche the to play / atte bokeler
His brother hym answerd and seide by seint Richer
While that the pestel is in thyn hand I wol come no ner
Brother I wol make the pees / I swere by goddes ore
Caste away the pestel / and wratthe the no more
I must nedes saide Gamelyn wratthe me attones
For thou woldest make thy men to breke my bones
Ne hadde I had mayn / and myght in myn armes
To have put hem fro me / they wolde have do me harmes
Gamelyn saide his brother / be thou not wroth
Forto seen the have harme / it were me right loth
I ne dide it nought brother / but for a fondyng
For to loken ȝif thou were strong and art so ying
Come a done than to me / and gᵃunte me my bone
Of oo thyng I wol the aske / and we shul sauȝte sone
Don than come his brother / that fykel was and fel
And was swithe sore aferd of the pestel
He seide brother Gamelyn / aske me thy bone
And loke thou me blame / but I it gᵃunte sone
Than seide Gamelyn / brother ywys
Than shul we be atone thou must gᵃunte me this
Al that Fader me bequath / while he was on lyue
Thou must do me it to have / ȝif we shul not stryve
That shalt thou have Gamelyn I swere by cristes ore
Al that thy fader the biquath / though thou woldest have more
Thy londe that lyeth leye wel it shal be sowe
And thyn houses reised vp / that ben͗e þᵗat leyd ful lowe
Thus saide the knyght to Gamelyn with mouthe
And thought on falsnes / as he wel couthe
The knyght thought on treson / and Gamelyn on non
And wente and kissed his brother / and whan they were aton
Allas yonge Gamelyn / no thying he ne wiste
With suche fals treson his brother hym kiste
¶ Litheth and lestneth / and holdeth youre tonge
And ye shul here talkyng / of Gamelyn the yonge
Ther was þere beside cried a wrastlyng
And therefore / ther was set a Ram ⁊and a ryng
And Gamelyn was in wille / to wende therto
For to preven his myght / what he couthe do
Brother seide Gamelyn / by seynt Richer
Thou most lene me to nyght a litel courser
That is fressh to the spores / on forto ride
I muste on an erand / a litel here beside
By god seide his broþer of stedes in my stalle
Go and chese the / þᵉ beste spare non of hem alle
Of stedes and of coursers that stonden hem beside
And telle me goode brother / whider þᵘ wilt ryde
Here beside brother / is cried a wrastlyng
And therefore shall be set a Ram and a ryng
Moche worshipe it were / brother to vs alle
Mighte I the Ram ⁊and the ryng / bryng home into this halle
A stede ther was sadeled smartly and skeet
Gamelyn dide a peire spores / faste on his feet
He sette his foot in the styrord / the stede he bi strood
And toward the wrastlyng / the yong child rood
Tho Gamelyn the yonge / was riden out atte gate
The fals knyght his brother / lokked it after thate
And bisought IħuIhesu crist / that is heuene kyng
He myght breke his nekke / in that wrastlyng
As sone as Gamelyn come there as the place was
He light don of his stede / and stood on the gras
And there he herde a frankeleyn welawey synge
And bigan bitterly / his hondes forto wrynge
Good man seide Gamelyn / why makest thou this fare
Is ther no may that may / you helpen out of care
Allas seide this Frankeleyn / that were was I bore
For two stalworth sones / I wene that I have lore
A champion is in the place / that hath wrough me sorowe
For he hath slayn my two sones / but ȝif god hem borowe
I wol yeve ten pound by IħuIhesu Crist and more
With the nones that I fonde a man to handle hym sore
Good man seide Gamelyn / wilt thou wel don
Hold myn hors while my man / draweth of my shon
And helpe my man to kepe my clothes and my stede
And I wol into place gon / to loke ȝif I may spede
By god seide the frankeleyn / it shal be done
I wol my selfi be thy man to drawe of thy shone
And wende thou / into that place IħuIhesu Crist the spede
And drede not of thy clothes / ne of thy goode stede
Barfoot and vngurt / Gamelyn in cam
Alle that were in the place / hede of hym nam
How he dorste auntre / to done his myght
That was so douȝty a champion in wrastlyng and in fyght
Vp sterte the champion rapely anon
Toward yonge Gamelyn / he bigan to gon
And seide who is thy Fader / and who is thy sire
For soth thou art a greet fool / that thou come here
Gamelyn answerd the champion tho
Thou knewe wel my fader / while he coude go
While he was on lyne by seynt martyn
Sir Iohn of boundys / was his name / and I Gamelyn
Felawe seide the champion so mote I thryne
I knewe wel thy fader / while he was on lyue
And thy self Gamelyn I wol that thou it here
While thou were a yonge boy / a moche shrewe thou were
