And to his two bretheren / right sone he com
Sir seide sir Ote / to the Shirreue tho
We be but thre bretheren / shul we neủere be mo
And thou hast enprisoned the best of vs alle
Such a nother brother / evel mote hym falle
Sir Ote saide the false knyght / lat be thy curs
By god for thy wordes / he shal fare the wors
To the kynges prison / he is ynome
And ther he shal abide / til the Iustice come
Parde seide ʆser Ote / better it shal be
I bidde hym to maympris / that thou gᵃunte me
Til the next sittyng / of delyủerance
And lat than Gamelyn stonde to his chaunce
Brother in such a forward I take hym to the
And by thy Fader soule / that the bigat ⁊and me
But he be redy whan the Iustice sit
Thou shalt be the iugement / for al thy grete wit
I gᵃunte wel saide sir Ote / that it so be
And delyủere hym anoon / and take hym to me
Than was Gamelyn delyủered / to sir Ote his brother
And that nyght dwelled / that oon / wᵗith þᵗat other
On the morowe saide Gamelyn / to sir Ote the hende
Brother he saide I mot / for soth fro you wende
To loke how my yonge men leden her lyf
Whether they lyuen in ioye / or in stryf
By god seide sir Ote / that is a colde rede
Now I see / that al the carke shal falle on myn hede
For whan the Iustice sit / and thou be noȝt yfounde
I shal anoon be take and in thy stede ybounde
Brother saide Gamelyn / dismaye ye nought
For by seint Iame in Gales / that many man hath sought
Ȝif that god almyghty / holde me in lyf and witte
I wol be redy / whan the Iustice sitte
Than saide sir Ote to Gamelyn / god shilde the fro shame
Come whan thou seest tyme / and brynge vs out of blame
¶Litheth and lesteneth and holdeth you stille
And ye shul here how Gamelyn hadde his wille
Gamelyn wente vnder wode Rys
And founde there pleyinge yonge men of pris
Tho was yonge Gamelyn / right glad ynowgh
Whan he founde his men / vnder wode bowgh
Gamelyn and his men / talked in fere
And they hadde good game her maist̉er to here
His men tolde hym of auentures / that they hadde founde
And Gamelyn hem tolde ageyn / how he was fast ybounde
While Gamelyn was outlawe / hadde he no curs
Ther was no man that for hym ferde the wors
But Abbotes and prisonrs / monk and chanon
On hem lefte he nought / whan he myght hem nome
While Gamelyn and his men / made merthes ryue
The false knyght his brother / euel mote he thryue
For he was aboute bothe day and other
Forto hiren the quest / to hangen his brother
¶Gamelyn stood on a day / and as he biheeld
The wodes and the shawes / in the wilde feeld
He thoughte on his brother / how he hym hette
That he wolde be redy / whan the Iustice sette
He thought wel he wolde withoute delay
Come afore the Iustice / to kepen his day
And seide to his yonge men / dighteth you ȝare
For whan the Iustice sit / we muste be thare
For I am vnder borowe / til that I come
And my brother for me to prison shal be nome
By seint Iame seide his yonge men / and thou rede therto
Ordeyne how it shal be / and it shal be do
While Gamelyn was comynge ther the Iustice sat
The false knyght his brother / forȝat he nouȝt þᵗat
To hire the men on the quest / to hangen his brother
Though they hadde not þᵗat oon / they wolde have þᵗat other
Tho come Gamelyn fro vnder the wode Rys
And broughte with hym / ȝonge men of prys
I see wel saide Gamelyn / the Iustice is set
Goo a forn Adam / and loke how it spet
Adam wente into the halle / and loked al aboute
He saugh there stonde lordes grete and stoute
And sir Ote his brother fetered ful fast
Tho wente Adam out of the halle / as he were agast
And seide to Gamelyn / and to his felawes alle
Sir Ote standeth fetered in the halle
Ȝif god ȝeve vs grace / wel forto do
He shal it abegge / that brought it therto /
Than seide Adam / that lokkes hadde hore
Cristes curs mote he have / that hym bounde so sore
And thou wilt Gamelyn / done after my rede
Ther is noon in the halle / shal bere awey his hede
Adam seide Gamelyn / we wol nouȝt do so
I wol sleen the gilty / and late the other go
I wol into the halle / and with the Iustice speke
On hem that been giltyf / I wol ben a wreke
Lat non scapen at the dore / taketh yonge men ȝeme
For I wol be Iustice this day / domes to deme
God spede me this day / at my newe werk
Adam come wᵗith me / for thou shalt be my clerk
His men answered hym / and bad hym done his best
And ȝif thou to vs have nede / thou shalt fynde vs prest
We wol stonde with the / while that we may dure
And but we werken manly / paie vs noon hure
Ȝonge men saide Gamelyn / so mote I wel the
As trusty a maist̉er ye shal fynde me
Right there the Iustice / satte in the halle
In wente Gamelyn / amonges hem alle
Gamelyn leet vnfettere his brother out of bende
Than saide sir Ote / his brother that was hende
Thou haddest almost Gamelyn dwelled to longe
For the quest is oute on me / that I shulde honge
Brother seide Gamelyn / so god yeve me good rest
This day thei shull ben honged / that ben on the quest
And the Iustice bothe / þᵗat is the Iuge man
And the Shirreue bothe / thurgh hym it bigan
¶Than saide Gamelyn to the Iustice
Now is thy power done / thou nedes must rise
Thou hast yeven domes / that ben euele dyght
I wol sitten in thy sete / to dressen hem aright
The Iustice sat stille / and ros not a noon
And Gamelyn in haste brak his cheke boon
Gamelyn toke hym in his armes / and no more spak
But threwe hym ouer the barre / and his arme brak
Doorst noon to Gamelyn / say but good
For ferde of the companie / that by hym stood
Gamelyn sette hym doıı̄un in the Iustice sete
And sir Ote his brother by hym / and Adam at his fete
Whan Gamelyn was set in the Iustice stide
Herke of a bourde / that Gamelyn dide
He lett fetere the Iustice / and his false brother
And lete hym come to the barre / that oon wᵗith that other
Tho Gamelyn hadde thus ydone / hadde he no rest
Til he hadde enquered / who was on the quest
Forto demen his brother / sir Ote forto honge
Er he wiste whiche they were / hym thought ful longe
But as sone as Gamelyn wiste where they were
He dide hem eủerychone to fetere in feere
And brynge hem to the barre / and sette hem in rewe
By my feith seide the Iustice / the Shirreue is a shrewe
Than seide Gamelyn / to the Iustice
Thou hast ȝeve domes / of the worst assise
And the xii sisours / that weren on the quest
They shul be honged thys day / so have I good rest
Than saide the Shirreue to yonge Gamelyn
Lord I crie the m̉ercy / brother art thou myn
Therfore seide Gamelyn / have thou cristes curs
For and thou were maist̉er / ȝit shulde I fare wors
Forto make short tale / and nought to longe
He ordeyned hym a quest / of his men so strong
The Iustice the Shirreue / bothe honged hye
To weyuen with the ropes / and with the wynde drye
And the xii sisours sorowe have that rekke
Alle they were honged fast by the nekke
¶Thus ended the fals knyght wᵗith his treccherie
That euere hadde lad his lyf / in falsnesse and folie
He was honged by the nekke / and nouȝt by the purs
That was the mede he hadde / for his Fadres curs
Sir Otes was eldest / and Gamelyn was ȝyng
Wenten to her frendes / and passed bloto the kyng
They maden pees with the kyng / of the beste sise
The kyng loued wel sir Ote / and made hym Iustice
And after the kyng made Gamelyn in est and west
Cheef Iustice of his free forest
div.fw: ¶ The prologe ¶Of the man of lawe
div.l: Alle his wighte yonge men / the kyng forȝaf hir gilt
And sitthen in goode office / the kyng hath hem pilt
¶Thus wan Gamelyn his londe / and his lede
And wrak hem on his enemys / and quyte hem her mede
And ʆser Ote his brother / made hym his heire
And sitthen wedded Gamelyn a wyf ful fayre
They lyueden to gidere / while that crist wolde
And sitthen was Gamelyn grauen vnder molde
And so was his wyf / and shul we
God bringe vs to the ioye / that ever shal be
¶Here endeth the Cookes tale / ¶And after foloweth the prologe of the man of lawe /
Owre hoost saugh wel / that the brighte sonne
The ark of his artificial day hadde yronne
The ferthe part and half an houre and more
And though he were nought depe exꝑpert in lore
He wiste it was the eytenthe day
Of Aprill / that is messager to May
And saugh wel / that the shadwe of eủery tre
Was as in lengthe / the same quantite
That was the body erect that caused it
And therfore by the shadwe he took his wit
That Phebus / whiche that shon so cleer and bright
Degrees was xlv clombe on hight
And for that day as in that latitude
It was x of the clokke he gan conclude
And sodeinly he plighte his hors aboute
Lordinges quod he / I warne you all this route
The farthe parte of this day is goon
Now for the loue of god / and of seint Iohn
Lesith no tyme / as ferforth as ye may
Lordynges the tyme it wasteth nyght and day
And steleth fro vs what priuely splepynge
And thurgh necligence / in oure wakynge
As doth the streme / that turneth never ageyn
Descendyng fro the mountayne into the pleyn
Wel can Senec and many a philosopher
Bywaylen tyme / more than gold in cofer
div.fw: ¶The ꝓprologe¶ of the man of lawe
div.l: For los of catel / may recoủered be
But los of tyme / shendeth vs quod he
It wol nouȝt come ageyn withoute drede
Namore than wol / Malkyns maydenhede
Whan she hath lost it in hir wantownesse
Lat vs nouȝt mowlen thus in ydelnesse
Sir man of lawe / quod he / so haue ȝe blisse
Telle vs a tale anoon / as forward is /
Ȝe be submitted / thurgh youre fre assent
To stonden in this caas / at my iugement
Aquiteth you now / of youre biheste
Than haue ye done / youre dever atte leste
¶Hoost quod he dꝑpardeux I assente
To breke forward is not myn entente
Biheste is dette / and I wol holde fayn
Al my biheste / I can no better sayn
For swiche lawe as a man / ȝeveth another wight
He shulde hym self vsen it by right
Thus wol oure text / but nathalees ⁊andser;tayn
I can right now no thrifty tale sayn
That Chaucer though he can but lewedly
On metres / or in rymyng craftily
Hath saide hem in swich englisshe as he can
Of olde tyme as knoweth many a man
And ȝif he have nought saide hem leue brother
In oo book he hath saide hem in a nother
For he hath tolde of louers vp andoıı̄un
Moo than Ouyde made of mencion
In his episteles / that ben ful olde
What shulde I tellen hem sen they be tolde
In youthe he made of Ceys and Alcione
And sithe hath he spoken of eủerychone
Thise noble wyfes / and thise louers eke
Who so þᵗat wole his large volume seke
Cleped the seintes legende of Cupide
There may he seen / the large woundes wyde
Of lucresse and Babilan Tesbe
The swerd of Dido for the fals Ene ¶ꝓpro¶
The tree of Phillis / for hir Demophon
The pleynt of Dyanyre / and of Ermyoıı̄un
Of Adryane / and of ysiphile
The bareyne yle / stondyng in the See
The dreynt leander for his Erro
The teres of Eleyne / and eke þᵉ woo
Of Brixseide / and of the ladomia
The cruelte of the queen Medea
The litel children hangynge by the hals
For thy Iason / that was of loue so fals
O yꝑpermistra penolope alceste
Ȝoure wyfhode he cōmmendeth wᵗith þᵉ beste
But certeinly no word ne writeth he
Of thilke wikked ensample of Canace
That loued hir owne brother synfully
Of swich cursed stories I sey fy
Or ellis of Tyro Appolloneus
How that the cursed kyng Antiochus
Birafte his doughter / of hir maydenhede
That is so horrible a tale forto rede
Whan he hir threw vpon the pauement
And therfore he of ful auisement
Wolde never write / in none of his sermons
Of swiche vnkynde abhominacions
Ne I ne wol non rehersen ȝif I may
But of my tale / how shal I done this day
Me were loith be likned douteles
To muses that ben cleped pierides
Methamorphoseos / woot what I mene
But nathales I recche nouȝt a bene
Though I come after hym / with hawe bake
I speke in prose / and late hym Rymes make
And with that word / he with a sobre chere
Bigan his tale / as ye shal after here /

¶Thus endeth the prologue
¶And bigynneth the tale/
¶ And bigynneth þe tale/
O hatefull harm condicioıı̄un of pouert
With thirst with colde wᵗith hunger so confounded
To asken helpe/ the shameth in thin herte
Ȝif thou noon aske wᵗith nede art thou so wounded
That verray nede vnwrappeth al thi wounde hid
Maugre thyn hed/ thou muste for indigence
Or stele or begge/ or borwe thy dispense
¶ Thou blamest crist and seist ful bitterly
He mys departeth richesse temporal
Thy neighbore/ thou wytest synfully
And thou hast to litel/ and he hath al
Parfey seistow somtyme he rekne shal
Whan that his tail shal brenne in the glede
For he nouȝt helpeth/ nedeful in her nede
¶ Herkne what is the sentence of the wyse
Better is dyen/ than have indigence
Thy selue neighbore wol the dispice
Ȝif thou be poủere/ fare wel thy reủerence
Ȝit of the wise man/ take this sentence
Alle the dayes of poủere men ben wikke
Be war therfore/ or thou come to the prikke
¶ Ȝif thou be poủere/ thy brother hateth the
And alle thy frendes fleen fro the allas
O riche marchant ful of wele be ye
O noble prudent folke as in this caas
Youre bagges be nouȝt filled wᵗith ambes aas
But wᵗith sys cynk/ that renneth for youre chaunce
At criste masse/ merye may ye daunce
¶ Ȝe seken londe and see/ for youre wynnynges
As wise folke ȝe knowen al the state
Of remes ȝe ben faderes of tidynges
And tales bothe/ of pees ⁊and of debate
I were right now of tales desolate
Nere that a marchant gon is many a ȝere
Me taughte a tale/ which as ye shal here
¶ In Surrie whilom dwelled a companye
Of chapmen riche/ and therto sadde and trewe
That wyde where sente her spicerie
Clothes of gold and satyne riche of hewe
Her chaffare was so thrifty and so newe
That euery wight hath deynte to chaffare
With hem/ and eke to sellen hem her ware
¶ Now fil it that the maistres of that sort
Han shapen hem to Rome for to wende
Where it for chapmanhode or for disport
Noon other message wolde they thider sende
But comen hem self to Rome/ this is the ende
And in swich place/ as thoughte hem auᵃntage
For her entent they take her herbergage
¶ Soiourned hau thise marchantȝ in that tōn
A c̉erteyne tyme/ as fel to her plesaunce
But so bifel/ that the excellent renōn
Of the Emꝑperoures Doughter dame Custaunce
Reported was with euery circumstance
Vnto thise Surrein Marchauntȝ in such wise
Fro day to day as I shal you deuise
¶ This was the comon voys of euery man
Oure Emꝑperour of Rome/ god hym see
A doughter hath/ that syn the worlde bigan
To rekne as wel hir goodnesse as beautee
Was never swich a nother/ as is she
I pᵃray to god in honoᵘur hir sustene
And wolde she were of al Europe the quene
¶ In hir is high beaute/ withoute pride
Ȝowthe withoute grenehede or folye
To alle hir werkes/ vertue is hir gide
Humblesse hath slayen al tyrannye
She is a mirrour/ of al curtesye
Hir herte is verray chambre of holynesse
Hir hande ministre of fredom for almesse
¶ And al this vois was soth/ as god is trewe
But now to purpos/ lat vs turne ageyn
These marchantȝ hau done fright her shippes newe
And whan they have this blisfull mayden seyn
Home to Surrie ben they went ayeyn
And done her nedes/ as they have done ȝore
And lyen in wele / as I can say yow no more/
Now fil it that thise marchantȝ stoden in gᵃrace
Of hym that was the Sowdon of Surrie
For whan they came/ fram eny strange place
He wolde of his benigne curtesie
Make hem good chere/ and besily aspie
Tithinges of sondry Reammes forto here
The wondres/ that they myghte seen or here
¶ Amonges other thynges specialy
Thise marchantȝ/ hau hym tolde of dame Custance
So grete noblesse in ernest ceriousely
That this Sowdan hath caught so grete plesance
To hau hir figure/ in his remembrance
And al his lust/ and al his besy cure
Was for to love hir/ whyle his lyf may dure
¶ Par aventure in thilke large book
Which that cleped is the heuene y writen was
With sterres/ whan that he his birthe took
That he for love sholde hau his deth allas
For in the sterres clerer/ than ys glas
Is writen god wote/ who so couthe it rede
The deth of eủery man withoute drede
¶ In sterres many a wynter ther biforn
Was writen the deth of Ector Achilles
Of pompe Iulius/ or they were born
The stryf of Thebes and of Hercules
Of Sampson Turnus and of Socrates
The deth / but mennes wittes ben so dulle
That no wight can wel rede it to the fulle
¶ This Soudon for his pⁱrive counseill sente
And shortly of this mat̉er for to pace
He hath to hem declared his entente
And seide hem certeyn/ but ȝif he myghte have gᵃrace
To have Custaunce withynne a lytell space
He nas but ded and charged hem in hie
To shapen for his lyf som remedie
¶ Diủerse men diủerse thinges seiden
And argumentes casten vp and don
Many a sotil reson/ forth they leyden/
They speken of magik/ and abusion
But finally as in conclusion
They can not seen in that non auᵃntage
Ne in noon other thyng/ sauf mariage
¶ Than saugh they therynne swich difficulte
By way of reson/ forto speke al playn
By cause that ther was swiche diủersite
Bitwene her bothe lawes that they sayn
They trowe / that no cristen prince wolde fayn
Wedden his childe/ vnder oure lawes swete
That vs was tauȝt by Mahon/ oure ꝓprophete
¶ And he answerde/ rather than I lese
Custaunce / I wol be cristened douteles
I mot ben hers / I may non other chese
I pᵃray you holdeth youre argumentes in pees
Saveth my lyf / and beth not rechelees
To geten hir/ that hath my lyf in cure
For in this wo/ I may not longe endure
¶ What nedeth gretter dilatacion
I say by tretys and ambassadrie
And by the popes mediacion
And al the chirche/ and the chyualrie
That in destruccion of mawmetrie
And in encres/ of cristes lawe dere
They ben accorded/ right as ye may here/
¶ How that the Sowdan/ and his Baronage
And alle his lieges sholde ycristened be
And he shall have Custance in mariage
And c̉erteyne golde/ I not what qᵃauntite
And her to founde sufficient surete
This same accord was sworn on eủery side
Now faire Custance/ almyghty god the gyde
¶ Now wolde some men/ wayten as I gesse
That I sholde tellen al the purveance
That the Emꝑperour of his noblesse
Hath shapen for his doughter dame Custaunce
Wel may men knowen/ that so grete ordynuance
May no man tellen/ in a litel clause
As was arayed/ for so high a cause
¶ Bisshoppes ben shapen/ with hir for to wende
Lordes ladyes/ knyghtes of renōn
And other folk ynawe / this is the ende
And notified is thurgh out the tōn
That euery wight with grete devociōn
Sholde praye crist/ that he this mariage
Receyue in gree / and spede this viage
¶ The day is comen of hir departynge
I say the woful day fatal is come
That ther may be no lenger taryinge
But forward/ they hem dresse alle and some
Custance/ that with sorowe is al oủercome
Ful pale arist and dresseth hir to wende
For wel she seeth/ ther is noon other ende
Allas what wonder is it though she wepte
That shal be sent to straunge naciōn
Fro frendes/ that so tenderly hir kepte
And to be bounden vnder subiection
Of oon she knoweth nought his condicion
Husbondes ben alle goode / and hau ben ȝore
That knoweth wyfes/ I dar say you no more
¶ Fader she saide/ thy wrecched childe Custance
Thy yonge doughter fostred vp so softe
And ye my moder/ my soủerayne plesance
Over all thyng/ outake crist on lofte
Custance youre childe/ hir recōmmandeth ofte
Vnto youre gᵃrace for I shall to Surrie
Ne shal I nevere seen you more with eye/
¶ Allas vnto the barbre naciōn
I muste anoon sitthe it is youre wille
But crist that starf for oure redempciōn
So yeve me gᵃrace/ his hestes to fulfille
I wrecche woman no fors though I spille
Wommen arn born to thraldome and penance
And to ben vnder mannes goủernance/
¶ I trowe at Troye/ whan Pirrus brak the wal
Or ylion that brende nor Thebes the Citee
Nor Rome thurgh the harme of hanybal
That Romaynes hath venquished tymes three
Nas herde such tendre wepyng for pitee
As in the Chambre was for hir departynge
But forth she mot wheither she wepe or synge
¶ O first mornyng/ cruel firmament
With thy diurnal sweigh that croudest ay
And hurlist al fro est to occident
That naturely wolde holde another way
Thy croudyng sett the heuene in swich array
At the begynnyng/ of this feers viage
That cruel mars hath slayn this mariage
¶ Infortunat ascendent tortuous
Of whiche the lorde is helpeles falle allas
Out of his angle into the derkest hous
O Mars/ o atazir/ as in this caas
O feble mone vnhappy ben thy paas
Thou knettist the there/ thou art nought receyued
There thou were wel fro thennes artow weyued
¶ Imprudent Emꝑperour of Rome allas
Was ther no philosophre in al thy ton
Is no tyme bet than other in such caas
Of viage is ther noon election
Namely to folk of high condicion
Nat whan a roote is of a birthe yknowe
Allas we ben to lewed or to slowe
¶ To ship is brought/ this woful faire mayde
Solempnely with eủery circumstance
Now iħuihesu crist be with you alle she saide
Ther nys no more/ but farewell faire Custance
She peyneth hir to make goode countenance
And forth I lete hir sayle/ in this manere
And torne I wol ageyn to my matere
¶ The moder of the Sowdon welle of vices
Aspied hath hir sones playn entente
How he wolde lete his olde sacrifices
And right anoon she for hir counsell sente
And they ben come to knowe what she mente
And whan assembled was/ this folk in fere
She sett hir don/ and saide as ye shal here
¶ Lordes qduod she/ ye knowen euerichon
How that my sone/ in point is for to lete
The holy lawes of oure Alkaron
That vs was yeven by Mahon oure ꝓprophete
But oon avow to grete god I hete
The lyf shal rather out of my body sterte
Or Machametes lawe out of myn herte
¶ What shulde vs tiden of this newe lawe
But thraldome to oure bodies and penance
And afterward in helle to be drawe
For we reneyed Mahon oure creance
But lordes wol ye make me assuraunce
As I shal saie/ assentynge to my lore
And I shal make vs sauf for euermore/
¶ They sworen and assenten euery man
To lyue wᵗith hir and dye/ and by hir stonde
And eủerych in the best wise he can
To strengthen hir shal alle his frendes fonde
And she hath this emprise take on honde
Whiche ye shal here/ that I shal deuise
And to hem alle/ she spak in this wise
¶ We shul first feyne vs cristendome to take
Colde water shal not greve vs but a lyte
And I shal suche a feste and revel make
That as I trowe I shal the Sowdon quite
And though his wyf be cristened neuer so white
She shal have nede to wasshe awey the rede
Though she a font ful of water with hir lede
¶ O Sowdonesse Rote of iniquite
Virago thou Semyram the seconde
O serpent vnder femininite
Lyke to the Serpent depe in helle ybonde
O feyned woman al that may confonde
Vertue and Innocence/ thurgh thy malice
Is bred in the as nest of euery vice
¶ O Sathan enuyous syn thilke day
That thou were chaced fro oure heritage
Wel knowest thou to wymen the olde way
Thou madest Eua to bringe vs in suage
Thou wilt fordone this cristene mariage
Thyn instrument so weleawey the while
Makestow of women whan thou wilt begile
¶ This Sowdonesse whom I thus blame and warie
Leet priuely hir counsell goon her way
What shulde I lenger in this tale tarie
She rideth to the Sowdon on a day
And seide hym that she wolde reneye hir lay
And cristendome of prestes hondes fonge
Repentynge hir/ she hethen was so longe
¶ Bysechinge hym to done hir that honour
That she muste hau the cristen folk to feste
To plesen hem/ I wol do my labour
The Sowdon saide/ I wol done at youre heste
And knelynge thanketh hir/ of that requeste
So glad he was/ he nyste what to seye
She kiste hir Sone/ and home she goth hir weye
¶ Arryued ben these cristen folk to londe
In Surrie/ with a greet solempne route
And hastely/ the Sowdon sende his sonde
First to his Moder/ and al the Regne aboute
And seide his wyf was comen out of doute
And prayde hir/ for to ride ageyn the queene
The honoᵘur of his Regne to sustene
¶ Greet was the prees/ and riche was the array
Of Surriens and Romaynes met yfere
The Moder of the Sowdon/ riche and gay
Receyueth hir with also glad a chere
As eny Moder myghte hir doughter dere
And to the nexte Cite ther biside
A softe paas solempnely they ride/
¶ Nought trowe I the triumphe of Iulius
Of whiche that Lucan maketh such a bost
Was ryaller ne more curious/
Than was the assemble/ of this blisfull hoost
But this scorpion/ this wikked goost
The Sowdonesse/ for al hir flaterynge
Caste vnder this/ ful mortally to stynge
¶ The Sowdon cometh hym self sone after this
So rially/ that wonder is to telle
He welcometh hir/ with al ioye and blis
And thus in merthe and ioye I lete hem dwelle
The fruyt of this mat̉er/ that I telle
Whan tyme come/ men thought it for the beste
That Revel stynte/ and men gon to her reste
¶ The tyme come/ this olde Sowdonesse
Ordeyneth hath/ the feste of whiche I tolde
And to the feste/ cristen folk hem dresse
In gen̉eral bothe yonge and olde
Here man men feste and rialte biholde
And deyntes/ mo that I can you deuise
But al to dere thei bought it or thei rise
¶ O sodeyn wo that euere art successour
To worldely blisse/ spreynd is with bitternesse
The ende of the ioye/ of oure worldly labour
Wo occupieth the fyn of oure gladnesse
Herke this counsell for thy sikernesse
Vpon thy glad day/ have in thy mynde
The vnwar wo/ or harme/ that cometh bihynde
¶ For shortly for to tellen/ at o word
The Sowdon and the cristen euerychone
Ben alle to hewen/ and stiked atte bord
But it were only dame Custance allone
This olde Sowdonesse/ this cursed crone
Hath with her frendes done this cursed dede
For she hir self wolde al the cuntre lede
¶ Ne ther nas Surreyn noon/ that was con̉erted
That of the counsell of the Sowdon woot
That he nas al to hewen/ or he asterted
And Custaunce hau they taken anon foot hoot
And in a ship al stereles god woot
They hau hir set/ and bidden hir lerne sayle
Out of Surrie/ ageynward to ytayle
¶ A certeyne tresour/ that she thider ladde
And soth to sayn/ vitaille grete plente
They hau hir ȝeuen/ and clothes eke she hadde
And forth she sayleth in the salte see
O my Custance ful of benignite
O Emꝑperours yonge doughter dere
He that is lorde/ over fortune be thy stere
¶ She blessith hir / and wᵗith ful pitous voys
Vnto the crois of crist/ thus saide she
O clere o welful auter holy croys
Rede of the lambes blood ful of pite
That wosshe the worlde fro the olde iniquite
Me fro the fende/ and fro his clawes kepe
That day I shal drenchen in the depe.
¶ Victorious tre ꝓprotection of trewe
That only worthy were for to bere
The kyng of heuene/ wᵗith his woundes newe
The white lamb/ that hurt was wᵗith a spere
Flemer of feendes/ out of him and here
On whiche thy lyves feithfully extenden
Me kepe/ and yeve me myght/ my lyf tamenden
¶ Yeres and daies fleet this creature
Thurgh out the see of Grece vnto the strayte
Of Marrok / as it was hir auenture
On many a sory meel/ now may she bayte
After hir deth/ ful ofte may she wayte
Or that the wilde wawes wol hir dryve
Vnto the place/ ther she shal aryve
¶ Men myghten axen why she was not slayn
Eke atte feste/ who myght hir body save
I answere to that demaunde agayn
Who saved daniel/ in the orrible caue
Where euery wyght/ saf he maist̉er or knave
Was wᵗith the leons fret/ or he \a/sterte
No wight but god/ that he bar in his herte
¶ God list to shewe his wonderful mlracle
In hir/ for she sholde / sen his mighty werkes
Crist which that is to eủery harme triacle
By certeyn menes of as knowe clerkes
Doth thyng for certeyne ende/ that ful derk is/
To mannes wit/ that for oure ignorance
Ne konne not knowe his prudent pᵘruveance
¶ Now sitthe she was not atte feste ylawe
Who kepte hir fro drenchyng in the see
Who kepte Ionas/ in the fisshe mawe
Til he was spowted vp at Nynyue
Wel may men knowe/ it was no wight but he
That kepte the peple Ebrayk from her drenchynge
With drie feet thurghout the see passynge
¶ Who bad the foure spirites of tempest
That power han to annoyen bothe londe and see
Bothe North and south/ and also west and est
Anoyeth neyther see ne land ne tree
Sothely the cōmaunder of that was he
That fro the tempest ay this woman kepte
As wel whan she wook as whan she slepte
¶ Where myght this woman mete and drynke have
Thre yere and more/ how lasteth hir vitayle
Who fedde the Egipcien Marie in the caue
Or in desert / no wight/ but crist sauȝ fayle
Fif thousand folk / it was as greet meruayle
With loves to fyve/and fisshes \two/ to fede
God sent his foyson/ at her grete nede/
¶ She dryveth forth into oure occean
Thurgh out oure wilde see til atte laste
Vnder an holde/ that nempnen I ne can
Fer in Norhumbirland the wawe hir caste
And in the sonde/ hir ship stiked so faste
That thennes wolde it nouȝt of al a tyde
The wil of crist was that she sholde abyde
¶ The Constable of the Castell don is fare
To seen this wrak/ and al the ship he soughte
And fonde this wery woman/ ful of care
He fonde also the tresour/ that she broughte
In hir langage mercy she bisought.
The lyf out of hir body for to twynne
Hir to delyuer of wo/ that she was Inne
¶ A maner latyn corrupt was hir speche
But algates ther by was she vnderstonde
The Constable whan hym list no lenger seche
This woful woman/ broughte he to the londe
She kneled don and thanked goddes sonde
But what she was/ she wolde no man seye
For foul ne faire/ though/ that she sholde deye
¶ She saide she was so mased in the see
That she forgat hir mynde by hir trouthe
The Constable of hir hath so greet pite
And eke his wyf/ that they wepte for routhe
She was so diligent/ withoute slouthe
To sue and plese/ eủery in the place
That alle hir loven/ that loken in hir face
¶ The Constable and dame Emengilte his wyf
Were payens/ and that Cuntre eủerywhere
But Ermyngeld loued hir right as hir lyf
And Custance hath so longe soioᵘurned there
In orisons/ with many a bitter tere
Til ihu hath conủerted thurgh his gᵃrace
Dame Ermyngild Constablesse of that place
¶ In al that londe/ dorst no cristen route
Alle cristen folk ben fled/ fro that cuntre
Thurgh payens/ that conquered ther aboute
The plages of the north/ by land and see
To Wales fledde the cristiante
Of olde Britons/ dwellynge in this Ile
Ther was her refute/ for the mene while/
¶ But yit ne were cristen Britons so exiled
That ther nere some in her pruite
Honᵘured crist/ and hethen folk begiled
And nygh the castell/ suche ther dwelled þre
That on of hem/ was blynd/ and myght not se
But it were wᵗith thilke eyen of his mynde
With whiche men seen/ after that they be blynde
¶ Bright was the sonne/ as in the somers day
For whiche/ the Constable/ and his wif also
And Custance hau ytake the right way
Toward the see/ a forlong way or two
To pleien/ and to romen to and fro
And in her walk/ this blynde man they mette
Croked and olde/ with eyen faste yshette
¶ In the name of crist/ cried this blynd Briton
Dame Ermyngild/ yeve me my sighte ageyn
This lady wax affrayed/ of the son
Lest that hir husbonde/ shortly forto sayn
Wolde hir for ihu cristes love/ hau slayn
Til Custance made hir bold/ and bad hir wirche
The wille of crist/ as doughter of his chirche
¶ The Constable was abassed/ of that sight
And seide what amounteth al this fare
Custance answerd sire it is cristes myght
That helpeth folk/ out of the feendes snare
And so ferforth/ she gan oure lady declare
That she the Constable/ or that it was eve
Coủerted/ and on crist made hym byleve/
¶ This Constable was no thyng lorde of this place
Of whiche I speke / there he Custance fonde
But kepte it strongly/ many a wynter space
Vnder Alla kyng of al Northumbirland
That was ful wys/ and worthy of hand
A geyn the Scottes/ as men may wel here
But torne I wol ageyn/ to my matere
¶ Sathan that vs eủere wayteth to begile
Saugh of Custance/ al hir ꝑprofeccion
And caste anon/ how he myghte quite hir while
And made a yonge knyght/ that dwelled in the ton
Love hir so hote/ of foul affeccion
That v̉errayly hym thoughte he sholde spille
But he of hir/ myght ones have his wille/
¶ He woweth hir/ but it avayleth nought
She wolde do no synne/ by no weye
And for despite/ he compassed in his thought
To make hir on shameful deth to deye/
He wayteth whan þe Constable was aweye
And priuely on a nyght he crepte
In Ermyngildes chambre / while she slepte
¶ Wery forwaked in hir orisons
Slepith Custance and Ermygild also.
Thus knyghte thurgh Sathanas temptacions
Al softely is to the bed y go
And cutte the throte of Ermyngild a two
And leyde the blody knyf by dame Custance
And went his way/ ther god yeve hym meschance
¶ Sone after cometh/ this Constable home agayn
And eke Alla/ that kyng was of that lond
And saugh his wif dispitouseliche y slayn
For whiche ful ofte he wepte/ and wrong his hond
And in the bed the blody knyf he fond
By dame Custance/ allas/ what myght she seye
For verray wo/ hir wit was al a weye
¶ To kyng Alla was tolde al this meschance
And eke the tyme/ and where/ and in what wise
That in a ship/ was founden this Custance
As here biforn/ ye han herd deuise
The kynges herte of pite gan agrise
Whan he saugh so benigne a creature
Falle in disese/ and in misauenture
¶ For as the lamb toward the deth is brought
So stant this innocent bifore the kyng
This fals knyght/ that had this treson wrought
Bereth hir in hande/ that she hath done this thyng
But natheles ther was greet mornyng
Amonge the peple/ and say/ they can nouȝt gesse
That she hadde done/ so greet a wikkednesse
¶ For they hau seen hir euere so vertuous
And lovyng Ermyngild right as hir lyf
Of thus bar witnesse/ euerich in that hous
Saaf he that Ermyngild slough wᵗith a knyf
This gentil kyng/ hath kaught a greet motyf
Of this witnesse/ and thoughte he wolde enquere
Depper in this caas/ a trouthe to lere
¶ Allas Custance/ thou ne hast no champion
And fyghte canst thou noȝt so wele away
But he that for oure redempcion
And bond Sathan/ that lieth yet there he lay
So be thy stronge champion this day
For but ȝif crist/ vpon the myracle kythe
Withoute gilt/ thou shalt be slayn as swythe/
¶ She sette hir done/ on knees/ and thus she saide
Immortal god/ that sauest Susanne
Fro fals blame/ and thou m̉ercyful mayde
Marie I mene/ doughter to seynt Anne
Bifore whos childe/ angeles synge Osanne
Ȝif I be gilteles of this felonie
My socour be/ or elles shall I dye
¶ Haue ye nought seen somtyme a pale face
A monge the prees / of hym thath hath be lad
Toward his deth/ where as hym get no gᵃrace
And suche a colour/ in his face hath had
Men myghten knowe his face/ that was bistad
Amonges alle þe faces/ in that route
So stant Contance/ and loked hir aboute
¶ O quenes lyuynge in prosꝑperite
Duchesses/ and ye ladies eủerchone
Have some routhe on hir adủersite
An Emꝑperoures doughter stant allone
She hath no wight/ to whom to make hir mone
O blood roial/ that stondest in this drede
Fer ben thy Frendes/ in thy grete nede
¶ This Alla kyng hath such compassion
As gentil herte is/ fulfilled of pite
That from his eyen/ ran þe wat̉er don>
Now hastely do fecche a book qduod he
And ȝif this knyght wel swere that she
This woman slough / ȝit wil we vs auyse
Whom that we wole / that shal be oure Iustice
¶ A Briton book writen with euᵃngelies
Was fet/ and on this book/ he swore a non
She gilty was / and in the mene whiles
An hand hym smote/ vpon the nekke bon
That don he fel attones/ as a ston
And bothe his eyen brost out of his face
In sight of eủery body/ in that place
¶ A vois was herde/ in gen̉eral audience
And saide thou hast disclaundred gilteles
The Doughter of holy churche in high p̉resence
Thus hastow done and ȝit I holde my pees
Of this mervayle/ agast was al the prees
As mazed folk / they stoden eủerichone
For drede of wreche/ sauf Custance allone
¶ Grete was the drede/ and eke the repentance
Of hem that hadden wrong suspeccion>
Vpon this sely Innocent Custaunce
And for this myracle in conclusion
And by Custances mediacion
The kyng and many another in that place
Conuerted were/ thanked be goddes gᵃrace/
¶ This fals knyght was slayn for his vntrouthe
By iugement of Alla hastily
And ȝit Custance/ hath of his deth grete routhe
And after this/ Ihus of his m̉ercy
Made Alla wedden ful solempnely
This holy Maiden / that is so bright and shene
And thus hath crist made Custance a queene
¶ But who was woful/ ȝif I shal not lye
Of this weddyng/ but Donegild and no mo
The kynges moder/ ful of tyrannye
Hir thoughte hir cursed herte brast a two
She wolde nought hir sone/ hadde don so
Hir thoughte a dispite/ that he sholde take
So strange a creature/ vnto his make
¶ Me list nouȝt of the chaaf/ ne of þe stree
Make so longe a tale/ as of the corn
What shulde I telle/ of the Rialte
Of mariage / or which cours goth biforn
Who bloweth in a trompe or in an horn
The fruyt of eủery tale/ is for to seye.
They eeten/ and drynkyn/ and synge and pleye
¶ They goon to bedde/ as it was skile and right
For though that wyfes/ ben ful holy thynges
They muste taken/ in pacience a nyght
Suche man̉ere necessaries/ as ben plesynges
To folc/ that hau ywedded hem wᵗith rynges/
And leye a lytel hir holynesse a syde
As for the tyme it may non other betide
¶ On hir he bigat a knaue child a non
And to a Bisshop/ and his Constable eke
He toke his wyf to kepen/ whan he is gon
To Scotland ward his fomen for to seke
Now faire Custance þᵗat is so humble and meke
So longe is gon wᵗith childe/ til that stille
She halt hir chambre abydynge goddes wille
¶ The tyme is come a knave child she bere
Mauricius at the fontston they hym calle
This Constable doth forth come a messagere
And wroot to his kyng/ that cleped was Alle
How that this blisful tidyng is bifalle
And other tidynges/ spedfull forto seye
He taketh the lre/ and forth he goth his weye
¶ This Messager/ to done his auᵃntage
Vnto the kynges Moder/ rideth swithe
And salueth hir ful faire/ in his langage
Madame qduod he/ ye may be glad and blithe
And thonketh god/ An hundred thousand sithe
My lady Queen hath childe wᵗithoute doute
To ioye and blis/ of alle this regne aboute
¶ Lo here þe lres enseled/ of this thing
That I moot bere/ wᵗith al the hast I may
Yif ye wol ought vnto youre sone the kyng
I am youre ʆserruᵃnt bothe/ nyght and day
Donegild answerd as now at this tyme nay
But here al nyght/ I wol thou take thy rest
To morowe wol I say what me lest
¶ This messagere drank sadly ale and wyn
This is a verray soth/ withoute glose
It faileth nouȝt/ while it is in youre holde
And whan this knyght hath thus his tale ytolde
He rydeth out of halle/ and don he lyght
His Stede/ which that shon/ as sonne bright
Stant in the Court/ stille as eny stoon
This knyght to his Chamber is lad anoon
And is vnarmed/ and to the mete y sett
The ꝑpersentes ben ful richely yfett
This is to saien/ the swerd and the miroᵘur
And born a non vnto the hie tour
With certayne offic̉ers yordeyned ther fore
And vnto Canace the ryng is bore
Solempnely there she sit at the table
But sikirly withouten eny fable
The hors of bras/ that may not be remewed
It stant as it were to the grounde yghiwed
Ther may no man/ out of the place it dryue
For noon engyn of wyndas or polyue
And cause why/ for they can not the craft
And therfore in the place/ they han it laft.
Til that the knyght hath tauȝt hem the manere
To voiden him/ as ye shal after here
Gret was the prees/ that swarmed to and fro
To gawren on this hors/ that stondeth so
For it so heigh was and so brode and loneg
So wel ꝓproporcioned forto be stronge
Right as it were a Stede of lombardie
Therwith so horsly/ and so quyk of eye
As it a gentil Polanes courser were
For certes fro his tayl vnto his ere
Nature ne art couthe hym nouȝt amende
In noo degre/ as al the peple wende
But euer more/ her moost wonder was
How that it couthe gon/ and was of bras
It was a Fayrye as the peple semed
Dyủerse folk diủersely han demed
As many hedes as many wittes ther ben
They mᵘurmored as doth a swarm of been
And maden skilles/ after her fantasies
Rehersynge of the olde Poetries
¶ And seiden it was lyk the Pegase
The hors that hadde wynges for to flee
Or ellis it was the grekes hors Synon
That broughte Troye to destruccion
As men in thise olde gestes rede
Myn herte qduod oon is eủere more in drede
I trowe some men/ of armes ben therynne
That shapen hem/ this Cite for to wynne
It were right good/ that al such thyng were knowe
Another rowned/ to his felowe lowe
And seide he lyeth/ for it is rather lyk
An apparence made/ by som magyk
As Iogeloures pleye at thyse festes grete
Of sondry thoughtes/ thus they iangle and trete
As lewed peple demeth comonly
Of thynges that bien made more subtilly
Than they can in her lewednesse comp̉rehende
They demen gladly to the badder ende
And sōmme of hem wondren on the Mirour
That born was vn the maister tour
How men myghte/ in it swiche thynges see
A nother answerde and seide it myghte wel be
Naturely by composicions
Of angeles and of slygh reflexions
And seide that in Rome was suche oon
They speke of Alocen and Vitilion
And of Aristotil/ that writen in hir lyues
Of queynte Mirours/ and of ꝑperspectues
As knowen they/ that han her bokes herd
¶ And other folk han wondred on the swerd
That wolde perce thurgh eủery thyng
And fele in speche of Thelophus the kyng
And of Achilles/ for his queynte spere
For he couthe with hit bothe hele and dere
Right in swich wyse/ as men may wᵗith the swerd
Of whiche / right now ye have youre selue herd
They speken of sondry hardyng of metal
And speken of medicines therwith al
And how and whan / it sholde harded be
Whiche is vnknowen / algate vnto me
¶ Tho speken they of Canaces ryng
And seiden alle / that swich a wondir thyng
Of craft of rynges / herde they neủere noon
Saf that he Moyses / and kyng Salomon̄
Hadde a name of konnynge in swich art
Thus seide the peple and drawen hem apart
But nathalees som seide that it was
Wonder to make of ferne asshen / glas
And ȝit is glas not lyk asshen of fern
But for they han knowen it so fern
Therfore ceseth her iangelyng and her wonder
As sore wondren some / of cause of thonder
On ebbe and flood / on gossomer and on mist
And of all thyng / til the cause is wist
Thus iangle they / and demen and deuise
Til that the kyng gan fro his bord arise
Phebus hath left the angle meridional
And ȝit ascendynge was the beste Roial
The gentil leoıı̄un with his aldrian
Whan that this Tartre kyng kambyuskan
Roos from his bord / there he sat ful hye
Biforn hym goth / the lowde mynstralcye
Til he come to his chambre of parementz
There as they sownen diủerse instrumentz
That lyk an heuene / it was forto here
Now dauncen lusty venus children dere
For in the fisshes her lady sat ful hye
And loked on hem with a frendly eye /
This noble kyng is set vp in his throne
This strange knyght is fet to hym ful sone
And vp on the daunce he goth wᵗith Canace
Here is the Reuel and the iolyte
That is not able a dulman to deuise
He muste have knowe / loue and his ʆseruice
And ben a festelich man / as fressh as may
That sholde you deuisen / swich array
Who couthe tellen you the forme of daunces
So vncouthe / and swich fressh countenances
Swiche subtile lokynges / and dissimilynges
For drede of ialouse mennes aꝑperceyuynges
No man but laıı̄uncelot / and he is ded
Therfore I passe over / al this lustyhed
I say no more / but in this iolynesse
I lete hem / til men to soper hem dresse
¶ The Stiward biddeth spices forto hye
And eke the wyn̄ / in al this melodye
The vsshers / and the Squyers ben ygon̄
The spices and the wyn / is come anon̄
They eete and dronke / and whan this hadde an ende
Vnto the temple / as reson was they wende
The ʆseruice done / they sopen al by day
What nedeth you / rehersen her array
Eche man̄ wote wel / that at a kynges feste
Is plente to the meste and to the leste
And deyntes moo / than ben in my knowynge
At after soper goth this noble kyng
To seen this hors of braas / with al a rowte
Of lordes and ladyes / hym aboute
Swich wondryng was ther / on this hors of braas
That sitthe the grete seege of Troye was
Ther as men wondred / on an hors also
Ne was ther swich a wondryng / as was tho
But finally the kyng asketh the knyght
The vertue of this courser / and the myght
And prayed hym to telle his goủernance
This hors anon̄ gan to trippen / and to daunce
Whan that the knyght / layde hond vppon his reyne
And seide sire / ther is no more to seyne
But whan thou list to ryden anywhere
Ye mut trille a pyn stant in his ere
Whiche I shall telle you / a twene vs two
Ye mote nempne hym / to what place also
Or to what contre / that you lyst to ryde
And whan ye come there / you lyst abyde
Bid hym descende / and trille another pyn
For ther yn lieth theffect / of al this gyn
And wol doıı̄un descende / and done youre wille
And in that place / he wol abide stille
Though al the world hadde the contᵃrarie yswore
He shall not thennes ben throwen trowen throwen ne ybore
Or ȝif list you bid hym thennes gon̄
Trille this pyn / and he wanysshe anon̄
Out of the sight of eủery maner wight
And come ageyn̄ / be it day or nyght
Whan that you list to clepen hym agayn̄
In swich awyse / as I shal to you sayn̄
Betwene you and me / and that ful sone
Ryd whan you list / ther is no more to done
¶ Enformed whan the kyng was of this knyght
And hath conceyued / in his wyt aright
The man̉ere / and the forme / of al this thyng
Ful glad and blithe / the noble doughty kyng
Repayryng to his Revel / as biforn
The bridel is into the tour yborn̄
And kept amonge his Iewels lief and dere
The hors vanisshed I not in what man̉ere
Out of her sight / ye gete no more of me
But thus I lete hem / in lust and iolyte
This kambyuskan his lordes festeynge
Til we nygh the day bigan to sprynge
¶ Explicit prima pars /
¶ The stag of an hert /
The norice of digestioıı̄un sleep
Gan on hem wenke / and bad hem take keep
That moche mete and labour wolde have reste
And with a galpyng mowth hem alle he keste
And seide that it was tyme to ligge a doıı̄un
For blood was in his dominacioıı̄un
Cherissheth blood natures frend quod he
They thanken hym / galpynge by two by thre /
And eủery wight gan drawen hym to reste
As sleep hem bad / they thoughte it for the beste
Hir dremes shul not now be told for me /
Ful were here hedes of fumosite
That causeth dreme / of whiche is no charge
They slepen til it was prime large
The most part / but it were Canace
She was ful mesurable / as women be
For of hir Fader / hadde she take hir leve
To goon to reste / sone after that it was eve
Hir lust not apalled forto be
On the morowe / ne vnfesteliche forto se
And slepte hir firste sleep / and a wook
For swiche a ioye / she in hir herte took
Bothe of hir queynte ryng / and hir myroᵘur
That twenty tyme / she chaunged hir coloᵘur
And in hir sleep / right for imp̉ressioıı̄un
Of hir miroᵘur / she hadde a visioıı̄un
Wherfore er that the sonne gan vp glide
She cleped vp hir Maistrasse hir biside
And seide / that hir liste forto ryse
Thise olde women / that bien gladly wyse
As is hir Maistrasse / answered hir anoon
And saide ma Dame / wheder wolde ye goon
Thus erly / for folk ben alle in reste
I woll qduod she arise for me leste
No lenger to slepen / but walken aboute
Hir maistresse clepeth women a grete route
And vp they risen / wel ten or twelue
And vp riseth faire Canace her selue
As rody and bright / as theigh the yonge sonne
That in the Ram is ten grees vp ronne
Non hir was like / whan she redy was
And forth she walked esely a paas
Arraied after the lusty sesoıı̄un swote
Lyghtly forto pleye / and walke on fote
Nat but v or vj of hir mayne
And in a trenche / fer in the parke goth she
The vapour whiche / that fro the erthe glood
Maketh the sonne to seme rody and brood
But nathales / it was so faire a sighte
That id made alle hir hertes / forto lighte
That for the sesoıı̄un / and the morwenynge
And for the foules / that she herde synge
For right anoon / she wiste what they mente
Right by her songe / and knewe al her entente
¶ The knotte why / that eủery tale is told
Ȝif it be taried / til lust be cold
Of hem that han it herkened after ȝore
The sauoᵘur passeth / eủere lenger the more
For fulsomnesse of prolixite
And by this same reson thinketh me
I shulde to the knotte condescende
And maken of hir walkyng sone an ende /
¶ A midde a tree for drye as white as chalk
As Canace was pleynge in hir walk
There sat a faucon / over hir heed ful hie
That wᵗith a pitous voys so gan to crye
That alle the wode / resede of the crye
And beten hadde she hir self so pitouslye /
With bothe hir wynges / tyl the reed blood
Ran endelong the tree / ther as she stood
And eủere in oon / she cried alwey and shrighte
And wᵗith hir bek / hir self alwey she pighte
That ther ne was tigre ne cruel best
That dwelleth eyther in wode or in forest
That nolde have wept / ȝif that he wepe couthe
For sorowe of hir / she shrighte alwey so louthe
For ther nas neủere ȝit man on lyue
Ȝif that I couthe a facon wel descryue
That herde of suche another / of fairenesse
As wel of plumage / as of gentilnesse
Of shap of al that myghte rekened be
A faucon ꝑperygryn̄ / than semed she
Of fremde londe / and eủere more as she stood
She swowned now and now / for lak of blood
Til wel nygh is she fallen fro the tre /
This kynges Daughter / this faire Canace
That on hir fynger bar the queynte ryng
Thurgh whiche / she vnderstood wel eủery thyng
That eny foule may in his ledne sayn
And couthe answere / in his ledne agayn
Hath vnderstonde / that this faucon saide
And wel nygh for routhe / almost she daide
And to the tree she goth ful hastely
And on this faucon / she loketh pitously
And heeld hir lappe a brood for wel she wiste
The faucon muste fallen / fro the twiste
Whan that it swowneth next for lak of blood
A long while to wayten hir she stood
Til atte laste / she spak in this manere
Vnto the hawk / as ye shal after here
¶ What is the cause / ȝif it be forto telle
That ye ben in this furial peyne of helle
Quod Canace / vnto this hauk above
Is this for sorowe of deth / or losse of love
For as I trowe / thise ben causes two
That causen most a gentil herte wo
Of other harme / it nedith not to speke
For thy youre self / vpon youre self you wreke
Which that proveth wel / that either Ire or drede
Muste ben encheson / of youre cruel dede
Syn that I see / noon other wight you chace
For love of god / so doth youre self grace /
Or what may be youre helpe / for west nor est
Ne saugh I neuer or now / no brid ne best
That ferde with hym self so pitousely
Ȝe slee me with youre sorowe verraily
I have of you so grete compassioıı̄un
For goddes love / come fro the tree a doıı̄un
And as I am a kynges Doughter trewe
Ȝif that I verraily the causes knewe
Of youre disese / ȝif it lay in my myght
I wolde amende it / or that it were nyght
As wisly helpe me grete god of kynde
And herbes shal I / right ynowe fynde /
To helen with youre hurtes hastely
She shrighte / ȝit this faucon̄ pitousely
More than eủere she dide / and fil to grounde anoon
And lyth on sowne ded as is a stoon
Til Canace hath in hir lappe hir take
Vnto the tyme / she gan of swown awake
And after that she of swowne gan abreide
Right in his hawkes leodne thus she seide
That pite renneth sone / in gentil herte
Felynge his similitude in peynes smerte
Is ꝓproved alday / as men may it se
As wel by werk / as by auctorite
For gentil herte / kepith gentilnesse
I see wel / that ye han of my distresse
Compassioıı̄un my faire Canace
Of verray womanly benignite
That nature / in youre principles hath set
But for non hope / forto fare the bet
But forto obeye / vnto youre herte fre
And to maken other ben ware by me
As by the whelp / chastised is the lyoıı̄un
Right for that cause / and for that conclusioıı̄un
While that I have a leyser and a spase
Myn harme I woll confessen or I pase
And eủere while that oon hir sorowe tolde
That other wepte / as she to water wolde
Til that the faucon / bad hir to be stille
And with a seke / thus she saide hir tille
Ther I was bred / allas that ilke day
¶ And fostred in a roche of marbull gray
So tenderly / that no thyng eyled me
I wyste nouȝt what was adủersite
Til I couthe fle ful high vnder the sky
Tho dwelled a tercelet me fast by
That semed welle / of alle gentilnesse
Al were he ful of tresoıı̄un / and falsnesse .
It is wrapped vnder humble chere
And vnder hewe of trouthe / and in suche manere
Vnder plesaunce / and vnder besy peyne
That no wight couthe han wend / that he couthe feyne
So depe in greyn / he dyed his colours
Right as a ʆserpent hit hym vnder floures
Til he may seen his tyme / forto byte
Right so this god of loves ypoocrite
Doth so his cerimonies / and obeisaunces
And kepith in semblaıı̄unt alle his obʆseruᵃaunces
That sowneth into gentilnesse of love
As in a toumbe is al the faire above
And vnder is the corps / swich as ye woot
Such was this ypocrite / both colde and hoot
And in this wise / he ʆserued his entente
That saf the feend / noon wiste what he mente
Til he so longe had wepen / and compleyned
And many a yere his ʆseruice to me feyned
Til that myn herte / to pitous and to nyce
Al innocent of his crowned malice
For ferd of his deth / as thought me
Vpon his othes / and his surete
Graunted hym love / on this condicioıı̄un
That eủere mo myn̄ honoᵘur and renoıı̄un
Were saved / bothe pryue and apert
This is to saien / that after his dissert
I ȝaf hym all myn̄ herte / and al my thought
God woot and he that other wise nought
And toke his herte / in chaunge of myn̄ for ay
But soth is seid / goon syn many a day
A trewe wight / and a theef thenken not oon
And whan he saugh / the thyng so fer ygoon
That I graunted hym / fully my love
In swich a gise / as I have seide above
And yeven hym my trewe herte / as fre
As he swoor / he yaf his herte to me
Anoon this tigre / ful of doublenesse
Fil on his knees / with so devoute humblesse
With high reuerence / and as by his chere
So lyke a gentil lovere of manere
So rauisshed / as it semed for the ioye
That never Iason̄ / ne paris of Troye
Iason certes ne non other man
Syn lameth was / that alther first bigan
To loven two / as writen folk biforn̄
Ne never sithe / the first man was born̄
Ne couthe man / by twenty thousand part
Counterfete the sophymes of his art
Ne were worthy to vnbokele his galoche
Ther doublenes or feynyng sholde approche
Ne so couthe thanke a wight / as he did me
His maner was an heuene forto see
Til eny woman were she neủere so wys
So peynted he / and kembeth at poynt deuys
As wel his wordes / as his countenᵃaunce
And I so loued hym / for his obeysaunce
And for the trouthe / I demed in his herte
That if so were / that eny thyng hym smerte
Al were it never so lyte / and I it wiste
Me thoughte I felte deth / at my herte twiste
And shortly so ferforth / this thyng is went
My wille was his willes instrument
This is to saien / my wille obeyed his wille
In al thyng / as fer as reson fille
Kepyng the boundes of my worshuppe eủere
Ne neủere hadde I thyng so leef ne leuere
As hym god wote / ne neủere shal no mo
This laste lenger / than a ȝere or two
That I supposed of hym / no thyng but good
But finally / thus atte laste it stood
That fortune / wolde that muste twynne
Out of the place / whiche that I was ynne
Wheither me was wo / it is no questioıı̄un
I can not make of it discripcioıı̄un
For oo thyng / dar I telle boldely
I knowe / what is the peyne of deth ther by
Swich harm I felte for he ne myghte bileue
So on a day of me he took his leue
So sorwefully eek that I wende verraily
That he hadde feelyd as muche harm as I
Whan that I herde hym speke and saw his hewe
But nathelees I thoughte he was so trewe
And eek that he repeyre sholde agayn
With Inne a litel while sooth to sayn
And reson wolde eek that he moste go
For his honour as ofte happeth so
Wherfor I wold not ben ayein his honour
That I made vertu of necessitee
And took it wel syn that it moste be
As I best myghte I hidde from hym my sorwe
And took hym by the hand Seint Iohn to borwe
And seyde thus lo I am youres al
Beeth swich as I to yow haue been and shal
What he answerde it nedeth nat reherse
Who kan seyn bet than he who kan doon werse
Whan he hath al wel seyd thanne hath he doon
Therfore bihoued hire a ful long spoon
That shal ete with a feend thus herde I seye
So at the laste he moste forth his weye
And forth he fleeth til he cam ther hym leste
Whan it cam hym to purpos for to reste
I trowe he hadde thilke text in mynde
That alle thyng repeiryng to his kynde
Gladeth hymself thus seyn men as I gesse
Men louen of propre kynde Newfangelnesse
As bryddes doon that men in Cages feede
For theigh thow nyght and day take of hem hede
And strawe hir Cages faire and softe as sylk
And yeue hem sugre hony breed and Milk
Yet right anon as that his dore is vppe
He with his feet wol sporne doun his cuppe
And to the wode he wole and wormes ete
So newfangel been they of hir mete
And louen nouelries of propre kynde
No gentilesse of blood may hem bynde
So ferde this tercelet / allas the day
Though he were gentil born̄ fressh and gay
And goodely forto seen / and humble and free
He saugh vpon a tyme / a kyte flee
And sodenly he loued this kyte so
That al his love / is clene fro me go
And hath his trouthe / falsed in this wyse
This hath the kyte my love in hir ʆseruyse
And I am lorn withoute remedie
And with that word / this faucon̄ gan to crye /
And swowned eft in Canaces barm
Greet was the sorowe / for that hawkes harm /
That Canace / and alle hir women made
They nyste how that they myght the faucon glade
But Canace home berith hir in hir lappe
And softly in plast̉ers gan hir wrappe
Ther as she / with hir bek / hath hurt hir selue
Now can not Canace / but herbes delue
Out of the grounde / and make salues newe
Of herbes p̉reciouse / and fyn of heewe
To helen with the hawk / fro day to nyght
She doth hir besynesse / and al hir myght
And by hir beddes heed / she made a mywe
And coủered it with velewettes bluwe
In signe of trouthe / that is in women sene
And al withoute the muwe / is peynted grene
In whiche were paynted / alle thise false fowles
As ben thise tidyfs tercelettes / and owles
Right for despite were peynted hem bisyde
Pyes on hem forto crie / and chyde
¶ Thus lete I Canace hir hawk kepynge
I wol no more speken as now of the ryng
Til it come eft to purpos forto seyn
How that this faucon̄ / gat hir love ageyn̄
Repentant as the storie telleth vs
By mediacioıı̄un of Camballus
The kynges sone / of whiche I you tolde
But hennes forth / I wol my proces holde
To speke of auentures and of batailles
That neuere yet was herd so greet meruailles
First wol I telle yow of Cambyuskan
That in his tyme many a Citee wan
And after wol I speke of Algarsyf
How that he wan Theodora to his wyf
For whom ful ofte in gret peril he was
Ne hadde he been holpen by the Steede of bras
And after wol I speke of Cambalo
That faught in lystes with the bretheren two
For Canacee er that he myghte hir wynne
And ther I lefte I wol ayein bigynne

Til that the god Mercuries hous the slye

¶ The prologe of the Marchant
In feith Squyer / thow hast the wel yquit
And gentilly / I prayse wel thy wit
Quod the Marchant / consideryng thy ȝowthe
So felyngly thow spekest / I allowthe
As to my dome / ther is noon that is here
Of eloquence / that shal be thy pere
For of thy speche / I have grete deynte
I have a sone / and by the Trynyte
I hadde lever than xx poundes worth of land
Though it right now were fallen in myn hand
He were a man / of suche discreciou
As that ye ben / Fy vpon possessiou
But ȝif a man be vertuous with al
I have my sone snybbed / and ȝit shal
For he to vertue listeth nouȝt entende
But forto pleye atte dees / and to dispende
And lese al that he hath / is his vsage
And he hath lever talke with a page
Than to comune / with any gentil wight
Where he myght lerne gentilnesse a right
Straw for youre gentilnesse qd oure host
What Marchant ꝑparde / wel thow wost
That ech of you moot tellen at the leste
A tale or two / or broken his biheste
That knowe I wel / qd the Marchant c̉erteyn
I pray you / have me not in disdeyn
Though to this man / I speke a word or two
Telle on thy tale withoute wordes mo
Gladly sir host / quod he / I wol obeye
Vnto youre wille / now herkeneth what I seye
I wol you not contᵃrie / in noo wyse
As fer as that my wittes wol suffise
I pray to god / that it may plesen yow
Than woot I wel / that it is good ynow
¶ Here endeth the prologe / and bigynneth the tale
¶ Here bigynneth / the Marchantes tale
Whilom / ther was dwellynge in Lumbardye
A worthy knyght / that born was of Pauye
In which he lyuede / in greet prosperitee
And sixty yeer / a wiflees man was he
And folwed ay / his bodily delit
On wommen / ther as was his appetit
As doon thise fooles / that been seculer
And whan that he / was passed sixty yeer
Were it for holynesse / or for dotage
I kan nat seye / but swich a greet corage
Hadde this knyght to been a wedded man
That day and nyght / he dooth al that he kan
To espien / where he myghte wedded be
Þat daie ⁊and nyht he doþe al þat he can
To aspie where he myht wedded be
Preyynge oure lord / to graunten hym / that he
Mighte ones knowe / of thilke blisful lyf
That is / bitwix an housbonde and his wyf
And for to lyue / vnder that holy bond
With which / that god / man and womman boond
Thee whiche god ferst blessede wᵗith his owne hand
Noon oother lyf seyde he / is worth a bene
For wedlok is so esy / and so clene
That in this world / it is a Paradys
Thus seyde this olde knyght that was so wys
¶ And certeynly / as sooth as god is kyng
To take a wyf / it is a glorious thyng
And namely / whan a man is old and hoor
Than is a wyf the fruyt of his tresor
Than shulde he take a ȝong wyf and a fair
On which he myght / engendre hym an heyr
And lede his lyf in ioy and in solas
Where as thise bachelers syngen allas
Whan they fynden eny aduersite
In love / whiche is but childes vanite
And trewely it sit wel to ben so
That bachelers han ofte peyne and wo
On brotil grounde / they belde brotilnesse
They fynde it whan they wene sikernesse
They lyue / but as a brid or a beste
In liberte / and vnder nyce areste
Ther as a wedded man / in his astate
Lyueth his lyf / blisful and ordinate
Vnder the yok of mariage ybounde
As hit is dayly seyen and founde
For who can be so buxūm / as a wyf
Who is so trewe / and also ententyf
To kepe hym syk and hool / as is his make
For wele ne wo / she nyl hym not forsake
She is not wery / hym to love and ʆserue
Theigh that he lye bedrede forto sterue
And ȝit some clerkes / seyn it is not so
Of whiche Theofrast is oon of tho
What no fors / though Theofrast lust to lye
Ne take no wyf / quod he for husbondrye
As forto spare in houshold thy dispence
A trewe ʆseruᵃaunt / doth more diligence
Thy good to kepe / than thyn owne wyf
For she wol clayme half part al hir lyf
And ȝif that thow be syk / so god me save
Thy verray frendes / or a trewe knave
Wol kepe the better than she that wayteth ay
After thy good and hath doon̄ many a day
And ȝif thow take a wyf that to the is vntrewe
Ful ofte tyme / it shal the rewe
This entente and an hundred sithes worse
Writeth thus man / ther god his bones curse
But take no kepe of al suche vanite
Defie Theofrast / and herkeneth me
A wyf is godes ȝifte v̉erraily
Alle other maner ȝiftes hardely
As landes rentes pasture or cōmmune
Or mebles alle / ben ȝiftes of fortune
That passen / as a shaddewe on a wal
But drede it nouȝt / pleynly speke I shal
A wyf wol laste / and in thyn hous endure
Wel lenger / than the lest ꝑparauenture
Mariage is a ful greet sacrament
The which hath no wyf / I telle hym shent
He lyueth helpelees / and is all desolate
I speke of folke / in seculer estate
And herken why / I say nouȝt thus for nought
The woman is for mannes helpe ywrought
The high god / whan he hadde Adam maked
And saugh hym allone / besy naked
God of his grete goodenes / seide than
Let vs make an helpe to this man
Lyk to hym self and than he made Eue
Here may ye see / and here by may ye p̉reue
That wyf is mannes confort
His paradis t̉errestre / and his disport
So buxom and so vertuous is she
They muste nedes lyuen in vnyte
Oo flessh they ben / and two saules as I gesse
Hath but oon herte / in hele and in distresse
A wyf a seint Marie benedicite
How myght a man han eny adủersite
That hath a wyf / certes I can seye
The blisse that is bitwixe hem tweye
Ther may no tonge telle / or herte thenke
Ȝif he be poủere / she helpith hym to swynke
She kepith his goode / and waste neủere a deel
And that hir husbond lust / hir leketh wel
She seith nat ones nay / when he seith ȝe
Do thus seith he / al redy sire seith she
O blisful ordre / o wedlok precious
Thow art so mery / and eke so vertuous
And so cōmmended / and so app̉reued eke
That eủery man / that halt hym worth a leke
Vpon his baar knees / ought al his lyf
Thanken his god / that hym hath sent a wyf
Or prey to god / hym forto sende
A wyf to laste / vnto his lyves ende
For than his lyf is set in sikernesse
He may not be disseyued as I gesse
So that he worche / after his wyfes rede
Than may he boldely / beren vp his hede
They be so trewe / and also so wys
For which ȝif thow wolt worchen / as the wys
Do alwey so / as women wol the rede
Lo how that Iacob / as thise Clerkes rede
By good conseil / of his Moder Rebecke
Bond the kides skyn / aboute his nekke
For whiche his Faders benesoıı̄un he wan
Lo Iudith / as the storie telle can
By wys counseil / she goddes peple kepte
And slough hym Olifernes while he slepte
Lo Abigayl / by good counseil how she
Saued hir husbond Nabal whan that he
Shulde have be slayn̄ / and loke after also
By good counseil / delyủered out of wo
The peple of god / and made hym marche
Of Assirie enhaunced forto be
Ther nys no thyng in grete suꝑperlatif
As seith Senek aboue an humble wyf
Suffre thy wyfes tonge / as Catoıı̄un bit
She shal comande / and thou shalt suffre it
And ȝit she wole obeye of curtesie
A wyf is keper of thyn housbondrie
Wel may the seke man / biwayle and wepe
Ther as nys no wyf / the hous to kepe
I warne the / ȝif wysely thou wilt wirche
Love wel thy wyf / as Crist loveth his chirche
Ȝif thou louest thy self / wel thou louest thy wyf
No man hateth his flessh / but in his lyf
He fostreth it / and therfore I bidde the
Cheryce thy wyf / or thou shalt neủere the
Husbonde and wyf what so men iape or pleye
Of worldly folk / holde the sikir weye
They be so knytte / ther may noon harme betide
And namely vpon the wyues side /
¶ For whiche this Ianuarie / of whiche I tolde
Considered hath / in his dayes olde
The lusty lyf and vertuous quiete
That is in mariage hony swete
And for his frendes / on a day he sente
To tellen hem / theffect of his entente
With face sad his tale / he hath hem tolde
He saide frende / I am hoor and olde
And almost god woot / on my pittes brynke
Vpon my soule / sumwhat muste I thynke
I have my body / folily dispended
Blessed be god / that it shal be amended
For I wol be certayn̄ / a wedded man
And that anoon / in al the haste I can
Vnto som mayde faire / and tendre of age
I pray you / shapeth for my mariage
Al sodeinly / for I wol not abide
I wol fonden to aspien on my side
To wham I may be wedded hastely
But for as moche / as ye be mo than I
Ȝe shul rather such a thyng aspien
Than I and ther me lust best to allien
But oo thyng warne I you my frendes dere
I wol noon olde wyf have / in noo manere
She shal not passen xvj yere certayn̄
Olde fissh and yonge flessh / that wol I have fayn̄
Bet is quod he / a pyke / than a pykerel
And bet than olde beef / is the tendre veel
I wol no woman of thritty wynter age
It nys not but bene strawe / and grete forage
And eke thise olde wyues / god it woot
They konnen so moche craft / on wades boot
So moche broke harme / whan hem leste
That with hem shulde I neủere lyue in reste
For sondry scoles / maketh subtile clerkes
Woman of many scoles / half a clerk is
But c̉erteinly a yong thyng / may man gye
Right as men may warm wax wᵗith handes plye
Therfore I seie you / pleinly in a clause
I wol noon olde wyf have / right for this cause
For ȝif so were / I hadde some meschaunce
That in hir / I ne couthe have no plesaunce
Than shulde I lede my lyve / in auenture
And so streight / to the Deuel sure
Ne children shulde I noon vpon hir geten
Than hadde I leuere / that houndes had me eten
Than that myn heritage shulde falle
In straunge handes / and thus I telle you alle
I dote nouȝt I not nouȝt the cause why
Men shulde wedde / and ferthermore woot I
Ther speketh meny a man of mariage
That woot no more of it / than doith my page
For whiche causes / men shulde take a wyf
Ȝif he may not chast ben in his lyf
Take hym a wyf / wᵗith grete deuocioıı̄un
By cause of leefful procreacioıı̄un
Of children / to the honoᵘur of god aboue
And nouȝt only for ꝑparamoᵘur ne for loue
And for they shulde leccherie eschewe
And ȝelde her dette / while that it is newe
And for that eche of hem / sholde helpe other
In meschief as a suster shal the brother
And lyue in chastite ful heuenly
But sires by youre leue / that am not I
For god be thanked I dar make avant
I fele my lemes starke and suffisant
To done al that a man behoueth to
I woot my self best / what I may do
Though I be hoor / I fare as doth a tree
That blosmeth er that the fruyt ywoxen be
That blosmed tre is / nother drye ne ded
I fele nowher hoor / but on myn hed
Myn herte and my lemes ben as grene
As lauriole is thurgh the yere forto sene
And sithen that ye han herde al myn entente
I pray you to my wille / that ye assente
Diuerse men / diuersely hym tolde
Of mariage / many ensamples olde
Some blamen it some pᵃraysen it certayn̄
But atte laste / shortly forto sayn̄
As alday / falleth altercacioıı̄un
Betwexe frendes / in disputacioıı̄un
Ther fel a strif betwexe his brethern̄ two
Of whiche oon was called placebo
Iustinus sothly called was that other
Placebo seide / o sire I am youre brother
Ful litel nede have ȝe / my lorde so dere
Counseil to aske / of eny that is here
But that ye be so ful of sapience
That ȝow ne leketh / for youre high prudence
To wayue fro the word of Saloman
This word saith to vs euerychon̄
Werke al thyng by counseil / thus saide he
And than shaltow not repente the
But though that Salomon speke suche a word
Myn owne dere brother / and my lord
So wisly god brynge my soule a reste
I holde youre owne counseil / is the beste
For brother myn̄ / take of me this motyf
I have ben a Courtman / al my lyf
And god woot / though I vnworthy be
I have stonden / in ful high degre
With wordy lordes / of ful grete estate
Ȝit had I neủere with none of hem debate
I neủere hem contᵃraried trewely .
I woot wel my lorde can more than I
That he seith / I holde it ferme and stable
I say the same / or ells thyng semblable
A ful grete fool / is any counseillour
That ʆserueth eny lorde of high honour
That dar presume / or ones thenken it
That his counsel / shulde passe his lordes wit
Nay lordes be noo foles / by my fay
Ȝe have youre self spoken here to day
So high sentence / so holy and so wel
That I concente / and conferme eủerydel
Ȝoure wordes / and ȝoure opinioıı̄un
By god ther is no man / in al this toıı̄un
Ne in Italie / that couthe bet han said
Crist holde of this hym / ful wel appaid
And trewely it is / an high corage
Of eny man / that stopen is in age
To taken a ȝong wyf / by my fader kyn
Ȝoure herte hongeth / on a mery pyn
Doth now in this mater / right as you lest
For fynally / I holde it for the best
¶ Iustinus that ay stille sat and herde
Right in this wyse / he to placebo answerde
Now brother myn̄ / be pacient I preye
Syn that that ye han seide / herkene what I seye
Senek amonge other wordes wise
Seith that a man / oughte hym wel avyse
To whom he ȝeueth his land or his catel
And sithens I oughte avyse me right wel
To whom I ȝeve my body for alwey
I warne you wel / it is no childes pley
To taken a wyf / withoute auysement
Men moste enquere / this is myn assent
Wheder she be wys / sobre / or dronkelewe
Other proud / or wast̉er or a shrewe
A chider other a destroier of thy good
Other riche other poủere / or ells a man is wood
Albe it so / that man fynde shal
Non in this worlde / that trotteth hool in al
Ne man ne beste / suche as men con deuise
But nathalees / it ought ynow suffise
With eny wyf / ȝif so were that she hadde
Moo goode thewes / than vices badde
And al this asketh leyser to inquere
For god woot / I have wept many a tere
Ful priuely sitthe I hadde a wyf
Preyse who so wole a wedded mannes lyf
Certeyne I fynde in it / but cost and care
And obseruaunces / of alle blisses bare
And ȝit god thanke my neghbores aboute
And namely of women a grete route
Sayn that I have / the most stedfast wyf
And eke the mekest oon / that bereth lyf
But I woot best / where wryeth my sho
Ȝe may for me / right as you luste to do
Aviseth you / ȝe ben a man of age
How that ye entren / into mariage
And namely wᵗith a yong wyf and a feyr
By hym / that made water / erthe / and eyr
The yongeste man / that is in al this route
Is besy ynow / to bryngen it aboute
To have his wyf allone trusteth me
Ȝe shulle not plesen hir fully ȝeres thre
This is to saie / to done hir plesaunce
A wyf asketh / ful many an obseruaunce
I pray you / that ye be nat evel appaied
Wel quod this Ianuarie / and hastow al ysaid
Straw for thy Senek / and alle thy prouerbes
I counte hem not a panyer ful of herbes
Of scole t̉ermes / wiser men than thow
As thow hast herde / assentith it right now
To my Purpos / Placebo what saie ȝe
I say it is a cursed man / quod he
That letteth matrimoyne sykerly
And with that word / they risen sodenly
And ben assented fully / that he sholde ¶
Ben wedded / whan hym leste / and where he wolde
¶ The fantasie / and the curiousnesse
Fro day to day / gan in the soule impresse
Of Ianuarie / aboute his mariage
Many faire shap / and many faire visage
There passeth his herte nyght by nyght
As who toke a mirroᵘur polisshed bryght
And sette it in a comune market place
Than shulde he seen many a figure pace
By his mirroᵘur and in the same wise
Grant Ianuarie in with his thought deuise
Of maydenes whiche that dwellen beside
He wist nat where / that he myght abide
For though oon thathath beaute in hir face
Another stant so in the peples gᵃce
For hir sadnesse / and hir benignite
That of the peple grettest voys hath she
And some were riche / and hadden bad name
But nathalees / bitwexe ernest and game
He atte laste appoynted hym in oon
And lette alle other from his herte goon
And chese her of his owne auctorite
For loue is blynde / alday and may not see
And whan that he was / in his bed ybrought
He portreyed in his herte / and in his thought
Hir fresshe beaute / and hir age tendre
Hir myddel smal / hir harmes longe and slendre
Hir wise goủernance / and hir gentilnesse
Hir womanly berynge / and hir sadnesse
And whan that he / to this was condescended
Hym thought his choys / myghte not ben amended
For whan that he hym self concluded hadde
Hym thought eche other mannes witte so badde
That impossible / it were to replie
Ageyn his choys / this was his fantasye
His frendes sent he to / at his instance
And preyeth hem / to done hym that plesaunce
That hastely they wolde to hym come ¶
He wolde abregge her labour al and some
It nedeth noo more / to hem to goon ne ryde
He was appoynted / ther he wolde abyde
Placebo cam / and eke his frendes sone
And altherfirst he bad hem alle abone
That noon of hem / noon argumentes make
Ageyn his purpos whiche he hath ytake
Which purpos was plesaunt to god as saide he
And verray grounde / of prosperyte
He saide ther was / a mayden in the tou
Whiche that of beaute hath grete renou
Al were it so she were of smal degre
Suffiseth hym / hir youthe / and hir beaute
Whiche mayde he saide / he wolde haue hir to wyf
To leden in ese / and in holynesse his lyf
And thonketh god / that he myghte han hir al
That noo wight his blisse parte shal
And preyeth hem / to labour in this nede
And shapeth / that I fayle not to spede
For than he saide / his spirt was at ese
Than is quod he / no thyng that may me displese
Sauf o thyng priketh in my conscience
The whiche I wol reherse in youre psence
I have quod he herd seid ful ȝore ago
Ther may no man / have ꝑparfite blisse two
That is to saie / in erthe and eke in heuene
For theigh he kepte hym / fro the synnes seuene
And eeke from eủery braunche / of thilke tre
Ȝit is there so parfite prosꝑperite /
And so greet ese / and lust in mariage
That euere I am a gast / now in myn age
That I shal lede / now so mery a lyf here
For sithen that verray heuene is bouȝt so dere
With tribulaciou / and greet penance
How sholde I leve / in suche plesance
As alle wedded men don / with her wyfis
Come to the blisse / ther crist et̉erne on lyue is
This is my drede / and ye my bretheren tweye ¶
Assoileth me this questiou / I you preye
¶ Iustinus whiche that hated his folye
Answerynge anoon / right in his iaperie
And for he wolde his tale abregge
He wolde noon auctorite allegge
But seide sire so ther be non obstacle
Othir than this / god of his high myracle
And of his mercy may so for you wirche
That er ȝe han youre ȝiftes of holy chirche
Ȝe may repente of wedded mannes lyf
In whiche ye saien / is neither wo ne stryf
And ellis god forbede / but ȝif he sente
A wedded man gᵃce / hym to repente
Wel often rather / than a sengle man
And therfore sire / the best reed I can
Dispeirith you nouȝt / haueth in memorie
Paraunter she may be youre purgatorie
She may be goddes mene / and goddes whippe
Than shal youre soule / vp to heuene skippe
Swifter than doth an arowe out of a bowe
I hope to god here after / shal ye knowe
That ther is noon so grete felicite
In mariage / ne neủere more shal be
That you shal lacke / of youre saluaciou
So that ye vse / as skille is and resou
The lustes of youre wyf attemprely
And that ye plese hir nouȝt to amarously
And that ye kepe you eke / fro other synne
My tale is done / for my wyt is thynne
Beth nouȝt agast / of this my dere brother
But late vs wade / fro this matere to another
The wyf of Bathe / ȝif ye wol vnderstonde
Of mariage / whiche ye han in honde
Declaren can ful wel in lytel space
Fareth now wel / god have you in his grace
¶ And with this worde Iustine and his brother
Han taken hir leve eche of hem of other
For whan they sawe it most nedes be ¶
They wrought so by wys and sligh trete
That she this Maide / which that Maius hight
As hastely / as euere she myght
Shal wedded ben / vnto Ianuarie
I trowe it were to longe you tarie
Ȝif I you tolde of euery scrite or bond
By whiche that she was feffed in his lond
Other forto herken of hir riche aray
But fynally / ycomen is the day
That to the chirche / bothe they went
Forto resceyue the holy sacrament
¶ Forth cometh the preste / wᵗith stole abovte his nekke
And bad hir lyk to be Sarra and Rebekke
In wisdam and trouthe of mariage
And seide his orisons / as is vsage
And crouched hem / and bad god sholde hym blesse
And made al sikir ynough with holynesse
¶ Thus ben they weddes / with solempnite
And atte laste / sitteth he and she
With other worthy folk / vpon the deys
Al ful of ioye and blisse is the paleys
And ful of instrumentz / and of vitayle
The moste deyntenous of al ytayle
Biforn hem of instumentz which son
That Orpheus ne of Thebes Amphion
Ne maden neủere suche a melodie
As at eủery cours com lowde of mynstralcye
That neuere Ioab trumped forto here
Neither Theodomas / ȝit half so clere
At Thebes / whan the Cite was in doute
Bacus the wyn hem shenketh al aboute
And venus lawgheth on euery wyght
For Ianuarie was bicome hir knyght
And wolde bothen assaien his corage
In liberte / and eke in mariage
And with hir fury brond in hir hande aboute
Daunseth bifore the bride al aboute
And certainly I dar wel sayn right this ¶
¶ Imineus / that god of weddyng is
Sawgh neủer in his lyf so mery a wedded man
Hald thow thy pees / thow poete Marcian
That writest vs / that thilke weddyng merye
Of hir philogie / and of hir Mercurye
And of the songes / that the Muses songe
So smale / and eke thy penne / and eke thy tonge
Forto discriuen of this mariage
Whan tendre ȝouthe hath wedded stoupynge age
Ther is suche merthe that it may nouȝt be wrete
Assaieth it youre self / than may ye wete
Ȝif that I lakke or noon in this matere
Maius that sit with so benigne a chere
Hir to be holde it semed a fayrye
Quen Ester loked neủere with such an eye
On Assuere so meke a look hath she
I may you nouȝt deuisen hir beaute
But thus moche / of hir beaute telle I may
That she was lyk / the bright morow of may
Fulfilled of beaute / and of plesaunce
This Ianuarie is rauisshed in a traunce
And at eủery tyme / he loked in hir face
In his herte / he gan hir to manace
That he that nyght / in armes wolde hir streyne
Harder than euere Paris dide Eleyne
But nathalees ȝit hadde he greet pite
That thilke nyght offenden hir muste he
And thoughte allas / o tendir creature
