Now wolde god / ȝe myghte wel endure
Al my corage it is so sharpe and kene
I am a gast / ȝe shul it nouȝt sustene
But god forbede / that I dide al my myght
Now wolde god / that it were woxen nyght
And that the nyght wolde lasten eủere mo
I wolde that al this peple were a go
And finaly he doth al his labour
As he best myght savyng his honour
To haste hym fro the mete in subtile wyse ¶
¶ The tyme com / that resoıı̄un was to ryse
And after that men daunce / and drynke faste
And spices al aboute the hous they caste
And ful of ioye and blisse is eủery man
Al but a Squyer / that hight Damyan
Which carf bifore the knyght many a day
He was so rauisshed on his lady May
That for verray peyne / he was nygh wood
Amost he swelte and sowned there he stood
As that she bar daunsyng in hir hand
So fressh she was / and therto so lykand
And to his bed / he wente hym hastely
No more of hym at this tyme speke I .
But there I let hym wepe ynough and pleyne
Til fressh may wol rewe vpon his peyne
¶ O ꝑperilous fyre / that in the bedstraw bredeth
O famuler foo / that his ʆseruice bedeth
O ʆseruᵃnt traitour / fals holy hewe
Lyke to the Nedder sligh / and in bosom vntrewe
God shylde vs alle fro youre iniquitance
O Ianuarie dronken in plesance
Of mariage / see how thy Damyan
Thy owne Squyer / and thy bore man
Entendeth to done the vylenye
God graunte the thyn harme forto aspie
For in this world nys worse pestilence
Than homely foo alday in thy psence
¶ Parformed hath this day his arke diourne
No lenger may the body of hym soiourne
The orisount as in that latitude
Nyght with his mantel / that is derk and rude
Gan forto hyde the enusperie aboute
For whiche departed is / this lusty route
Fro Ianuarie with thank on euery side
Home to her houses / lustely they ryde
Ther as they done her thinges as hem luste
And whan they say her tyme / they go to reste
¶ Sone after that this hasty Ianuarie ¶
Wool gon to bedde / he wol no lenger tarie
He drynketh ypocras clarre and vernage
Of spices hote / to encresen his corage
And many a letuarie hadde he ful fyn
Suche as the cursed Monk daun Costantyn
Hath writen / in his book of Coitu
¶ To eten hem alle / he nas no thyng eschu
And thus to his pryue frendes saide he
For goddes love as sone / as it may be
Lat voyden al this hous / in curteys wyse sone /
Men dronken / and the trauers drawe anone
The bride was brought to bedde as stille as stoon
So hasted Ianuarie / it muste be doon
And whan that the bed was wᵗith the prest yblessed
Out of the chambre / hath euery wight hym dressed
And Ianuarie hath faste in armes take
His fresshe may / his paradys his make
He lulleth her / he cusseth her ful ofte
With thilke bristelis of his berde vnsofte
Lyk to the skyn of houndfissh / sharpe as brere
For he was shave al newe in his manere
He rubbeth hir vpon hir tendre face
And saide thus allas I moot trespace
To you my spouse / and you gretely offende
Or tyme come that I wol dou descende
But nathalees / considereth this qd he
Ther nys no workeman / what so euere he be
That may bothe wirche wel and hastely
This wol be done / at laiser parfitly
It is no fers how longe that we pleye
I trowe in wedlok ycoupled be we tweye
And blessid be the ȝok that we ben ynne
For in oure actes / we may do no synne
A man may do no synne with his wyf
Ne hurte hym self / with his owne knyf
Now we have leue to pleie vs by the lawe
¶ Thus labourth he til that the day gan dawe
And than he taketh a sop in fyn clarre ¶
And vpright in his bed / than sitteth he
And after that ful loude he song and clere
And cussed his wyf / and made wantou chere
He was al coltisshe / and ful of ragerie
And ful of girgou / as is a flekked pie
The slakke skyn / aboute his nekke shaketh
While that he sang / so chaunteth he and craketh
But god woot / what may thoughte in hir herte
Whan she hym saugh vp sittynge in his shirte
In his nyght cappe / and with nekke lene
She preiseth nouȝt his pleying worth a bene
Than saide he thus / my restyng wole I take
Now day is come I may no lenger wake
And don he leyde his heed / and sleep til prime
And afterward whan that he saugh his tyme
Vp riseth Ianuarie / but fresshe May
Holdith hir chambre / vnto the feerthe day
¶ As vsage is of wyues for the beste
For euery labour somtyme moot have reste
Or ellis longe may it nouȝt endure
This to saie no lyues creature
Be it of fissh or brid or beste or man
Now wol I speke of woful Damyan
That longoureth for loue / as ȝe shul here
Therfore I speke to hym / in this mane
¶ I say o sely Damian allas
Answere to this demaunde / as in this caas
How shaltow to thy lady fressh May
Tellen thy thought / she wol alwey sey nay
Eke if thow speke she wol the bewreye
God be thyn helpe / I can no better seye
¶ This seke Damian in venus fyre
So brenneth that he deyeth for desire
For which he putte his lyf in auenture
No lenger myghte he / in this wyse endure
But priuely / a penner gan he borowe
And in a lre wroot he al his sorowe
In man of a compleynt other alay ¶
Vnto this faire and fressh lady May
And a purs of sylk / that henge on his sherte
He hath yput / and leyd it at his herte
¶ The mone that none was / that ilke day
That Ianuarie hath wedded fressh May
Out of taure was into Cancre gliden
So longe hath she in hir Chambre abiden
As custume is vnto thise nobles alle
A bride shal not eten in the halle
¶ Til dayes foure / or thre dayes atte leste
Y passed ben / than lete go to feste
The ferthe day complete fro noon to noon
Whan that the high masse was ydoon
In halle sit this Ianuarie and May
As fressh as is the bright somes day
And so bifel how that this goode man
Remembreth hym vpon this Damian
And seide seint Marie / how this bee
That Damian entendeth nought to me
Is he ay seke / or how may it betide
His Squyers / whiche that stoden hym beside
Excusynge hym / by cause of syknesse
Whiche that lettith hym / to done his besynesse
Noon other cause myght make hym care
That me forthynketh quod this Ianuare
He is a gentil Squyer by my trouthe
Ȝif that he deide it were harme and routhe
He is a wys discrete and secree
As eny man I woot of his degree
And therto manly and eke seruisable
And forto ben a man thrifty and right able
And after mete / as sone as I eủere may
I wol my self / visite hym / and eke May
To don hym al the confort that I can
And for that worde hym blessed eủery man
That of his bounte / and of his gentilnesse
He wolde so conforten hym in his sykenesse
His Squyer forto visite / it was a gentil dede ¶
Dame quod thus Ianuare take hede
That after mete / ȝe with youre women alle
Whan ye han ben in Chambre out of this halle
That alle ye goon to see this Damian
Doth hym disport / he is a gentil man
And tellith hym / that I wol hym visite
Have I no thyng / but rested me alite
Now with that worde / he gan to hym calle
A Squyer that was Marchal of his halle
And tolde hym certayn thynges what he wolde
This fresshe may hath streight hir way yholde
With alle hir women vnto this Damian
Doon by his beddes syde / sat she than
Confortynge hym / as goodely as she may
This Damian whan that he hys tyme say /
In secre wyse / his purs and eke the bille
In whiche that he writen hadde his wille
Hat put into hir hond / withoute more
Sauf that he siked wonderly sore
And softely to hir / right thus saide he
Mercy / and that ȝe discoủere nouȝt me
For I am ded ȝif / that this thing be kid
Thus purs hath she / within hir bosom hid
And wente hir way / ȝe gete no more of me
But vnto Ianuarie / ycomen is she
And on his beddes syde / sitteth ful softe
He taketh hir and cusseth hir ful ofte
And leyde hym dou to slepe / and that anon
She feyned hir as that she muste goon
Ther as ye woot that eủery wight moot nede
And whan she of this bille hath taken hede
She rente it al to cloutes atte laste
And in the priue softly she it caste
¶ Who studieth now / but faire fressh may
And a dou by Ianuarie she lay
That sleep til that the coughe hath hym awaked
Anoon he prayed hir to strepen hir al naked
He wolde of hir he saide have som plesance ¶
He seide hir clotles dide hym encombrance
And she obeyeth be she leef or loth
But lest that pcious folk be with me wroth
How that he wrouȝte / I dar to you not telle
Or wheither that he thouȝte / on paradys or on helle
But I lete hem worthe / in her wyse
Til euensong rynge / and that they muste aryse
Were it by destyne / or by auenture
Were it by influence / other by nature
Or in constellaciou / that in suche estate
The heuene stood / that tyme fortunate
Was forto putte a bille of venus werkes
For al thyng hath tyme / as seyn the clerkes
To eny woman / forto gete hir loue
I can not say / but the grete god aboue
That knoweth / that noon acte is causeles
He demeth of alle / for I wol holde my pees
But soth is this / how that this fressh May
Hath taken suche impssion that day
Of pite / of this syke Damian
That fro hir herte / she ne dryue can
The remembrance / forto done hym ese
Certayn thouȝt she whom / that this thyng displese
I rekke nouȝt for to here I am assure
To loue hym best of eny creature
Though he no more hadde than his sherte
Lo pite renneth sone / in gentil herte
Heere may ye se / how excellent fraunchise
In woman is / whan they narwe hem auyse
So tyraunt ther is / as ther ben many oon
That hath an herte as hard as eny stoon
Whiche wolde han lete hym sterue in the place
Wel rather than have graunted hym that gᵃce
And hem reioysen in her cruel pride
And recche nought / to ben an homicide
This gentil May / fulfilled of al pite
Right so of hir owne hand / a lre made she
In which she graunteth hym of hir verray gᵃce ¶
Ther lacketh nouȝt / but only day and space /
Where that she myght / to his lust to suffise
For it shal ben right / as he wol deuise
And whan she saugh hir tyme vpon a day
To visite this Damian / goth faire May
And subtily this lre dou she thriste
Vnder his pilwe / rede it ȝif hym liste
She taketh hym by the honde / and harde hym twiste
So secretly / that no wight it wiste
And bad hym ben al hool / and forthe she wente
To Ianuarie whan that he for hir sente
Vp riseth Damian / the nexte morowe
Al passed was his sekenes and his sorowe
He kembeth hym / and proigneth hym and pyketh
He doth al that his lady lust and leketh
And eke to Ianuarie he goth as lowe
As eủere dide a dogge for the bowe
He is so plesant to euery man
For craft is al who that it can
That euery wight is fayn to teche hym good
And fully in his lady grace he stood
Thus lete I Damian / aboute his nede
And in my tale / forth wol I procede
Some clerkes holden that felicite
Stant in delite / and therfore he
This noble Ianuarie with al his myght
In honest wyse / as longeth to a knyght
Shoop hym to lyue / ful deliciously
His housyng / his array al honestely
To his degre was maked as a kynges
Amonge other of his honest thynges
He hadde a gardeyn / walled al wᵗith stoon
So faire a gardeyn / woot I nowher noon
For out of doute / I verrayly suppose
That he that wroot the romance of the rose
Ne couthe of it / the beaute wel deuise
Ne priapus ne myght nouȝt suffise
Though he be god of gardeynes forto telle ¶
The beaute of the gardeyn and of the welle
That stood vnder a laurer alweye grene
Ful oft tyme / kyng pluto and his queene
Proserpina / and al hir fareye
Disporten ham / and maken melodye
Aboute that welle / and daunsed as men tolde
This noble knyght / this Ianuarie the olde
Suche deynte hath in it to walken and to pleye
That he wol suffre noo wight to bere the keye
Sauf he hym self / for of the smal wyket
He bare alwey of syluer a clyket
Which the whiche / whan that hym lust vnshette
And whan that he wolde paie his wyf his dette
In a somer sesou / thider wolde he go
And May his wyf and no wyght but they two
And thynges whiche that were not done abedde
They in the gardeyne / ꝑparformed han and spedde
And in this wyse / mery a mery a day
Lyued this Ianuarie / and fressh May
But worldly ioye / may not alwey endure
To Ianuarie / ne to no worldly creature
¶ O sodeyn hap / o thow fortune vnstable
Lyke to the scorpiou variable
That flaterest wᵗith thyn hede / whan thou wilt stynge
Thy tayl is deth / thurgh thyn enuenymynge
O brotel ioye / o swete poison queynte
O Muster that subtily canst peynte
Thy ȝiftes vnder the hewe of stifastnesse
That thou deceyuedest / bothe more and lasse
Why hastow Ianuarie / thus deceyued
And haddest hym for thy ful frende receyued
And now thou hast birafte hym bothe his eyen
For sorwe of whiche / desireth he to deyen
Allas this noble Ianuarie / that is so free
Amidde his lust / and his prosꝑperite /
Is woxen blynd / and al sodeinly
His deth therfore / desireth he outerly
And ther with al / the fyre of Ialousie ¶
Lest that his wyf / sholde falle in some folie
So brente his herte / that he wolde fayn
That som man / bothe hir and hym hadde slayn
For neủere after his deth / ne in his lyf
Ne wolde he / that she were loue ne wyf
But euere lyue / as a wodewe in clothes blake
Soul as the turtul doth that hath lost hir make
But atte / laste after a monthe or tweye
His sorwe gan to swage / soth to seye /
For whan he wiste it myghte noon other be
He paciently took his aduersite
Sauf oute of doute / may he nouȝt forgon
That he nas ialous / eủermore in on
Which ialousie it was so outrageous
That neither in halle / ne in noon other hous
He nolde suffre hir forto ryde nor go
Ne in noon other place neuer the mo
But ȝif that he hadde hond on hir alway
For whiche ful ofte wepith fressh May
That loueth Damian so benignely
That she moot eyther deye sodeinly
Or ellis she moot han hym at hir lest
She wayteth whan hir herte wolde brest
¶ Vpon that other syde Damian
Bicomen is the sorwefullest man
That eủere was / for neither nyght nor day
Ne myght he speke a word / to fresshe May
As to his purpos of no such matier
But ȝif that Ianuarie muste it here
That hadde oon hand on hir eủere mo
And nathales by wryteng to and fro
And pⁱriue signes / wiste he what she mente
And she knewe of the signe of his entente
O Ianuarie / what myght the avayle
Though thow myghtest seen / as fer as shippes sayle
For as good is al blynd deceyued bee
As to ben deceyued / whan a man may see
Lo Argus which that hadde an C eyen ¶
For al that ever he couthe poure or pryen
Ȝit was he blent / and god woot so ben mo
That wenen / wisly that it is nouȝt so
Passe over is an ese / I say no more
This fressh May / of whiche I spak of ȝore
In warme wax hath enpreented this clyket
That Ianuarie bar of that smal wyket
By whiche into his gardeyn ofte he wente
And Damian / that knewe hir entente
The cliked countrefeted pryuely
Ther nys noo more to say but hastely
Som wonder by this clyket shal be tyde
Whiche ȝe shul here / ȝif ye wol abyde
¶ O noble Ouide / soth saist thou god woot
What sleighte is it / though it be longe and hoot
That he nyl fynde it out in some mane
By Pyramus and Thesbe may men lere
Though they were kepte ful longe and streete oủer al
They ben accordet rownynge thurgh a wal
Ther is no wyght that couthe han founde suche a sleighte
But now to purpos / er that dayes eyghte
Were passed / or the monthe of Iuyl befil
That Ianuarie / hath caught so gret a wil
Thurgh eggyng of his wyf hym forto pleye
In his gardeyn / and no wight but they tweye
That in a morowe / vnto his May saide he
Ryse vp my wyf / my loue / my lady fre /
The turtelles voys / is herde / my dowve swete
The wynter is goon / with alle his reynes wete
Come forth now with thyn eyen columbyne
How faire ben thy brestes / that is wyne
The gardeyn is closed al aboute
Come forth my whyte spouse / out of doute
That hast me wounded / in my herte o wyf
No spotte in the / nas in the al thy lyf
Come forth / and late vs taken oure disport
I chees the for my wyf and my confort
Suche olde lewed wordes / vsed he ¶
On Damian / a signe made she
That he shulde go bifore / with his clyket
This Damian / hath opened the wyket
And in he sterte / and that in suche manere
That noo wight / myghte it se ne here
And stil he sitte / vnder a bussh anoon
This Ianuarie / as blynd as is a stoon
With Mayus in his hande / and no wight mo
Into the fressh gardeyn / is he go
And clapte to the wyket sodeynly
Now wyf quod he / here ne is but thou and I
That art the creature / that I best loue
For by that lord / that sitte vs alle aboue
I hadde lever dyen on a knyf
Than the offenden / dere trewe wyf
For goddes sake / thenke how I the chees
Nouȝt for no couetise / doutlees
But only for the loue / I hadde to the
And though that I be olde / and may not see
Be to me trewe / and I wol telle you why
Certes thre thynges / shul ȝe wynne ther by
First love of crist / and to youre self honour
And in al myn herytage / toun and tour
I ȝeve it you / maketh charters as you leste
This shal be done to morowe / er sonnes reste
So wysly god / my soule brynge in blysse
And I pray you on counenᵘnt / that ye me kisse
And though that I be ialous / wyte me nouȝt
Ȝe be so depe / enprented in my thouȝt
That whan I considere / youre beaute
And ther with al / the vnlyklyhede of me
I may nouȝt certes / though I shulde dye
For bere to been / out of youre companye
For verrey loue / this is withoute doute
Now kis me wyf / and lete vs rome aboute
¶ This fressh May / whan she thise wordes herde
Benignely / to Ianuarie answerde
But first and forward / she bigan to wepe
I have / quod she / a soule forto kepe
As wel as ye / and also myn honour
And of my wyfhode / thylke tender flour
Which that I have / assured in youre hand
Whan that the prest / to you my body band
Wherfore I wol answere / in this manere
With leue of you / my lorde so dere
I pᵃy to god / that neủer dawe that day
That I ne sterue / as foule as woman may
Ȝif eủere I do / vnto my kynne that shame
Or ellis so I empeyre my name
That I be fals / and ȝif I do that lak
Do stripe me and pitte me in a sak
And in the next ryuere do me drenche
I am a gentil woman / and no wenche
Why speke ye thus / but men been eủere vntrewe
And women have repreef / of you ay newe
Ȝe can noon other countenance / I leue
But speke to vs / as vntriste and repreue
And with that word / she saugh where Damyan
Sat in the bussh / and knele he bigan
And with hir fynger / signes made she
That Damyan / shulde clymbe vpon a tre
That charged was wᵗith fruyt / and vp he wente
For verraily / he knewe al hir entente
And eủery signe / that she couthe make
Wel bet than Ianuarie / hir owne make
For in a lre / she hadde tolde hym al
Of this matere / how he worchen shal
And thus I lete hym / sitte in the pirie
And Ianuarie and Mayus / rownynge ful merie
¶ Bright was the day / and blewe the firmament
Phebus of gold hath dou his stremes sent
To gladen eủery flour / with his warmenesse
He was that tyme / in gemines as I gesse
But litel / fro his declinaciou
Of canser Iouis exaltaciou
And so bifel / that in a bright morowtyde
In that Gardeyn / on the ferther syde
Pluto that is the kyng of fayrye
And many a lady / in his companye
Folwyng his wyf / the queen ꝓproserpina
Which that he rauisshed out of Cecilia
Whiles that she gadred / floures in a mede
In Claudyan / ȝe may the stories rede
How in his grisly carte / he hir sette
This kyng of fayrie / a doun hym sette
Vpon a benche of turves / fressh and grene
And right anoon / seide he thus to the quene
¶ My wyf quod he / that may no wight seye nay
The exꝑperience / proveth it eủery day
The tresou / which that woman doth to man
Ten hundred thousand / tellen I can
Notable of youre vntrouthe / and brotilnesse
O Salomon richest of al richesse
Fulfilled of sapience / and of worldly glorie
Ful worthy ben thy wordes / to memorie
To euery wight / that wit and reson can
Thus preiseth he ȝit / the bounte of woman
Among a thousand men / ȝit fonde I oon
But of alle women / founde neủere noon
Thus seith this kyng / that knowith youre wyckednesse
And ihus filius Syrach / as I gesse
Ne speketh of you / but selde reủerence
A wylde fyre / a corrupte pestilence
So falle vpon youre bodies / ȝit to nyght
Ne se ȝe not / this honourable knyght
By cause allas / that he blynde and olde
His owne man / shal make hym cokewold
Lo where he sit / the lecchour in the tree
Now wol I graunte / of my magestee
Vnto this olde / blynde worthy knyght
That he shal have ageyn / his eyen sight
Whan that his wyf / wol done hym vilenye
Than shal he knowe / al her harlotrie
Bothe in repreef / of hir and other mo ¶right
Ȝe shal quod ꝓproserpyne and wole so
Now by my moders sires soule I swere
That I shal ȝeue hir / suffisant answere
And alle women / after for hir sake
That though they ben / in eny gylt ytake
With face bold / they shul hem self excuse
And bere hem dou / that wolde hem accuse
For lak of answere / noon of hem shal deyen
Al had ȝe seen a thyng / with bothe youre eyen /
Ȝit shal we so / visage it hardely
And wepe and swere / and chide subtilly
That ye shul be as lewed / as are gees
What rekketh me / of youre auctoritees /
I wote wel this Iewe / this Salomon
Fonde of vs women / foles manyoon
But though that he / fonde no good woman
Ther hath yfounde many another man
Women ful trewe / ful good ful vertuous
Witnesse of hem / that dwelle in cristes hous
With martirdome / they preved her constance
The Romayne iestes / make remembrance
Of many a verray trewe wyf also
But sire be not wroth / al be it so
Though that he seide / he fonde no good woman
I pᵃy you take / the sentence of the man
He mente thus / that in soủereyne bounte
Ne is noon but god / but neither he ne she
Ey for verrey god / that nys but oon
What make ye so moche / of Salomon
What though he made a temple / goddes hous
What though he were riche / and glorious
So made he a temple / of false goddis
Who myght do a thyng / that more forbode is
Parde as fayre / as ye his name plastre
Ȝit was he a lecchour / and an ydolastre
And in his elde / he verrey god forsook
And ȝit that god ne hadde / as seith the book
Spared hym for his faders sake / he sholde ¶
Have loste his regne / souner than he wolde
I sette nouȝt / of al the vilenye
That ye of wōmmen write / abotirflye
I am a woman / nedes mote I speke
Or ellis swelle / til myn herte breke
For sitthen he seide / that we be iangelers
As euere mote I broke / bothe my tresses
I shal not spare / for no curtesye
To speke hym harme / that wolde vs vylenye
Dame quod this pluto / be no lenger wroth
I ȝeve it vp / but sitthens I swore myn oth
That I wolde gᵃunte / hym his sight ageyn
My worde shal stande / that telle I the certeyn
I am a kyng / it sit me nouȝt to lye
And I quod she / a queen of fayrie
Hir answere she shal have I vndertake
Let vs no moo wordes / make
For soth I wol no lenger / you contᵃrie
Now lat vs turne ageyn / to Ianuarie
That in this gardeyn / wᵗith his faire May
Syngeth ful merier / than the popyniay
Ȝow loue I best / and shal / and other noon
So longe abovte the aleys / is he goon
Tyl he was come / ageyne thilke pirie
Where as this Damyan sitteth ful merie
On high amonge / the fressh leves grene
This fressh May / that is so bright and shene
Gan forto syke / and seide allas my syde
Now sire quod she / for ought that may betide
I muste have of the peres / that I see
Or I mut dye / so sore longeth me
To eten of smale peres grene
Helpe for hir love / that is heuene quene
I telle you wel / a woman in my plyte
May have to fruyt / so grete an appetyte
That she may dyen / but she it have
Allas quod he / that I ne hadde here a knave
That couthe clymbe / allas allas quod he ¶
For I am blynd / ȝe sire noo fors quod she
But wolde ye fouche sauf / for goddes sake
The pirie inwith / youre armes forto take
For wel I woot that ye mustruste me
Than sholde I clymbe / wel ynow quod she
So I my foot / myghte sette vpon youre bak
For soth seide he / in me shal be no lak
Might I you helpe with myn herte blood
He stopith doon / and on his bak she stood
And caught hir by atwyste / and vp she goth
Ladies I preye you / that ye be not wroth .
I can not glose / I am arude man
And sodeinly / anoon this Damyan
Gan pullen vp the smok / and in he throng
And whan that pluto saugh thus grete wrong
To Ianuarie / he ȝaf his sight agayn
Ne was ther neuere man / of thyng so fayn
But on his wyf his thought was eủere mo
Vp to the tree / he caste his eyen two
And saugh how Damyan / had his wif dressed
In suche mane it may not been expressed
But ȝif I wolde / speke vncurtesly
And vp he ȝaf / a roryng and a cry
As doth the Moder / whan the child shal dye
Out helpe allas / harrow he gan to crye
O stronge lady stoure what dostow
And she answereth / sire what eyleth ȝow
Have pacience and reson / in youre mynde
I have you holpen / of bothe youre eyen blynde
Vp ꝑperile of my soule / I shal not lyen
As me was thaught / to hele with youre eyen
Was no thyng bet forto make you see
Than strogle with a man / vpon a tree
God wote I dide it / in ful goode intente
Strogle quod he / algate in it wente
God ȝeve you bothe / on shames deth to deyen
He swyued the / I saugh it wᵗith myn eyen
And ellis be I honged by the hals ¶¶
Than is quod she / the medicyne fals
For certeynly / ȝif that ye myght see
Ȝe wolde not say / tho wordes vnto me
Ȝe have som glymsyng / and no ꝑparfit sight
I se quod he / as wel as eủere I myght
Thanked be god with bothe myn eyen two
And by my trought me thoughte / he dide the so
Ȝe mase mase goode sire quod she
This thanke have I for I made ȝou se
Allas quod she / that eủery I was so kynde
Now Dame quod he / lat al passe out of mynde
Come dou my wyf / and ȝif I have myssayde
God helpe me so / as I am euel apayde
But by my Fader / soule I wende have seyn
How that this Damyan / had by the leyn
And that thy smok / had leyn vpon his brest
Ȝe sire quod she / ȝe may wene / as you lest
But sire a man / that waketh out of his slepe
He may not sodeinly / wel take kepe
Vpon a thyng / and sen it ꝑparfytely
Til that he be / adawed verreily
Right so a man / that longe hath blynde ybe
Ne may not sodeinly / so wel se
First whan he sight / is newe come ageyn
As he that hath / a day or two yseyn
Til that youre sighte / stabled be a whyle
Ther may ful many a sighte you begyle
Beth war I pray you / for by heuene kyng
Ful many man weneth / forto se a thyng
And it is al / another / than it semeth
He that mysconceyueth / mysdemeth
And with that worde / she leep dou fro the tree
This Ianuarie / who is gladde but he
He kisseth hir / and clippeth hir ful ofte
And on hir wombe / he stroketh hir ful softe
And to his paleys / home he hath hir lad
Now goode men / I pray you to be glad
Thus endeth here my tale of Ianuarie ¶¶
God blesse vs / and his Moder seynt Marie
¶ Thus endeth the Marchantes tale / ¶ Prologus
¶ And bigynneth the prologe of the goode Wyf of Bathe / ¶ prologus
Exꝑperience though noon auctorite
Were in this world / is right ynow for me
To speke of wo / that is in mariage
For lordynges / syn I was twelue ȝere of age
Thanked be god / that is et̉erne a lyue
Housbandes / at the chirche dore / I have had fyue
Ȝif I so ofte / myghte have wedded be
But alle were worthy men / in her degre
But me was tolde / certeyn nouȝt longe agoon is
That sitthe that criste wente neủere but onys
To weddeng in the Cane of galile
That by thilke ensaumple tauȝte he me
That I ne sholde wedde me but ones
Herke eek loo / which a sharp word for the nones
Biside a welle / Ihu god and man
Spak in repreef / of the Samaritan
Thow hast yhad / fyue housbandes quod he
And that ilke man that now hath the
Is not thyn housbonde thus saide he certayn
What he mente therby / I can not sayn
Wel but that I aske / why that the fifte man
Was not housbonde / to the Samaritan
How many myght she / han in mariage
Ȝit herde I never telle in myn age
Vpon this nombre / diffiniciou
Men may devyne and glosen vp and dou
But wel I wote expresse / withoute lye
God bad vs forto wexe / and multiplie
That gentil text can I wel vnderstande
Eke wel I wote / he saide myn housbonde
Sholde lete Fader and Moder / and take to me
But of no nombre / menciou made he
Of bygamye / or of octogamye
Why shulde men / than say of it vilenye
Loke here the wise man / kyng Salamo
I trowe that he hadde / wyues mo than on
Now wolde god / it leeful were to me
To be refresshed / half so ofte as he
Whiche yifte of god / had he for alle his wyues
No man hath suche / that yn this world alyue is
God woot this noble kyng / as to my witte
The first nyght / had many a mery fitte
With eche of hem / so wel was hym a lyue
Blessed be god / that I have wedded fyue
Welcome the sixte / whan that ever he shal
For sithe I may not kepe me chast in al
Whan myn housbande is fro the world agon
Sum cristen man shal wedde me anon
For than the Apostil / seith that I am fre
To wedde a goddes halue / where that lyketh me
He saith that to be wedded / is no synne
Betre is to be wedded / than to brenne
What rekketh me / though folk sey vilenye
Of shrewed lameth and bygamye
I woot wel Abraam was an holy man
And Iacob eke as fer as eủere I can
And eche of hem had wyues mo than two
And many another holy man also
Where can ȝe say / in eny mane age
That the high god / defended mariage
By expresse word / I pᵃy you telleth me
Or where cōmmaunded he virgynyte
I woot as wel as ye / it is noo drede
The Apostil / whan he speketh of Maydenhede /
He saide that pcept ther of hadde he noon
Men may conseile / a woman to be oon
But counseillyng is no cōmmaundement
He putte it / in oure owne iugement
For had god / cōmmaunded maydenhede
Than had he dampned / weddyng wᵗith the dede
And certes ȝif ther were / no seed ysowe
Virgynyte than / wher of shulde it growe
Poule durste nouȝt / cōmmaunden at the lest
A thyng / of which his Maist / ȝaf hym non heste
The darte is set vp / for virginite
Chace who so may / who renneth best lat see
But this worde is nouȝt / take of euery wyght
But there as god wolde / ȝeve it of his myght
I woot wel / that the Apostel / was a mayde
But nathalees / though that he wrote and saide
He wolde that euery wyght / were such as he
Al nys but counsel / to virgynyte
And forto be a wyf / he ȝaf me leve
Of indulgence / so is it noo repreve
To wedde me / ȝif that my make dye
Withoute excepciou / of Bygamye
Al were it good / no woman forto touche
He mente as in his bed / or in his couche
For ꝑperile is bothe / fir and tow tassemble
Ȝe knowe what / this cause may resemble
This is al and sum / he heeld virgynyte
More ꝑparfite / than weddyng in frelte /
Frelte clepe I not but that he and she
Wolde lede hir lyf / al in chastite
I graunte it wel / I have non envye
Though mayndenhede / pferre bygamye
It lyketh hem to be clene / in body and gost
Of myn astate / I wol make noo bost
For wel ȝe knowe / a lord in his houshold
Hath not eủery vessel of gold
Some ben of tree / and done her lord ʆseruice
God clepeth folk / to hym / in sundry wyse
And eủery hath / of god a propre ȝifte
Some this some that / as hym lyketh shifte
Virginite is greet ꝑperfecciou
And contynence eke / with deuociou
¶ But crist that of ꝑperfecciou is welle
Bad not eủery wight / that he shulde selle
Al that he hadde / and ȝeue it to the pore
And in suche wyse / folwe hym and his lore
He spak to hem that wolde lyue ꝑparfytel
And lordynges by youre leue that am not I
I wol bistowe / the floure of al myn age
In charite / and fruyt of mariage
Tel me also / to what conclusiou
Were membres made / of generaciou
And so ꝑparfite wyse / and why ywrought
Tristeth right wel / they were not made for nouȝt
Glose who so wole / and seye bothe vp and dou
They were made / for purgaciou
Of vryne / and oure bothe thynges smale
Were made to knowe / a femal from a male /
And for non other cause / what sey ȝe no
Exꝑperience / woot it is not so
So that ye clerkes / be not with me wrouthe
I sey that they / ymaked be for bothe
This is to seye / for office and for ese
Of engendrure / ther we not god displese
Why shulde men ellis in hir bokes sette
That man shal ȝelde / to his wyf his dette
Now wher with shulde he / make his paiement
Ȝif that he ne vsed / his sely instument
Than were they made / vpon a creature
To purge vryne / and eke for engendrure
But I sey not / that eủery wight is holde
That hath suche harneis / as I to yow tolde
To goon and vsen hem / in engendrure
Than shulde men take of chastite no cure
Crist was a mayden / and shapen as a man
And many a seynt / syn that the worlde bigan
Ȝit lyued they euere / in ꝑparfite chastite
I wol enuye / with no virgynyte
Late hem ete brede / of pured whete seed
And late vs wyues ete barly breed
And ȝit wᵗith barly breed / Marc telle can
Oure lorde Ihu / refresshed many a man
In suche astate / as god hath cleped vs
I wol ꝑperserue I am not precious
In wyfhode / wol I vse myn instrumen
As frely as my maker / hath it me sent
Ȝif I be dangerous / god ȝeve me sorowe
Myn husbond shal it have / bothe eue and morowe
What that hym liste / come forth and paie his dette
An husbonde I wol have / I wol not lette
Whiche shal be bothe / my dettour and my thral
And have his tribulacion with al
Vpon his flessh / whyle that I am his wyf
I have the power / duryng al my lyf
Vpon his propre body / and not he
¶ Right thus the Apostel / tolde vnto me
And bad oure husbondes / forto love vs wel
Al this sentence / me lyketh eủerydel
Up stirte the Pardoner / and that anoon
Now dame qd he / by god and by seynt Iohn
Ȝe ben a noble pchour / in this cas
I was aboute to wedde a wyf allas
What shulde I bye it / on my flessh so dere
Ȝit have I leủere wedde noo wyf to ȝere
A byde qd she / my tale is not bygonne
Nay thow shalt drynke / of a nother tonne
Or that I go / shal sauoure worse than ale
And whan that I have / tolde forth my tale
Of tribulacion in mariage
Of which I am expert / in al myn age
This is to say my self hath ben the whippe
Than mayst thow chese / whider that thou wilt skippe
Thilke tonne that I shal abroche
Be ware therfore / or thow to nygh approche
For I shal telle ensamples / mo than ten
Who so that wol not be ware / by other men
By hym shulle other men corrected be
This same worde / writeth ꝑpartholome
Rede in his almageste / and take it there
Dame I wol pray ȝow / ȝif ȝoure wille were
Seyde this ꝑpardoner / as ȝe bigan
Telle fourth ȝoure tale / spare for no man
And teche vs ȝonge men / of youre practike
Gladly quod she / sithe it may ȝow lyke
But that I pray / to al this company
Ȝif that I speke / after my fantasy
As taketh not a greef / of that I seye
For myn entente is / not but for to pleye
Now sires than shal I telle you my tale
As euere mote I drynke wyn or ale
I shal seye sothe / tho housbandes / that I hadde
As thre of hem were goode / and two were badde
The thre were goode men / and riche and olde
Vnnethe myghte they / the statute holde
In whiche they were / bounde vnto me
Ȝe woot wel / what I mene / of this parde
As helpe me god / I lawȝe / whan I thynke
How pitousely / a nyght / I made hem swynke
But by me fay / I tolde of it no store
They hadde me ȝeue / her londe and her tresore
Me neded nought / do lenger diligence
To wynne her love / and do hem reủerence
They loved me so wel / by god above
That I ne tolde / no deynte of her love
A wys woman / wol besie hir eủere in oon
To gete hir loue / ȝee there she hath noon
But sitthe I had hem / holy in myn hand
And that they hadde / ȝeue to me her land
What shulde I take kepe / hem forto plese
But ȝif it were / myn ꝓprofit and myn ese
But I sette hem so a werke / by my fay
That many a nyght / they sunge wele away
The bacon was not / fette for hem I trowe
That some men have / in Essex at Donmowe
I goủerned hem / so wel after my Lawe
That eche of hem / ful blisful was and fawe
To brynge me gay thynges / fro the feyre
Knyues and rynges / and purses ful feyre
For god it woot / I chidde hem spitusely
Now herkeneth / how I bar me ꝓpropirly
Ȝe wise wyues / that can wel vnderstand
Thus shulde ȝe speke / and bere hem wrong in hande
For half so boldely / ther can noo man
Swere and lye / as a woman can
I say not thus / by wyves that ben wyse
But it be whan that they hem misauise
¶ A wys wyf shal / ȝif that she can hir goode
Bere hym on honde / how that the kowe is woode
And take witnesse / of hir owne Mayde
Of hir assente / but herkeneth how I sayde
Sir olde Caynard / is this thyn aray
Why is my neighbores wyf so gay
She is honoured / oủeral where she goth
I sitte at home / I have no thrifty cloth
What dostow / at my neighbores hous
Is she so faire art thow so amerous
What rowne ȝe wᵗith oure mayde / ey benedicite
Sir olde lecchour / lat thy iapes be
And ȝif I have / a gossib or a frende
Withoute gilt ȝe chiden as a feende
Ȝif that I walke or pley vnto his hous
Thow comest home / as dronken as a mous
And prechest on thy benche with evel preef
Thou saist to me / it is a greet mescheef
To wedde a pore woman for costage
And ȝif that she be riche of grete ꝑparage
Than saist thou that it is a tormentrie
To suffre hir pride / and hir malyncolye
And ȝif that she be faire thou verray knave
Thou saist that eủery holour wol hir have
She may no while in chastite abide
That is assayled vpon eche a side
Thow seist some folk desire vs for richesse
Some for oure shap and some for oure fairenesse
And some for that she can / outher synge or daunce
Thus seistow wernard / god ȝeve the mischaunce
Some for her handes and her armes smale
Thus goth al to the deuel / by thy tale
Thou seist men may not kepe a castel wal
It may so longe assayled ben oủeral
And ȝif she be foul / thou seist that she
Coueiteth eủery man / that she may se
For as a spaynel / she wol on hym lepe
Til that she fynde / som man hir to chepe
Ne noon so grey goos / goth ther by the lake
As seist thou / that wol be withoute a make
And seist it is / an hard thyng forto welde
A wight that no man / wole his thankes helde
Thus seistow lorel / whan thou gost to bedde
And that no wys man / nedeth forto wedde
Ne no man / that entendeth to the heuene
With wylde thonder dent / and firy leuene
Mote thy welked nekke / be to broke
Thow seist that droppynge houses / and eke smoke
And chydynge wyves / maken men to fle
Out of her owne houses / a benedicite
What eyleth suche an olde man / forto chyde
Thow seist we wyves / wole oure vices hyde
Til we be faste / and than wole we hem shewe
Wel may this be / a proverbe of a shrewe
Thow seist that oxen assen horses and houndes
They ben assayd / at dyủerse stoundes
Bacyns lauours / or that men hem bye
Spones stoles / and such housbondrye
And so ben pottes clothes / and othere arayes
But of women / are maked noon assayes
Til they be wedded / olde dotard shrewe
And seist how than / we wole oure vices shewe
Thow seist also / that it displeseth me
But ȝif thou wilt preise / my beaute
And but thou poure / alwey vppon my face
And clepe me faire Dame / in eủery place
And but thou make a feste / on thilke day
That I was born / and make me fressh and gay
And but thou do / to my norice honour
And to my Chambrer / wᵗithynne my bour
And to my fadres folk / and his alye
Thus seistow olde barel / ful of lyes
And ȝit of oure Appntys Iankyn
For his crispe heer / shynyng as gold fyn
And for he squyereth me / bothe vp and dou
Ȝit hastow cauȝt / a fals suspeciou
I wol hym nouȝt / though thow were ded to morowe
But telle me this / why hydest thou with sorowe
The keyes of thy cheste / awey fro me
It is my good / as wel as thyn ꝑparde
What wenestow make / an ydiot of oure dame
Now by that lorde / that called is seynt Iame
Thow shalt not bothe / though thou were wood
Be mayster / of my body / and of my good
That oon thou shalt forgo / maugre thyn eyen
What helpeth it of me / to enquere or spyen
I trowe þou woldest / loke me in thy cheste
Thow shuldest seye / wyf go where you leste
Take youre disport / I wol leue noo tales
I knowe you for a goode wyf Dame Alis
We loue no man / that taketh keepe or charge
Where that we go / we wol be at oure large
Of alle men / blessed mote he be
The wyse Astrologen / Daun ptolome
That seith this ꝓprouerbe / in his Almageste
Of alle men / his wisdam is the hyeste
That rekketh not who hath the world in hande
By this ꝓproủerbe / thou shalt wel vnderstande
Have thou ynow / what dar the rekke or care
How meryly / other folkes fare
For certes olde Dotard / by youre leue
Ȝe shul have queynte / right ynogh at eue
He is a greet nygard / that wol werne
A man to lighte a candel at his lanterne
He shal have / neủere the lasse light parde
Have thou ynogh / the thar not pleyne the
¶ Thou seist also / that ȝif thou make vs gay
With clothyng or with pcious array
That it is a ꝑperile / of oure chastite
And ȝit with wordes / thou must enforce me
And sey thise wordes / in the Apposteles name
In abite made / with chastite and shame
Ȝe women shulde apparaile you / quod he
And not in tressed heer / and gay perre
As perle / ne wᵗith gold / ne clothes riche
After thy text / ne after thy rubriche
I wol not wirche / as moche as a gnat
Thou saist also / that I was lyk a cat
But who so wolde / senge a cattes skyn
Than wolde the cat / wel dwellen in his In
And ȝif the cattes skyn / be slyke and gay
She wol not dwelle in house / half a day
But forth she wole / or eny day be dawed
To shewe hir skyn / and go a caterwawed
This is to say / ȝif I be gay sir shrewe
I wol renne ouut my berel forto shewe
Sir olde fool / what helpeth the to spyen
Though thou preye argus / wᵗith his hundred eyen
To be my wardecorps / as he can best
In feith he shal not kepe me / but ȝif me liste
Ȝit couthe I make his his berde / so mote I the
Thou seist eke / that ther be thynges thre
The whiche thynges / troublen al this erthe
And that no wight / may endure the ferthe
O leue ʆsir shrewe / Ihu short thy lyf
Ȝit pchest thou / and seist an hateful wyf
Y rekened is / for oon of thise mischaunces
Be ther none other resemblaunces
That ye may lykne / youre ꝑparables to
But ȝif a sely wyf / be oon of tho
Thou liknest womans loue / to helle
To bareyne lond / ther water may not dwelle
Thou liknest it also / to wylde fyre
The more it brenneth / the more it hath desire
To consume eny thyng / that brent wol be
Thou seist that right as wormes / shende a tre
Right so a wyf / destroieth hir housband
Lordynges right thus / as ye have vnderstande
Bar I stifly / my olde husbandes on hande
That thus they seide / in her dronkenesse
And eke that he hadde / suspeciou and Ialousnesse
Of Iankyn / and of my necyte also
O lorde the peyne I dide hem / and the wo
Ful gilteles / by goddes swete pyne
For as an hors I couthe bothe bite and whyne
I couthe pleyne and I was in the gilt
Or ellis ofte tyme I had be spilt
Who so first to mylle cometh / first grint
I pleyne first so was oure werre stynt
They were ful glade to excusen hem ful blyue
Of thyng of whiche / they agilte neủere her lyue
Of wenches wolde I beren hem on honde
Whan that for syke vnnethe they myghte stonde
Ȝit tikelid I his herte for that he
Wende I had of hym so greet chierte
I swore that al my walkyng by nyghte
Was forto aspie wenches that he dyghte
Vnder that colour had I many a merthe
For al such thyng / was ȝeue vs in oure berthe
Deceite wepyng spynnyng god hath ȝeve
To woman kyndely while that she may leve
And thus of oo thyng I auaunte me
At the ende I had the best in eche degre
By sleigthe byforce or by some man̉ere thyng
As by contynuel murmoᵘur or grucchyng
Namely a bedde had he meschaunce
There wolde I chide and do hem no plesaunce
I wolde no lenger in the bed abide
Ȝif that I felte his arme over my syde
Til he had made his raunson to me
Than wolde I suffre hym done his nycete
And therfore to eủery man / this tale I telle
Wynne who so may / for al is forto selle
With empty hand men may none haukys lure
For wynnyng wolde I / al his lust endur
And make a feyned / appetite
And ȝit in bacon / had I neủere delite
That made me / that eủere I wolde hem chyde
For though the pope / had seten hym besyde
I wolde not spare hym / at his owne bord
For by my trouthe / I quyte hem eủery word
As helpe me verray god / omnipotent
Though I righ now / shulde make my testament
I ow him not a word / that it nys quit
I brouȝte it so aboute / by my wyt
That he muste ȝeve it vp / as for the beste
Or ellis had we / neủere ben in reste
For though he loked / as a lyoıı̄un
Ȝit shulde he fayle / of his conclusiou
Than wolde I seye / good leef take kepe
How mekely loketh / wilkyn oure shepe
Come nere my spouse lat me ba thy cheke
Ȝe shulde be al pacient and meke
And have a swete spiced conscience
Syn ȝe so preche of Iobes pacience
Suffreth alwey syn ȝe so wel can preche
And but ȝe done certayne we shal you teche
That it is faire to have a wyf in pees
Oon of vs mot bowe doutelees
And sitthe a man / is more resonable
Than woman is / sire ȝe muste be suffrable
What eyleth you to grucche thus and grone
Is it for ye wolde have my queynte allone
Whi take it al / lo have it eủerydel
Petir I shrewe ȝow / but ȝe love it wel
For ȝif I wolde / selle my bele chose
I couthe walke as fressh as a rose
But I wol kepe it / for youre owne tothe
Ȝe be to blame / by god I say you sothe
¶ Suche man̉ere wordes / had we on honde
Now wol I speke of my ferth husbonde
My ferth husbonde was a reuelour
This is to say / he had a paramou
And was yong / and ful of ragerie
Stiborne and strong / and ioly as a pie
How couthe I daunce / to an harpe smale
And synge iwis / as any nyghtyngale
Whan I had drounke / a draught of swete wyn
Methellius the foule cherle the swyn
That with a staf / brafte his wyf here lyf
For she dranke wyn / though I had ben his wyf
Ne shulde he nouȝt / have daunted me of drynke
And after wyn on venus muste I thynke
For also siker / as cold engendreth hayle
A lykerous mowth / muste have a lykerous tayle
In woman vynolent / is no defence
This knowe lecchours / by exꝑperience
But lorde crist whan it remembreth me
Vpon my ȝouthe and my iolyte
It tikeleth me / aboute myn herte rote
Vnto this day / it doth myn herte bote
That I have had my world / as in my tyme
But age allas that al wilt envenyme
Hath me biraft my beaute and my pith
Lat go farewel / the devel go ther with
The floure is goon ther is no more to telle
The bren as I best can now muste I selle
But ȝit to be right merye wol I fonde
Now forth to telle of my ferthe husbonde
I sey I had / in herte grete dispite
That he of eny other had delite
But he was quit by god and by seynt Iose
I made hym of the same wode a crose
Not of my body in no foule man̉ere
But certeynely I made folk suche chere
That in his owne grece I made hym frye
For anger / and for verray ialousye
By god in erthe / I was his purgatorie
For whiche I hope / his soule be in glorie
For god it woot he sat ful ofte and song
Whan that his sho / ful bitterly hym wron
For ther was noon / but god and he that wiste
In many wyses / how bitterly I hym twiste
He dyed whan I come home / fro Ierusalem
And lyth ygraven / vnder the rode beem
Al is his tumbe / not so curious
As was the sepulcre / of him darius
Which that Appelles / wroughte subtily
It nere but wast / to burye hym pciously
Late hym fare wel / god ȝeue his soule reste
He is now in his graue / and in his cheste /
Now of my fifte husbonde / wol I telle
God late neủere his soule / come in helle
And ȝit was he to me / the moste shrewe
That fele I on my ribbes / al by rewe
And euere shal / vnto myn endyng day
But in oure bed / he was so fressh and gay
And ther with al / so wel couthe he me glose
Whan that he wolde have / my belechose
That though he had / me bete eủery bon
He couthe wynne / ageyn my loue anon
I trowe I loued hym / the bet for he
Was of his loue / daungerous to me
We wōmmen have / ȝif that I shal nat lye
In this man̉ere / a queynte fantasye
Wayte what thyng / we may not lightly have
Ther after wol we / crie alday and craue
Forbede vs thyng / and that desiren we
Prese on vs faste / and than wol we fle
With daunger oute we / al oure chaffare
Greet prees at Market / maketh dere ware
And to greet chepe / is holden at lytel prys
Thus knoweth eủery woman / that is wys
¶ My fifte husbonde / god his soule blesse
Whiche that I toke / for loue / and no richesse
He sumtyme was / a clerk of Oxenforde
And had left scole / at wente at home to borde
With my gossyb / dwellynge in oure tou
God have her soule / hir name was Aliso
She knewe myn herte / and al my pryuyte
Better than oure prest / so mote I the
To here bewryed I my counseil al
For had myn husbondman / pissed vpon a wal
Or done a thyng that sholde haue cost his lyf
To hir and to another worthy wyf
And to my Nece whiche I love wel
I wolde have tolde / his conseil eủerydel
And so I dide ful ofte / god it woot
That made his face / oft rede and hoot
For verray shame / and blamed hym self for he
Had tolde me / so grete a pryuyte
And so it bifel / that ones in a lente
So ofte tyme / I to my gossib wente
For eủere ȝit / I loued to be gay
And forto walke / in march Aủerel and May
Fro hous to hous to herkene sundry tales
That Iaynkyn clerk and my gossib Dame Alys
And I my self / into the feldes wente
My husbonde was at londou al that lente
I had the better leyser forto pleye
And forto se / and eke forto seye
Of folke / what wiste I where my gᵃce
Was shapen forto be / or in what place
Therfore made I my visitacions
To vigilies and to processions
To prechynge eke and to thise pilgrimages
To pleyes of myracles and to mariages
And wered vpon my gaye scarlet gytes
These wormes / ne thise mothes ne thise mytes
Vpon my ꝑperile / they frette hem neủere adel
And wost thou why for they were vsed wel
¶ Now wole I telle forth what happed me
I say that in the feldes / walked we
Til trewely / we had such daliaunce
This clerk and I / that of my purueance
I spak tm and sayde how that he
Yif I widewe / he shulde wedde m
For certeynly / I sey for no bobaunce
Ȝit was I neủere / withoute purueance
Of mariage / ne of other thynges eek
I holde a mouses herte not worth a leek
That hath but oon hole / forto stirte to
And ȝif that fayle / than is al ydo
¶ But now sire lat me se / what shal I seyn
A ha by god / I have my tale ageyn
Whan that my ferthe husbande / was on bere
I weep algate and made sory chere
As wyves moten / for it is vsage
And with my coủerchief couered my visage
But that I was purveyed of a make
I weep but litel and that I vndertake
To chirche was my husbonde yborn on morowe
With neighbours / that for hym made sorowe
And Iankyn oure clerk was oon of tho
As helpe me god whan that I saugh hym go
After the bere / me thought he had a payre
Of legges and feet so clene and fayre
That al myn herte / I ȝaf vnto his holde
He was I trowe twenty wynter olde
And I was fourty ȝif that I shal say sothe
But ȝit I hadde alwey a coltes tothe
Gad tothed I was and that bicam me wel
I hadde the prente of seynt venus seel
As helpe me god / I was a lusty oon
And faire and riche and yong ⁊and wel begon
And trewely as myn husbondes tolde me
I hadde the best quoniam that myghte be
Myn ascendent was taure and Mars therynne
Allas Allas that eủere loue was synne
I folwed ay myn inclynaciou
By vertue of my constellaciou
That made me / I couthe nat withdrawe
My chambre of venus / fro a good felawe
What shulde I say / but at the monthes ende
This ioly Clerk / Iankyn that was so hend
Hath wedded me / with grete solempnite
And to hym ȝaf I / al the land and fee
That eủere was me ȝeven / there bifore
But afterward / I repented me ful sore
He wolde suffre / no thyng of my lest
By god he smote me ones / on the lest
For that I rente / out of his book a leef
That of that stroke / myn eres woxe deef
Stibourne I was / as is leonesse
And of my tung a verray iangeleresse
And walke I wolde / as I had don biforn
From hous to hous / al though he had it sworn
Wherfore ful oft tyme / he wolde pche
And me olde Romaunces gestes teche
How he simplicius gallus / lefte his wyf
And hir forsoke / for t̉erme of his lyf
Nat but for openhede he hir say
Lokyng out at his dore on a day
Another Romayn / tolde he me by name
That for his wyf was at a somer game
Withoute his wetynge / he forsoke hir eke
And than wolde he / vpon his bible seke
That ilke ꝓprouerbe / of Ecclesiaste
Where he cōmmaundeth and forbedeth faste
Man shal not suffre his wyf go roule aboute
That wolde he say / right thus withoute doute
¶ Who so that bildeth his hous of salwes
And priketh his blynde hors ouer the falwes
And suffreth his wyf forto seke halwes
Is wordy to ben honged / on the galwes
But al for nouȝt / I sette nouȝt an hawe
Of his ꝓproủerbes / ne of his olde sawe
Ne I wolde not of hym corrected be
I hate hym / that my vices telleth me
And so do mo / god woot than I
This made hym wᵗith me / wood al outrely
I wolde not forbere hym / in no cas
Nowe wol I sey you sothe by seynt Thoma
Why that I rente / out of his book a leef
For whiche he smote me / that I was deef
He had a book / that gladly nyght and day
For his disport / he wolde rede alway
He cleped valerie / and theofraste
At whiche boke / he lowȝ alway ful faste
And eke ther was / sumtyme a clerke in Rome
And was a cardynal / that highte seint Ierome
That made a book / ageyn Iouynian
In whiche book eke / ther was terculan
Crisippus Tortula and helowys
That was Abbasse / nat fer fro parys
And eke the parables / of Salamon
Ouides art and bokes manyon
And alle thise were bounden in volume
And eủery day and nyght was his custume
Whan he had leyser and vacaciou
From other worldly / occupaciou
To reden in this book of wicked wyves
He knewe of hem / mo legendes and lyves
Than ben of goode wyves in the bible
For trusteth wel it is an impossible
That eny clerk wol speke goode of wyves
But ȝif it be / of holy seyntes lyues
Ne of non other woman neuer the mo
Who peynted the lyou tel me who
By god ȝif women hadde writen stories
As clerkes han / withynne hir oratories
They wolde have writen of men more wickednesse
Than al the marke of Adam may redresse
The children of mercurie / and of venus
Ben in her wirkyng / ful contrarious
Mercurie loueth wisdam / and science
And venus loueth / ryot and dispence
And for her dyủerse disposiciou
Eche falleth / in others exaltaciou
And thus god woot / mercurie is desolate
In pisces / whan venus is exaltat
And venus falleth / ther mcurie is reysed
Therfore no woman / of man ys preysed
The clerk whan he is olde / and may nat do
Of venus werkes / wroth his olde sho
Than sitte he dou / and writ in his dotage
That women can not / kepe hir mariage
¶ But now to purpos / why I tolde the
That I was beten / for a book ꝑparde
Vpon a nyght Iankyn / that was oure sire
Radde in his book / as he satt by the fyre
Of Eua first / that for hir wickednesse
Was al mankynde / brought to wrecchednesse /
¶ Tho radde he me / how Sampson lost his heres
Slepynge his lēmman cutte hem wᵗith hir sheres
Thurgh which tresoıı̄un / loste he bothe his eyen
¶ Tho redde he me / ȝif that I shal not lyen
Of hercules and of his Dyanyre
That caused hym to sette hym self a fyre
¶ No thyng forgat he the penance and the wo
That Socrates hadde wᵗith his wyves two
¶ How that Antipa caste pisse on his hed
This sely man sat stille as he were ded
He wyped his hed no more durste he seyn
But er that thonder stynte cometh reyn
¶ Of Phasipha that was the kyng Crete
For shrowednes hym thought that tale swete
Fy speke no more it is a grisly thyng
Of hir horrible lust and hir lykyng
¶ Of Clitermistra for hir leccherie
That falsly made hir husbonde forto die
He redde it wᵗith ful good deuociou
¶ He tolde me / for what occasiou
Amphiorax at Thebes loste his lyf
Myn husbonde hadde a legende of his wyf
Eryphylem that an owche of gold
Hath pryuely vnto the grekes told
Where that hir husbonde / hidde hym in a place
For whiche he hadde at Thebes sory grace
¶ Of lyuia tolde he me / and of lucye
They bothe / made her husbondes forto dye /
That oon for love / that other was for hate
Lyuia hir husbonde / on euen late
Enpoysoned hadde / for that she was his fo
Lucya liberous / loued hir husbonde so /
That for he shulde / alwey vpon hir thynke
She ȝaf hym suche / a loue man̉ere drynke
That he was ded / er it were by the morowe
And thus algate / husbondes hadde sorowe
¶ Than tolde he me / how oon latumius
Compleyned / vnto his felawe arius
That in his gardeyne growed suche a tree
On whiche he seide / that his wyve three
Honged hem self / for hertes dispitous
O leue brother / quod this Arious
Ȝeve me a plante / of that blessid tree
And in my gardeyn / planted shal it be
¶ Of later date of wyues / hath he red
That have slayn her husbondes in her bed
And leet hir lecchour dighte hir al the nyght
Whan that the corps / lay in the flore vpright
And some have dryuen / nayles in her brayn
Whiel that they slepe and thus they han hem slayn
Some han ȝeve hem poisou in hir drynke /
He spak more harme that herte may bethynke
¶ And ther wᵗith al he knewe of moo ꝓprouerbes
Than in this world ther growen gras or herbes
Bet is quod he thyn habitaciou
Be with a lyon / or a foule dragou
Than with a woman / vsynge forto chyde
Bet is quod he / high in the roof abyde
Than with an angry wyf dou in the hous
They ben so wicked / and contrarious
They haten that her husbondes loven ay
He sayde a woman / cast hir shame away
Whan she cast of hir smok / and furthermo
¶ A fayre woman / but she be chaste also
Is lyke a gold ryng / in a sowes nose
Who wolde wene / or who wolde suppose
The wo that in myn herte was / and pyne
Whan that I saugh / he wolde neủere fyne
To reden on this cursed book / al nyght
Al sodeinly / thre leves / have I plight
Out of his book as he redde and eke
I with my fist / toke hym so on the cheke
That in oure fyre / he fil bacward a dou
And vp he sterte / as dooth a wood lyou
And with his fiste / he smote me on the hed
That in the flore / I lay as I were ded
And whan he saugh / how stille that I lay
He was a gast / and wolde han fled his way
Til at the laste out of myn swouȝ I brayde
O hast thou slayn me / false theef I sayde
And for my lande thus hastow mordred me
Er I be ded / ȝit wol I cusse the
And nere he com and kneled fayre adou
And saide dere Suster Alisou
As helpe me god I shal the neủere smyte
That I have don / it is thy self to wyte
For yeue it me / and that I the biseke
And ȝit eftsones / I toke hym on the cheke
And saide theef / thus moche am I wreke
Now wol I dye / I may no lenger speke
But atte laste / with more care and wo
We felle accorde by vs seluen two
He ȝaf me al the bridel in myn hond
To have the goủernaunce of hous and land
And of his tonge / and of his hand also
I made hym brenne his book anon right tho
And whan that I hadde geten vnto me
By maystry al the soueraynte
Than seyde he / myn owne trewe wyf
Do as you lust / the t̉erme of al youre lyf
Kepe thyn honour / and kepe eke myn estate
After that day / we hadde neuer debat
God helpe me so / I was to hym as kynde
As eny wyf / fro Denmark into ynde
And also trewe / and so was he to me
I pray to god / that sit in mgeste
So blesse his soule / for his mercy dere
Now wol I say my tale ȝif ȝe wolde here /

¶Thus endeth the prologe of the wyf of Bathe
¶ The wordes of the Frere /
The Frere lowgh / whan he had herde al this
Now dame quod he / so have I ioy or blis
This is a longe / ꝑperamble of a tale
And whan the Sompnor / herde the Frere gale
Lo quod the Sompnoᵘur / for goddes armes two
A Frere wol ent̉remete hym eủere mo
Lo goode men / a flye and eke a frere
Wole falle in eủery dissh and eke matere
What spekest thow / of pambulaciou
What amble or trotte / or pees or go sit don
Thow lettest oure disport / in this manere
ȝe wilt thou so / Sompnour quod the Frere
Now by my fay / I shal er that I go
Telle of a sompnour / suche a tale or two
That al the folk shul laughen in this place
Now ellis Frere / I byshrewe thy face
Quod this sompnour / and I beshrewe me
But ȝif I telle / tales two or thre
Of Freres / er I come to Sidyngborne
That I shal make / thyn herte forto morne
For wel I wote / thy pacience is goon
Oure host cride pees / and that anon
And seide lat the woman / telle hir tale
Ȝe faren as folk / that dronken ben of ale
Do dame telleth forth youre tale / ⁊and that is best
Al redy sire / quod she right as you lest
Ȝif I have licence / of this worthy Frere
Ȝis dame quod he / tel forth thy tale I wol here

div.l: (base) Narrat

(base) As thikke as any motis in the sonne beme

div.l: (base) So longe preyden the kyng of grace

(base) And after this thus spak she to the knyght
(base) Whan that she saw hir tyme vpon a day
(base) Thow standest yet quod she in swich array
(base) That of thy lyf yet hastow no suretee
(base) That of þi life / yit hastou kanst tel me
(base) I graunte thee lyf if thow kanst tellen me
(base) What thyng is it that wommen moost desiren

(base) And seuretee wol I han er that thow pace

div.l: (base) And with attendaunce and with bisynesse

(base) And that no man repreue vs of oure vice
(base) But seye that we be wise and no thyng nyce

(base) If any wight wolde clawe vs on the galle

(base) We wol be holden wise and clene of synne

(base) And nat biwreye thyng that men vs telle

(base) Ful sotilly from euery mannes sighte

(base) This knyght of which my tale is specially
(base) Whan that he say he myghte nat come ther by

(base) The day was come that homward moste he torne

(base) In al this care vnder a Forest syde
(base) Wher as he say vpon a daunce go
(base) Of ladyes twenty foure and yet mo

div.l: (base) Plight me thy trouthe here in myn hand quod she
(base) The nexte thyng that I requere thee
(base) Thow shalt it do if it lye in thy myght
(base) And I wol telle it yow er it be nyght
(base) Haue here my trouthe quod the knyght I graunte
(base) Thanne quod she I dar me wel auaunte
(base) Thy lyf is sauf for I wole stonde ther by
(base) Vpon my lyf the queene wol seye as I
(base) Lat see which is the prouddeste of hem alle
(base) That wereth on a couerchief or a calle
(base) That dar seye nay of that I shal thee teche
(base) Lat vs go forth withouten lenger speche
(base) Tho rowned she a pistel in his ere

(base) Whan they be comen to the Court this knyght
(base) Seyde he hadde holde his day as he had hight

(base) Ful many a noble wyf and many a mayde

(base) As wel ouer hir housbonde as hir loue

div.l: (base) Which that the knyght say sittyng on the grene

div.l: (base) Pouerte is thyng althogh it seme elenge
(base) Possessioun that no wight wol chalenge
(base) Pouerte ful often whan a man is lowe

(base) Pouerte a spectacle is as thynketh me
(base) Thurgh which he may his verray freendes se
(base) And therfore sire syn that I noght yow greue
(base) Of my pouerte namoore ye me repreue
(base) Now sire of elde ye repreue me
(base) And certes sire thogh noon auctoritee

(base) Seyn that men an old wight sholde doon fauour

(base) And Auctours shal I fynden as I gesse

(base) For filthe and elde also mote I thee
(base) Been grete wardeyns vpon chastitee
(base) But nathelees syn I knowe youre delit
(base) I shal fulfille youre worldly appetit
(base) Chees now quod she oon of thise thynges tweye
(base) To han me foul and old til that I deye
(base) And be to yow a trewe humble wyf
(base) And neuere yow displese in al my lyf
(base) Or ellis ye wol han me yong and fair
(base) And take youre auenture of the repair

(base) Or in som oother place may wel be
(base) Now chees your seluen wheither that yow liketh
(base) This knyght auyseth hym and soore siketh
(base) But atte laste he seyde in this manere
(base) My lady and my loue and wyf so deere

(base) Cheseth youre self which that may be moost plesaunce
(base) And moost honour to yow and me also
(base) I do no fors the wheither of the two

(base) Thanne haue I gete of yow maistrye quod she
Syn I may chese / and goủerne as me leste
Ȝe certes wyf quod he / I holde it for the beste
Kisse me quod she / we be no lenger wrothe
For by my trouthe / I wol be to yow bothe
This is to seyen / bothe faire and good
I pray to god / that I may steruen wood
But I to you / be also also sad and trewe
As euere was wyf / syn þᵗat the world was newe
And but I be to morn / as faire onto sene
As eny lady / emꝑperesse or queene
That is betwene / the est / and eke the west
Doth with my lyf / and deth right as yow lest
Cast vp the curteyn / and loke how it is
And whan the knyght / saugh al this
That she so faire was / and so yonge therto
For ioye he hente hir / in his armes two
His herte bathed / in a bath of blisse
A thousand tyme a rowe / he gan hir kisse
And she obeyed hym / in euery thyng
That myght done hym plesaunce or likyng
And thus they lyued / vnto hir lyves ende
In ꝑparfit ioye / and IħuIhesu crist vs sende
Husbondes meke / yonge and fressh a bedde
And grace to ouerleue hem / þᵗat we wedde
And eke I pᵃray / that IħuIhesu short her lyues
That wol not be goủerned / by her wyues
And olde and angry / and nygard of dispence
God sende hem sone / a verray pestilence
¶ Thus endeth the tale of þᵉ wyf of Bathe
¶ And bygynneth þᵉ prologe of the Frere
This worthy lymytour / this noble Frere
He made alwey / a man̉ere lowrynge chere
Vpon the Somnour / but ȝit for honeste
No vileyns word / as ȝit spak he
But atte laste / he saide vnto the wyf
Goode dame / god ȝeue you right goode lyf
Ȝe have touched here / also mote I the
In scole mater / greet difficulte
Ȝe have saide moche thyng / right wel I seye
But dame / here as ryde by the weye
Vs nedeth not / to speke but of game
And lete auctorites go / a godes name
To p̉rechyng / and to scole eke of clergie
But ȝif it lyke / vnto this companye
I wol you of a Somnoᵘur / telle a game
Parde ȝe may wel knowe / by the name
That of a Somnoᵘur / may no goode be sayd
I pray that noon of ȝou / be euel appaied
A somnour is a renner vp and doıı̄un
With maundementes / for fornicacioıı̄un
And is ybete at eủery townes ende
¶ Oure tho spak / a sire shulde be hende
And curteys as a man / of youre astate
In company / we wol no debate
Telleth youre tale / and lat the somnoᵘur be
¶ Nay quod the somnoᵘur / lat hym say to me
What so hym liste / whan it cometh to my lot
By god I shal I quyte eủery grot
I shal hym telle / whiche a grete honoᵘur
It is forto be / a flaterynge lymytoᵘur
And eke of ful many / another cryme
Whiche nede nat / reherse / at this tyme
And his office / I shal hym telle ywis
Oure host answerde / pees no more of this
And afterward / he seide vnto the frere
Telle forth youre tale / leue Maist̉er dere
¶ Here endeth the prologe of þe Frere
¶ And here bigynneth þᵉ tale of þᵉ Frere
Whilom ther was / dwellyng in my cuntre
An Erchedekene / a man of high degre
That boldely / dide execucion
In punysshyng / of fornicacion
Of wicchecraft / and eke of baudrie
Of diffamacion / and avoutrie
Of cherche reves / and of testamentes
Of contractes / and of lak of sacramentes
Of vserie / and of symonye also
But certes lechours / dide he grettest wo
They shulde synge / ȝif they were hent
And smale tythers / were foule yshent
Ȝif any ꝑperson / wolde vpon hem pleyne
Ther myght astirte him / no pecunial peyne
For smale tythes and eke smale offrynge
He made the peple / dispitousely to synge
For er the bisshop̄p / cauȝte hem wᵗith his hook
They were in the erchedekenes book
And than had he / thurgh his iurisdiccioıı̄un
Power to done on̄ hem correccioıı̄un
He had a somnoᵘur / redy to his hand
A slyer boy nas noon en England
For sotilly he had his especiayle
That thaught hym / where that he myght avayle
He couthe spare of lecchours / oon or two
To teche hym / to foure and twenty mo
For though this somnoᵘur / wood were as an hare
To telle his harlotrie / I wol nat spare
For we ben out / of her correccioıı̄un
They have of vs / noo iurisdiccioıı̄un
Ne neủere shulle / terme of all oure lyves
¶ Peter so ben the women / of the styves
Quod thus somnoᵘur put out of oure cure
Pees with mischaunce / and misauenture
This seyde oure host / and lete hym telle his tale
Now telleth forth / and lat the somnour gale
Ne spareth nouȝt myn owne Maist̉er dere
This false theef / this somnoᵘur quod þe Frere
Had alwey bawdes / redy to his hond
As eny hauke / to lure in englond
That tolde hym al the secre þᵗat they knewe
For hir aqueyntance / was not come of newe
They were his approwers / priuely
He toke hym self / a grete ꝓprofit therby
His maist̉er knewe nouȝt / alwey what he wan
Withoute maundement / of a lewed man
He coude sompne / vp peyne of cristes curs
And they were inly glad / to fille his purs
And made hym grete festes / atte nale
And right as Iudas / had purses smale
And was a theef / right such a theef was he
His maister hadde / but half his duete
He was ȝif I shal ȝeve hym his laude
A theef / and eke a sompnoᵘur and a baude
He hadde eke / wenches / of his retenue
That wheither ʆsir Robert / or ʆsir hue
Or John or Rauf / or who so that it were
That lay by hem / they tolde it in his ere
Thus was the wenche / and he of oon assent
And he wolde fecche / a feyned maundement
And sompne hem to the chapitre / bothe two
And pele the man / and late the wenche go
Than wolde he seye / frende I shal for þi sake
Do stryke the out / of oure lett̉res blake
The dar nomore / as in this cas trauayle
I am thy frende / ther I the may avayle
Certeyn he knewe / of bribours moo
Than possible is / to telle you vnto
For in this world / is dogge for no bowe
That coude an hert dere / from another knowe
Than that this sompnoᵘur / knewe a slye lecchour
Or auoutour / or a paramour
And for that was / the fruyt of al his rente
Therfore on it / he sette al his entente
And so bifel / ones on a day
This somnoᵘur eủere / waytynge on his pray
Rode forto sompne / an olde wyf a rybibe
Feynynge a cause / for he wolde bribe
And happed that he saugh / bifore hym ride
A gay ȝoman / vnder a forest syde
A bowe he bar / and arwes bright and kene
He had vpon / a courtepy of grene
An hat vp on his hede / with frenges blake
Sir quod this Sompnoᵘur / heyl and wel ytake
Welcome quod he / and eủery goode felawe
Whider ridest þou / vnder this grene shawe
Seide this ȝoman / wilt thou fer to day
The sompnoᵘur hym answerde / and seyde nay
Here faste by quod he / is myn entente
To ryde forto reysen / vp a rente
It longeth to my lordes duete
Art thou than a baylyf / ȝe quod he
He dorste nat / for verray filthe and shame
Say that he was a sompnoᵘur / for þe name
Deꝑpardeux quod this ȝoman / dere brother
Thou art a baylyf / and I am another
I am vnknowen / as in this cuntre
Of thyn aqueyntance / I wol pᵃray the
And eke of brotherhede / ȝif that þou lest
I have golde and syluer / in my chest
Ȝif the happed / to come in oure shire
Al shal be thyn / right as thou wilt desire
Grant mercy / quod this sompnoᵘur be my feith
Euerich in others hand / his trouthe leyth
Forto be swore brother / tyl they dye
And with that worde / they ride forth her weye
This sompnoᵘur with that / was as ful of iangles
As ful of venyme / as be þise waryangles
And eủere enquerynge / vpon eủery thyng
Brother quod he / where is youre dwellyng
An other day / ȝif I shulde you seche
This ȝoman hym answerde / in softe speche
Brother quod he / fer in the north cuntre
Where as I hope / somtyme I shal the se
Or we departe / I shal the so wel wisse
That of my hous / shalt þou neủere misse
Now brother quod this sompnoᵘur / I the pray
Teche me while we / ryden by the way
Syn that ȝe ben / a baillif as am I
Som sotellte / telle me faithfully
In myn office / how þᵗat I may most wynne
And spareth not / for conscience ne synne
But as my brother / tel me how do ȝe
Now by my trouthe / brother dere saide he
As I shal tellen the / a feithful tale
My wages ben / ful streite and smale
My lorde is harde to me / and dangerous
And myn̄ office / ful laborous
And therfore / by extorcions I lyue
For soth in al / þᵗat men wol me ȝeve
Algate by slighte / or violence
Fro ȝere to ȝere / I wynne al my dispence
I can no better telle / feithfully
Now certes quod this Sompnoᵘur / so fare I
I spare not to take / god it woot
But ȝif it be / to heuy or to hoot
What I may gete / in counseil priuely
No manere conscience / of that have I
Nere myn extorcioıı̄un / I myght not lyuen
Of swiche iapes / wol I not be shryven
Stomak ne conscience / ne knowe I noon
I shrewe thise shriftefaders / eủerychoon
Wel be mette / by god and by seynt Iame
But leue brother / telle me than thy name
Quod this sompnoᵘur / in this mene while
This ȝoman gan a lytel / forto smyle
Brother quod he / wilt thou that I the telle
I am a feend / my dwellyng is in helle
And here I ride / aboute my purchasyng
To wite where / men wol ȝeue me eny thyng
My purchas is the effect / of al my rente
Loke how thou ridest / for the same entente
To wynne good / thou rekkest neủere how
Right so fare I / for ride wolde I now
Vnto the worldes ende / for a preye
A quod this somnoᵘur / bn̄enedicite what ȝe seye
I wente ȝe were / a ȝeman trewely
Ȝe have a mannes shaap / as wel as I
Have ȝe a figure / that det̉ermynate
In helle ther ȝe ben / in youre estate
Nay certeynly / quod he / ther have we noon
But whan vs leketh / we can take vs oon
Or ellis make you seme / þᵗat we be shape
Somtyme a man / or lyk an ape
Or lyk an angel / can I ride or go
It is no wonder thyng / though it be so
A lousy iogelour / can deceyue the
And ꝑparde ȝit can I / more craft than he
Why quod this somnoᵘur / ride ye than or goon
In sondry shap̄ / and nat alwey in oon
For we quod he / wol vs suche forme make
As most able is / oure prayes forto take
What maketh you / to have al this labour
For ful many a cause / leue sir somnoᵘur
Seide this feende / but al thyng hath tyme
The day is short / and it is passed pryme
And ȝit ne wan I no thyng in this day
I wol entende / to wynnyng ȝif I may
And nat entende / oure wittes declare
For brother myn̄ / þi witte is al to bare
To vnderstonde / though I tolde hem the
But for thau askest / why labour we
For somtyme be we / goddes instrumentes
And menes to do / his cōmmaundementes
Whan that hym liste / vpon his creatures
In diủerse attes and in diủerse figures
Withoute hym we have no myght certayn̄
Ȝif that hym lyste / to stonde ther agayn̄
And at somtyme / at oure pray / have we leue
Only the body / and nat the saule greue
Witnesse of Iob / whom þᵗat we dide wo
And somtyme have we myght / of bothe two
This is to seyen / of soule and body eke
And somtyme we / be suffred forto seke
Vpon a man / and do his soule vnreste
Nat the body / and al is for the beste
Whan he withstondith / oure temptacioıı̄un
It is a cause / of his saluacioıı̄un
Al be it þᵗat it was not oure entente
He shulde be sauf / but þᵗat we wolde hym hente
And somtyme be we ʆseruᵃaunt vnto man
As the Erchebisshop̄ / seint Dunstan
And to the aposteles / ʆseruᵃaunt was I
Ȝit tellith me / quod the sompnoᵘur feithfully
Make ye you newe bodyes / thus alway
Of the elementes / the feende answered nay
Somtyme we feyne / and somtyme we arise
With dede bodyes / in ful sundry wise
And speke as resonably / and fayre and wel
As to the phitonessa / dide Samuel
And ȝit wol som men say / it was not he
I do no force / of youre diuinite
But oo thyng warne I the / I wol nat iape
Thow wilte algates / wite how we be shape
Thow shalt here afterward my brother dere
Come where þe nedeth nat of me to lere
For þou shalt / by thyn owne exꝑperience
Come into the chayer / and rede this sentence
Bet than virgile / while he was a lyue
Or Daunt also / now lat vs ryde blyue
For I wol holde / company with the
Til it be so / þᵗat thou forsake me
Nay quod this sompnour / þᵗat shal nat betyde
I am a ȝeman / þᵗat knowen is ful wyde
My trouthe wol I holde to þe / as in this cas
For though thou were / the Deuel sathanas
My trouthe wol I holde / as to my brother
As I am swore / and eche of vs to other
Forto be trewe / brother in this cas
And brother we gon / to oure purchas
Take þou thy part / what men wol the ȝeue
And I shal myn̄ / þus may we bothe leue
And ȝif that any of vs / have more than other
Lat him be trewe and parte with his brother
I graunt quod the Deuel / by my fay
And with that worde / they riden forth her way
And right at the entrynge / of the townes ende
To which the sompnoᵘur / shope him forto wende
They sey a carte / that charged was with hey
Which that the carter / drof forth on his wey
Depe was the wey / for which the carte stood
This carter smote / and cried as he were wood
Hayt brok / hayt scot / what spare we for the stones
The fende quod he / you fecche body and bones
As ferforthely / as eủere ye were foled
So moche wo / as I haue for you tholed
The devel have al / bothe hors carte and hey
Though this somnoᵘur / here shul we have a pley
And nere the feend he drough / as nouȝt ne were
Ful priuely / and rowned in his ere
Herken my brother / herken by thy feith
Herest thou nouȝt / what the carter seith
Hente it anoon / for he hath ȝeuen the
Bothe hey and carte / and eke his caples thre
Nay quod the Deuel / god woot neủere adel
It is nat is entente / truste me wel
Aske hym thy self / ȝif thou nat trowest me
Or ellis stynte a while / and thou shalt se
This Carter thakked his hors / on the croupe
And they bigonne / to drawe and to stoupe
Hayt now quod he / that IħuIhesu crist you blesse
And al his hondy werk / bothe more ⁊and lesse
That was wel twight / my owne lyard boy
I pᵃray god save the / and seint loy
Now is my carte / out of the slough parde
Lo brother quod the fende / what tolde I the
Here may ye se / myn owne dere brother
The carle spak oo thyng / but he thought another
Late vs go forth / aboute oure viage
Here wynne I noo thyng vpon cariage
Whan that they come / somwhat out the town
This sompnoᵘur to his brother / gan to rown
Brother quod he / here woneth and olde rebekke
That hadde almost / as leef to lese her nekke
As forto yeve a peny / of hir good
I wol have twelue pens / þᵗat she be wood
Or I wol sompne / hir to oure office
And ȝit god woot / of hir knowe I no vice
But for thou canst nouȝt / as in this cuntre
Wynne thy cost / take here ensample of me
This sompnour clappeth / at the wydewes gate
Come oute he seide / þou olde viritrate
I trowe thou hast / som prest or frere wᵗith the
Who clappeth seide this wyf / benedicite
God save you sire / what is youre wille
I have quod he / of somons of the here a bille
Vp peyne of cursyng loke that thou be
To morowe bifore / the Erchedekenes kne
To answere to the court / of certeyn thynges
Now lorde quod she / IħuIhesu kyng of kynges
So wisly helpe me / as I ne may
I have ben seke / and that ful many a day
I may nat go so fer / quod she ne ride
But I be ded / so priketh it in my side
May I not aske a libel / sir sompnour
And answere there / by my ꝓprocutour
To suche a thyng as men / wolde appose me
Ȝis quod this sompnoᵘur / paie anoon lat se
Twelue pens to me / and I wol thee acquyte
I shal no ꝓprofit have therby / but lite
My Maist̉er hath the profite / and nat I
Come of / and lat me / riden hastely
Ȝeve twelue pens / I may no lenger tarie
Twelue quod she / oure lady seynt Marie
So wisly helpe me / out of care and synne
This wyde worlde / though þᵗat I shulde wynne
Ne have I nat twelue pens / wythynne myn holde
Ȝe knowen wel / that I am pore and olde
Kythe youre almes / on me pore wrecche
Nay than quod he / the foule fende me fecche
Ȝif I the excuse / theigh þou should be spilte
Allas quod she / god woot I have no gilte
Pay me quod he / or by swete seynt Anne
As I wol bere awey / with me thy newe panne
For dette which / thou owest me of old
Whan that thow madest / thyn husbond cokewold
I paied at home / for thy correccioıı̄un
Thow lixt quod she / by my saluacioıı̄un
Ne was I neủere er now / widewe ne wyf
Somned to youre court / in al my lyf
Ne neủere I was / but of my body trewe
Vnto the Deuel / rough and blak of hewe
Ȝeue I thy body / and my panne also
And whan the Deuel / herde her curse so
Vpon hir knees / he seide in this manere
Now Mabely / myn owne moder dere
Is this youre wille / in erneste as ye seye
The Deuel quod she / fette hym or he deye
And panne and al / but he wol hym repente
Nay olde stot / that is nat myn entente
Quod this sompnour / forto repente me
For eny thyng / that I have had of the
I wolde I had thy smok / and eủery cloth
Now brother quod the Deuel / be nat wroth
Thy body and thy panne / is myn̄ be right
Thou shalt wᵗith me / to helle ȝit to nyght
Where thou shalt knowe / of oure priuite
More than a Maist̉er / of diuinite
And with that worde / this foule feende hem hente
Body and soule / he wᵗith the Deuel wente
Where that sompnoᵘurs / han her heritage
And god that made / after his ymage
Mankynde / save and hgide hide gide vs alle and some
And leue this sompnour / a good man become
¶ Lordynges I couth have told you / quod this Frere
div.note: a
div.l: Hadde I had leyser / for this sompnoᵘur here
After the text of crist poul and Iohn̄
And of oure othere / doctours manyon̄
Swiche peynes / that youre hertes myght agrise
