Al be it so / no tunge may deuise
Thought that I myght / a thousand wynter telle
The peyne of thilke / cursed hous of helle
But forto kepe vs / fro that cursed place
Waketh and praieth / IħuIhesu for his gᵃrace
So kepe vs fro the temptour sathanas
Herkeneth this worde / be war as in this cas
The leoıı̄un sitt in his awayte alway
To slee the innocent / ȝif that he may
Disposeth ay youre hertes / to withstonde
The feend that you / wolde make thral and bonde
He may not tempte yowu / oủer ȝoure myght
For crist wol be / youre champioıı̄un and knyght
And prayeth that this somnoᵘur / may hym repente
Of his mysdede / or þᵗat the feend hym hente
¶ Thus endeth the Freres tale

¶ And here
Bygynneth the prologe of the somnour
This Somnoᵘur in his stirop / high stood
Vpon this Frere / his herte was so wood
That lyke an aspen leef / he quok for ire
Lordynges quod he / but oo thyng I desire
I you biseche / that of youre curtesie
Sitthen ye have herde / the fals Frere lye
As suffre me / I may a tale telle
This frere bosteth / how that he knoweth helle
And god woot / that is litel wonder
For freres and feendes / are not fer asunder
For ꝑparde / ye han ofte tyme herde telle
How that a frere / rauissht was into helle
In spirite ones / by avysyoıı̄un
And as an angel / led hym vp and doıı̄un
To shewen hym the peynes þᵗat there were
In al the places / saugh he not a frere
Of other folk he saugh ynowe in wo
Vnto this aungel / spak the Frere tho
Now sire quod he / han freres such a gᵃrace
That none of hem / shal come into this place
Ȝis quod this aungel / many a mylioıı̄un
And vnto sathanas / he ladde him doıı̄un
And now hath sathanas / seith he a tayl
Brodder / than of a carrak is the sayl
Holde vp thy tayl / thou sathanas quod he
Shewe forth thyn ers / and let the frere se
Where is the nest / of freres in this place
And er that half a forlong wey / of space
Right so as bees swarmen / out of an hyue
Out of the deueles ers / they gunne dryue
Twenty thousand freres / on a route
And thurgh out helle / swarmed al aboute
And come ayen / as faste as they may gon
And in his ers / they crepten eủerychon
He clapte his tayle ageyn / and lay stille
This frere / whan he loked hadde his fille
Vpon the tormentes / of this sory place
His spirit god restored / of his grace
Vnto his body ageyn / and he awook
But nathalees / for fere ȝit he quook
So was the deueles ers / ay in his mynde
That is his heritage / of verray kynde
God saue vs alle / saf this cursed frere
My prologe wol I ende / in this manere
¶ This endeth the prologe of the sompnoᵘur
¶ And here bygynneth his tale ⁊et c̉etera
LOrdynges ther is yorkshire as I gesse
A mersshy cuntre / called holdernesse
In which ther went / a lymytoᵘur aboute
To p̉reche / and eke to begge / it is no doute
And so bifel / that on a day this frere
Hadde p̉reched at chirche / in his manere
And specialy / aboue euery thyng
Excited he / the peple in his p̉rechyng
To trentales / and for godes sake
To ȝeue when wᵗith men myght / holy houses make
Ther as the deuine ʆseruice / is honoured
Nouȝt ther as it is wasted / and deuoured
Ne there it nedeth not / forto be ȝeve
As to possessioners / that may elles lyue
Thanked be god / in wele and abundance
Trentales saide he / deliủereth fro penance
Her frendes soules / as wel olde as yonge
Ȝif that they be / hastely ysonge
Nouȝt forto holde a preste / ioly and gay
He singeth not / but oo masse in a day
Deliủereth out quod he / anoon the soules
Ful hard it is / with flesshoke oþ̉er with oules
Now spede you hastely / for cristes sake
To kepe you fro peynes of feendes blake
And whan the Frere / had saide al his entente
With Qui cūm patre / streight forth he wente
Than folk in chirche / had ȝeve him / what hem leste
He went his way / no lenger wolde he reste
With strippe and tipped staf / ytukked ful hie
In eủery hous / he gan to poure and prie
And beggeth mele chese / or elles corn
His felawe had a staf / tipped with horn
A peire of tables / of Iuory
And a poyntel polisshed / fetisly
And wroot the names / alwey as he stood
Of the folk / that ȝaf hem any good
Ascaunce / that he wolde for hem preye
Ȝeve vs a busshel whete / malt or reye
A goddes kechel / othe a trip of chese
Or ellis what you lest / we may nat chese
A goddes halpeny / or a masse peny
Or ȝeve vs of youre braun / and ȝe have eny
A dagon̄ of youre blanket / leue dame
Oure suster dere / lo here I write youre name
Bacon or beef / or suche thynge as ye fynde
A sturdy harlot / wente hem ay behynde
That was her ostes man / and bar a sak
And what men ȝaf hem / heeng it at is bak
And whan he was out / at the dore anon
He planed awey / the names eủerychoon
That he biforn had / writen in his tables
He serued hem with nyfles / and wᵗith fables
Nay ther thou lixt / þou somnoᵘur quod the Frere
Pees quod oure host / for cristes moder dere
Telle forth thy tale / spare it nouȝt at al
So thryue I quod this sompnoᵘur so I shal
So longe he wente hous by hous þᵗat he
Cam to an hous / ther as he was wont to be
Refresshed more / than in an hundred places
Syke say the bonde man / whos the place is
And vpon a cowche / lowe he lay
Deus hic / quod he / O Thomas frende good day
Saide this frere / curteisly and softe
Thomas seide he / god ȝelde you ful ofte
Have I vpon this benche / yfare ful wel
Here have I eten / ful many a mery mel
And fro the benche / he drof a way the cat
And leyde doıı̄un / his potent and his hat
And eek his scrippe / and sat hym sel adoıı̄un
His felowe was go walked in to the town̄
Forth with this knave / into þᵗat hostelrye
Wheer as he shoop him / in that nyght to lye
¶ O dere Maist̉er quod this seke man
How have ȝe faren / sitthe March bygan
I saugh you nouȝt / this fortnyght and more
God woot quod he / laboured have I ful sore
And specially / for thy saluacioıı̄un
I have seide / many a p̉recious orisoıı̄un
And for oure other frendes / god hem blesse

rdg.seg:
I have to day done / at youre
chirche a messe

app.rdg: I have to day done / at youre chirche a messe

div.l: And seide a sermon / after my symple wit
And nouȝt al after / the text of holy writ
For it hard is is to you as I suppose
Therfore wol I / teche you al the glose
Glosyng is / a glorious thyng certayn̄
For the łletre sleeth / so as the clerkes sayn̄
Ther have I tauȝt hem / to be charitable
And spende her good / ther it is resonable
And there I saugh oure dame / a where is she
Ȝonde in the ȝerde / I trowe that she be
Sayde thus man / and she wolde come anoon
Ey maist̉er welcome be ȝe / by seynt Iohn
Seide this wyf / and how fare ye hertely
The Frere ariseth vp / ful curtesly
And hir embrsed / in his armes narwe
And cussed hir swete / and chirked as a sparwe
With his lippes dame quod he / right wel
As he that is / youre ʆserunt euerydel
Ythanked be god / that you ȝaf soule and lyf
Ȝit saugh I not to day / so faire a wyf
In al the chirche / god so saue me
Ȝe god amende the defautes / sir quod she
Algate welcome be ȝe / by my fey
Grant mercy dame / this have I founde alwey
But of youre grete goodnesse by youre leue
I wol pray you / that ȝe nouȝt yow greue
I wol wᵗith Thomas / speke a lytel throwe
Thise creatures ben / ful negligent and slowe
To grope tenderly / a conscience
In shrifte / and in prechyng / is my diligence
And studie in petres wordes / and in poules
I walke and fisshe / mennes soules
To ȝelde IħuIhesu crist / his ꝓpropre rente
To sprede his wordes / I sette al myn entente
Now by youre leve / my dere sir quod she
Chideth him wel / for godes trinite
He is as angry / as a pessemyre
Though that he have / al that he wol desire
Though I hym wrye a nyght and make him warme
And on hym leye / my leg or myn arme
He groneth lyke oure boor liggynge in oure sty
Other disport of him / right noon have I
I may nat plesen him in no man̉ere cas
O Thomas / ieo vous dy / thomas thomas
This maketh the feend this mot ben amended
Ire is a thyng / þᵗat high god defended
And therof wol I speke / a word or two
Maist̉er now quod the wyf er that I go
What wol ȝe dyne / I wol go ther aboute
Now dame quod he / ieo vous dye sanz doute
Have I of a capoıı̄un / but the lyuere
And of youre softe bred / but a shyuere
And after that / a rosted pigges hed
But that I wol for me / no beste be ded
Than had I wᵗith you / homely suffisance
I am a man / of litel sustenance
My spirite is fostred / in the bible
The body is ay so redy / and penyble
To wake / that my stomak is destroyed
I pray you dame / that ye be not anoyed
Though I so frendely / my counseil shewe
By god I wolde not / telle it but a fewe
But sir quod she / oo word er I go
My childe is ded / withynne thise wykes two
Sith that ȝe wente / out of this toun
His deth saugh I / by reuelacioıı̄un
Seide this frere / at home in oure dortour
I der wel saien / that er þan half an hour
After his deth / I saugh hym bore to blisse
In myn̄ myn̄ avisioıı̄un / so god me wisse
So dide oure sexteyn / and oure Fermerer
That han ben trewe Freres fifty ȝer
They may now / god thonked be of his lone
Maken her iubile and walken allone
And vp I roos / and al oure couent eke
With many a tere / trillynge on my cheke
Withoute noyse / or clateryng of belles
Te deum was oure song / and other thynges elles
Saf that to crist / I seide an orisoıı̄un
Thankynge hym / of the reuelacioıı̄un
For sir and dame / trusteth me right wel
Oure orisons / be more effectuel
And more we se / of cristes secre excellence
Than berel folk / in richesse and dispence
Of mete and drynke / and in hir foule delyte
We have this worldes lust / al despite
Lazar and diues / lyueden dyủersely
And diủerse guerdoıı̄un / had they ther by
Who so wol praye / he moste faste and be clene
And fatte his soule / and make his body lene
We fare as seith the apostel / cloth and fode
Suffiseth vs / though they be nat goode
The clennes and the fastyng / of vs freres
Maketh that crist / accepteth oure prayeres
Lo Moyses fourty dayes / and fourty nyght
Fasted er that / þe high god of myght
Spak wᵗith him / in mount of Synay
With empty wombe fastynge many a day
Receyued he the lawe / that was writen
With godes fynger / and hely wel ȝe witen
In the mount oreb / er he hadde eny speche
With high god / that is oure lyves leche
He fasted longe / and was in contemplaunce
And aaron that hadde / the temple of god in goủernaunce
And eke the other prestes / eủerychon
Into the temple / whan they shulde gon̄
To preye for the peple / and don ʆseruice
They nolde drynke / in no man̉ere wise
No drynke / which þᵗat myghte hem dronke make
But ever in abstynance / to pray and wake
Lest þᵗat they deyed / take hede what I say
But they be sobre / þᵗat for the peple pray
War þᵗat I say no more / for it suffiseth
Oure lorde IħcIhesu / and holy writ deuiseth
Ȝeveth vs ensaumple / of fastyng and prayers
Therfore we mendyvantes / we pore Freres
Be wedded to pouert / and to contynence
To charite / humbelnesse and to pacience
To ꝑpersecucioıı̄un / for rightwisnesse
To wepyng mysericorde / and to clennesse
And therfore may ȝe se / that oure prayers
I speke of vs / we mendyvantes we Freres
Ben to the high god / more acceptable
Than ȝoures / with youre fastes at þᵉ table
Fro paradys first / ȝif that I shal nat lye
Was man out chaced / for his glotenye
And cast was man / in paradis certayn
But herken how that was / that shal I sayn
I have no texte of þᵗat / as I suppose
But I shal fynde it / in a man̉ere glose
That specially / oure swete lorde IħuIhesus
Spak by vs / whan he seide thus
Blessed be they / that poủerte in spirite be
And so forth al the gospel / mowe ȝe se
Wheither it be lyke / oure professioıı̄un
Or thayres / that swymmen in possessioıı̄un
Fy on her pompe / and her glotenye
And for her lewednesse / I hem defye
Me thenketh they ben / lyke to Iouynian
Fat as whale / and walkynge as a swan
As vinolent / as botel in the spence
Her prayer is / ful of greet reuerence
Whan they for soules / sayn the salme of Dauid
Lo but they sey / cor meūm eructauit
Who folweth cristes gospel / and his fore
But we that humble be / chast and pore
Worchers of goddes worde / and not auditours
Therfore right as an hawke / atte a sours
Vp springeth vnto the heyr / right so prayeres
Of charitable and chaste besy freres
Maken hir sours / to goddes eren two
Thomas thomas / so mote I ryde or go
And by that lorde / that cleped is synt Iue
Ner thou oure brother / shuldest thou neủere thryue
In oure chapitre / pray we day and nyght
To crist / that he sende the hele and myght
Thy body forto welden / hastely
God woot quod he / no thyng therof wot I
As helpe me criste / as in fewe ȝeres
Have I dispended / vpon diủerse man̉ere freres
Ful many a pound / ȝit fare I neủere the bet
Certayn my good / have I almost byset
Fare wel my gold / for ȝit is al a go
The Frere answerde / Thomas why dost thou so
What nedeth you / dyủerse Freres to seche
What nedeth him / that hath a parfite leche
To sechen other leches / in the toun
Ȝoure inconstaunce / is youre confusioıı̄un
Holde ȝe than me / or elles youre couent
To praye for ȝou / ben insufficient
Thomas that iape is nouȝt worth a myte
Ȝoure maladie / is for we have to lyte
A ȝeve oure couent / half a quart̉er of otes
And to another couent / foure and twenty grotes
And ȝeue that frere a peny / and lat him go
Nay nay Thomas / it may no thyng be so
What is a ferthyng worth / deꝑparted in twelue
Lo eech thyng / that is oned in him selue
Is more stronge / than whan it is scatered
Thomas of me / thou shalt not be flatered
Thou woldest oure labour / have for nouȝt
The high god / that al this worlde hath wrought
Seith that the workeman / is worthy to have his hire
Thomas of youre tresour / nouȝt I desire
As for my self / but for for al oure couent
To pray for the / is ay so diligent
And forto bulden / cristes owne chirche
Thomas ȝif ye wol lerne / forto wirche
Of buldyng / vpon chirches / may ye fynde
Ȝif it be good / in thomas lyf of ynde
Ȝe ligge here / ful of angre and of Ire
Wᵗith whiche the deuel / set youre herte afire
And chide here / this sely innocent
Ȝowre wyf that is / so meke and pacient
And therfore thomas / trowe me ȝif ye lest
Ne stryue not with thy wyf al for the best
And bere this wel away / by youre faith
Touchyng thyng / lo what the wise man seith
Withynne thyn hous / ne be thou no lyon
To thy sugettes / do noon opp̉ression̄
And make nouȝt thyn acqueyntance forto fle
And Thomas / eftsone say I the
Bewar of hir / that in thy bosom slepeth
Bewar of the ʆserpent / that so slighly crepeth
Vnder the gras / that stingeth subtily
Bewar my sone / and herkene paciently
That twenty thousand men / han lost her lyves
For stryvyng wᵗith hir lēmmans / and her wyfes
Now sitthe ye have so noble / and so meke a wyf
What nedeth you thomas / forto make stryf
Ther is ywis / no serpent so crueƚƚ
Whan men trede on his tayƚƚ / ne half so feƚƚ
As woman is / whan she hath caught an Ire
Vengeance is than / al that they desire
Ire is a synne / oon of the grete of seuene
Abhominable / vnto god of heuene
And to hym self it is destruccioıı̄un
This eủery lewed vicary / or ꝑpersoıı̄un
Can say how Ire / engendreth homicide
Ire in soth / is executor of pride
I couthe of ire / say so moche sorowe
My tale shulde laste / vntil to morowe
And therfore I pᵃray god / bothe day and nyght
An irous man / sende litel myght
It is grete harme / and certes grete pite
To sett an irous man / in high degre
¶ Whilom ther was / an irous potestate
As seth Senek / durynge his estate
Vpon a day / out riden knyghtes two
And as fortune / wolde it were so
That oon of hem com home / þᵗat other nouȝt
Anon this knyght / to fore the Iuge is brouȝt
And saide thus / thou hast þi felowe slayn
For whiche I deme / the to deth certayn
And to a nother knyght / cōmmaunded he
Go lede hym to the deth / I charge the
And happed as they wente / by the weye
Toward the place / ther he shulde dye
The knyght com / which men wende had be ded
Than thouȝte they / it were the beste red
To leden hem bothe / to the Iuge agayn
They seide lorde / the knyȝte hath nought slayn̄
His felawe / here he stant on lyue
Ȝe shul be ded / quod he so mote I thryue
This is to sayn̄ / bothe oon two and thre
And to the first knyght / right thus spak he
I dampned the / þou must algate be ded
And thou also / must nedes lese thyn hed
For thou art cause / why that thy felawe dyeth
And to the thridde knyght / thus he seith
Thou hast not done / that I cōmmaunded the
And thus he dide / do slayn hem aƚƚ thre
¶ Irous Cambises / was eke dronkelewe
And ay delyted him / to ben a shrewe
And so bifel / a lord of his meyne
That loued vertuous moralite
Seide on a day / to hym self right thus
A lorde is lost / if he be vicius
And dronkenesse is eke a foul record
Of eny man / and namely in a lord
Ther is ful many an eye / and many an ere
Awayteng on a lorde / and he not where
For goddes loue / drynketh more attemprely
Wyn maketh men / to lesen wrecchedly
Hys mynde / and eke his lymes eủerychon̄
The reuers shalt thou se / and that anon̄
And prove it / by thyn owne exꝑperience
That wyn doth folk / noon suche offence
Ther may no wyn / bereve me my myght
Of hand ne foot / ne of myn eyen syght
And for dispite / he drank ful moche more
An hundred part / than he had do bifore
And right anoon / this cursed wrecche
Leet this knyghtes sone / bifore him fecche
Cōmmaundynge hym / he shulde to fore hym stonde
And sodeinly / he toke his bowe / in his honde
And vp the streng / he pulled to his ere
And with an arewe / he slough the childe right there
A now wheither have I / a siker hond or noon
Quod he is al my myght / and al my mynde agoon
Hath wyn berofte me myn eye sight
What shulde I telle / the answere of the knyght
His sone was slayn / ther is no more to sayn
Beth war therfore / with lordes forto playn
Syngeth placebo / and I shal ȝif I can
But ȝif it be / vnto a pore man
To a pore man / men shulde his vices telle
But nouȝt to a lorde / though he shulde go to helle
¶ Lo Irous Cyrus / thilke ꝑpercien
How he destroyed / the ryuer of gysen
For that an hors of his / was dreynt ther ynne
Whan that he wente / Babiloyne to wynne
He made that the Ryuer / was so smal
That wȳmmen myghte / wade it ouer al
Loo what saide he / that wel techen can
Ne be no felawe / to an irous man
Ne with no wood man / walke by the way
Lest the repente / I wol no more say
Now leve brother / lef thyn ire
Thow shalt me fynde / as yust as is a squyer
Holde nouȝt the deueles knyf / ay at thyn herte
Thyn anger doth the / al to sore smerte
But shewe to me / al thy confessioıı̄un
Nay quod the sike man / by seynt Symoıı̄un
I have be shryue this day / at my curate
And have hym tolde / al holy myn astate
It nedeth no more / speken of it seith he
But ȝif me luste / of myn humilite
Ȝeve me than of thy golde / to make oure cloystre
Quod he / for many a muscle / and many an oystre
Whan other men have ben̄ / ful wel at ese
Hath ben oure fode / oure cloystre forto reise
And ȝit god woot / vnnethes the foundement
Parformed is / ne of oure pauement
Ne is nought a tyle / ȝit withynne oure wones
By god we owe / fourty pound for stones
Now helpe Thomas / for him that harwed helle
Or ellis mote we / oure bokes selle
And ȝif ye lakke / oure predicacioıı̄un
Than goth the worlde / al to destruccioıı̄un
For who so wolde fro this world / oure dottryne byreue
So god me save / Thomas by youre leue
He wolde byreue / out of this world the sonne
For who can teche / and worche as we konne
And that is not of lytel tyme / quod he
But syn hely was / or helisee
Han freres ben / that fynde we of record
In charite / ythanked be oure lord
Now Thomas helpe / for seynt charite
Adoon anoon / he sette hym on his kne
This sike man / wax wel nygh wood for ire
He wolde that the frere / hadde ben afire
With his false / dissimilacioıı̄un
Such thyng as is here / in my possessioıı̄un
Quod he / that I may ȝeve / and noon other
Ȝe say me thus / that I am youre brother
Ȝee certes quod the Frere / trusteth me wel
I toke oure dame / oure łletre / and oure sel
Now quod he / and sumwhat shal I ȝeue
Vnto youre holy couent / while that I leue
And in thy hand / thou shalt it have anoon
Vpon this condicioıı̄un / and vpon other noon
Than thow departe it so / my owne dere brother
That euery Frere / have asmoche as other
This shalt thou swere / vp thy professioıı̄un
Withoute fraude / or cauellacioıı̄un
I swere it quod this Frere / vpon my feith
And ther with al / his hand in his he leith
Loo here my feith / in me shal be no lak
Than put thyn hand / doıı̄un by my bak
Seide this man / and grope wel bihynde
Bynethe my buttok / there shalt thou fynde
A thyng that I have / hid in pryuyte
A thouȝt this frere / that shal go with me
And doun his hand he launcheth vnto the clyft
He hoped there / forto have founde a ȝift
And whan the sike man / filte this Frere
Aboute his tuel / gropynge fer and neer
Amyddes his hand / he let the frere a fart
Ther is no capil / drawyng in a cart
That myghte have lete a fart / of such a soıı̄un
The Frere vpsterte / as a fers lyoıı̄un
A false cherle / quod he for cokkes bones
Thus hastow for despite / done for the nones
Thow shalt abye this fart / ȝif that I may
His meyne / whiche that herde this afray
Come lepynge in / and chaced out the Frere
And forth he goth / with a ful angry chere
And fette his felawe / there as lay his store
He loked as he were / a wylde bore
He grunteth his teth / so was he wroth
A sturdy pas / doun to the court he goth
Where as ther woned / a man of grete honour
To whom he was alwey / confessour
This worthy man was lorde / of that village
This Frere cam / as he were in a rage
Where as this lorde / sat etyng at his bord
Vnnethes myghte the Frere / speke aword
Til atte laste / he saide god ȝou se
This lorde gan loke / and seide benedicite
Quod he Frere Iohn̄ / what man̉er world is this
I se wel that som thyng / ther is amys
Ȝe loke as the world / were ful of theves
Sit doun anoon / and tel me what youre greef is
And it shal be amended / ȝif that I may
I have quod he had / a despite today
God ȝelde ȝow adoıı̄un / in youre village
That in this world / is noon so pore a page
That ne wolde have / abhominacioıı̄un
Of that I have receyued / in youre toıı̄un
And ȝit me greueth no thyng so sore
As that this olde cherle / with lokkes hore
Blasphemed hath / oure holy couent eke
Now Maist̉er quod this lorde / I you beseke
No maist̉er quod he / but ʆseruitour
Though I have had / in scole that honoᵘur
God lyketh not / that men vs raby calle
Neyther in market / ne in youre large halle
No force quod he / but telle me of youre greef
Sire quod this Frere / an odious mescheef
This day betid is / to myn ordre and me
And ꝑpar consequens / to eche degre
Of holy chirche / god amende it sone
Sir quod the lorde / ȝe wote what is to done
Distempre ȝou nouȝt / ȝe be my confessour
Ȝe be the salt of the erthe / and the sauour
For goddes loue / youre pacience ye holde
Telleth me youre greef / and he anon hym tolde
As ȝe have herde bifore / ȝe woot wel what
The lady of that hous / ay stille sat
Til she had herde / what the Frere sayde
Ey goddes Moder blisful she saide
Is ther nouȝt elles / telleth me faitfully
Ma dame quod he / how thenketh you therby
How that me thenketh therby / so god me spede
I say a cherle / hath don̄ a cherles dede
What shulde I say / god late hym neủere ythe
His seke hede / is ful of vanyte
I halde hym in man̉ere / of frenesie
Ma dame quod he / by god I shal not lie
But I in other wise / may ben a wreke
I shal sclaundre hym / ouer al where I speke
The false blasphemour / that charged me
To part that / þᵗat myȝt nouȝt departed be
To eủery man yliche / with mischaunce
The lorde sat stille / as he were in a traunce
And in his herte / he rolled vp and doıı̄un
How had this cherle / this ymagynacioıı̄un
To shewe such a ꝓprobleme / to the Frere
Neủere erst er nowe / herde I of suche matere
I trowe the deuel / putte it in his mynde
In ars metrik / shal ther no man fynde
Before this day / of suche a questioıı̄un
Who shulde make / a demonstracioıı̄un
That eủery man / shulde have ylike his part
Of a soıı̄un / or a sauour / of a fart
O nyce proude cherle / I shrewe thy face
Lo sires quod the lord / with harde grace
Who eủere herde / of such a thyng or now
To eủery man yleke / tel me how
It is an impossible / it may not be
Ey nyce cherle / god late hym neủere the
The rumblyng of a fart / and eủery soun
Nys not but of the heire / reủerbaricioıı̄un
And eủere it wasteth / lytel and lytel away
Ther is noo man / can deme by my fay
Ȝif that it were departed equaly
What lo my cherle / lo ȝit how shrowedly
Vnto my confessour / to day he spak
I holde hym certaynly / a demoniak
Now eteth youre mete / and late the cherl go pleye
Lat hym go honge hym self / a deuel weye
¶ Nowe stood the lordes squyer / at the bord
That carf his mete / and herde eủery word
Of al thyng / of whiche I have sayd
My lorde quod he / beth nouȝt evel apayed
I cowthe telle / for a gowne cloth
To you sire Frere / so ȝe be nouȝt wrought
How that this fart / shulde euene deled be
Among youre couent / ȝif it like the
Tel on quod the lorde / and thou shalt have anoon
A gowne cloth / by god / and by seynt Iohn̄
¶ My lorde quod he whan that the weder ys fair
Withoute wynde / or ꝑperturbyng of the air
Lat bryng a cartwhel / here into this halle
But loke he have / his spokes alle
Twelue spokes / hath a carte comounly
And brynge in than / twelue Freres / wite ȝe why
For thrittene is a couent / as I gesse
Youre confessour here / for his worthynesse
Shal ꝑparforme vp the nombre of his couent
Than shul they knele adoıı̄un / by oon assent
And to eủery spokes ende / in this man̉ere
Ful sadly lay his nose / shal a Frere
Youre noble confessour / ther god hym saue
Shal holde his nose / vpright to the nave
Than shal this cherl / with bely hard and touȝt
As eny tabour / hither ben ybrouȝt
And sette hem on the whele / riȝt of this cart
Vpon the nave / and late him lete a fart
And ȝe shul se / vꝑ ꝑperil of my lyf
By preef / which that is demonstratyf
That equaly the soun / of it wol wende
And eke the stynk / vnto the spokes ende
Saf that this worthy man / this confessour
By cause he is a man / of grete honour
Shal have the first fruyt / as resoıı̄un is
The noble vsage / of Freres ȝit is this
The worthy men of hem / shul first be serued
And certeynly he hath it wel disserued
He hath to day / tauȝt vs so moche good
With p̉rechyng in the pulpyt / ther he stood
That I may fouche sauf / I say for me
He hadde the first smel / of fartes thre
And so wolde al his couent / hardely
He berith hym so faire / and holily
The lorde the lady / and eche man saf the Frere
Saiden that Iaynkyn / spak wel in this matere
As wel as Ouyde / or ptolome
Touchinge the cherl thei seide / that subtilite
And high wit / made hym speke as he spak
He is noo fool / ne no demoniak
And Iaynkyn hath ywonne / a newe gowne
My tale is done / we ben almost at towne
¶ This ende the Somnoᵘur /

¶ And bygynneth the ꝓprologe of the Clerk
of Oxenford
Sire clerk of Oxenford / oure host saide
Ȝe ride as stille / and coy as doth a mayde
Were newe spoused / sittynge atte bord
This day ne herde I / of youre mouth a word
I trowe that ye studie / aboute some sophyme
But Salamon seith / that al thyng hath tyme
For goddes sake / betth of better chere
It is no tyme / now to studie here
Tel vs som mery tale / by youre fay
For what man is entred / into a play
He nedes mut / to that play assente
But precheth nouȝt / as Freres done in lente
To make vs for oure olde synnes / forto wepe
Ne that thy tale / ne make vs not to slepe
Tel vs som mery thyng / of auentures
Ȝoure t̉ermes youre figures / and youre coloures
Kepe hem in store / vntil ye luste endite
High stile / as men to kynges write
Speketh so playn̄ / at this tyme I you pray
That we may vnderstonde / what ye say
¶ This worthy clerk / benignely answerde
Ost quod he / I am vnder youre ȝerde
Ȝe have as now / of vs the goủernance
And therfore wol I / do you obeysance
As fer as reson asketh hardely
I wol you telle a tale / which that I
Lerned at padow / of a worthy Clerk
As proued by his wordes / and by his werk
He is now ded / and nayled in his cheste
I pray to god / so sende his soule good reste
Franceys petrak / the laureat poete
Hight this clerk / whos rethorik swete
Enlumyned al lumbardie / of poetrie
As lynyan dide / of philosophie
Or lawe / or other art particuler
But deth that wol suffre no thyng here
But as it were / in twenkelyng of an eye
Bothe hath he slayn / and alle shull deye
But forto tellen / of this worthy man
That taughte me this tale / as I first bigan
I say that he first / with high stile enditeth
Er he the body / of his tale enditeth
A proheme in the whiche / dyscryueth he
The mount / and of saluces the cuntre
And speketh of appenyn / the hilles hye
That ben in the boundes / of west lumbardie
And of mount vesulus / in special
Where as the poo / out of a welle smal
Taketh his first spryngyng / and his sours
Where he holdeth euene / his streght way the cours
To emelward ferare / and venise
The whiche a long thyng were to deuise
And trewely / as to my Iugement
Me thinketh it a thing imꝑpertinent
Save who wol conueye his matere
But this is the tale / which as ȝe shul here /
¶ Thus endeth the prologe / of the Clerk of Oxenford
¶ And here bygynneth his tale ⁊and cᵒ/
¶ Ther is at the west side of ytaile
Don at the rote / of vesulus the colde
A lusty playn / habundant of vitaile
Where many a ton / thou maist biholde
That founded where / in tyme of elders olde
And many another / delitable sight
And Saluces / that noble cuntre hight
¶ A marquis was whilom / in that lond
As were his worthy elders / hym bifore
And obeysant / and redy to his hond
Were alle his leges / bothe lasse and more
Thus in delyte he lyued / and had done ȝore
Beloued and drad / thurgh fauour of fortune
Bothe of his lordes / and of his comune
Ther with was he / as to speke of lynage
The gentillest yborn / of al limbardie
A faire ꝑperson and strong / and yonge of age
And ful of honoᵘur / and of curtesie
Discret ynow / his cuntre for to gye
Save in some thinges / he was to blame
And Walt̉er was / this yonge lordes name
¶ I blame hym thus / that he considered nought
In tyme comynge / what myght betyde
But on his lust p̉resent / was al his thought
And forto hawke / and hunte on euery syde
Wel nygh alle other cures / he leet slyde
And eek he nolde / that \was/ worst alle
Wedde no wyf / for ought that myght bifalle
¶ Only that poynt / his peble bar sore
That flokmel on a day they went
And oon of hem / that wisest was of lore
Or elles that the lorde / wolde best assente
That he shulde telle hym / what his peple mente
Or elles couthe he wel / shewe such matere
He to the marquis / seide as ye may here
¶ O noble marquis / youre humanite
Assureth vs / and ȝeveth vs hardynesse
As ofte tyme / as it is necessite
That we you may telle / oure heuynesse
Accepteth lorde / of youre gentilnesse
That we to you / with pitous herte compleyne
And lat youre eres / nouȝt my voys disdeyne
¶ Al haue I nouȝt to done / in this matere
More than another / hath in this place
Yit for as moche / as ye my lord so dere
Han alwey shewed / fauour and grace
I dar the better / aske of you a space
Of audience / and shewen oure requeste
And ye my lord / to done right as you leste
¶ For certes lord / so wel vs liketh you /
And alle youre werkes / and eủere have done þᵗat we
Ne couthe nouȝt oure self / deuysen how
We myght more lyue / in felicite
Saf oo thing lord / ȝif it youre wille be
That for to be a wedded man / ȝif you leste
Than were youre peple / in souerayn hertes reste
¶ Boweth youre nekke / vnder that blissful ȝok /
Of soủeraynte / nought of seruise
Whiche men clepe / spousaile or wedlok
And thenketh lord / amonge youre thoughtes wise
That of wedlok / cometh grete emprise
For though we slepe / or wake rome or ride
Ay fleeth the tyme / it wol no man abide
¶ And though youre grene youthe / growe as ȝit
In crepeth age / alwey as stille as stoon
And deth manasseth / eủery age and smyt
In eủery astate / for ther ascapeth noon
And also certayn / as we knowe eủerychoon
That we shul dye / and vncerteyn that we alle
Ben of that day / that deth shal on vs falle
¶ Accepteth than of us / the trewe entente
That neủerer ȝit refused youre heste
And we wol alle lorde / ȝif ye wol assente
Chese you a wyf / in short tyme at the leste
Born of the gentillest / and of the meste
Of al this land / so that it ought seme
Honoᵘur to god and yow / as we can deme /
¶ Delyủere vs lorde / of al this besy drede
And take a wyf / for high godes sake
For ȝif it so bifel / as god forbede
That thurgh youre deth / lynage shulde slake
And a straunge lynage shulde take
Youre heritage / o wo were vs on lyue
Wherfore we pray you / hastely to wyue
¶ Her meke prayer / and her pitous chere
Made this marquis / haue such pite
Wol ȝe quod he / myn owne peple dere
To that I neủere er thouȝte / constreyne me
I me reioyse / of my liberte
That selde tyme / is founde in mariage
Ther I was fre / I mot be in seruage
But natheles / I see ȝoure trewe entente
And trust vpon you / and have done ay
Wherfore of my free wil I assente
To wedde me / as sone as eủere I may
But ther as ye / han ꝓprofred me to day
To chese me a wyf / I you relese
That choys / and pray ȝow / of that ꝓprofre cesse
¶ For god it wote / that children ofte been
Vnleke her worthy elders hem bifore
Bounte cometh al of god / nouȝt of the streen
Of whiche they ben / engendred and ybore
I truste in goddes bounte and therfore
My mariage / and myn astate and reste
I him bitake / he may done as him leste
¶ Let me allone / in chesyng of my wyf
That charge vpon my bak / I wol endure
But I pᵃray you / and charge vpon youre lyf
That wyf that I take / ȝe me ensure
To worshipe hir while my lyf endure
In worde and werke / bothe here and elleswhere
As she an emꝑperours doughter were /
¶ And furthermore / this shul ȝe swere þᵗat ȝe
Ageyn my choys / shul neither grucche ne strue
For sithen I shal / forgo my liberte
At youre requeste / as eủere mot I thryue
Ther as myn herte is set / ther wol I wyue
And but ye wol assente / in suche manere
I pray you speketh no more / of this matere
¶ With hertely wil / thei sworen and assenten
To al this thyng / ther saide no wight nay
Besechinge him of gᵃrace / er thei wenten
That he hem wolde graunte / a c̉erteyn day
Of his spousaile / as sone as eủere he may
For ȝit alway / the peple / somwhat dredde
Lest this marquis / wolde no wyf wedde
¶ He gᵃraunted hem a day / such as him leste
On whiche he wolde / be wedded sikerly
And seide he dide al this at her requeste
And they with humble entent / ful buxumly
Knelyng vpon her knees ful reuerently
Him thonkyng alle / and thus thei han an ende
Of her entente / and home aȝen thei wende /
¶ And here vpon / he toke his offic̉ers
Cōmmaundynge for the feste to purueye
And to his prime knightes and squiers
Suche charge ȝaf hem / as him lust on hem leye
And they his comaundentes / dide obeye
And eche of hem / doth his diligence
To done vnto the feste / gret reủerence
Nouȝt fer from thilke place honourable
Where as this marquis / shoop his mariage
Ther stood a thorp / of sigh delitable
In which pore folke / of that village
Hadden her bestes / and herbigage
And of labour / toke her sustenance
After the erthe / ȝaf hem abundaunce
¶ Among this pore folk / ther dwelled a man
Which that was holden / the porest of hem alle
But high god / somtyme sende can
His grace / vnto a litel oxe stalle
Ianicula / men of that thorp him calle
A doughter had he / faire and yong of sight
And Grisildes / this faire maiden hight
¶ But forto speke / of vertuous beaute
Than was she oon the fairest vnder sonne
For poủerly / yfostred vp was she
No likerous lust / was in her yronne
Wel ofter of the welle / than of the tonne
She drank / and she wolde vertue plese
She knewe wel labour / but noon ydelese
¶ But thogh this mayde / tender were of age
Ȝit in the brest of hir virginite
Ther was inclosed / sad and ripe corage
And in grete reủerence / and charite
Hir olde pore Fader / fostred she
A fewe sheep spynnynge on felde she kepte
She wolde not ben ydel / til she slepte
¶ And whan she home com / she welde brynge
Wortes or other herbes tymes ofte
The whiche she shradde / and seth for hir lyuynge
And made hir bedde / ful hard / and thing softe
And eủere she kepte / hir fadres lyue on lofte
With eủery obeysance / and diligence
That child may do / to faders reủerence
¶ Upon Grisilde / that poủere creature
Ful ofte sithes / this marquis sette his eye
As he on hountyng rede / ꝑparauenture
And whan it fel / that he myght here aspye
He nouȝt wᵗith wanton lokyng of folye
His eyen caste on hir / but in sad wise
Vpon hir chere / he wolde him ofte avise
¶ Comendynge in his herte / hir womanhede
And eke her vertue / passyng eny wight
Of so yong age / as wel in chere as dede
For though the peple / haue no grete insight
In vertue / he considered right
Hir bounte / and supposed that he wolde
Wedden her / ȝif eủere he wedden sholde
¶ The day of weddyng cam / but no man can
Telle what woman / it shulde be
(base) For which muayle / wondred many a man
(base) And seiden / whan they were in pduite
(base) Wol nouȝt oure lord / ȝit leue his vanite
(base) Wol he not wedde / allas the while
(base) Why wol he him self / and vs so begile
(base) But natheles / this marquis hath don make
(base) Of gemmes sette / in gold and in asure
(base) Broches and rynges / for Grisildes sake
(base) And of hir clothing / toke he the mesure
(base) Of a maide / ylyke to hir stature
(base) And eke of othere / ornamentes alle
(base) That vn to suche / a weddyng shulde falle
(base) ¶ The tyme of vnderne / of the same day
(base) Approcheth / that this weddyng shulde be
(base) And al the paleys / put was in aray
(base) Bothe halle and chambres / eche in his degre
(base) Houses of office / stuffed with plente
Ther maist thou se / of deyntes vitayle
That may be founde / as fer as laste Itayle
¶ This real Marquis / rychely arrayed
Lordes and ladyes / in his companye
The whiche vnto the feste / were yprayed
And of his retenue / the bachelrye
With many a soıı̄un / of sundry melodye
Vnto the village / of whiche I tolde
In this aray the right way han holde /
¶ Grisilde of this / god woot is ful innocent
That for hir shapen was / al this aray
To fecche water at the welle / is she went
And cometh home / as sone as eủere she may
For wel she had herde / that thilke day
The Marquis shulde wedde / and ȝif she myȝte
She wolde fayn / han seen of that sighte
She saide she wolde / wᵗith other maydenes stande
That ben my felowes / in oure dore and se
The marquis / and therfore wol I fande
To done at home / as sone / as it may be
The labour / which that longeth vnto me
And than I may at leiser / hir biholde
Ȝif she this way / to the Castel holde
¶ And as she wolde / ouer thresshold goon
The Marquis cam / and gan hir forto calle
And sette she don / hir water pot a noon
Beside the thresshold / of the oxe stalle
And don vpon hir knees / she gan falle
With sad cuntynance / knelyng stille
Til she had herde / what was the lordes wille
¶ This thoughtful marquis / spak vnto this mayde
Ful sobrely and seide in this manere
Where is youre Fader / Grisilde he sayde
And she with reủerence / and in humble chere
Sayde / lorde he is al redy here
And in she goth / withoute eny lette
And to the marquis / she hir Fader sette
¶ He by the hand / toke this olde man
And saide thus / whan he him had a side
Ianicula / I neither may ne can
Lenger the plesaunce / of myn herte hide
Ȝif that thou fouchesauf / what so betide
Thy doughter wol I take / er than I wende
As for my wyf / vnto hir lyues ende /
¶ Thow louest me / I woot it wel certayn
And art my liege man ybore
And al that liketh me / I dar wel sayn
It leketh the / and specially therfore
Tel me that poynt / that ȝe han herde bifore
Ȝif that ye wole / vnto this purpos drawe
To take me / as for thy sone in lawe
¶ This sodeine cas / the man astoned so
That rede he waxe / abasshed al quakynge
He stood vnnethes / seide he wordes mo
But only thus / lord quod he my wilnyng
Is as \ȝe/ wele / natheles ageyn youre lykyng
I wol noo thyng do / ȝe be my lorde so dere
Right as you luste / so goủerneth this matere /
¶ Ȝit wol I quod this marquis / that softely
That in thy chambre / I and thou and she
Haue a colacion / and wost thou why
For I wol aske / ȝif it hir wille be
To be my wyf and rule hir after me
And al this shal be done / in thy p̉resence
I wol nouȝt speke / out of thyn audience
And in her chambre / whiles thei were aboute
Her tretys / which ȝe shul after here
The peple com / to the hous withoute /
And wondred hem / in how honeste man̉ere
And tentifly she kepte her Fader dere
But outterly / Grisilde wondre myght
For neủere er / saugh she / such a syght
¶ No wonder is / though she were astoned
To se so greet a gest / come in suche a place
She neủere was to suche gestes woned
For whiche she loked / with ful pale face /
But shortly / this mater for to pase
Thise ben the wordes / that the marquis saide
To this benigne / verray feithful mayde
¶ Grisilde he saide / ȝe shal wel vnderstande
It liketh vnto youre Fader / and to me
That I you wedde / and eke it may so stande
As I suppose / ȝe wol that it so be
But thise demaundes / aske I furst quod he
That sithe it shal be done / in hasty wyse
Wole ȝe assente / or wol ȝe ȝou avise
¶ I say thus / be ȝe redy with goode herte
To al my lust / that I frely may
As me best luste / to do ȝou laughe or smerte
And neủere ȝe / to grucche / nyght ne day
And eke whan I say ȝe / ne say nouȝt nay
Neither by worde / frownyng ne countenance
Swere this / and I assure oure alliaunce
¶ Wonderynge vpon this worde / quakynge for drede
She saide lorde / vndigne and vnworthy
Am I to thilke honour / that ȝe me bede
But as ȝe wol youre self / so wele I.
And here I swere / that neủere willyngly
In werke ne in thought / I wol ȝou disobeye
For to be ded / though me were loth to deye /
¶ This is ynogh / Grisilde myn / quod he
And forth he goth / with a noble chere
Out at the dore / and after that com she
And to the peple / he saide in this manere
This is my wyf quod he / that standeth here
Honureth hir / and loueth hir I you pray
Who so loue me / ther is no more to say
¶ And for that no thyng / of hir olde gere
She shulde brynge / into his house he bad
That wymen shulde / spoylen hir right there
Of whiche ladies / were no thyng glad
To handele hir clothes / wher in she was clad
But nathelees / this mayde bright of hewe
Fro foot to hed / they have clothed al newe
¶ Here heres / thei kembed / that lay vtressed
Ful redely / and with hir fyngers smale
A corowne on hir hed / have they dressed
And sette hir ful / of owches smale
Of hir aray wharto / shulde I make a tale
Vnnethes the peple / knewe hir for hir fayrnesse
Whan she tᵃransunted was / in suche richesse
¶ This marquis hath hir / spoused wᵗith a ryng
Bouȝt for the same / cause / and than hir sett
Vpon an hors white / and wel āmblyng
And to his palys / er he lenger lett
With ioyful peple / that hir ladde and mett
Couneyinge hir / and thus þis day they spende
In reuel / til day condescende
¶ And shortly / this tale forto pace
I say that this newe / marquisesse
God hath such fauour / sende of his gᵃrace
That it ne semeth not / by liknesse
That she was born / and fed in rudenesse
As in a cote / or in an oxe stalle
But in an emꝑperours halle /
¶ To eủery wight / she woxen is so dere /
And worshipful / that there she was born
And fro hir birthe / knewe hir ȝere by ȝere
Vnnethes trowe they / but dorste hau sworn
That to Ianicle / of which I spak biforn
She douȝter nas / as by comecture
Hem thought she was / a nother creature
¶ For though that vertuous was she
She was encresed / in excellence
Of thewes goode / and set in grete bounte
And for discrete / and faire of eloquence
So benigne / and so digne of reủerence
And coude so / the peples herte enbrace
That alle hir loued / that loked in hir face
¶ Nouȝt only of saluces / in the toun
Publisshed was / the bounte of hir name
But eke beside / in many a regioun
Ȝif oon seide wel / another saide the same
So spredeth / of here grete bounte the name
That men and wymmen / bothe yonge and olde
Goon to Saluces / hir beaute to be holde
¶ This walter worthyly / and really
Weddeth this honest mayde / with herte fre
In goode pees / they lyue ful honestly
And for he saugh / vnder lowe degre
At home and outward / grace ynogh had she
Was ofte vertue hid / the peple hir heelde
As prudent / and that is seen ful seelde
¶ Nouȝt only this Grisilde / thurgh hir wyt
Coude al the feet / of wyfly humblenesse
But eke whan the cas / required it
The comom ꝓprofite / couthe she redresse
Ther nas discord / rancour ne heuynesse
In al that land / that she ne couthe it pese
And wysly brynge hem / in hertes ese /
¶ Though that hir husbonde / were or noon
Or gentil men othere / of that cuntre
Were wrough / she wolde bryngen hem at oon
So wise and ripe wordes / had she
And iugementes / of so greet equite
That she from heuene sent was men wende
Peple to save / and eủery wrong to amende /
¶ Nouȝt longe tyme / that this Grisilde
Was wedded / she a childe had y bore
Al had she leủere / hau boren a knave childe
Glad was the marquis / and his folk therfore
For though a mayde / child / come al bifore
She may vnto / a knave child atteyne
Licly syn she is nouȝt bareyne /
Ther fel it as it falleth tymes mo
Whan that this child / had soken but a throwe
This marquis in his herte / thouȝt so
To tempte his wyf hir sadnesse forto knowe
That he ne myȝte it / out of his herte throwe
This meruaillous desire / his wyf to assaye
Nathalees god woot / he thouȝte hir forto affraye
¶ He hath assaied here / ynogh bifore
And founde hir her good / what nedeth it
Hir forto tempte / alday more and more
But as for me / I say that euele it sit
Though some men preise it / for a subtil wit
To assaien a wyf / whan it is nede
And putten hir / in anguissh and in drede
¶ For which this Marquis / wrouȝte in this man̉ere
He come a nyght / allone ther as she lay
With sterne face / and troubled heuy chere
And saide thus / Grisilde that ylke day
That I you toke / out of youre poủere aray
And putte you in astate / of high noblesse
Ȝe have it nouȝt / forgeten as I gesse
¶ I say Grisilde / this p̉resent dignite
In which I have put you / as I trowe
Maketh you foryetfull / for to be
That I you toke / in poủere estate ful lowe
For eny wele / ȝe moten youre seluen knowe
Take hed of euery worde / that I you say
Ther is no wight / that hereth but we tway
¶ Ȝe wete youre self ful wel / how ȝe com here
Into this hous / it is not longe ago
And though to me / ȝe be right leef and dere
Vnto my gentiles / ȝe be no thyng so /
They to hem / it is greet shame and wo
Forto \be/ suget / and forto be in serviage
To the that born art / in so smal lynage
¶ And namely sithe thy doughter was ybors
Thise wordes have they / spoken douteles
But I desire / as I have do bifore
To loue my wyf with hem in reste and pees
I may nouȝt in this cas / be recheles
I mot do by thy doughter / for the beste
Nouȝte as I wolde / but as my gentiles leste
¶ And ȝit god woot/ it is ful wo to me
And nathalees / withoute youre wetynge
I wol nouȝt do / but this wolde I quod he
That ȝe to me assente / as in this thynge
Sheweth now youre pacience / in youre wirchynge
That me bihighte / and swore in youre village
That day that maked was oure mariage /
¶ Whan she had herde al this / she nouȝt ameued
Neither in worde / chere / ne in cuntenance
For as it semed / she was not agreued
She saide lorde / al lith in youre plesance
My childe and I / with mylde obeysance
Be ȝoures / al may ȝe save or spille
Ȝoure owne thyng / worcheth after youre wille /
¶ Ther may no thyng / so god my soule save
Likyng to you / that may displese me
Ne I desire / no thyng forto have
Ne drede forto lese / saf only ȝe
This wil is in myn herte / and ay shal be
No lengthe of tyme / ne deth may this deface
Ne chaunge my corage / to noon other place /
¶ Glad was this Marquis / for hir answeryng
But ȝit he feyned / as it were not so
Al drery was his chere / and his lokyng
Whan that he shulde / out of the chambre go
Sone after this / a forlong wey or two
He priuely / hath tolde al his entent
Vnto a man / and to his wyf him sent
¶ A maner of a seriaunt / was this pⁱriue man
The whiche feithful / he yfounden hadde
In thinges greet / and eke suche folk can
Done execucion / on thinges badde
The lorde knewe wel / that he him loued and dradde
And whan this seriaunt / knewe his lordes wille
Into the chambre / he stalketh him ful stille /
¶ Madame he seide / ȝe mot forȝeue it me
Though I do thyng / to which I am constreyned
Ȝe be ful wys / that ful wel knowe ȝe
That lordes heste / may not ben yfeyned
They may wel biwayled / or compleyned
But men mote nedes / to hir lust obeye /
And so wol I / ther is no more to seye
¶ This child am I / comaunded forto take
And spak no more / but vp the child he hente
Dispitously / and gan a chere make
As though he wolde / han slayn it er he wente
Grisilde mote nede / al suffre and consente
And as a lamb / she sit meke and stille
And lete this cruel seriaunt done his wille
¶ Suspecious was the fame / of this man
Suspect his face / suspect his word also
Suspect the tyme / in which he this bigan
Allas hir doughter / that she loued so
She wende he wolde / han slayn hir right tho /
But nathelees / she noþ̉er wepeth ne syketh
Conformynge hir to þᵗat the Marquis lyketh
¶ But atte laste / to speken she bigan
And mekely to the seriaunt preyde
So as he was / a worthy gentil man
That she must kisse / hir childe er þᵗat it deyde
And in hir barme / this litel childe she leyde
With ful sad face / and gan the childe to blesse
And lulled it / and after gan it kisse /
¶ And thus she seide / in hir benigne voys
Fare wel my childe / I shal the neủere y se
But sithen I have marke the / with the croys
Of thilke fader / blessed mote thou be /
That for vs deyed / vpon a croye of tree
Thy soule litel childe / I him bytake
For this nyght shalt thou dye for my sake
¶ I trowe that to a norice / in that caas
It hadde ben harde / this ruthe to se
Wel myghte a moder / than cryen allas
But natheles so sad / and stedfast was she
That she endured / al hir aduersite
And to the seriaunt / mekely she sayde
Have here ageyn / ȝoure litel mayde
¶ Goth now quod she / and doth my lordes heste
But oo thyng wole I pᵃray you / of youre gᵃrace
That but my lorde / forbede ȝou at the leste
Berieth this litel body / in som place
That bestes ne briddes / ne do it race
But he no worde / to the purpos wolde seye
But toke the childe / and wente forth his weye
¶ This seriaunt com / vnto his lorde ageyn
And of Grisildes wordes / and of hir chere
He tolde hym poynt fro poynt / short and playn
And him p̉resenteth / with his dought̉er dere
Somwhat this lorde / hath ruthe in his man̉ere
But nathalees / his purpos halt he stille
As lordes done / whan they wol han her wille
¶ And bad this sergeant / that he priuely
Shulde this childe / ful softe wynde and wrappe
With alle circumstances tenderly
And carie it in a cofre / or in a lappe
But vp peyne his hed of / forto swappe
That no man shulde knowe / of this entente
Ne whennes he com / ne whider that he wente
¶ But at Boleyne to his Sust̉er dere
That thilke tyme / of pauye was contesse
He shulde it taken / and shewen hir this mat̉er
Bisechyng hir / to done hir besynesse
This childe to fostren / in al gentilnesse
And whos childe that it was / bad hir hide
Fro eủery wight / for oughte þᵗat myght betyde /
¶ The sergeant goth / and hath fulfilled thyng
But to this Marquis / now retorne we
But now goth he / ful of ymaynyng
Ȝif by his wyves cheere / he myght yse
Or by hir word / and pᵃarceyue that she
Were chaunged / but neuere he couthe fynde
But eủere in oon / in lyche sad and kynde
¶ As glad as humble / as blithe in seruise
And eke in loue / as she was wont to be
Was she to hym / in eủere man̉er wise
Ne of hir doughter / nouȝt a word spak she
Ne noon accident / for noon adủersite
Was seen in hir / ne neủere hir doughter name
Nempned she / in ernest / nor in game
In this estate / passed ben foure ȝere
Er she wᵗith child was / but as god wolde
A knaue childe she had / by this walter
Ful gᵃracious / and faire to be holde
And whan that men / to his Fader tolde
Nouȝt only he / but al his cuntre merye
Was for this child / and god they thonke and herye
¶ Whan this was two ȝere olde / and fro the breste
Departed fro his norice / vpon a day
This Marquis cauȝte ȝit / another lest
O nedeles was / he thought he wol assay
To tempte his wyf eft / ȝif that if he may
But wedded men / knowe no mesure
Whan that they fynde / a pacient creature
¶ Wyf quod this Marquis / ȝe han herde or this
My peple sikly bere / youre mariage
And namely now / my sone born is
Now is it worse / than eủere in al oure age
The murmoᵘur sleeth myn herte / and my corage
For to myn eres / cometh the voys so smerte
That wel nygh destroyed is / al myn herte /
¶ Now say they thus / whan walter is a goon /
Than shal the blood / of Ianycle succede
And ben oure lord / for other have we noon
Suche wordes seith my peple / it is no drede
Wel oughte I / of suche murmoᵘur take hede
For certeinly I drede such sentence
Though they not pleinly speke in myn audience
¶ I wolde lyue in pees / ȝif that I myghte
Wherfore I am disposed / al vtterly
As I his sust̉er / serued by nyghte
Right so thenke I / to serue him trewely
This warne I you / that ȝe not sodeinly
Out of youre self / for no wo shulde outraye
Beth pacient / and therof I you praye
¶ I have quod she / said and eủere shal
I wol no thyng / ne wilne no thyng certayn
But as you lust / nouȝt greueth me at al
Though that my dought̉er / and my sone be slayn
At youre cōmmaundement / this is to sayn
I haue nouȝt had / part of children tweyne
But first siknes / and after wo and peyne /
¶ Ȝe be my lorde / doth with youre owne thyng
Right as you lust / asketh no rede of me
For as I lefte at home / al my clothyng
Whan I com first to ȝou / right so quod she
Lefte I my wil / and my liberte
And toke youre clothyng / and therfore I you praye
Doth youre plesance / I wol youre lust obeye
¶ And certes / ȝif I had prescience
Ȝoure wil to knowe / or ȝe youre lust me tolde
I wolde it do withoute negligence
But now I woot ȝoure lust / and what ȝe wolde
Al youre plesaunce / ferme and stable I holde
For wist I that my deth / wolde do ȝou ese
Right gladly wolde I dye / ȝow to plese
¶ Deth may not make / no comparison
Vnto oure loue / and that Marquis say
The constance of his wyf / he cast a don
His eyen two / and wondreth that she may
In pacience / suffren al this aray
And forth he goth / with drery countenance
But to his herte / it was ful greet plesance
¶ This egre sergeant / in the same wise
That he hir doughter caught / right so he
Or worse / ȝif he worse couthe deuyse
Hath caught hir sone / þᵗat was ful of beaute
And eủere in oon / so pacient was she
That she no chere made / of heuynesse
But kisseth hir sone / and after gan it blesse
¶ Sauf this she prayed him / ȝif that he myghte
Hir litel sone / he wolde on erthe graue
His tendre lymes / delicate to sighte
Fro foules and bestes / forto save
But she non answere / of hym myght have
He wente his way / as he no thyng rouȝte
But into Boloyne / he tenderly it brouȝte
¶ This Marquis wondreth / euere lenger the more
Vpon his pacience / and ȝif that he
Ne had sothly yknowe / therbifore
That parfitely / hir childern loued she
He wolde haue wend / that of som sotilte
Or of malice / or cruel corage
That she had suffred this / wᵗith sad visage
¶ But he knewe / that next hym self certayn
She loued hir childern / best in eủery wise
But now of women / wolde I aske fayn
Ȝif thise assaies / myghte not suffise
That couthe / a sturdy husbond deuise
To preue hir wyfhode / and hir stidefastnesse
And be contynuynge / in sturdynesse
¶ But ther be folk / of such condicion
That whan they have / a certayn purpos take
They con not stynte / of her entencion
But as they were / bounde to a stake
They wol not / of that purpos slake
Right so this Marquis / hath fully purposed
To tempten his wyf as he was first disposed
¶ He wayteth ȝif by wordes / or contenance
Ȝif she to hym / was chaunged of corage
But neủere couthe he / fynde variance
She was ay oon in herte / and visage
But ay the ferther / that she was in age
The more trewe / ȝif it were possible
She was to hym in loue / and more penible
¶ For which it semed / thus of hem two
Ther nas but oon wil / but as walter lest
That same lust was hir plesaunce also /
And god be thanked / al fel for the best
She shewed wel / for noo worldly vnrest
A wyf as of hir self / no thyng sholde
Wilne in effecte / but as hir husbonde wolde
¶ The sclaunder of Walter / ful wyde aboute spradde
That of cruel herte / he wickedly
For he a pore woman / wedded hadde
Hath morthered / bothe his children pryuely
Which among hem / was tolde comōmonly
No wonder was / forto the peples ere
Ther com no word / but that they mordred were /
¶ For which ther as the peple / ther bifore
Had loued him wel / the sclaunder of his name
Made hem that they / haten hem therfore
To ben a morderer / it is an hateful name
But nathalees / for ernest ne for game
He of his cruel purpos / wolde neủere stynte
To tempte his wyf / was al his entente
Whan that this doughter xii ȝere was of age
He to the court of Rome / in sotil wise
Enformed of his wil / sente his message
Cōmandynge hem / suche bulles to deuise
As to his cruel purpos / may suffise
How that the pope / for his peples reste
Bad hym to wedde a nother / ȝif that hym leste
¶ I say he bad / they shulde countrefete
The popes bulles / makyng mencion
That he hath leue / first wyf to lete
As by the popes / dispensacion
To stinte rancour and discencion
Betwixe the peple and hym / thus saith the bulle
The whiche they have / publisshed to the fulle
¶ The rude peple / as no wonder is
Wende ful wel / it had be right so
But this tidyng come to Grisilde is
I deme that \hir/ herte / was ful wo
But she was ylike sad / eủere mo
Disposed was / this humble creature
This adủersite / of fortune to endure /
¶ Abidyng eủere his lust / and his plesaunce
To whom she was / ȝeuen herte and al
As to hir worldly suffisaunce
For certeinly / his story telle I shal
This Marquis / ywreten hath in special
A łlet in whiche / he sheweth his entente
And sikerly he it to boleyne sente
¶ To the yerle of pauye / which that had so
Wedded his suster / he prayed specialy
To bringen hym ayen / his children two
In honurable estate / al openly
But of oo thyng / he prayed al vtterly
That he to no wight / though men wolde enquere
Sholde not telle / whos childern they were /
¶ But say that the mayde / shulde wedded be
Vnto the Marquis / of Saluce anon
And as the Erle was preide / so did he
For at a day ysett / he on his way is gon
Toward Saluce / and lordes manyon
In ryche aray / this mayde forto gyde
Hir yonge brother / rydynge by hir syde
¶ Arrayed was / toward this mariage
This Maide fressh / ful of gemmes clere
Hir brother / that seuene ȝere was of age
Arrayed eke was fresshly / on his manere
And in grete noblesse / and glad chere
Toward Saluce / shapinge her iournay
From day to day / they riden forth her way
¶ Among al this / after his wikked vsage
This Marquis / ȝit his wyf to tempte more
To the vtterest preef / of his corage
Fully to have / exꝑperience in lore
Ȝif that she were / as stedefast as byfore
He on a day / in open audience
Ful boistousely / hath saide hir this sentence
¶ Certes Grisilde / I had ynogh plesaunce
To have you to my wyf / for youre goodenesse
And for youre trouthe / and for youre obeysaunce
Nouȝt for youre lynage / ne for youre richesse
But is now knowe / in verray sothnesse
That in greet. lordshipe / ȝif I wol avise
Ther is greet soủeraignte / in sundry wise
¶ I may not done / as eủery ploughman may
My peple me constreyne forto take
Another wyf / and cryen day by day
And eke the pope / rancour forto slake
Consenteth it / that thar I vndertake
And trewely / thus moche I wol you say
My newe wyf / is comynge by the way
¶ Be stronge of herte / and voyde anon place
And thilke dowary / that ȝe brought to me
Take it ayen / I graunte it of my grace
Retourneth to youre Faders hous / qduod he
No man may alwey / have prosꝑperite
With euene herte / I rede you to endure
The strook of fortune / or of auenture
¶ And she ayein / answerde in pacience
My lorde qduod she / I woot and wiste alway
How that I swore / to youre magnifice
And my pouert / no man ne can ne may
Make no comparison / it is no nay
I helde me never / digne in no manere
To be youre wyf / ne ȝit youre chambrere
¶ And in thus hous / there ye me lady made
The high god / take I for witnesse
So wisly / as he my soule save
I heeld me neither / lady ne maistresse
But humble seruant / to youre wordynesse
And euẻer shal / while my lyf may endure
Aboue euery other creature
¶ That ye so longe / of youre benignite
Have holde me in honour / and in nobleye
Where I was not / worthy forto be
That thonke I god and you / whom I preye
For ȝelde it you / ther is no more to seye
Vnto my Fader / gladly wol I wende
And with him dwelle / vnto my lyves ende
¶ Ther as I was fostred / a child ful smale
Til I be ded my lyf wol I lede
A widewe clene / in herte body and al
For sitthen I ȝaf / to you my maydenhede
And am youre trewe wif / it is no drede
God shilde / suche a lordes wyf to take
A nother man / to husbonde or to make
¶ And of youre newe wif / god of his gᵃrace
So graunte you welthe / and ꝓprosꝑperite
For I wol gladly / ȝelden hir my place
In whiche I was blisful wont to be
For sitthe it leketh / to you my lorde quod she
That whilom were / al myn hertes reste
That I shal goon / I wol goon whan you leste
¶ But there as ye me profre / suche doware
As I first brouȝt / it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrecched clothes / no thyng faire
The whiche to me / were now ful harde to fynde
O god / how gentil / and how kynde
Ȝe semed by youre speche / and youre visage
The day that maked was / oure mariage
¶ But soth is said / algate I fynde it trewe
For in effecte / it is ꝓproued now on me.
Loue is not olde / as whan it is newe
For certes lorde / for non adủersite
To dyen in this caas / it shal not be
That in worde or werk / I shal me repente
That I you ȝaf myn herte / in good entente
¶ My lorde ȝe woot that in my faders place
Ȝe dide me stripe / out of my pore wede
And richely ye cladde me / of youre gᵃrace
To ȝou brought I not ellis / out of drede
But faith mekenesse / and maidenhede
But here aȝein / youre clothyng I restore
And eke my weddyng ryng / for euermore
¶ The remanent of youre Iewels / redy be
Withynne youre chambre / dar I sauely seyn
Naked out of my faders hous / quod she
I cam / and naked mote turne ageyn /
Al youre plesaunce / wol I folwe fayn
But ȝit I hope / it be nouȝt oure entente
That I smoklees / out of youre paleis wente
¶ Ȝe coude not do / so dishonest a thyng
That thilke wombe / in whiche youre childern lay
Shulde bifore the peple / in my walkynge
Be seen al bare / wherfore I you pray
Lat me not lyke a worme / gon by the way
Remembre you / myn owne lorde so dere
I was youre wyf / though I vnworthy were /
¶ Wherfore in guerdon / of my maydenhede
Which that I brought / and nouȝt ageyn bere
As voucheth sauf / to ȝeue me to my mede
But suche a smok / as I was wont to were
That I therwith / may hele the wombe of here
That was youre wyf / and here I take my leve
Of ȝou myn owne lorde / lest I you greue
¶ The smok quod he / that thou hast on thy bak
Lat it be stille / and bereth it forth wᵗith the
But wel vnnethe / that worde he spak
But wente his way / for ruthe and pite
Bifore the folk / hir self stripeth she
And in hir smok / with hed and feet al bare
Toward hir fadres hous / forth is fare
¶ The folk folwed / wepyng in hir way
And fortune eủere / they cursed as they goon
But she fro wepyng / kepte eyen ay
Ne in this tyme / word spak she noon
Her fader that here of / herde anoon
Cursed the day / and tyme þᵗat nature
Shape him to be / a lyues creature /
¶ For out of doute / this olde pore man
Was eủere suspecte / of hir mariage
For eủere he demed / sithen it bigan
That whan the lorde / had filled his corage
Him wolde thenke / it were a disꝑparage
To his astate / so lough to alighte
And voiden here / as sone as eủere he myghte
¶ Ayein his doughter / hastely goth he
For he by the noyse of folk / knewe hir comynge
And with hir olde cote / as it myght be
He coủereth hir / ful sorowefully wepynge
But on hir body / myght he it not brynge
For rude was the cloth / and more of age
By dayes fele / than hir mariage
¶ Thus with hir fader / for a certein space
Dwelleth this flour / of wyfly pacience
That neủere by here wordes / ne by hir face
Bifore the folk / ne in hir absence
Ne shewed she / that to hir was done offence
Ne of high astate / in remembrance
Ne had she / as by hir countenaunce
¶ Ne wonder is / for in greet astate
Here goost was eủere / in pleine humilite
Ne tender mouth / ne herte delicate
Ne pompe / ne semblant of rialte
But ful of pacience / and benignite
Discrete prudent / and eủere honurable
And to hir husbond / eủere meke and stable
¶ Men speke of Iob / and most for his humblesse
As clerkes what hem lust / can wel endite
Namely of men / but in sothfastnesse
Though clerkes preise wymen but a lite
Ther can no man / in humblesse hem aquite
As wōmen can / ne ben half so trewe
As wōmen ben/ but it be falle of newe
¶ Fro boloyne is this Erle / of panye come
Of whiche the worde / sprong to more and lesse
And to the peples eres / alle and some
Was come eke / a newe marquisesse
He with him brought / in pompe / and such richesse
That was neủere seen / with mannes eye
So noble aray / in westlumbardye
¶ The Marquis / that shop and knewe al this
Er that this Erle was come / sente his message
For sely pore Grisilde / which his wyf is /
And she with humble herte / and glad visage
Nouȝt with swollen herte / in hir corage
Come at his heste / and on hir knees hir sette
And reủerently / and wisely she him grette
¶ Grisilde quod he / my wil is vtterly
This mayde that shal / wedded be to me
Receyued be to morowe / as realy
As it is possible / in myn hous to be
And eke that eủery wight in his degre
Haue his estate / in sittyng and seruise
And also plesaunce / as ye can best deuise
¶ I haue no woman / suffisant certayn
The chambres to araye / in ordinance
After my lust / and therfore wolde I fayn
That thyn / were al such goủernance
Thou knewest eke of olde / al my plesance
Though thyn aray be badde / and euel yseye
Do thy deuour / at the leste weye
¶ Nouȝt only lorde / that I am glad quod she
To do youre lust / but I desire also
Ȝoure wyf for to plese / and serue in my degre
Withoute feyntise / and shal eủere mo
Ne neủere for no wele / ne for no wo
Ne shal þe goost / wᵗithyn myn herte stente
To loue you best / wᵗith al my trewe entente
¶ And with that word / she gan the hous to dighte
And tables to sette / and beddes to make
And peyned hir / to done al that she myghte
Prayinge the chambrers / for goddes sake
To hasten hem / and faste swepe and shake
And she the moste / seruisable of alle
Hath eủery chambre / arrayed and his halle
¶ Aboute vnderne / gan this Erle alighte
That with him brought / thise noble children tweye
For whiche the peple / ran to se that sight
And hir aray / so richely beseye
And than at erst / among hem thei gan seye
That walter was noo fool / though him leste
To chaunge his wyf / for it was for the beste
¶ For she is fairer / as they demen alle
Than is Grisilde / and more tendre of age
And fairer fruyt / bitwene hem shulde falle
And more plesant / for hir high lynage
Hir brother so faire was / of his age
That him to seen / the peple hath cauȝt plesance
Cōmendynge now / the Marquis goủernance
¶ O sterne peple / vnsad and vntrewe
Euere vndiscrete / and chaungynge as a fane
Delitynge eủere in rumour / that is newe
For lyke the mone / eủere wexe ȝe and wane
Eủere ful of clappyng / dere ynogh a Iane
Ȝoure dome is fals / youre constance euele p̉erueth
A wel greet fool is he / that on you leueth
¶ Thus seide sad folk / in that Citee
Whan that the peple / gased vp and don
For they were glad / right for the nouelte
To make a newe lady / of her ton
No more of this / make I mencion
But to Gresilde / aȝen wol I me dresse
And tellen hir constance / and hir besinesse
¶ Wel besy was Grisilde / in eủery thyng
That to the feste / was ꝑpertinent
Right nouȝt was she / abasshed of hir clothyng
Though thei were rude / and eke somdel to rent
But with glad chere / to the gate is went
With other folk to grete the Marquisesse
And after doth she forth / hir besynesse
¶ With ful glad chere / the gestes she receyveth
And buxomly / eủerich in his degre
That no man defaute / ther ꝑperceyveth
But eủere thei wondren / what she myght be
That in so poủere aray / was for to se
And couthe such honour / and reủerence
And worthyly / they preysen hir prudence
¶ In al this mene while / she ne stente
This maiden / and eke hir brother to comende
With al hir herte / and benigne entente
So wel that no man / coude hir pⁱrise amende /
But atte laste / whan alle thise lordes wende
To sitte a don / he gan to calle
Grisilde as she was besy in the halle /
¶ Grisilde quod he / as it were in play
How liketh the / my wyf in hir beaute
Right wel quod she / my lord / for in goode fay
A fairer / saugh I neủere / noon quod she
I pray to god / so ȝeve you ꝓproꝑper>ite
And so hope I / he wol to you sende
Plesance ynogh / to ȝoure lyues ende
¶ But oo thyng I biseche / and warne also
That ȝe prike / with no tormentyng
This tendre mayde / as ye have do mo
For she is fostred / in hir norisshyng
Ful tenderly / in hir yonge pleying
She coude not / aduersite endure
As coude / a pore fostred creature
And whan this walter / saugh hir pacience
Hir glad cheer / and no malice at al
And he so ofte / hath done hir offence
And she eủere constant / and sad as a wal
Contynuynge euere / hir innocence oủer al
This sturdy Marquis / gan his herte dresse
To rewe vpon hir / wifly stidefastnesse
¶ This is ynogh / Grisilde myn quod he
Be no more agast / ne evel appaied
I have thi feith / and thi benignite
As wel as eủere / woman was assaied
In grete astate / and poủerly araied
Now knowe I dere wyf / thi stedefastnesse
And hir in his armes / toke and gan to kesse
¶ And she for wonder / toke therof no kepe
She herde not what thing / that he saide
She ferde as she had stert out of hir slepe
Til she out of the masednesse abreide
Grisilde quod he / by god that for vs deide
Thou art my wyf / and noon other wol I have
Ne neủere had / as god my soule save /
¶ This is thy doughter / which thou hast supposed
To be my wyf / and noon other feithfully
Thy sone shal be myn heire / as I haue euere disposed
Thou bere hym in thy body / trewely
At boloyne have I kepte / hem sikerly
Take hem aȝein / for thou myght nouȝt seyn
That thou hast lorn / eny of thy children tweyn
¶ And folk that other wise han seide of me
I warne hem wel / that I have done this dede
For noo malice / ne for noo cruelte
But for to assaie / thy womanhede
And not forto sle my children / god forbede
But forto kepen hem / priuely and stille
Til I thy purpos knewe / and al thy wille
¶ And whan she this herde / adōn in swon she falleth
For pitous ioying / and after hir swownynge
She bothe hir yonge children / to hir calleth
And in hir armes / pitously wepynge
Enbraced bothe / tenderly kissynge
Wel like a moder / wᵗith hir salt teres
She bathed bothe / her visage and her heres /
¶ O suche a pitous thyng / it was to se
Hir swownynge / and hir pitous voys to here
Gram̉ercy my lorde / god thonke you quod she
That ȝe han saued me / my children dere
Now recche I neủere / to be ded right here
Sitthe I stonde in youre loue / and in youre grace
No force of deth / ne whan my spirite pace
¶ O tendre / o dere / o yonge children myn
Ȝoure woful Moder / wende stedefastly
That cruel houndes / or som vermyn
Had eten you / but god of his mercy
And youre benigne Fader / tenderly
Hath done you kepte / and the same stounde
Al sodeinly she swapte don to grounde
¶ And in his swon / so sadly holdeth she
Hir children two / whan she gan hem brace
That with grete sleighte / and dificulte
The children from her armes / gonne they to rase
O many a tere / o many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem / that stoden hir beside
Vnnethe aboute hir / myghte they abide
¶ Walter hir vptaketh / and hir sorwe gladeth
She ariseth vp al a basshed / from hir traunce
And eủery wight hir ioy / and feste maketh
Til she have caught / aȝen hir countenaunce
Walter hir doth / so feithfully plesance
That it was deynte / forto se the chere
Bytwext hem two / now thei ben mette in fere
¶ Thise ladyes / whan they hir tyme say
Han taken hir / and into chambre is goon
And stripen hir / out of hir rude aray
And in a cloth of gold / that bright shon
With a crowne of many a riche stoon
Vppon hir hede / thei hir in halle broughte
And there she was / honoured as she oughte
¶ Thus hath this pitous day / a blisful ende
And eủery man / and woman doth his myght
This day in merthe / and reuel to dispende
Tyl on the welken / shon the sterres bright
For more solempne / in eủery mannes sight
This feste was / and gretter of costage
Than was the reuel / of the mariage
¶ Ful many a ȝere / in high proꝑperite
Lyuen thise two / in oon accorde and reste
And richely his doughter maried he
Vnto a lorde / oon of the worthieste
Of al ytaile / and than in pees and in reste
His wifes Fader / in his courte he kepeth
Til that his soule / out of his body crepeth
¶ His sone entreth / into his heritage
In reste and pees / after his Fadres day
And fortunat was eke / in mariage
Al putt he nouȝt / his wyf in assay
This worlde is not so strong / it is no nay
As it hath ben / in olde tymes ȝore
And herkeneth what the Auctour seith therfore
¶ This storie is seid / not that wyues shulde
Folwe Grisilde / as in humylite
For it were unportable / thuogh thei wolde
But that eủery wight / in his degre
Shulde be constant / in adủersitee
This storie which / he high stile enditeth
With pacience / Grisilde he quiteth
For sithen a woman / was so pacient
Vnto a mortal man / moche more we ought
(base) Receyue al in gree / that god vs sent
(base) For grete skelis / he pueth that he bouȝt
(base) Mankynde / þe which þat he wrouȝt
(base) As seith seint Iame / ȝif ȝe his pistel rede
(base) He preueth folk / alday / it is no drede
(base) And suffreth vs / as for oure exc̉ercise
(base) With sharpe shoures / of adủersite
(base) Wel ofte to be beten / in sundry wise
(base) Now for to knowe vs / for certes he
(base) Er we were born / knewe al oure frelte
(base) And for oure best / is al his goủernance
(base) Lat vs it haue þan / in v̉ertuous suffrance
(base) But oo witte herkeneth / lordynges er ȝe go
(base) It were ful hard now adayes
(base) In al a toun to fynde Grisildes thre or two
(base) For ȝif þei were putte / in suche assayes
(base) The gold of hem / hath now so harde alayes
(base) With bras / þᵗat þogh þe kynde . be faire at eye
(base) It wol rather breste a two / þan plye
¶ Lenuoye ¶ Chaucer
Grisilde is ded / and eke hir pacience
And bothe at ones / yburyed in ytaile
For whiche I crie / in open audience
No wedded man / be hardy be assaile
His wyves pacience / in trust to fynde
Grisildes / for in certeyn he shal faile ¶¶
O noble wyves ful of high prudence
Lit no humylite / ȝoure tonge nayle
Ne let no clerk / have cause ne diligence
To write of you a storie / of such muayle
As of Grisilde / pacient and kynde
Lest cheuache / ȝou swolwe in hir entrayle
¶ Folweth Ecco / that holdeth no silence
But eủere answereth / at the countretaile
Beth nat be daffed / for ȝoure innocence
But sharpely take on you / the goủernaile
Empnteth wel / this lessou in youre mynde
For comon ꝓprofit / sith it may auayle
¶ Ne drede hem nouȝt / doth hem no reủerence
For though thy husbond / armed be in mayle
The arwes / of thy crabbed eloquence
Shal perce his brest / and eke his aduentaile
In ialousie eke / I rede thou hym bynde
And that thou make hym couche / as doth a quayle
¶ Ȝif thou be faire / ther folke ben in psence
Shewe thou thy visage / and thyn apparaile
Ȝif thou be foule / be fre of thy dispence
To gete the frendes / ay do thy trauayle
Be ay of chere / as light as leef on lynde
And lat hym care and wepe / wrynge and wayle
¶ Ȝe archewyues / stondeth at ȝoure defence
Sith ȝe be stronge / as is a greet Camaile
Ne suffreth not that man do ȝow offence
And sklendre wyves / febel as in batayle
Beth egre as a tiger / ȝonde and ynde
Ay clappeth as as mylle / I you coıı̄unsaile
> ¶ Thus endeth the tale of the Clerk of Oxenford /

¶ Thus endeth the tale of the Clerk of Oxenford /
¶ And here bygynneth the prologe of the Frankeleyn
I have a wyf quod oure Ost though she pore be
Ȝit hath she an heep / of vices lo
For of hir tonge / as moche shrewe is she
Therof no force / lat alle suche thinges go
But wite ye what / in counsail be it said ¶¶
Me reweth sore / that I am to hir tayd
¶ Sire Frankeleyn cometh nere / ȝif it youre wil be
And say vs a tale / as ye are a gentilman
It shal be don trewely host quod he /
I wol you telle / as hertely as I can
Holdeth me excused though I vnworthy am
To telle you a tale / for I wol not rebell
Agenist youre wille / a tale now wol I telle

(base) Whiche layes with hir Instrumentz they songe
(base) Or ellis redden hem for hire plesaunce
(base) And oon of hem haue I in remembraunce
(base) Which I shal seyn with good wyl as I kan
(base) But sires by cause I am a burel man
(base) At my bigynnyng first I yow biseche
(base) Haue me excused of my rude speche
(base) I lerned neuere Rethorik certeyn
(base) Thyng that I speke It moot be bare and pleyn
(base) I sleep neuere in the Mount of parnaso
(base) Ne lerned Marcus Tullius Scithero
(base) Colours ne knowe I none withouten drede
(base) But swiche colours as growen in the mede
(base) Or ellis swiche as men dye or peynte

div.l: (base) Telle hire his wo his peyne and his distresse
(base) But atte laste she for his worthynesse
(base) And namely for his meke obeysance
(base) Hath swich a pitee caught of his penance
(base) That priuely she fel of his acord
(base) To taken hym for hir housbonde and hir lord
(base) Of swich lordshipe as men han ouer hir wyues
(base) And for to lede the moore in blisse hir lyues
(base) Of his fre wyl he swoor hire as a knyght
(base) That neuere in al his lyf he day ne nyght
(base) Ne sholde vpon hym take no maistrye
(base) Agayn hir wyl ne kithe hire Ialousye
(base) But hire obeye and folwe hir wyl in al
(base) As any louere to his lady shal
(base) Saue that the name of soueraynetee
(base) That wolde he haue for shame of his degree
(base) She thonked hym and with ful gret humblesse
(base) She seyde sire sith of youre gentilesse
(base) Ye profre me to haue so large a reyne
(base) Ne wolde neuere god bitwix vs tweyne
(base) As in my gilt were outher werre or stryf
(base) Sire I wol be youre humble trewe wyf
(base) Haue heer my trouthe til that myn herte breste
(base) Thus been they bothe in quiete and in reste
(base) For o thyng sires saufly dar I seye
(base) That freendes euerich oother moote obeye
(base) If they wol longe holden compaignye
(base) Loue wol nat be constreyned by maistrye
(base) Whan maistrie comth the god of loue anon
(base) Beteth his wynges and farwel he is gon
(base) Loue is a thyng as any spirit free
(base) Wommen of kynde desiren libertee
(base) And nat to been constreyned as a thral
(base) And so doon men if I sooth seyn shal
(base) Looke who that moost is pacient in loue
(base) He is at his auantage al aboue
(base) Pacience is an heigh vertu certeyn
(base) For it venquysseth as thise clerkes seyn
