div.l: (base) Thynges that rigour sholde neuere atteyne
(base) For euery word men may nat chide or pleyne
(base) Lerneth to suffre or ellis so moot I gon
(base) Ye shul it lerne wher so ye wole or non
(base) For in this world certeyn ther no wight is
(base) That he ne dooth or seith som tyme amys
(base) Ire siknesse or constellacioun
(base) Wyn wo or chaungyng of complexioun
(base) Causeth ful ofte to doon amys or speken
(base) On euery wrong a man may nat be wreken
(base) After the tyme moste be temperaunce
(base) To euery wight that kan on gouernaunce
(base) And therfore hath this wise worthy knyght
(base) To lyue in ese suffraunce hire bihight
(base) And she to hym ful wisly gan to swere
(base) That neuere sholde ther be defaute in here
(base) Here may men seen an humble wys acord
(base) Thus hath she take hir seruant and hir lord
(base) Seruant in loue and lord in mariage
(base) Thanne was he bothe in lordshipe and seruage
(base) Seruage nay but in lordshipe aboue
(base) Sith he hath bothe his lady and his loue
(base) His lady certes and his wyf also
(base) The which that lawe of loue acordeth to
(base) And whan he was in this prosperitee
(base) Hom with his wyf he gooth to his contree
(base) Nat fer fro Pedmark ther his dwellyng was
(base) Wher as he lyueth in blisse and in solas
(base) Who koude telle but he hadde wedded be
(base) The ioye the ese and the prosperitee
(base) That is bitwix an housbonde and his wyf
(base) A yeer and moore lasted this blisful lyf
(base) Til that the knyght of which I speke of thus
(base) That of kairrud was clepid Arueragus

div.fw: ¶ The Prologe of the secunde Nonne
div.l: Toke mannes shap / the et̉erne loue and pees
That of the tryne compas / lord and gide is
Whom erthe and see / and heuen withoute lees
Ay herien / and thou virgyne wēmmelees
Bar of thy body / and dwelledist maide pure
The creatour / of eủery creature
¶ Assembled is / in the magnificence
With mercy goodnesse / and with such pite
That thou art the sonne of excellence
Nough only helpest hem / that prayen the
But ofte tyme / of thi benignite
Ful frely / er that men / thyn helpe beseche
Thou goost biforn / and ert her lyues leche
¶ Now helpe thou meke / and blisful faire mayde
Me flemed wrecche / in this desert of galle
Thenke on the woman / of Canane that sayde
That whelpes eten / some of the crōmmes alle
That from her lordes table / ben yfalle
And though that I / the vnworthy sone of Eue
Be sinfuƚƚ / ȝit accepte my beleue
¶ And for that feith is ded / withoute werkes
So for to werchen / so ȝeue me lyf and space
That I be quit from the place / that most derke is
O thou that art so faire / and so ful of grace
Be myn aduocate / in so high a place
Ther as withouten ende / is sungen osanne
Thou cristes moder / and doughter of seynt Anne
¶ And of thi light / my soule in prison lighte
That troubled is by contagioıı̄un
Of my body / and also by the wighte
Of erthely lust / and fals affeccioıı̄un
O heuene o refute / o saluacioıı̄un
Of hem that ben / in sorwe and in distresse
Now helpe / for vnto my werk I wol me redresse
¶ Ȝit pray I you / that reden that I write
Forȝeveth me that I do / no diligence
This ilk story / sotilly to endite
For bothe have I the wordes / and the sentence
div.fw: ¶ The prologe of the secunde Nonne
div.l: Of hem / that at seintes reuerence
The storie wroot / and folwen her legende
And I pray you / that ye my werke amende
¶ First wolde I the name of seint Cecilie
Expowne you / as men may in hir storie see
It is to saie in englissh / heuenes lilie
For pure chastnesse / of virginite
Outher for she witnesse had of honeste
Of grene of conscience / and of goode fame
The swote sauour lilie / was hir name
¶ Outher Cecilie is to say / the way to blynde
For she ensample was / by good techynge
Or ellis Cecilie is / writen as I fynde
Ioyned by a maner conioynynge
Of heuene and lya / and hir in figurynge
The heuene is set / for thought of holynesse
And lya / for hir lastinge besinnesse
¶ Cecilie may eke be said in this man̉ere
Wanting of blindnes / for hir greet liȝt
Of sapience / and for hir thewes clere
Or ellis loo / this maydenes name briȝt
Of heuene and leos comth . for which be right
Men myghte the heuene / of peple hir calle
Ensaumple of goode / and wise werkes alle
¶ For leos peple / in englissh is to say
And right as men / may in this heuene see
The sonne and mone / and sterres eủery day
Right so goostly / in this mayde free
Seen is the feith of shynynge clerte
Of helthe and eke of sapience
And soundry werkes / bright of excellence
¶ And right as thise philosophres write
That heuene is swift / round and brennynge
Right so was faire Cecilie / the white
Ful swift / and besy ay in good werchinge
And rounde and hool in good ꝑperseuerynge
And brenne eủere / in charite lighte
Now haue I declared you / what she hight
¶ Thus endeth the prologe ¶ And begynneth the tale
This maide bright Cecilie / as hir lyf saith
Was comen of Romaynes / ⁊and of noble kynde
And so forth fostred vp in the faith
Of crist / and bar his gospel in hir mynde
She neủere cessed / as I wreten fynde
Of hir prayers and god to loue and drede
Besechinge him to kepe hir maydenhede
¶ And whan this mayde / shulde vnto a man
Ywedded be / that was ful yonge of age
Which that ycleped was Valerian
And the day was comen of hir mariage
She ful deuoute / and humble in hir corage
Vnder hir robe of gold / that sat ful faire
And next hir flessh clad was in an haire
¶ And whiles the organs / maden melodie
To god allone / thus in herte song she
O lord my soule / and eke my body gie
Vnwēmmed / lest / that I confounded be
And for his loue / that dyed vpon a tree
Eủery secunde or thridde day faste
Ay biddinge / in hir orisons ful faste
¶ The night com / and to bedde she must goon
With hir husbond / as ofte is the manere
And priuely / she saide anoon
O swete / and welbiloued spouse dere
Ther is a counseil / and ȝe wolde it here
Which that right fayn / I wol vnto you sayn
So that ȝe me ensure / it not to bewrayn
¶ Valerian gan faste vnto hir swere
That for no cas / ne thing that miȝt be
He shulde for no thyng / neủere bewryen here
And than at erst / thus to him saide she
I have an angel / the whiche that loueth me
That with greet loue wheither so I wake or slepe
Is redy ay / my body forto kepe
¶ And that he may felen out of drede
That ȝe ȝow goủerne / in noo thyng amis
He wol you save and kepe / til ye be dede
For youre clene lyuynge / and youre goodnis
And bryng you striȝt / into heuene blis
He wolde you loue / as me for youre clennesse
And shewe you of his ioye / and his brightnesse
¶ Valerian corrected / as god wolde
Answerde ageyn̄ / ȝif I shal truste the
Lat me the Aungel see / and him beholde
And ȝif that it / a verray aungel be
Than wole I done / as thou hast prayed me
And ȝif thou loue / another man for sothe
Right with this swerde / I wol slee you bothe
¶ Cecilie answerde anoon in this wise
Ȝif that ȝe luste / that Aungel shul ȝe see
So that ȝe trowe on crist / and youre baptise
Goth forth to via apia / quod she
That from this toıı̄un / ne stant but myles thre
And to the pore folk / and there dwelle
Say hem right thus / as that I shaƚƚ you telle
¶ Telle hem that I Cecilie / you to hem sent
To shewen you / the good Vrban / the olde
For secre nedes / and for goode entent
And whan that ye / seint Vrban han beholde
Telle him the wordes / which that I to you tolde
And whan that he hath purged ȝou of synne
Than shul ȝe see / that Aungel / er ye twynne
¶ Valerian / is to that place ygoon
And right as him was tauȝt / by his lernynge
He fonde this holy Vrban anoon
Among the seintes buriels lotynge
div.note: latitans
div.l: And he anoon withoute taryinge
Dide his message / and whan he had ytolde
Vrban for ioye / gan his handes vpholde
¶ The teres from his eyen / leet he falle
Almyghty god / o IħuIhesu Crist quod he
So were of chast counseiƚƚ / and heerde of vs alle
The fruyt of thilke seed / of chastite
That thou hast sowe in Cecilie / take to the
Loo lyke a besy be / withoute gile
The serueth ay / thyn owne thral Cecile
¶ For thilke spouse / that she toke but now
Ful lyk a feers / she sendeth here
As meke as eny lamb / was to you
And with that worde / anoon ther gan appere
An olde man / clad with white clothes clere
And had abook / with łletres of golde in hounde
And gan bifore Valerian to stounde
¶ Valerian as ded / fel doıı̄un for drede
Whan he hym saugh / and he him hente vp tho
And on his book / right thus he gan to rede
O lord of feith / oo god withoute moo
Of cristendome / and fader of aƚƚ also
Abouen alle / and oủer aƚƚ eủery where
Thise wordes aƚƚ / with gold wreten were
¶ Whan this was rad / than saide this olde man
Leeuest thou this or noo / say ȝe or nay
I leeue al thing / than this I dar wel say
Vnder the heuene / no wight thenke may
Tho vanisshed the olde man / he niste where
And Pope Vrban / him cristened right there
¶ Valerian goth home / and seint Cicelie
Withynne his chambre / he fynt an Aungel stande
This Aungel had / of rose and of lilie
Corones two / the whiche he bar in hande
And firste to Cecile / as I vnderstande
He ȝaf that oon / and after gan he take
That other / to Valerian hir make
¶ With body clene / and with vnwēmmed thouȝt
Kepeth ay wel / thise corones quod he
From Paradis to you I have brought
Ne neủere more / shuƚƚ they roten be
Ne lese her swete sauour / trusteth to me
Ne neủere wight / shal seen hem with his eye
But he be cast and hate vilenye
¶ And thou Valerian / for thou so sone
Assentest to good counseiƚƚ also
Say what thou lust / and thou shalt haue thy bone
I have a brother / quod Valerian tho
That in this world / I loue no man so
I pray you that my brother / may haue grace
To knowe the trouthe / as I do in this place
¶ The aungel answerde / god liketh youre requeste
And bothe with the palme / of martirdome
Ȝe shul come / vnto the blisful feste
And with that worde / Tiburce his brother come
And whan that he / that sauour vndernome
Whiche that the roses / and the lilies caste
Withynne his herte / he gan to wondren faste
¶ And seide in this tyme I wondre of the ȝere
Whennes this swote sauour cometh so
Of roses and lilies / that I smelle here
For though I had hem / in myn hondes two
The sauour myght in me / no depper go
The swete smel / that in myn̄ herte I fynde
Hath chaunged me / al in another kynde
¶ Valerian seide / two corones have we
Snowȝ whit / and rose reed / that shyne clere
Whiche þᵗat thyn eyen / have no myght to see
And as thou smellest hem / thurgh my prayer
So shalt thou seen hem / leue brother dere
Ȝif it so be / that thou wilt withoute slouthe
Beleue aright / and knowe verray trouthe
¶ Tibuce answerde / saist thou this to me
In sothnes / or in dreme herkene I this
In dremes quod Valerian have we be
Vnto this tyme / brother myn̄ ywys
But now at erst / oure trewe dwellynge is
He woost thou quod Tiburce / and in what wise
Quod Valerian / that shaƚƚ I the deuise
¶ The Aungel of god / hath me the trouthe tauȝt
Whiche that thou shalt seen / ȝif that thou wilt reneye
The ydoles / and be clene / and ellis nauȝt
And of the miracles / of thisei corones tweye
Seint Ambrose in his p̉reface / lust to seye
Solempnely this noble doctour dere
Cōmmendeth it / and seith in this manere
¶ The palme of martirdome forto receyue
Seynt Cecilie fulfilled / of goddes ȝifte
The worlde and eke hir chambre / gan she weyue
Witnesse Tiburce / and Cecilies shrifte
To whiche god of his bounte / wolde shifte
Corones two / of floures wel smellynge
And made the Angel hem / tho corones brynge
¶ This mayde hath brought / thise men to blisse aboue
The world hath wist / what it is worth certeyn̄
Deuocioıı̄un of chastite / to loue
Tho shewed him Cecilie / open and pleyn̄
That alle ydoles / are but thyng in veyn̄
For they ben dombe / and therto they ben deve
And charged him / his ydoles forto leve
¶ Who that this troweth not / a beest he is
Quod tho Tiburce / ȝif that I shal not lye
She gan kisse his brest / whan she herde this
And was ful glad / he couthe trouthe aspye
This day I take the / for myn̄ allye
Saide this blisful maide / fair and dere
For after that / she saide as ye may here
¶ Loo right so as the loue of crist quod she
Made me thy brothers wyf / right in that wise
Anoon for myn̄ allye / here take I the
Sitthen that thou wilt / thyn ydoles despise
Go with thy brother now / and the baptise
And make the clene / so þᵗat thou maist beholde
The aungeles face / of whiche thy brother tolde
¶ Tiburce answerde / and seide brother dere
First tel me whider I shal and to what man
To whom quod he / come forth wᵗith right goode chere
I wol the leden / vnto the Pope Vrban
To Vrban brother myn̄ / Valerian
Quod tho Tiburce / wilt thou me thider lede
Me thinketh that it were / a wonder dede
¶ Remenest thou nouȝt / Vrban quod he tho
That is so often dampned to be ded
And woneth in halkes / to and fro
And dar not ones / putte forth his hed
Men shulle him brenne in a fire so reed
Ȝif that he were founde / and men myght him aspie
And we also / that bere hym companye
¶ And whiles we seken / thilke diuinite
That is in heuene / yhid priuely
Algate in this world / ybrend shuƚƚ we be
To whom Cecilie / answered boldely
Men myȝt drede / wel and skilfully
This lyf to lese / my owne dere brother
Ȝif this were lyuyng only and noon other
¶ But ther is bettre lyf in other place
That neủere shal be lost / ne drede the nought
Whiche goddes sone / vs tolde thurgh his grace
Right as a man hath sapiences dure bouȝt
Memorie engine / and intellette also ysouȝt
So in oo beyng / of diuinite
Thre ꝑpersones / right wel ther may be
¶ Tho gan she hym / besely to preche
Of cristes comyng / and of his peynes tolde
And many poyntes / of his passioıı̄un teche
How goddes sone / in this world was with holde
To done mankynde / pleyn̄ remissioıı̄un ysolde
That was ybounde / in synnes and cares colde
Al this thyng / she vnto Tiburce tolde
¶ And after this Tiburce / in good entent
To Pope Vrban / with Valerian went
Which thanked god / and with glad herte and liȝt
He cristened him / and made him in that place
ꝐParfite in his lynynge / goddes knyght
And after thus Tiburce gat suche gᵃrace
That eủery day he saugh in tyme a space
The Angel of god / and eủrey maner bone
That he god asked / it was sped ful sone
¶ It were ful harde / by ordre forto seyn̄
How many wondres / IħuIhesu for hym wrought
But atte laste / to telle short and pleyn
The seriaunt of the toıı̄un of Rome / hem souȝt
And hem bifore Almache / the prouost brouȝt
Which hem apposed / and knewe al hir entente
And to the ymage / of Iupiter hem sente
¶ And saide who so wole not sacrifice
Swapp̄ of his hede / this is my sentence here
Anoon thise martires / that I you deuise
Oon Maximius / that was an officere
Of the p̉refectes / and of Corniculere
Hem hente / and whan he / the sonnes ledde
Him self he weep / for pite that he hadde
¶ Whan Maximius / hadde herde the seintes lore
He gat hem / of the tormentours leue
And had hem in his kepyng withoute more
And with hir p̉rechyng / er that it were eue
They goonne from the tormentours to reue
And fro Maximius / and fro his folk echone
The false faith / and to trowe in god allone
¶ Cecilie com / whan it was woxen nyght
With prestes / that hem cristened alle yfere
And afterward / whan day was woxen light
Cecilie hem seide / with a noble chere
Now cristes owne knyghtes / leue and dere
Casteth al awey / the werkes of derknesse
And armeth you / in armes of lightnesse
¶ Ȝe han for sothe ydone / a grete batayle
Ȝoure is done / ȝoure feith / han ȝe conʆserued
Goth to the corone / of lyf / that may not fayle
The rightful Iuge / which that ye han serued
To fore hym ȝe ben / feithfully preʆserued
And whan this thing / was seid as I deuise
Men lad hem forth / to done the sacrifise
¶ But whan they were / vnto the place ybrought
To telle shortly / the conclusioıı̄un
They nolde encense / ne sacrifise right nought
But on heer knees / they saten hem adoıı̄un
With humble herte / and sad deuocioıı̄un
And leften bothe her hedes / in the place
Here soules wenten / to the kyng of grace
¶ This Maximiꝯus / that saugh this thyng betide
With pitouse wordes / tolde it anoon right
That he hir soules / saugh to heuene glide
With Aungeles ful of clernes / and of light
And with his worde / conủerted many a wight
For which Almachius / did him so to bete
With whippes of leed / til he the lyf gan lete
¶ Cicilie him toke / and buried him anoon
By Tiburce / and Valerian softely
Withynne hir heriynge place vnder the ston̄
And after this / Almachius hastely
Bad his ministres / fecchen openly
Cecilie / so she myghte in his p̉resence
Done sacrifise / and Iupiter encence
¶ But they conuerted / thurgh hir wise lore
Wepten sore / and ȝaf credence
Vnto hir worde / and cried more and more
Crist goddes sone / withoute difference
Is verray god / this is al oure sentence
That hath so good a ʆseruᵃaunt him to serue
This with oo voys / we trowe thouȝ we st̉erue
¶ Almachius / that herde al this thyng
Bad fecche Cecilie / that he myght hir see
And altherfirst / lo this was his askyng
What man̉er woman art thou / tho quod he
I am a gentil woman born / quod she
I aske quod he / thouȝ that it the greue
Of thy religioıı̄un / and of thy beleue
¶ Why than began / youre questioıı̄un folily
Quod she that woldest / two answeres conclude
In oo demaunde / ȝe asked lewedly
Almachius answerde / to that similitude
Of whennes quod she / whan that she was refreyned
Of conscience / and of good feith vnfeyned
¶ Almachius seide / takest thou noon heede
Of thyn answere / and she him answerd thus
Ȝoure myght quod she / litel is to drede
For eủery mortel / mannes power is
But lyk a bladder / ful of wynd ywis
For with a nedeles point / whan that it is blowe
May al the bost of hit be leyd ful lowe
¶ Ful wrongfully / began thou quod he
And ȝit in wronge / is thi ꝑperseuerance
Wostow not how / oure mythy pⁱrince free
Ben thus cōmmaunded / and maken ordinance
That eủery cristen wight / shal have penance
But ȝif that he / his cristendome with seye
And goon al quyt / ȝif he wol it reneye
¶ Ȝoure Pⁱrinces erren / as youre nobles doth
Quod tho Cecilie / and a wood sentence
Ȝe make vs gilty / and it is not soth
For ye that knowen / wel oure innocence
For asmoche / as we done a reủerence
To crist / and for we bere / a cristen name
Ȝe putte on vs / a cryme / and eke a blame
¶ But we that knowe / thilke name so
Vertuous / we may not say nay
Almachius answerde // chees oon of thise two
Do sacrifice / and cristendome renay
That thou may now / scape by that way
At which the holy blisful mayde
Gan forto laughen / and to the Iuge sayde
¶ O Iuge confuse / in nycete
Wiltow that I reneye / innocence
To makn me a wicked wight quod she
Loo he dissimileth / here in audience
He stareth and wodeth / here in his adủertence
To whom Almachius / o vnsely wrecche
Ne wost thou nouȝt / how fer my myght may strecche
¶ Hath nouȝt oure myghty pⁱrince / to me yiven
Ȝe bothe power / and auccorite
To make folk / to dyen or to lyuen
Why spekestow / so proudly than to me
I ne speke it nouȝt / but stidefastly quod she
Nouȝt proudly / for I say as for my side
I hate dedly / thilke vice of pride
¶ And ȝif thou drede nouȝt / a soth to here
Than wol I shewen / al openly be right
That thou hast made / a ful greet lesyng here
Thou seist the pⁱrinces / han ȝeue myght
Bothe to sleen / and to quyke a wight
Thou that ne mayst / but onely lyf bereue
Thou hast therto / neither power ne leue
¶ But thou maist say / the pⁱrinces han the maked
Ministre of deth / for ȝif tho speke of mo
Thou lyest for thy power / is ful naked
Do wey thy boldnesse / saide Almachius tho
And sacrifise / vnto oure goddes two
I recche nouȝt / what wrong that thou me ꝓprofre
For I can suffre it / as a philosophre
¶ But thilke wronges / may I not endure
That thou spekest of / oure goddes here qduod he
Cecilie answerde / o nyce creature
Thou saidest no worde / syn thou spake to me
That I ne knewe / therwith thy nycete
And that thou were / in eủery maner wise
A lewed officer / and a veyne Iustise
¶ Ther lacketh no thing to thyn vtter eyen
That thou nart blynd / for thyn that we seen alle
That is a stoon / that men may wel espyen
And thilke stoon̄ / a god thou wolt it calle
I rede the lat thyn hond / vpon it falle
And taste it wel / and stoon thou shalt it fynde
Syn that thou seest it nouȝt / with thyn eyen blynde
¶ It is a shame / that the peple shal
So scorne the / and laughen at thy folye
For cōmmonly wōmmen / woot it oủer al
That myghty god / is in his heuenes hye
And thise ymages / wel maistow than espye
To the / ne to hem self may they not ꝓprofyte
For in effecte / they be not worth a myte
¶ Thise and suche other wordes seyde she
And wax wrothe / and bad men shulde hir lede
Home to hir hous / and in hir hous quod he
Lat brenne hir in a fire / with flammes rede
And as he bad / right so was done in dede
And in a bath / they gan hir faste shette
And nyght and day / greet fire vnder bette
¶ Al the longe nyght / and eke the day also
For al the fire / and eke the bathes hete
She sat al colde / and felte of it no wo
Ne nouȝt a drope / made hir forto swete
But in that bathe / hir lyf she muste lete
For he Almachie / with ful wicked entent
To sleen hir / in the bath / his sonde sent
¶ The strokes in the nekke / he smote hir tho
The tormentour / but for no maner chaunce
He myȝte not smyten / al hir nekke atwo
And for ther was / that tyme an ordynance
That no man shulde do / to man such penance
The ferthe stroke / to smyte softe or sore
This tormentour / durst do no more
¶ But half ded with hir nekke ycorven there
He lefte hir lye / and in his wey he wente
The cristen folk / which aboute hir were
With shetes home / ful faire hir hente
Thre dayes lyued she / in this torment
And neuere cessed / hem the feith to teche
That she had fostred / hem she gan to preche
¶ And hem she ȝaf / hir mebles and hir thyng
And to the Pope Vrban / bytoke hem tho
And seide I asked this / of heuene kyng
To have respite / thre dayes and no mo
To recōmmaunde to ȝou / er that I go
Thise soules loo / and that I myght do wirche
Here of myn hous / ꝑperpetuelly a chirche
¶ Seynt Vrban / with his dekenes pryuely
They fette hir and buried it be nyghte
Amonge his other seyntes / honestly
Hir hous / the chirche of seynt Cecilie highte
div.fw: ¶ The prologe of the Chanons man
div.l: Seynt Vrban / halwed it / as he wel myghte
In the whiche / into this day / in noble wise
Men done to crist / and to his seintes / seruise
¶ Thus endeth the secunde Nonnes tale
¶ And here bygynneth the prologe of the Chanons yoman
Whan ended was the tale of seynt Cecyle
Er we fully / had riden fif myle
At boughtoıı̄un / vnder the blee / vs gan atake
A man that clothed was / in clothes blake
And vnder that / he had a whit surplys
His hakeney that was / al pomel grys
So swette that wonder was to see
Hit semed he had / pⁱriked myles thre
The hors eke / that his yoman rood vpon̄
So swette / that vnnethe myȝte he gon̄
Aboute the peytrel / stood the foom ful hiȝe
He was of fome / al flekked as a pie
A male twyfold / vpon his croper lay
It semed / that he caried / lytel aray
Al light for somer / rood this worthy man
And in myn herte / wondren I bigan
What that he was / til that I vnderstood
How that his cloke / was sewed to his hood
For which whan I longe / had avised me
I demed him / som chanon forto be
His hat heeng at his bak / doıı̄un by a laas
For he had riden / more than a trot or a paas
He had ay priked / lyk he were wood
A clote lyf / he hadde vnder his hood
For swoot / and forto kepe his heed fro hete
But it was ioye / forto seen him swete
His forhed dropped / as a stillatorie
Were ful of plaunteyn̄ / and of peritorie
And whan that he com / he gan to crie
God saue qduod he / this ioly companye
Faste have I priked / qduod he for youre sake
By cause that I wolde / yow ouertake
To ryden / in this mery companie
div.fw: ¶ The prologe of the Chanons yoman
div.l: His yoman eke / was ful of curtesie
And sire now / in the morwe tyde
Out of youre hostery / y saugh you ryde
And warned here / my lorde and my soủerayn
Which that to ryde / with you / is ful fayn
For his disport / he loueth daliaıı̄une
And for thy warnyng / god yeve the good chaunce
Saide oure hoost / certes it wolde seme
Thy lorde were wys / and so I may wel deme
He is ful iocunde / also dar I leye
Can he ought telle / a mery tale or tweye
With whiche / he gladde may thys companye
Who sir my lorde / ȝe ȝe withoute lye
He can of myrthe / and eke of iolyte
Nought but ynow / also sire trusteth me
And ȝe hym knewe / as wel as do I
Ȝe wolde wondre / how wel and thriftily
He couthe wirke / and that in sondry wise
He hath taken on hym / many greet apprise
Whiche were ful harde / for any that is here
To brynge aboute / but they of hym it lere
As homely as he rit / amonges ȝow
Ȝif ȝe hym knewe / it wolde be youre prow
Ȝe wolde not forgoon / his aqueyntance
For moche goode / I dar leye in balance
Al that I have / in my possessioıı̄un
He is a man / of high discrecioıı̄un
I warne you wel / he is a passyng man
Wel quod oure hoost / I pᵃray the tel me than
Is he a clerk or noon / tel what he is
Nay he is gretter / than a clerk ywis
Seyde the ȝoman / and in wordes fewe
Hoost of his craft / somwhat I wol you shewe
I say my lorde / can suche a sotilte
But al his craft / ȝe may not wite of me
And somwhat helpe I ȝit / to his worchyng
That al this grounde / that we ben on rydyng
Til that we come / to Cauntirbury toun
He couthe al clene / turne vp so doun
And paue it al / of syluer and of gold
And whan this ȝoman / had this ytold
¶ Vnto oure hoost / he saide benedicite
This thyng / is wonder meruaillous to me
Sithe thy lorde / is of so high prudence
By cause of whiche / men shulde hym reủerence
That of his worshipe / rekketh he so lyte
His ouer sloppe / is not worth a myte
As in effecte / to hym so mote I go
It is al baudy / and to tore also
Why ys thy lorde / so sluttissh I the prey
And is of power / better clothes forto bey
Ȝif that his dede / accorde with thy speche
Tel me that / and that I the beseche
¶ Why quod this ȝoman / wherto aske ȝe me
God helpe me so / for he shal neủer ythe
But I wol not avowe that I say
And therfore kepe it secre / I yow pray
He is to wys / in feith as I beleue
That þᵗat is oủerdone / it wol not preue
And right as clerkes seyn / it is a vice
Wherfore in that / I holde him lewde and nyce
For whan a man / hath ouer greet a wyt
Ful ofte him happeth / to mysvse it
So doth my lorde / and that me greueth sore
God it amende / I can say ȝow noo more
¶ Therof no fors / goode man qduod oure hoost
Sitthen of the cūnnynge / of thy lorde thou woost
Telle how he doth / I pray the hertely
Sitthen that he is / so crafty ⁊and so sotelly
Where dwelle ȝe / ȝif it be to telle
In the subarbe / of a toun quod he / we dwelle
Lurkyng in hernes / and in lanes blynde
Where thise robbers and theefs be kynde
Holden hiᵃr pryue / in ferful residence
As they that dar not / showen hir p̉resence
So fare we / ȝif I shal say the sothe
Ȝit quod oure hoost / lat me talke to the
Why art thou / discoloured on thy face
Petir quod he / god ȝeue it harde grace
I am so vset / in the fyre to blowe
That it hath chaunged / my colour as I trowe
I am not wont / in no myrroir to prye
But swynke sore / and lerne to multiplie
We bloundren eủere / and pouren in the fyre
And for al that we faylen / of oure desyre
For eủere we lakken / oure conclusioıı̄un
To moche folk we be / but illusioıı̄un
And borwe gold / be it a pound or two
Or ten or twelue / or many sōmmes mo
And make ham wene / atte leste weye
That of a pound / we couthe make tweye
Ȝit is it fals / and ay we han good hope
It forto done / and after it we grope
But that science is / so fer vs biforn
We may not / al thogh we had it sworn
It is ouertake / it slit awey so faste
It wol vs make / beggers atte laste
¶ Whiles this ȝoman / was thus in his talkyng
This chanon drow him nere / and herde al thyng
Which that this ȝoman spak / for suspecioıı̄un
Of mennes speche / eủere had this Chanoıı̄un
For Catoıı̄un seith / he that gylty is
Demeth al thyng / of him be spoke ywis
By cause of that / he gan so nygh to drawe
His ȝoman / and herde al his sawe
And thus he seide / vnto his ȝoman tho
Hold now thy pees / and spek wordes noo mo
For ȝif thou doost / thou shalt it abye
Thou sclaundrest me here / in this companye
And eke discoủerest þᵗat / thou shuldest hyde
Ȝe quod oure hoost / tel on what so be tyde
Of al his thretenynge / recche the nat a myte
In feith quod he / no more I do but lyte
And whan this Chanon / saugh it wolde not be
But that his yoman / wolde telle his pryuyte
He fledde away / for verray sorowe and shame
A quod the ȝoman / here shal rise a game
Al that I can / anoon wol I telle
Syn he ys goon / the foule feende hym quelle
For neủere here after / wol I with hym mete
For peny ne for pound / I the behete
He that me brouȝt / first vnto that game
Er that he deye / sorwe haue he / and shame
For it is ernest / to me by my feith
That fele I wel / what so eny man seith
And ȝit for al my smerte and al my greef
For al my sorwe / labour and mescheef
I coude never leue it / in no wyse
Now wolde god my wit myght suffise
To tellen al that / longeth to that art
The whiche hath caused me to lese / of gold my part
But syn that my lorde is goon / I wol not spare
Swich thyng as I knowe / I wol declare
¶ Thus endeth the prologe
¶ And bygynneth the tale
With this Chanon / dwelled have I vij. ȝere
And of his science / am I neuer the nere
Al that I hadde / have I lost therby
And god woot / so have many mo than I
Ther I was wont / to be right fressh and gay
Of clothyng / and of good array
Now may I were / an hose vpon my heed
And where my colour / was bothe fressh and reed
Now is it wan / and of leden hewe
Who so it vse / sore shal him rewe
And of my swynk / ȝit blered is myn̄ ye
Lo which auantage / it is to multiplie
That slidynge science / hath me maad so bare
That I have no good / where that eủere I fare
And ȝit I am / endetted so therby
Of gold that I have borwed trewely
That while I leue / I shal it quyte neủere
Lat eủery man / be war by me / for eủere
What maner man / that casteth him therto
Ȝif he contynue / I holde his thrifte ydo
For so helpe me god / ther by shal he not wynne
But empte his purs / and make his wittes thynne
And whan he thurgh his madnesse and folie
Hath lost his owne good / thurgh Iuꝑpartie
Than he exciteth / other men therto
To lese her good / as him self hath do
For vnto shrewes / ioye it is and ese
To have here felawes / in peyne and disese
Thus was I ones / lerned of a clerk
Of that no charge / I wol speke of oure werke
¶ Whan we be there / as we shul exc̉ercise
Oure eluyssh craft / we seme wonder wise
Oure t̉ermes be / so clergial and so queynte
I blowe the fire / tyl that myn herte feynte
What shulde I telle / eche ꝓproporcion̄
Of thynges / whiche that we worchen oon
As of fyve or sixe vnces / it may wel be
Of syluer / or of som other quantite
And besie me / to telle you the names
Of orpement brent bones yren squames
That into pouder / grounde be ful smal
And in an erthen pot / how it put is al
And salt yput in / and also papire
Bifore thise pouders / that I speke of here
And wel ycoủered / with a lampe of glas
And of moche other thyng what that ther was
And of the pot / and glas englutyng
That of the eyre / myght passe no thyng
And of the esy fire / and smart also
Whiche that were made / and of the care and wo
That we had / in oure mat̉ers sublymynge
And almalgamynge / and calcenynge
Of quyc syluer / ycleped m̉ercurie crude
For alle oure slightes / we can not conclude
Oure orpement / and sublymed mercurie
Oure grounde litarge / eke on the porphirie
Of eche of thise / of vnces a certayn
Not helpeth vs / oure labour is in vayn̄
Ne eke oure spirites / ascensioıı̄un
Ne eke oure mater / that lyn alfixe adoıı̄un
May in oure wirchyng / no thyng vs avayle
For lost is al oure labour / and travayle
And al the cost / on twenty devel way
Is lost also / whiche we vpon it lay
Ther is also many another thyng
That is to oure craft / aꝑpertenyng
Though I by ordre hem here / ne reherse can
By cause that I am a lewde man
Ȝit wol I telle hem / as they come to mynde
Though I ne can / sette hem in her kynde
As boole amoniak / v̉erdegres boras
And sondry vesselles / made of erthe and glas
Oure vrynals / and oure descensories
Violes cressellettes / and sublymatories
Concurbites / and alembikꝭes eke
And othere / dere ynogh a leke
Not nedeth it / to rehersen hem alle
Waters rubisiynge / and boles galle
Arsenyk sal armoniak and brymston̄
And herbes / couthe I telle eke manyon
As egremoyne / valerian and lunarie
And other suche / ȝif that me lust tarie
Oure lampes brennynge / bothe nyght and day
To brynge aboute / oure craft ȝif that we may
Oure fourneys eke / of calcinacioıı̄un
And of oure waters / albificacioıı̄un
Vnslekked lyme / chalk / and gleyre of an eye
Poudres diủerse / asshes dong pisse and cleye
Cered pokettes / sal petre and vitriole
And diủerse fyres / made of wode and cole
Sal tartre / alcaly and salt p̉reparat
And combust materes and coagulat
Cley made with horses / or mannes heer and oyle
Of tartre / alumglas / breme wort and argoyle
Reysalgar / and other mat̉ers enbibynge
And eke of oure mat̉eres encorporinge
And of oure syluer / citrinacioıı̄un
Oure seementing and fermentacioıı̄un
Oure Ingottes / testes and many mo
I wol you telle / as was tauȝt me also
The foure spirites / and the bodies seuene
By ordre as I have herde / my lorde neuene
The first spirit / quik syluer called is
The seconde orpement / the thridde ywys
Sal armoniak / and the fourthe brymston̄
The bodies seuene / eke loo here hem anoon
Sol gold is / and luna syluer we threpe
Mars yren / Mercurie quik syluer we clepe
Saturnꝰus leed / a Iupiter is tyn
And venus copir / by my fader kyn̄
This cursed craft / who so wol exc̉ercise
He shal no good han / that may suffise
For al the good / he spendeth ther aboute
He lese shal / ther of have I noo doute
Who so that lust / to outen his folie
Lat him come forth / and lerne multiplie
And eủery man / that hath auȝt in his cofre
Lat him appere / and wexe a philosophre
Ascaunce that craft / is so light to lere
Nay nay god woot / al be he monk or Frere
Preest or Chanon / or eny other wight
Though he sitte at his book bothe day and nyght
In lernyng of this eluissh nyce lore
As is in veyne / and parde moche more
Is to lerne a lewed man / this sotilte
Fy spek not therof / for it wol not be
Al coude he lettrure / or coude he noon̄
As in effecte / he shal fynde it al oon̄
For bothe two / by my saluacioıı̄un
Concluden in multiplicacioıı̄un
Yliche wel / whan they han al ydo
This is to say they fayle bothe two
Ȝit forȝat I to moche rehersaille
Of waters corosyf / and of lymaille
And of bodies / mollificacioıı̄un
And also of hir induracioıı̄un
Oyles ablucioıı̄un / and metal fusible
To tellen al / wolde passen eny bible
That ougher is / wherfore as for the beste
Of alle thise names / now wol I me reste
For as I trowe / I have you tolde ynogh
To reisen a feend / loke he neủere so rogh
A nay let be / thy philosophres stoon
Elixir cleped we / sethen faste echoon
For had we him / than were we siker ynow
But vnto god / of heuene I make avow
For al oure craft / whan we have al ydo
And al oure sleighte / he wol not come vs to
He hath vs made / spende moche good
For sorwe of whiche / almost I wexe wood
But that good hope / crepeth in oure herte
Supposyng eủere / thogh we sore smerte
To be releued / by hym afterward
Supposyng and hope / is sharp̄ and hard
I warne you wel / it is to seken eủere
That future temps / hath made men disseuere
In trust therof / from al that eủere they hadde
Ȝif of that art / they coude not wexe sadde
For vnto hem / it is a bitter swete
So semeth it / for ne had they but a shete
Which they myghte / wrappe hem in a nyght
And a bak to walken in / by day light
They wolde hem selle / and spenden on the craft
They can not stinte / til no thyng be laft
And eủere more / where that eủere they goon̄
Men may hem knowe / by smel of brymstoon̄
For al the world / they stynken as a goot
His sauoᵘur is / so rāmmyssh and so hoot
That thogh a man / from hem a myle be
That sauoᵘur wol infecten hym / trusteth me
Lo thus by smellyng / and thred bare array
Ȝif that men liste / this folk they knowe may
And ȝif a man / wol aske hym pryuely
Why they be clothed / so vntriftily
Right anoon they wol / rownen in his ere
And sey ȝif they aspied were
Men wolde hem sleen / by cause of her science
Lo thus this folk / bitrayen innocence
Passe over this / I go my tale vnto
Er that the pot / be on the fire ydo
Of metalles / with a c̉erteyn qᵃuantite
My lorde hem tempreth / and no man but he
Now he is goon / I dar say boldely
For as men sayen / he can do craftely
Algate I woot wel / he hath suche a name
And ȝit ful ofte / he renneth in the blame
And wete how / ful ofte it happeth so
The pot to breketh / and farewel al is go
Thise metalles ben / of so grete violence
Oure walles may not / make hem resistence
But ȝif they be wrouȝt of lyme and stoon
They ꝑpercen so / and thurgh the walle they goon
And some of hem / synken into the grounde
Thus have we lost / be tymes many a pounde
And some are scat̉ered / al the floor aboute

l.seg: Some lepen into the roof withoute do

div.l: Though that the feend / nat in oure sight him shewe
I trowe that he / be with vs / that shrewe
In helle wher he is / lord and sire
Ne is ther no more wo / ne angir ne ire
¶ Whan that oure pot is broken / as I have said
Eủery man chit and halt hym euele payd
Some seide it was longe / on the fire makyng
Some seide nay / it was long / on the blowyng
Than was I ferd / for that was myn office
Strawe quod the thride / ȝe be lewed and nyce
It was not tempred / as it ouȝt be
Nay quod the ferthe / stinte and herken me
By cause oure fire / was not made of beech
That is the cause / noon other so theech
I can not telle / wher on it is along
But wel I wote / greet strif is vs among
What quod my lorde / ther is no more to done
Of thise ꝑperiles / I wol be war eft sone
I am right siker / that the pot was crased
Be as be may / be ȝe no thyng / amazed
As vsage is / lat swepe the floor as swithe
Plucke vp ȝoure herte / and be ȝe glad and blithe
The mollok on an heep / yswopen is
And on the floor / cast a canavas
And al this mollok / in a syve ythrowe
And sifted and yplucked many a throwe
Parde quod oon / somwhat of oure metaƚƚ
Ȝit is ther her / though we have not aƚƚ
And though this thyng / myshapped hath now
Another tyme / it may be wel ynow
Vs muste putte oure good in auenture
A Marchaunt ꝑparde / may nat ay endure
Trusteth me wel / in his prosꝑperite
Some tyme his good / is drowned in the see
And some tyme cometh it sauf vnto the londe
Pees quod my lorde / the nexte tyme I wol fonde
To bryng oure craft / al in another plyte
And but I do sires / lat me have the wyte
Ther was defaute / in somwhat wel I woot
And other saide / the fire was oủerhoot
But be it hoot or cold / I dar wel say this
That we conclude / eủermore amys
We faylen of that / whiche we wolde have
And in oure madnesse / eủermore we raue
And whan we ben / to gider eủerychon̄
Euery man semeth / as wys as Salomon
But al thyng / whiche that semeth golde
Is nat golde / as I have herde tolde
Ne eủery appel / that is faire at eye
Ne is not good / what so men clappe or seye
Right so loo fareth it / amonges vs
He that semeth the wisest by IħusIhesus
Is moost fool / whan it cometh to the preef
And he that semeth trewest / is the mooste þeef
That shul ye knowe / er that I fro you wende
By that I of my tale / have made an ende
Ther is a Chanon of Religioıı̄un
Amonges vs / wolde enfecte al a toıı̄un
Though it as greet ware / as was Niniue
Rome Alisaundre / Troye and other thre
His slightes / and his infinite falnesse
Ther coude no man / writen as I gesse
Though that he myghte / lyven a thousand yeer
In al this world of falsnesse / nis his peer
For in his t̉ermes / he wol hym so wynde
And speke his wordes / in so sligh a kynde
Whan he cōmmune shal / with eny wight
What he wol make hym / dote anon right
But it the feende be / as him self is
Ful many a man / hath he begiled er this
And wole ȝif that he may / lyuen a whyle
And ȝit men ryden and goon ful many a myle
Hym forto seke / and have aqueyntance
Nought knowyng / of his fals goủernance
And ȝif ȝe lust / to ȝeue me audience
I wol it telle / here in youre p̉resence
But worshupfuƚƚ Chanon Religious
Ne demeth not / that I sclaundre youre hous
Al though my tale / of a Chanon be
Of eủery ordre / som shrewe is parde
And god forbede / that al a companye
Shulde rewe / a singuler mannes folie
To sclaundre you / is not myn entent
But to correcten / that is mys ywent
This tale was not oonly / tolde for yow
But eke for other moo / ye wote wel how
That amonges cristes Aposteles twelue
Ther was no traytoᵘur / but Iudas him selue
Than why sholde the remanant alle have blame
That gilteles were / by you sey I the same
Sauf only thus / ȝif ye wol herkne me
Ȝif any Iudas / in youre couent be
Remeweth hym by tyme / I you rede
Ȝif shame or losse / may causen any drede
And beth no thyng displesed / I you pray
But in this caas / herkeneth what I say
In londoıı̄un was a preest an annueler
That therynne dwellyd had many a ȝeer
Which was so plesaunt / and so seuysable
Vnto the wyf where he was at table
That she wolde suffre hym / no thyng forto paie
For bord noþ̉er clothyng / wente he neủere so gaie
And spendyng syluer had he right ynowȝ
Therof no force / I wol procede as now
And tel forth my tale / of the Chanoıı̄un
That brought this preest / to confusioıı̄un
¶ This fals Chanon / com vpon aday
Vnto the prestes chambre / there he lay
Besechinge hym / to lene hym a certeyn̄
Of gold / and he wolde / quit hym ageyn̄
Leneth me a marc / qduod he but dayes thre
And at my day / I wol it quite the
And ȝif so be / thou fynde me fals
Another day / hange me by the hals
This preest hym toke a marc / ⁊and that as swythe
And this Chanon / hym thanked ofte sithe
And toke his leue / and went forth his weye
And atte thridde day / broughte his moneye
And to the preest / he took this gold ageyn
Ther of this preest / was glad and fayn̄
Certes quod he / no thyng anoyeth me
To lene a man a noble / or two or thre
Or what thyng were / in my possessioıı̄un
Whan he so trewe is / of condicioıı̄un
That in no wise / he breke wol his day
To swich a man / I can neủere say nay
What quod this Chanon / shulde I be vntrewe
Nay that were thyng / fallen al of newe
Truthe is a thynge / that I wol eủere kepe
Vnto the day / in which þᵗat I shal crepe
Into my grave / and ellis god forbede
Beleveth this / as siker as the crede
God thanke I / and in good tyme be it said
That ther was neủere man / ȝit euel appaid
For gold ne siluer / that he to me lente
Ne neuere falshede / in myn herte I mente
And sire quod he / now of my pryuyte
Syn ȝe so goodly / have ben to me
And kythe to me / so grete gentilnesse
Somwhat to quiten with youre kyndenesse
I wol you shewe / and ȝif you lust to lere
I shal it shewe / to you anon right here
How I can worchen / in philosophie
Taketh good hede / ȝe shul wel seen at yȝe
That I wol done / a maistrie or I goo
Ȝee quod the preest / ȝe sire wol ȝe soo
Marie therof / I pray you hertely
At youre cōmmaundement / sire trewely
Quod the Chanoıı̄un / and ellis god forbede
Loo how this theef / couthe his seruice bede
Ful sothe it is / that suche ꝓprofre seruice
Stinketh / as witnessen thise olde wise
And that ful sone / I wol it verifie
In this Chanon that is rote / of al trecherie
But eủermore delite hath and gladnesse
Suche feendly thouȝtes / in his herte empresse
How cristes peple / he may to mescheef brynge
God kepe vs / from his fals dissimilynge
What wiste this preest / wᵗith whom that he delte
Ne of his harme comynge / no thyng he felte
O sely preest / o sely innocent
With couetise anoon / thou shalt be blent
O graceles / ful blynd is thy conceyt
No thyng art thow ware of the deceyt
With that this Fox / shapen hath to the
His wily wrenches / thou maist not flee
Wherfore to go / to the conclusioıı̄un
That referreth / to thy confusioıı̄un
Vnhappy man / anoon I wol me hie
To telle thyn vnwitte / and thy folie
And eke the falsnes / of that other wrecche
As ferforth / as eny connynge wol strecche
This Chanon was my lorde / ȝe wol wene
Sire in feith / and by the heuene quene
Hit was a nother Chanoıı̄un / and nouȝt he
That can an hundred fold / More sotiltee
He hath betrayed folk / many tyme
Of his falsnesse / it dulleth me to ryme
Eủere whan I speke of his falshede
For shame of hym / my chekys wexe rede
Agates they begonne / forto glowe
For reednesse have I now / right wel I knowe
In my visage / for fumes diủerse
Of metalles whiche / ȝe han herde me reherse
Consumed and wasted / han my reednesse /
Now take heede of this / Chanons cursednesse
¶ Sir quod he to the preest lat ȝoure man goon̄
For quicsiluer / that we it had anoon̄
And lat hym brynge / vnces twoo or three
And whan he comyth / as faste shul ȝe see
A wondir thyng / whiche ȝe say neủere ar this
Sir quod the preest / it shal be done ywis
He bad his seruant / fecchen hym this thyng
And he al redy / was at his biddyng
And wente hym forth / and come anoon ageyn̄
With this quicsiluer / shortly forto seyn̄
And toke thise vnses three / to the Chanoıı̄un
And he it leyde / faire and wel adoıı̄un
And bad the ʆseruᵃaunt / coles forto brynge
That he anoon / myghte go to his worchynge
The coles right anoon / were yfette
And this Chanon / toke out a crosselette
Of his bosome / and shewed it the preest
This instrument qduod he / the whiche that thou seest
Tak in thin hond / and put thy self therynne
Of this quicsiluer an vnce / and here begynne
In the name of crist / to wexe a philosophre
Ther ben ful fewe / whiche that I wolde ꝓprofre
To shewe hem this moche / of my science
For ȝe shuƚƚ see / here by exꝑperience
That this quicsiluer / I wol mortefie
Right in youre sight / anoon withoute lie
And make it as good siluer / and as fyn
As ther is eny in youre purs or in myn
Or elliswhere / and make it malleable
And ellis holde me / fals and variable
Amonges folc / eủere to appere
I have a powder here / that cost me dere
Shal make al golde / for it is cause of aƚƚ
My connynge / whiche that I yow shewe shaƚƚ
Voydeth ȝoure ȝoman / and lat hym be ther oute
And shute the dore / whiles we ben aboute
Oure priuete / that no man vs espie
Whiles we werken / in this philosophie
Al as he bad / fulfilled was in dede
This ilke ʆseruᵃaunt / anoon right out ȝede
And his mayster / shette the dore anoon
And to her labour / spedely they goon
This preest / at this cursed Chanons biddyng
Vpon the fire / anoon sette this thyng
And bliwe the fire / and besied hym ful faste
And this Chanoıı̄un / into the crosselet caste
A powder / not I wher of / that it was
Ymade / outher of chalk / or of glas
Or sumwhat ellis / was not worth a flie
To blynde with this preest / and bad hym hie
The coles forto cowche / al aboue
The crossolet / for in tokene that I the loue
Quod this Chanon / thyn hondes two
Shuƚƚ werke al thyng / which as shaƚƚ be do
Graunt m̉ercy quod the preest / and was ful glad
And couched coles / as the Chanoıı̄un bad
And whiles he besy was / this feendly wrecche
This fals chanoıı̄un / the foule feend hym fecche
Out of his bosoms / took a bechen cole
In which ful sotilly / was made an hole
And ther ynne put was / of syluer lymayle
An vnce / and stopped was withoute fayle
This hole with wex / to kepe the lymayle in
And vnderstondeth / that this fals gyn
Was not made there / but it was maad bifore
And other thynges / as I shaƚƚ telle more
Here afterward / which that he wᵗith hym brouȝte
Ar he com there / to begile him he thouȝte
And so dede / or they wente a twynne
Til he had torned him / coude he not blynne
It dulleth me / whan þᵗat I of him speke
On his falshede / fayn wolde me a wreke
Ȝif I wiste how / but he is here and there
He is so variant / he abideth nowhere
But taketh heede / now sires for goddes loue
He toke his cole / of whiche I spak aboue
And in his hond / he bar it priuely
And whiles the preest / couched besily
The coles / as I tolde ȝou er this
This Chanoıı̄un seide frende ȝe done amis
This is not couched / as it ouȝte be
But sone I shaƚƚ / amende it quod he
Now lat me medle with it / but a while
For of you have I pite / by seint gyle
Ȝe be right hoot / I see wel how ȝe swete
Haue here a cloth / and wype away the wete
And whiles the preest / him wyped haas
This Chanon toke his cole / I shrewe his faas
And leyde it vpon / aboue the midward
Of the crossolet / and blewe wel afterward
Til that the coles gonne faste brenne
Now ȝeue vs drynke / quod this Chanoıı̄un thenne
As swithe / al shal be wel I vndertake
Sitte we doıı̄un / and lat vs mery make
And whan the Chanons bechen cole
Was brent / al the lymayle / out at the hole
Into the Crossolet / anoon fil adoon
And so it muste nedes by resoıı̄un
Syn it so euene / aboue couched was
But therof wiste / no thyng the prest allas
He demede alle thise coles lyche goode
For of the sleighte / noo thynge he vnderstoode
And whan this Alkamystre / sagh his tyme
Riseth vp sire preest and stondith byme
And for I woot wel / Ingot have ȝe noon
Goth walketh forth / and bryng a chalk stoon
For I woƚƚ make it / of the same shapp̄
That is an Ingot / ȝif I may have happ̄
And bryng with you / a bolle or a panne
Ful of water / and see shuƚƚ ȝe thanne
How that oure besynesse / shal happe ⁊and preve
And ȝit for ȝe shul have noo misbileve
Ne wrong conceyte of me / in ȝoure absence
I wol not ben / out of ȝoure p̉resence
But go with you / and come with you ageyn
The chambre dore / shortly forto seyn̄
They opened and shette / and went forth her weye
And forth wᵗith hem / they caried the keye
And come ageyn̄ / withoute eny delay
What sholde I tarie / al the longe day
He took the chalk / and shoop it in the wise
Of an Ingot / as I shal ȝou deuise
I say he took out / of his ownesleue
A teyne of siluer / euel mote he cheue
Which that was / but an ounce of weighte
And taketh heed now / of this cursed slighte
He shoop his Ingot / in lengthe and brede
Of the teyne / withoute eny drede
So slighly / that the preest it not espide
And in his sleue / ageyn he gan it hide
And from the fire / took vp the matere
And into the Ingot / it putte wᵗith mery chere
And into the water vessel he it caste
Whan that hym liste / and bad the preest as faste
Loke what there is / put in thyn hand and grope
Thou shalt fynde there / syluer as I hope
What deuel of helle / shulde it ellis be
Shauyng of syluer / silủer is parde
He putte in his honde / and toke vp ateyne
Of syluer fyn̄ / and glad eủery veyne
Was this preest / whan he sagh it was so
Goddes blessyng / and his moders also
And alle halwes / have ȝe sire Chanoıı̄un
Seyde the preest / and I here malisoıı̄un
But and ȝe vouchesauf to teche me
This noble craft / and this sotilte
I wol be ȝoures / in al that eủere I may
Quod the Chanon / ȝit wol I make assay
The seconde tyme / that ȝe may take hede
And ben exꝑpert of this / at youre nede
Another day in myn absence
This discipline / and this crafty science
¶ Lat take another ounce quod he tho
Of quiksiluer / withoute wordes mo
And do therwith / as ȝe have done er this
With that other / that now syluer ys
This preest hym besieth / in al that he can
To doıı̄un as this Chanoıı̄un / this cursed man
Cōmmaundeth hym / and faste blewe the fire
Forto come to the effecte / of his desire
And this Chanoıı̄un / right in the mene while
Al redy was / this preest eft to begile
And for a countenance / in his honde he bar
An holgh stykke / take hede and be war
In the ende of whiche / an ounce and nono more
Of siluer lymayle / put was al bifore
As was his cole / and stopped with wax wel
Forto kepe in / his lymayle eủerydel
And whiles this preest / was in his besynesse
This Chanon with his stikke / gan him dresse
To hym anoon / and his pouder cast In
As he dide er / the deuel out of his skyn
Hym torne / I pray to god / for his falshede
For he was eủere fals / in worde and dede
And with his stikke / aboue the crossette
That was ordeyned / with that false gette
He stereth the coles / til relente gan
The wax ageyn the fire / as eủery man
But it a fool be / woot wel and moot nede
And al that in the hole was / out ȝede
And into the crosselet / hastely it fel
The preest supposed / no thyng but wel
But besied hym faste / and was wonder fayn̄
Supposyng noght but trouthe / soth forto sayn̄
He was so glad / I can it not expresse
In noo man̉ere / his merthe and his gladnesse
And to the Chanon / he profred eft sone
Body and good / ȝe quod the Chanon sone
Thogh poủere I be / crafty thou shalt me fynde
I warne the / ȝit is ther more behynde
Is ther ony coper / here yn saide he
Ȝe sire quod the preest / I trowe therbe
Ellys go bye some / and that asswithe
Now sire go forth / thy way and hythe
He went his way / and with this coper he cam
And this Chanon / in hand it nam
And of that coper / weyed out but an ounce
Al to symple is my tunge / to ꝓpronounce
His moustre / and his witte . the doublenesse
Of this Chanon / rote of cursednesse
He semed frendely / to hem that knewe hym noght
But he was frendely / bothe in werke and thought
It werieth me to telle / of his falsnesse
And nathalees / ȝit wole I it expresse
To that entente / that men may be war ther by
And for noon other cause trewely
He putte this ounce of coper / in the crosselet
And on the fire / asswithe he hath it set
And cast in pouder / and made the prest to blowe
And in his worchinge / forto stoupe lowe
As he dide erst / and al nas but a iape
Right as him liste / the preest he made his ape
And afterward / into the Ingot he it caste
And in the panne / putte it atte laste
Of water / and in he putte his owne hand
And in his sleue / as ȝee biforehand
Herde me telle / he had a syluer teyne
He sleighly toke it out / this cursed heyne
Vnwetyng this preest / of his fals craft
And in the pannes botme / he hath it laft
And in the water / rombleth to and fro
And wonder pryuely / took it vp also
The coper teyne / not knowyng this preest
And hidde it / and hent him by the breest
And to hym spak / and thus saide in his game
Stoupeth adoıı̄un / by god ȝe be to blame
Helpeth me now / as I dide ȝou whiler
Putte in ȝoure hande / and loketh what is there
This preest toke vp / this siluer teyne anoon
And than seide the Chanon / lat vs goon
And thise thre teynes / whiche as we have wroght
To som goldsmyth / to wete ȝif it be ouȝt
For by my faith / I nolde for myn hood
But ȝif they siluer were / fyn and good
And that asswithe / pⁱriued shal it be
This sottid preest / who was gladder than he
Was neuer brid gladder / ageyn the day
Ne nyghtengale / in the sesoıı̄un of May
Was neủer noon / that liste better synge
Ne lady lustier / in carolynge
And forto speke of loue / and womanhede
Ne knyght in armes / to done an hardy dede
To stande in grace / of his lady dere
Than hadde this preest / this craft forto lere
And to the Chanoıı̄un / thus he spak and seyde
For the loue of god / that for vs alle deyde
And as I may / deserue it vnto ȝow
What shaƚƚ this receyt coste / telleth now
By oure lady / quod this Chanon it is dere
I warne ȝou for sothe / sauf I and a frere
In Englond / ther can no man it make
No fors quod he / now sire for goddes sake
What shal I paie / telle me I the pray
Ywis quod he / it is ful dere I say
Sire at oo worde / ȝif that ȝe lest it have
Ȝe shul paie fourty pounde / so god me save
And ne were the frendshippe / that ȝe dide er this
To me / ȝe shulde paie more ywis
This preest the sōmme / of fourty pound anoon
Of nobles fette / and toke hem eủerychoon
To this Chanon / for this ilke receyt
Al his worching / was fraude and deceyt
Sir preest he saide / I kepe to have noo loos
Of my craft / for I wolde it were kept cloos
And as ȝe loue me / kepeth it secree
For and men knewe / al my sotiltee
By god men wolde have / so grete envie
To me by cause / of my philosophie
I shulde be deed / ther were no nother weye
God forbede quod the preest / what seyȝe
Ȝit had I levere spenden al the good
Whiche that I have / and ellis wexe I wood
Than that ȝe shulde / falle in suche meschief
For ȝoure good wil / sire have ȝe right good preef
Quod the Chanon / and sire fare wel graunt m̉ercy
He went his way / and neủere the preest hym sey
After that day / and whan this preest sholde
Maken assaie / at suche tyme / as he wolde
Of this receyt / fare wel it wolde not be
Lo this by iaped / and bygiled was he
¶ Thus maketh he his introduccioıı̄un
To bringe folke / to her destruccioıı̄un
Considereth sires / how that in eche astate
Bitwixe men and gold ther is debate
So ferforth / that vnnethes ys ther oon
This multiplying / blyndeth so many oon
That in goode faith / I trowe that it be
The cause grettest / of this grete scarste
This philosophres / speken so mystely
In this craft / that men can not come therby
For eny witte / that men have now adayes
They may wel chitren / and ianglen as done iayes
And in her termes / sette lust and peyne
But to her purpos / shul they neuer atteyne
A man may lightly lerne / ȝif he have oght
To multiplie / and bryng his good to noght
Loo suche a lucre / is in this lusty game
A mannes merthe / it wol torne al to grame
And empten also / grete and heuy purses
And make folk / to purchace curses
Of hem that han þ̉erto / her good ylent
O fy for shame / they that have be brent
Allas can they not flee / the fires hete
Ȝe that it vsen / I rede that ȝe lete
Lest ȝe lesen al / for bet than neủere is late
Neủere to thryue / were to longe a date
Though ȝe prolle ay / ȝe shuƚƚ it neủere fynde
Ȝe ben as bolde / as is bayard the blynde
That blundreth forth / and periƚƚ caste he noon
He is as bold / to renne ageyn̄ a stoon
As forto go besides / in the weye
So fare ȝe / that multiplie I seye
Ȝif that ȝoure eyen / can not seen aright
Loke that ȝoure mynde / lakke not his sight
For thogh ȝe loke / neủere so brode and stare
Ȝe shul not wynne / a myte in that chaffare
But wasten al / that ȝe may rappe and renne
Withdrawe the fire / lest it so faste brenne
Medleth no more / wᵗith that art I mene
For ȝif ȝe done / ȝoure thrifte is goon ful clene
And as swythe / I wol ȝow telle here
What that the philosophres / seyn in this matere
Loo thus seith Arnold of the newe toun
As his Rosarie / maketh mencioıı̄un
He seith right thus / withoute eny lye
Ther may no man / m̉ercurie mortifie
But it be wᵗith his brotheres knowelechyng
How that he / which first seide this thyng
Of philosophres / fader was hermes
He seith how that / the dragoıı̄un douteles
Ne dyeth not / but ȝif he be slayn
ith his brother / and that is forto sayn̄
By the dragoıı̄un / m̉ercurie and noon other
He vnderstod / that bremston̄ were his brother
That out of sol and luna were ydrawe
And therfore seide he / take hede to my sawe
Lat no man besie him / this art forto seche
But he / that the entencioıı̄un and speche
Of philosophres / vnderstonde can
And ȝif he do / he is a lewed man
For this science / and this cunnynge quod he
Is of the secre / of secrees parde
Also ther was a disciple of Plato
That on a tyme / seide his maister to
As his book Somer / wol bere witnesse
And this was his demaunde / in sothfastnesse
Tel me the name / of the pryue stoon̄
And Plato answerde vnto hym anoon
Tak the stoon / that titanos men name
Which is that quod he / Magnesia is the same
His disciple seide / ȝe sire and is it thus
This is ignotūm / ꝑper ignotius
What is Magnesia / good sire I pray
It is a water / that is made I say
Of elementes foure / quod Plato
Tel me the roche / good sire qduod he tho
Of that water / ȝif it be ȝoure wille
Nay nay quod Plato / certeyn that I Nylle
The philosophres / were sworn ecchoon̄
div.fw: ¶ The prologe of the Doctour of Phisyk
div.l: That they shulde not discoủere it to no Man
Ne in noo book / it write in noo manere
For vnto god / it was so leef and dere
That he wol not / that it discoủered be
But where it leketh to his deyte
Man to enspire / and eke forto defende
Whom that him liketh / loo this is the ende
¶ Than conclude I thus / syn that god of heuene
Wol not / that the philosophres nevene
How that a man / shal come vnto this stoon̄
I rede / as for the beste / lat it goon̄
For who so maketh god his adủersarie
And forto worche eny thyng / in contᵃrarie
Vnto his wil / certes neủere shal he thryve
Thogh that he multiplie / terme of his lyve
And there apoynt / for endid is my tale
God sende eủery trewe man / bote of his bale
¶ Thus endeth the tale of the Chanons yoman
¶ And bygynneth the Prologe of the Dottour of Physik
Whan that this yoman / his tale ended hadde
Of this fals Chanon / whiche that was so badde
Oure host gan seye / trewely and certayn
This preest was bigiled / sothly forto sayn
He wenynge forto be / a philosophre
Til he right no gold / lefte in his cofre
And sothly this preest / hadde a luder iape
This cursed Chanoıı̄un / putte in his hood an ape
But al this / passe I ouer as now
Sir dottour of Phisik / I pray ȝow
Telle vs a tale / of som honest matere
It shaƚƚ be don̄ / ȝif that ȝe wole it here
Saide this Dottour / and his tale began anon
Now goode men quod he / herkeneth eủerychoıı̄un
Ther was as telleth vs / Titus liuius
A knyght / that cleped was Virgineus
Fulfilled of honour / and wordynesse
And stronge of freendes / and of greet richesse
A Doghter he hadde / by his wyf
And neủere hadde he moo / in al his lyf
Faire was this Mayden / in excellent beaute
Aboue eủery wight / that men myght see
For nature hath / with souerayn diligence
Formed hir / in so grete excellence
As though she wolde say / I nature
Thus can I forme / and peinte a creature
Whan that me lust / who can me count̉erfete
Pigmalion not though / he alwey forge and bete
Or graue or peinte / for I dar wel sayn̄
Appollo zephirus / shulde worche in vayn̄
To grave or peynte / or forge or bete
Ȝif they p̉resumed / me to counterfete
For he that is / the formoᵘur principal
Hath maad me / his viker gen̉eral
To forme and peinte / ech erthely creature
Right as me list / for al thyng is in my cure
Vnder the mone / that may wane and waxe
And for my werke / no thyng wol I axe
My lorde and I / be fully at accord
I made hir / to the worshipe of my lord
So do I alle / othere myn creatures
Of what colour they be / or what figures
Thus semeth me / that nature wolde say
This Maide was of age xij yeer and tway
In which that nature / hath suche delyte
For right as she can peynte / a lylie whyght
And rody as rose / right with swich peinture
She peynted hath / this noble creature
Er she was born / vpon hir lymes free
Were also brighte / as suche coloures shulde be
And Phebus dyed had / hir tresses grete
Lyk to the stremes / of his boorned hete
And ȝif that excellent was hir beaute
A thousand fold / more vertuous was she
In her ne lakketh / no condicioıı̄un
That is to preise / as by discrecioıı̄un
As wel in body as goost / chaast was she
For whiche she florisshed in virginite
With aƚƚ humilite / and abstinence
With aƚƚ attemꝑperance / and pacience
With mesure eke / and beringe of aray
Discrete she was / in answerynge alway
Thogh she were wis / as pallas dar I seyn
He facunde eke / ful womanly and pleyn
No counterfeted t̉ermes had she
To seme wys / but after hir degre
She spak and aƚƚ hir wordes more and lesse
Sownynge in vertue / and in gentilnesse
Shamefast she was / in maydenes shamfastnesse
Constant in herte / and eủere in besinesse
To dryve hir out of slogardie
Bachus had of hir mouth no maystrie
For wyn and thoght / done Venus encrece
As men in fyr / wil casten oyle or grece
And of hir owne vertue vnconstreyned
She hath ful ofte tyme / hir syke feyned
For that she wolde / fle the companye
Where licly was / to treten of folye
As is at festes / at Reueles / and at daunces
That bien occasions / of daliaunces
Suche thynges maken / children forto be
To sone rype / and bold as men may see
Which is ful ꝑperilous / and hath ben yore
For aƚƚ to sone / may she lerne lore
Of boldnesse / whan she is a wyf
And ye maistresses / in youre olde lyf
That lordes doghters / han in goủernance
Ne taketh of my worde / no displesaunce
Thynges that ben sette / in goủernynges
Of lordes doghters / oonly for two thynges
Outher for ȝe han kept youre honeste
Or ellis ye have falle in frelte
And knowen wel ynogh the olde daunce
And konne forsake / fully meschaunce
For eủermo / therfore for cristes sake
Kepeth wel tho / that ȝe vndertake
A theef of venisoıı̄un / that hath forlaft
His likerous Mouth / and al his theefs craft
Can kepe a Forest / best of any man
Now kepeth hem / for and ye wol ye kan
Loketh wel to no vice / that ye assente
Lest ye be dampned / for youre entente
For who so doth / a traytour is certayn̄
And taketh of that / which that I shal sayn̄
Of aƚƚ tresoıı̄un / souereyn̄ pestilence
Is whan a wight / betrayeth innocence
Ye Faders and moders / eeke also
Thogh ye have children / be it oon or mo
Youre is the charge / of al her suffrance
Whiles they ben̄ / vnder youre goủernance
Beth war that by ensaumple / of youre lyuynge
Other by necligence / in chastisynge
That they ne ꝑperisshe / for I dar wel seye
Yif that they done / ye shul ful sore abeye
Vnder a shepherde / softe and necligent
The wolf hath many a sheep and lambe to rent
Suffiseth oon ensample / now as here
For I mut turne ageyn̄ / to my matere
¶ This mayde / of whiche I telle my tale exp̉resse
She kepte her self hir neded no maystresse
For in hir lyuynge / maydenes myght rede
As in a book eủery goode worde or dede
That longeth to a mayde vertuous
She was so prudent / and so bountevous
For whiche out spronge / on eủery syde
Bothe of hir beaute / and of hir bounte wide
That thurgh the londe / they preised hir ecchon̄
That loued vertue / sauf envie allone
That sory is of other mennes wele
And glad is of his sorwe / and vnhele
¶ The Doctoᵘur made this discripcioıı̄un
This wente on a day / into the toıı̄un
Toward the temple / with hir moder dere
As ys of yonge maydenes the manere
Now was there a Iustice / in the toun
That goủernoᵘur was / of that Regioun
And so bifel / this Iuge his eyen caste
Vpon this mayde / avisynge hir fulfaste
As she come forthby / there as the Iuge stood
Anoon his herte chaunged / and his mood
So was he caghte / wᵗith beaute of this mayde
And to hym self / ful pryuely he sayde
This mayde shal be myn / for ony man
Anoon the feend / into his herte ran
And thaghte hym sodeinly / by what sleighte
The mayde to his purpos / he wynne myghte
For certes by no force / ne by noo mede
Hym thoghte he was not able forto spede
For he was strong of frendes / and eke she
Conformed was / in such soủerayn beaute
That wel he wiste / he myght hir neủere wynne
As forto make hir / with hir body synne
For which / with grete delib̄eracioıı̄un
He sente after a Clerk / in the toıı̄un
Whiche he knewe / for subtile and for bolde
This Iuge vnto this clerk / his tale hath tolde
In secre wise / and made hym to assure
He shulde telle it / to no creature
And ȝif he dide / he shold lese his heed
Whan assented / was this cursed reed
Glad was the Iuge / and made glad chere
And yaf him yiftes / p̉recious and dere
Whan shapen was / al this conspiracie
Fro poynt to poynt / how that his lecherie
Parformed shulde be / ful subtily
As shal here afterward openly
Hom goth this clerk / that hight Claudius
This false Iuge / that hight Apius
So was his name / for it is no fable
But knowen for an historial thing notable
The sentence of it / soth is out of doute
This false Iuge / goth now faste aboute
To hasten his delite / al that he may
And so bifel sone after / on a day
This fals Iuge / as telleth vs the story
As was wont / sat in his consistory
And yaf his domes / vppon sundry cas
This fals clerk / cam forth a wel good paas
And seide lorde / if it be youre wille
As doth me right / vpon this pitous bille
In whiche I pleyne / vpon Virgineus
And ȝif that he wol seyn̄ / it is not thus
I wol preue it / and fynde goode witnesse
That soth is that / my bille wol exp̉resse
The Iuge answerde / of this in his absence
I may not yeue / diffinitif sentence
Lat done hym calle / and I wol gladly here
Thou shalt haue right / and no wrong here
Virgineus cam / to wite the Iuges wille
And right anoon / was rad this cursed bille
The sentence of it / was as ye shul here
¶ To you my lord / sir Apius so dere
Sheweth youre poủere ʆseruᵃaunt Claudius
How that a knyght / called Virgineus
Ageyn the lawe / ageyn al equite
Holdeth expresse / ageyn the wille of me
My ʆseruᵃaunt / which that thral be right
Which fro my hous / was stolen on a nyght
While she was ful yonge / I wol it preue
By witnesse lorde / so that ye you not greue
She is nat his doughter / what so he say
Wherfore my lorde / sire Iuge / to you I pray
Yelde me my thraƚƚ / yif it be youre wille
Loo this was al the sentence / of the bille
Virgineus gan / vpon the clerk beholde
But hastely / er he his tale tolde
And wolde have defended it / as shulde a knyght
And by witnesse / of many a trewe wight
That al was fals / that saide his adủersarie
This cursed Iuge / wolde no lenger tarie
Ne here a word / more of Virgineus
But yaf his iugement / and seide thus
I deme anoon / this clerk his ʆseruᵃaunt have
Thou shalt no longer / in thyn hous hir have
Go bryng here forth / and putte hir in oure warde
This clerk shal haue his thraƚƚ / thus I awarde
And whan this worthy knyght / Virgineus
Thurgh thassent / of this Iuge Apius
Muste byforce / his dere doghter yeuen
Vnto the Iuge / in lecherie to lyuen
He goth hym home / and sitte hym in his halle
And lete anoon / his dere doughter calle
And with a face deed / as asshen colde
Vpon hir humble face / he gan biholde
With Faders pite / stikyng thurgh his herte
Al wolde he not / fro his purpos conủerte
Doughter quod he / Virginea by thy name
Ther ben two weyes / outher deth or shame
That thou must suffre / allas that I was bore
For neủere thou deseruedest wherfore
To dye with a swerd / or with a knyf
O dere doughter / ender of my lyf
Whiche I have fostred vp / with such plesaunce
That thou ne were / out of my remembraunce
O doughter / which that art my last wo
And of my lyf / my laste ioye also
O gēmme of chastite / in pacience
Take thou thy deth / for this is my sentence
For loue / and not for hate / thou must be deed
My pitous hond / moot smyten of thyn heed
Allas that eủere / Apius the say
Thus hath he falsly / iuged the to day
And tolde hir al the caas / as ye bifore
Han herde / it nedeth not to telle it more
Mercy dere Fader / quod this Mayde
And with that worde / she bothe hir armes layde
Aboute his nekke / as she was wont to do
The teres brasten out / of hir eyen two
And seide goode Fader / shal I dye
Is ther no gᵃrace / is ther no remedye
No certes dere doughter myn / quod he
Than ȝeve me leve Fader myn / quod she
My deth to compleyne / a litel space
For ꝑparde Iepte yaf his doghter grace
For to compleyne / or he hir slogh allas
And god it woot / no thyng was hir trespas
But that she ran / hir Fader first to see
To welcome him / with grete solempnite
And with that worde / she fil on swoun anoon
And after / whan hir swounyng was agoon
She riseth vp / and to hir Fader saide
Blessed be god / that I shal dye a mayde
Ȝeve me my deth / er that I have a shame
Doth with youre childe / youre wil a goddes name
And with that worde / she pᵃrayed hym ofte
That with his swerde / he shulde smyte hir softe
And with that worde / on swoune doun she feƚƚ
Hir fader with sorwefuƚƚ herte and feƚƚ
Hir heed of smoot / and by the top it hende
And to the Iuge / he yaf it to p̉resente
As he sat in his dome / in consistorie
Whan the Iuge it say / as seith the storie
He bad take hym / and honge him also faste
But right anoon / al the peple in thraste
To save the knyght / for ruthe and for pite
For knowen was / the fooles iniquite
The peple anoon / had suspect / in this thyng
By maner / of the clerkys chalengyng
That it was by thassent / of Apius
They wiste wel / that he was leccherous
For whiche / vnto this Apius / they goon
And casten him in prisoıı̄un right anoon
Where as he slough hym self and Claudius
That ʆseruᵃaunt was / vnto this Apius
Was demed to honge / vppon a tre
But Virgineus / of his greet pite
Prayed for hym / that he was exiled
And ellis certes / he had be begiled
The remanent were honged / more and lesse
That consented were / to this cursednesse
Here may men see / how synne hath his meryte
Be war for no man woot / how god wol smyte
In no degre / ne in which man̉er wyse
The worme of conscience wil arise
Of wykked lyf / thogh it so pryue be
That no man woot of it / but god and he
Wheyther he be lewed man / or lered
He note how sone / that he may be a fered
Therfore I rede you / this counseƚƚ take
Forsaketh synne / or synne you forsake
¶ Thus endeth the tale of the Doctoᵘur of Phisik
¶ And here bygynneth the ꝓprologe of the pardoner
Oure hoost gan swere / as he were wood
Harrow quod he / by nayles and by blood
This was a cursed theef / a fals Iustise
As shameful deth / as herte can deuise
So falle vpon his body / and his bones
Allas to dere boughte she hir beaute
Wherfore I say / that alle men may see
That yiftes of fortune / or of nature
Ben cause of deth / of many a creature
Hir beaute was hir deth / I dar wel sayn̄
Allas so pitously / as she was slayn̄
But trewely / myn owne Maist̉er dere
This is a pitous tale / forto here
But nathalees passe over / it is no fors
I pᵃray to god / so save thy gentil corps
And thyn vrynals / and thy iordans
Thyn ypocras / and thy galians
And eủery box / ful of thy letuarie
God blesse hem / and oure lady seint marie
So mote I the / thou art a ꝓpropir man
And lyke a p̉relate / by seynt Roniian
Saue that I can not speke wel in t̉erme
But wel I woot / thou doost myn herte erme
That I have almost / caught a cardiacle
By corpus bones / but if I have triacle
Or ellis a draught / of moyst and corny ale
Or but I here anoon / a mery tale
Myn herte is lost / for pite of this mayde
Thou belamy / Ioh̄an ꝐPardoner he sayde
Telle vs som m̉erthe / or iapes right anoon
It shal be done / quod he by seint Iohan
But first quod he / at the nexte ale stake
I wol bothe drynke / and eten of a cake
But right anoon / thise gentiles gonne to crie
Nay late hym telle vs / of no rebaudie
Telle vs sōmme moral thing / that we may lere
Som wit / and than we wol gladly here
I graunte Iwis quod he / but I mot thinke
Vpon som honest thing / while that I drynke
¶ Explicit prologus
¶ And here begynneth the tale
Lordynges quod he / in churche whan I p̉reche
I peyne me / to have an hauteyn speche
I rynge it out / as round as goth a belle
For I can al be rote / that I telle
My teeme is alwey oon / and euere was
Radix oıı̄ıı̄mnium maloꝝrum / est cupiditas
First I ꝓpronounce / whennes that I come
And than my bulles / I shewe alle and some
Oure liege lordes seal / en my patent
That shewe I first / my body to warent
That no man be so bold / preest ne clerk
Me to distourbe / of cristes holy werk
And after that / telle I forth my tales
Bulles of popes / and of cardinales
Of patriarkes / and bisshoppes I shewe
And in latyn / I speke wordes fewe
To sauoure with my p̉redicacioıı̄un
And forto stere men / to deuocioıı̄un
Then shewe I forth / my longe cristal stones
Ycrammed ful of cloutes and of bones
Relikes they ben / as wene they ecchoon
That have I in latou / a shulder boon
Which that was / of an holy Iewes shepe
Good men I sey / take of my wordes kepe
Ȝif that this boon / be wasshen in a welle
Ȝif kow or calf / shepe or Oxe swelle
That any worme hath eten / or stōnge
Or ellis aboute the herte / or the lonnge
It is hool anoon / and ferthermore
Of pokkes / and of scabbe / and of eủery sore
Shal eủery sheep ben hooll / that of this welle
Drynke a draught / take heed that I telle
If that the goodman / that the bestes oweth
Wol eủery wyke / or that the Cok him croweth
Fastynge drynke / of this welle a draught
As thilke holy Iewes / oure elders taught
His bestes and his store / shal multiplie
And sires also / it heleth Ialousie
And though a man be fallen / in a ialous rage
Lat make wᵗith the water / his potage
And neủere shal he / his wyf mystriste
Though he / the sothe / of hir defaute wiste
Al had she taken / preestes two or thre
Here is a myteyne eke / that ye may se
He that his hand / wol put in this myteyne
He shal have multyplyinge / of his greyne
Whan he hath sowen / be it whete or otes
So that he brynge me goode pans or ellis grotes
And men and women / oo thyng I warne yow
If any wight / be in this churche now
That hath done synne / horible that he
Dar not for shame / of it shryven be
Or any woman / be she yong or olde
That hath made hir husbond Cokewold
Suche folke shul have noo power / ne no gᵃce
To offre to my relikes / in this place
And who so fyndeth hym / out of suche blame ¶¶
They may come vp / and offre in godes name
And I assoille hem / by the auctorite
Suche as by my bulles / was graunted me
By this gaude / have I wonnon eủery yere
An hundred mark / syn I was pardoner
I stonde lyk a Clerk / in my pulpitte
And shewe to lewed peple thynges vnshitte
I preche so / as I have lered bifore
And telle an hundred iapes more
Than peyne I me / to strecche forth the nekke
And est and west / vppon the peple I bekke
As doth a dowve / sittynge vpon a berne
Myn handes and my tunge / goon ful yerne
That it is ioye / to se my besynesse
Of Auarice / and suche cursednesse
Is al my pchynge / forto make hem fre
To yeue her pans / namely vnto me
For myn entente is not / but forto wynne
And no thyng / for correcciou of synne
I recche neủere / whan that they be buried
Though that her soules / goo a blakburied
For certes / many a pdicaciou
Cometh ofte tyme / of euel entenciou
Some for plesance of folc / and for flaterie
Sōmme ben auaunced / by ypocrisie
And some for venglorie / and for hate
For whan I dar not / other wayes debate
Than wole I stinge hem / with my tunge smert
In pchyng / so that he shal not stert
To ben defamed falsly / so that he
Hath trespassed to my brethern / and to me
For though I telle not / his ꝓpropre name
Men shal wel knowe / that it is the same
By som signe / and other circumstances
Thus smyte I folk / that doth vs displesances
Thus spitte I out my venyme / vnder hewe
Of holynesse / to seme good and trewe
But shortly myn entente / I wol deuise ¶¶
I preche no thyng / but of couetise
Therfore my teme / is and eủere was
Radix omnium malorum / est cupiditas
Thus can I preche / ageyn the same vice
Whiche that I vse / and that is auarice
But though my self / be gilty in that synne
Yit can I make / other folke to wynne
Fro auarice / and sore hem repente
But that is nouȝt / my principal entente
I preche not / but for couetise
Of this matere / it ought ynow suffise
Than telle I hem / ensamples manyoon
Of olde stories / long tyme a goon
For lewed peple / louen tales olde
Suche thinges con they / reporte and holde
What trowe ye / whiles that I may preche
And wynne golde / and syluer for to teche
That I wol lyue in pouert wilfully
Nay nay I thought it neủere trewely
For I wol preche / and begge in sundry londes
I wol do noo labour / with my hondes
Ne maken baskettes / and lyue therby
By cause I wol nouȝt / lyuen ydelly
I wol noon of the Appostelles countrefete
I wol have moneye / chese or whete
Al were it yeven / of the poủerest page
Or of the pouerest widewe / in a village
Al shulde hir childerne sterue / or famyne
And I wol drenken / the licour of the wyne
And have a ioly wenche / in euery toun
But herkeneth lordes / in conclusioun
Youre lykyng is / that I shal telle a tale
Now I have dronken / a draughte of corny ale
By god I hope / I shall telle you a thyng
That by reson / shal be to youre lykyng
For thogh my self / be a vicious man
A moral tale / ȝit I you telle can
Whiche Iames wente to preche / forto wynne ¶¶
Now holdeth youre pees / my tale I wol bigynne
In Flaundres whilom / ther was a companye
Of yong folk / that haunted folye
As hasard / riot / stewes / and tauernes
Harpes rubibes / lutes and / gyternes
They dauncen and playen / atte dys nyght ⁊and day
And eete also / ouer that myght may
For they do to the deuel sacrifice
Withynne the deuelles temple / in sondry wise
By suꝑparfluite / abhominable
Her othes ben so greet / and dampnable
