That it is grisely / forto here hem swere
Oure blessed lordes body / they to tere
Hem thoughte Iewes / rente hym nough ynogh
And eche of hem / at others synne logh
And right anoon / come in the tumblisters
Fetise and smale / and yonge fruters
Syngers wᵗith harpes / baudes and waferers
Suche ben verrayly / the Deuels officers
To kyndely and blowe / the fire of leccherie
That is annexed / vnto glotenie
Holy writte / take I to witnesse
That leccherie is in wyn / and in drunkenesse
Loo how that drunken Loth / vnkyndely
Lay by his doghters two / vnwetingely
So dronken he was / he niste what he wroght
Herodes / who so hath the stories souȝt
Whan he of wyn / was replete atte feste
Right at his owne table ȝaf hes heste
To sleen the Iohn Baptist / ful gilteles
Senec seith a good worde douteles
He seith he can / no difference fynde
Betwixe a man / þᵗat is out of his mynde
And a man / that is drounkelewe
But that wodnesse / is fallen in a shrewe
Perseủereth lenger / than doth drunkenesse
Of glotenie ful / of cursednesse
O cause first / of oure confusiou ¶¶
Original / of oure dampnaciou
Til crist had bouȝt vs / with his blood ageyn
Lo how dere shortely for to seyn
Abought was / the cursed vilanie
Corrupte was al this world thurgh glotenie
Adam oure Fader / and his wyf also
Fro paradys / to labour and to wo
Were dreven for that wise / it is no drede
For whiles / that Adam fasted / as I rede
He was in paradys / and whan that he
Eet of the fruyt / defended on the tree
Anoon he was outcast / to wo and pyne
Of glotenie / on the wel oughte vs pleyne
O wist a man / how many maladyes
Folweth of excesse / and of glotenyes
He wolde ben / the more mesurable
Of his diete / sittinge at his table
Allas the short throte / the tendre mowth
Maketh that est and west / north and sowth
In erthe / in eyer / in water men to swynke
To geten a gloten / deynte mete and drynke
Of this matere / o paule wel canstow trete
Mete vnto wombe / and wombe eke vnto mete
Shal god destroye / bothe as paule seith
Allas a foule thinge / it is by my feith
To say this word / and fouler is the dede
Whan men so drynketh / of the white and rede
That of his throte / he maketh his pryuite
Thurgh thilke cursed super fluyte
The Apostil wepynge / seith ful pitousely
Ther walken manye / of whiche tolde have I
I say it now wepynge / wᵗith pitous voys
They ben enemyes / of crystes croys
Of whiche the ende is deth / wombe is her god
O wombe o baly / o stynkynge cod
Fulfilled of dong and of corrupciou
At eyther of the / foul is the sesou
How grete cost and labour / is to fynde ¶¶
Thise Cookes how they stampe / streyne and grynde
And turne substance / into accident
To fulfille all / thy lykerous talent
Out of the harde bones / knokke they
The mary / for they cast it not awey
That may go thurgh the golet / softe and swote
Of specery / of leues / bark and rote
Shal ben his savce / ymaad be delite
To maken him ȝit / a newe appetite
But certes he / that haunteth suche delites
Is ded / whyles he lyueth / in tho vices
And lecherous thing is wyn / and dronkenes
It is ful of stryuyng / and of wrecchednes
O dronken man / disfigured in thy face
Foul is thy breth / foul art thou to enbrace
And thurgh thy dronken nose / sowneth thy soun
As though thou seidest ay / sampsou sampsoun
And ȝit god woot / Sampson dranke neủere wyn
Thow fallest as it were / a dronken swyn
Thy tonge is lost / and al thyn honeste cure
For dronkenes / is verray sepulture
Of mannes wit / and his discreciou
In whom that drynke hath dominaciou
He can noo counseile kepe / it is no drede
Now kepe you / fro the white and fro the rede
Namely fro the white wyn / of leepe
That is to selle in fisshstrete in chepe
Thys wyn of spayne / crepeth subtyly
In other wynes / growyng fast by
Of whiche riseth / suche fumosite
Than whan a man / hath dronken a drauȝt two or thre
And weneth that he be / at home in chepe
Than is he in spayne / right at the toun of lepe
Nought at the Rochell / ne at Burdeaux toun
And than wol they say / Sampsou Sampsoun
But herkeneth lordynges / o word I you pray
That alle the soủerayne actes / dar I say
Of victories / in the olde testament ¶¶
That thurgh verray god / that is omipotent
Were done / in abstynence and in prayere
Loketh the bible / and there ye may it lere
Loketh Attila / the grete conquerour
Deyed in his slepe / wᵗith shame and dishonour
Bledynge at his nose / in dronkenesse
A Capitayne shul lyue / in sobornesse
And ouer al this / auise you right wel
¶ What was cōmmaunded / vnto Lamuel
Not Samuel / but Lamuel say I
Redeth the bible / and fyndeth it expssely
Of wyn yevyng / of hem that are Iustice
No more of this / for it may suffice
And now that I have spoken of gloteny
Now wol I defende / you hasardy
¶ Hasard is verray moder / of lesynges
And of desceyte cursed forswerynges
Blaspheme of crist manslaghter ⁊and wast also
Of batayle / and of tyme / and ferther mo
It is repreef / and contrarie to honour
For to be holden / a comou hasardour
And eủere the hyer / he is of estate
The more he is / holden desolate
Ȝif that a prince / vse hasardie
In all goủernance / and policie
He is as by comou opiniou
Holde the lasse / in reputaciou
Stilbon a . man þat was holde / a wys enbassatour
Was sent into Corinthe / with ful grete honour
Fro Calidoyne / to make hem alliance
And whan he cam / happed this chaunce
That alle the gretest / that were of that londe
Pleyinge atte hasard / he hem fond
For which as sone / as it myght be
He stal hym home / aȝen to his cuntre
And seide there / wolde I not lese my name
I wolde take nought on me / so grete diffame
For to allie you / to nonne hasardours ¶¶
Sendeth other wyser embassatours
As by my will and by me trete
Than I shulde you / to hasardours allie
For ye that ben so glorious in honoures
Shal not allie you / wᵗith hasardoures
As by my will / ne as by my trete
This wise philosophre thus saide he
Loke eke that to kyng Demetrius
They of pardes / as the book seith thus
Sent hym a payre of dees of gold in scorne
For he had vsed hasardry / ther biforne
For which heeld / his glorie and his renou
For no value / of reputaciou
Lordes myght fynde / other maner play
Honest ynow / to dryve the day away
¶ Now wol I speke / of othes false and grete
A worde or two / as other bokes trete
Greet sweryng / is a thyng abhominable
And fals sweryng / is more reprouable
The high god forbad / sweryng at al
Witnesse of Matheu / but in special
Of swerynge / the holy Ieromie
Thow shalt swere soth / thyn oþes ⁊and not lye
And swere in dome / and eke in rightwisnes
But ydel sweryng / is a cursednes
Beholde and see / that in the first table
Of the high goddes hestes honurable
How that oon heste of hem is this
Take nouȝt my name in ydelnes amys
Lo rather he forbedeth / such sweryng
Than homicide / or any other thyng
I say as thus / by ordre it stondeth
This knoweth / that his hestes vnderstondeth
How that the secunde heste / of god is that
And further oủer / I wol the telle al plat
That vengeance shal not passe fro his hous
That of his othes / is so outrageous
By goddes pcious herte / and by his nayles ¶¶
And by his blood that is in hayles
Seuen is my chaunce / as is fyve and thre
By goddes armes / ȝif thou falsly play me
This dagger shal thurgh thyn herte go
This fruyt cometh / of thilke bones two
For sweryng Ire / falsnes homicide
Now for the loue of crist / that for vs deyde
Leveth youre othes / bothe grete and smale
For I shal telle you / a mvaylous tale
Thise Riotours / of whiche I telle
Longe erst or prime / rong eny belle
Were sett in a taủerne to drynke
And as they sate / they herde a belle ryng
Before a corps / was caried to his grave
That oon of hem / gan calle to his knave
Go bet quod he / and aske redely
What corps is that / that passith forth by
And that thou reporte / his name wel
Sire quod this knave / it nedeth neủere adel
It was me tolde / er ȝe come here two houres
He was ꝑparde / an olde felawe of youres
And sodeinly was he slayn / to nyght
For dronken as he sat / vpon his benche vpright
Ther come a puy theef / men clepe deth
That in his countre / al the peple sleeth
And with his spere / he smote his herte a two
And wente his way / wᵗithoute wordes mo
He hath a thousand slayn / this pestilence
And maist̉er er come / to his psence
Me thenketh / that it were necessarie
Forto be war / of suche an aduersarie
Beth redy forto meten him eủeremore
Thus tauȝte me my dame I say no more
By seint Marie / seide this tauerner
The childe saith soth / for he hath slayn to ȝere
Hennes over a myle / withynne a grete village
Bothe man and woman child and page
I trowe his habitaciou be there ¶¶
To ben avised / grete wysdam it were
Or that he dide aman / dishonour
Ȝe goddes armes / quod this Riotour
Is it such perile / wᵗith hym forto mete
I shal hym sechyn / by sty and by strete
I make a vow / by goddes digne bones
Herkeneth felawes / we thre ben alle ones
Lat eche of vs / holde vp his hand to other
And eche of vs bicome / others brother
And we wol sle / this fals traytour deth
He shal be slayn / that so many sleth
By goddes dignite / er hit be nyght
To gider han thise thre / her trouthes plight
To lyue and dye / ech of hem with other
As though he were / his owne born brother
And vp they sterten / and dronken in this rage
And forth they goon / toward that vilage
Of which the taủerner / hath spoke biforn
And many a grisly othe / than have they sworn
And cristes blessed body / they to rente
That deth shal be ded / ȝif we may hym hente
Whan they haue goon / not fully a myle
Right as they wolde have troden oủer a style
An olde and a pore man / wᵗith hem mette
This olde man / ful mekely hem grette
And saide thus / now lordes / god you se
The proudest of thise Riatours thre
Answerde ageyn / what cherl wᵗith hardy gᵃce
Why artow al forwrapped / saue thy face
Why lyuest thou so longe / in so gret age
This olde man gan loke in his visage
And saide thus / for I can not fynde
A man / thogh I walked into ynde
Neither in Citee / ne in no village
That wol chaungen his youthe / for myn age
And therfore mote I have myn age stille
As longe tyme / as it is goddes wille
Ne deth allas wol not have my lyf ¶¶
Thus walke I lyk / a resteles caytyf
And on the grounde / which is my moder gate
I knokke wᵗith my staf / bothe erly and late
And say leue moder / late me Inne
Lo how I wanshe / flessh blood and skynne
Allas whan shul my bones / ben at reste
Moder wᵗith you / wol I chaunge my cheste
That in my chamber / long tyme hath be
Ȝe for an hier cloute to wrappe me
But ȝit to me / she wol not done that gᵃce
For whiche fulwelked is my face
But sires to you / it is no curtesie
To speken vnto an olde man velonie
But he trespace in worde / or in dede
In holy writt / ȝe may ȝoure self rede
Agayn an olde man hoor / vpon his hede
Ye shul avise you / therfore I you rede
Ne doth vnto an olde man / harme as now
No more than ȝe wolde / a man dede to yow
In age ȝif that ȝe so longe abide
And god be with ȝou / wheither ȝe go or ryde
I mote go thider / as I have to go
Nay olde cherle / by god þou shalt not so
Seide thise other hasardours anoon
Thow ꝑprotest not so lightly by seint Iohn
Thow spake right now / of thilke traytoᵘur deth
That in this countre / alle oure frendes sleeth
Have heer my trouthe / as thou art his aspie
Telle where he is / or ellis thou shalt dye
Be god / and by the holy sacrament
For sothly / thou art of his assent
To sleen vs yonge folk / thou fals theef
Now sires / ȝif it be you so leef
To fynde deth / turne vp this croked way
For in that groue / I lefte hym by my fay
Vnder a tree and there he wol abide
Ne for youre boost / he wol hym no thyng hide
Se ȝe that ook / right there / ȝe shul hym fynde ¶¶
God save you / that bouȝt ageyn mankynde
And ȝow amende / thus saide this olde man
And eủery of thise riotours ran
Til they come to the tre / and there they founde
Floreyns of gold fyne ycoyned rounde
Wel nygh a vij busshels / as hem thought
No lenger than after deth they sought
But eche of hem / so glad was of that sight
For that the Floreynes / so faire were and bright
That doun they sette hem / by that pcious hoord
The werst of hem / spak the first word
Bretheren quod he / take hede what I say
My witt is greet / though I bourde ⁊and play
This tresour hath fortune / to vs ȝeuen
In mthe and iolyte / oure lyf to lyuen
And lightly so as it cometh / so wol we spende
Ey pcious goddes herte / who wende
To day that we / shulde have so faire a gᵃce
But myght this gold / be caried fro this place
Home vnto myn hous / or ellys to ȝoures
For wel I woote / that al this golde is oures
Than were we in high felicite
But trewely by day / it may not be
Men wolde say that we were theefes stronge
And for oure tresour / done vs to honge
As wysly and as slighly / as it myghte
This tresour muste / ycaried be by nyghte
Wherfore I rede / lat loke among vs alle
To drawe and late see / where the cut wol falle
He that hath the cut / with herte blithe
Shal renne to towne / and that ful swythe
To brynge vs breed and drynke / ful pryuely
And two of vs / shul kepen ful subtily
This tresour wel / and ȝif he wol not tarie
Whan it is nyght / we wol this tresour carie
By oon assent / where as vs liketh best
That oon of hem / brought gras in his fest
And bad hem drawe / and loke on whom it wolde falle ¶¶
And it fel on the yongest / of hem alle
And forth toward the toun / he wente anoon
And also sone / as he was gon
That oon of hem / spak vnto that other
Thow wost wel / þou art my owne swore brother
Thy ꝓprofite / wol I telle the anoon
Thow wost wel / that oure felawe is goon
And here is gold / and that right grete plente
That it shal departed ben among vs thre
But nathalees / ȝif I can shape it so
That it deparded were among vs two
Had I not done a frendes turne to the
That other answerde / I not how that myght be
I wolde wel the golde were oures two
What shull we do / that it myght be so
Shal it be counseill / seide the first shrewe
And I shall telle the / in wordes fewe
What we shul done / and bryngen it aboute
I graunt quod that other / out of doute
That by my trouthe / I wol the not bewrye
Now quod the first / thou woost wel we be tweye
And two of vs / shul strenger be than oon
Loke whan he is sette / and that anoon
Arise as though / thou woldest wᵗith hym pleye
And I shal ryve him / thurgh the sides tweye
Whiles that thou strogelest wᵗith him as in game
And with thy dagger / loke thou do the same
And than shal al this golde / departed be
My dere frende / atwixe the and me
Than may bothe / oure lustes fulfille
And pley atte dys / right at oure owne wille
And thus accordet ben / thise shrewes tweye
To sle the thridde / as ȝe herde me seye
¶ This yongest / which that went to the toun
Ful ofte in his herte / it rolled vp and doun
The beaute of thise floryns / faire and bright
O lorde quod he / ȝif it so were I myght
Have al this tresour / to my self allone ¶¶
Ther is no man / that lyueth vnder trone
Of gold that shulde / lyue so mery as I
And atte laste / the feend oure enemy
Put in his herte / that he shulde poysou beye
With which he myght / sleen his felawes tweye
For why the feende / fonde him in suche lyvynge
That he had leue / him to sorowe brynge
For this was outerly his entente
To sleen hem bothe / and neủere to repente
And forth he gooth / no lenger wolde he tarie
Into the toun / vnto apothecarie
And preyde him / that he wolde him selle
Som poyson / that he myght his rattes quelle
And eke ther was a polkat in his hawe
That as he seide / his capons had yslawe
And seyde he wolde werke him ȝif he myght
Wo ⁊and sorow er to morowe at nyght
This Pothecarie answerde / thou shalt have
A thing / that als god my soule save
In al this worlde / ther is no creature
That ete or drynke / of this confecture
Not but the mountance / of a corne of whete
That he ne shal his lyf / anoon forlete
Ȝe sterve he shal / and that in lasse while
As thou wolt goon a paas / not but a myle
This poyson that is so hard / and violent
This cursed man / hath in his hond it hent
And putte it in a box / and sithens he ran
Into the nexte strete / vnto a man
And borwed him large botelles thre
To his felawes / ageyn repaireth he
The thridde he kepte clene for his drynke
For al the nyght / he shoop him forto swynke
In carying of that golde / out of that place
And whan this ryotour / with sory grace
Had with him filled his grete botelles thre
To his felawes / ageyn repayreth he
What nedeth to sermone therof more
For right as they had cast his deth before ¶¶
Right so they han him slayn / and that anoon
And whan that this was done / than spak that oon
Now late vs sitte / and drynke / and make vs merye
And afterward we wol his body berye
And afterthat / it happed hem ꝑpar cas
To taken the botel / wher yn the poyson was
And yaf his felawe drynke also
Thurgh which / anon they sterven bothe two
¶ But certes I suppose / that Avyseceon
Wroot neuere in no Canou ne in no fon
Mo wonder sorwes of enpoysonyng
Thus had thise wrecches to her endyng
Thus ended ben / thise homicides two
And eke this false / enpoysoner also
O cursed synne / ful of cursednes
O traytours homicides o wickednes
O glotonie / luxurie / and hasardie
Thou blasphemoᵘur of crist / with vilanie
And othes grete of vsage / and of pride
Allas mankynde / how may it betide
That to thy creatour which the wrought
And with his pcious blood the bouȝt
Thou art so fals / and so vnkynde allas
Now goode men / god forȝeve you youre trespas
And kepe you fro the synne of auarice
Myn holy ꝑpardou / may ȝow alle warisshe
So that ȝe offre / nobles or sterlynges
Or ellis syluer spones / broches or rynges
Boweth youre hede / vnder this bulle
Cometh vp ȝe wyues / offreth youre wolle
Ȝoure names I entre / in my rolle anoon
In the blisse of heuene / shull ȝe all goon
I ȝou assoile / by my high powere
Ȝe that offre / as clene / ⁊and eke as clere
As ȝe were born / and lo sires / thus I preche
And ihu crist / that is oure soules leche
So graunte you this ꝑpardoıı̄un / to resceyue
For that is best / I wol ȝow not disceyue ¶¶
But sires oo word / forgat I my tale
I have Relikes and ꝑpardou / in my male
As faire / as any man in Englond
Whiche were ȝeve me by the popes hond
Ȝif any of you / wol of deuociou
Offren and have / myn absoluciou
Cometh forth anoon / and kneleth here adou
That ȝe may have part / of my ꝑpardou
Or ellis taketh ꝑpardou / as ȝe wende
Al newe and fresshe / at eủery townes ende
So that ye offren / alway newe and newe
Nobles and pans / whiche that ben goode and trewe
It is an honoᵘur / to eủery that ben here
That ye may have / a sufficiant ꝑpardonere
To assoile you / in cuntre as ye ride
For auentures / whiche that may betide
For ꝑparauenture / ther may falle oon or two
Doun of his hors / and breke his nekke a two
Loke whiche a suerte / it is to you alle
That I am in youre felawshipe falle
That may assoile you / bothe more and lasse
Whan that the soule / shal fro the body passe
I rede that oure host / shal bigynne
For he is most / envolupe of synne
Come forth sir host / and offre first anon
And thou shalt kisse / the Relikes eủerychon
Ȝe for a grote / vnbocle anon thy purs
Nay nay quod he / than have cristes curs
Lat be quod he / it shal not be so theech
Thou woldest make me cussen thyn olde breech
And swere it were / the relik of a seint
Though it were / wᵗith thy foundement depeynt
But by the cros / whiche seint Eleine fonde
I wolde I hadde / thy coylions in myn honde
In stede of Relikes / and of seintuarie
Lett cutte hem of / and I wol helpe hem carie
They shulbe shryned / in an hogges tord
This ꝑpardoner / answerede nouȝt a word ¶¶
So wroth he was / he wolde no worde say
Now quod oure hoost / I wol no lenger play
With the / ne with noon other angry man
But right anoon / the worthy knyght bigan
Whan that he sawgh / that al the peple lowgh
No more of this / for it is right ynowgh
Sir ꝑpardoner be mery and glad of chere
And ȝe sire hoost / that be to me so dere
I pʳᵃy you / that ye cusse the ꝑpardoner
And ꝑpardoner I pray you drawe you ner
And as we dide late vs lawgh and play
And anoon they cussed / and riden forth her way
¶Here endeth the pardoneres tale
¶And here bigynneth the ꝓprologe of the Shipman
Now frendes saide oure hoost so dere
Now likith you by Iohn þe ꝑpardonere
For he hath vnbokeled wel the male
He hath vs tolde / right a thryfty tale
As touchyng of good goủernaıı̄unce
I pʳᵃy to god yeve him goode chaunce
As ye hau herde / of thise Riotours thre
Now gentil maryner / hertely I pʳᵃy the
Telle vs a goode tale / and that right anon
It shal be don / by god and by seynt Iohn
Seyde the Maryner / as wel as euer I can
And right anoon / his tale thus he bigan
¶Thus endeth the prologe
¶And here bygenneth the tale
A Marchaunt whilom dwelled at seint denys
That riche was / for whiche / men helde hym wys
A wyfe he hadde / of excellent beaute
And companable / and reuerent was she
Which is a thyng that causeth more dispence
Than worth is al the chere and reủerence
That men hem done at festes and at daunces
Such salutacions / and coıı̄untenᵃnces
Passeth as doth the shadowe vpon a walle
But woo is hym / that paien mote for alle
The sely housbond / algate he mote pay
He mote vs clothe / and vs aray
Al for his owene worship richely
In which aray we daunsen iolily
And if that he may not ꝑparauenture
Or list noon such enspence endure
But thenketh / that it is waast ⁊and lost
Than mote another paie for oure cost
Or lene vs golde / and that is ꝑperilous
This worthy Marchant / helde a noble hous
For whiche / he hadde alday grete repair
For his largesse / and for his wyf was faire
That wonder is / but herkeneth to my tale
Amonges alle his gestes / grete ⁊and smale
Ther was a monk / a faire man ⁊and a bolde
I trowe thirty wynter / he was olde
That euer in oon was drawyng to that place
This yonge Monk / that was so faire of face
Aquented was so wᵗith that goode man
And eke this monke / of which I bigan
Were bothe twoo born in oo vilage
The monke him claymed / as for cosyunage
And he ayein seith not onys nay
But as glad was therof / as foule of day
Forto his herte / it was a greet plesaunce
Thus ben they knytte / with eutrer alliaunce
And eche of hem gan other for assure
Of brethered / whil hir lyf may dure
Fre was daun Iohn / and namely of dispence
As in that hous / and ful of diligence
To do plesaunce / and also grete costage
He not foryate / to yeve the leste page
In al that hous / but after her degre
He yaf the lord / and sithen his meyne
Whan that he come / som maide honest thing
For which they were as glad / of his comyng
As foule is fayn / whan the sonne vp riseth
No more herof as nowe for thus suffiseth
But so bifelle this Marchaunt on a day
Shope him / to make redy his aray
Toward the toun of Brugges forto fare
To bien there a porcion of ware
For which / he hath sent to Paris anon̄
A messager / and prayed hat daun Iohn̄
That he shulde come / to seint Denys to pley
With him / and wᵗith his wyf a day or twey
Or he to Brugges wente in al wise
This noble Monke / of whiche I you devise
Hath of his Abbot / as him list licence
By cause he was a man / of high prudence
And eke an officere / out forto ride
To seen his graunges / and her bernes wide
And vnto seynt Denys / he comyth anon̄
Who was so welcome / as my lorde Daun Iohn̄
Oure dere cosin / ful of curteisie
With him brought he / a Iubbe of malvesie
And eke an other / ful of fyne vernage
As volatile / as ay was his vsage
And thus I let hem ete and drynke and pleye
This Marchaunt and this Monke a day or tweye
The thred day / this Marchaunt vp riseth
And on his nede sadly hym aviseth
And vp into his countre hous goth he
To rekne wᵗith him self as wel may be
Of thilke yere / how that it wᵗith him stood
And howe he dispended had his good
And ȝif that he encresed / were or non
His bokes and his bagges / mony oon
He leith to fore him / on his countyng borde
Ful riche was his tresour / and his horde
For which ful faste / his countre door he shette
And eke he nolde / that no man shuld hym lette
Of his accountes / for the mene tyme
And thus he sitte / til it was passed prime
Daun Iohn was risen / in the morowe also
And in the Gardeyne / walked to and fro
And hath his thinges / seide ful curteisly
This good wyf / come walkyng pryvely
Into the gardeyn / ther he walked soft
And him saluth as she hath done oft
A maide childe / come in hir companye
Whiche as she lust / that she may goủerne ⁊and gye
For ȝit vnder the yerde / was the mayde
O dere cosyn myn / Daun Iohn she saide
What eileth you / so sone to arise
Nece quod he / it ought ynogh suffise
Fyve houres forto slepe / vppon a nyght
But it were / for an olde palled wyght
As bene thise wedded men / that lye ⁊and dare
As in a forme sitte / a verray hare
Were al for straught / with hondes grete and smale
But dere Nece whi bene ȝe so pale
I trowe certes / that our good man
Hath you laboured sith the nyght bigan
That ȝe had nede / to resten hastely
And with that word he logh ful meryly
And of his thoght / he wex alle rede
This faire wyf / gan to shake her hede
And saide thus / ȝe god woot al quod she
Nay cosyn myn / it stant not so wᵗith me
For by that god / that yave me soule and lif
In al the Reaume of Fraunce is ther no wyf
That lasse lust / hath to that sory pley
For I may syngen allas / and welawey
That I was born / but to no nyght quod she
I Dar not tellen / how it stant wᵗith me
Wherfore I thenke out of this lande / to wende
Or ellis of my self / to make an ende
So ful I am of drede / and eke of care
This Monke bygan / vpon this wyf to stare
And seide allas Nece / god forbede
That ȝe for eny sorowe / or eny drede
Fordo youre self / but telleth me youre greef

div.l: (base) Par auenture I may in youre meschief
(base) Conseille or helpe and therfore telleth me
(base) Al youre anoy for it shal been secree
(base) For on my Porthors I make an oth
(base) That neuere in my lif for lief or loth
(base) Ne shal I of no conseil yow biwreye
(base) The same agayn to yow quod she I seye
(base) By god and by this Porthors I swere
(base) Thogh men me wolde al in to peces tere
(base) Ne shal I neuere for to gon to helle
(base) Biwreye a word of thyng that ye me telle
(base) Nat for no cosynage ne alliance
(base) But verraily for loue and affiance
(base) Thus been they sworn and her vpon they keste
(base) And ech of hem tolde oother what hem leste
(base) Cosyn quod she if that I hadde a space
(base) As I haue noon and namely in this place
(base) Thanne wolde I telle a legende of my lyf
(base) What I haue suffred sith I was a wyf
(base) With myn housbonde al be he youre cosyn
(base) Nay quod this Monk by god and Seint Martin
(base) He is namore cosyn vnto me
(base) Than is this leef that hangeth on the tree
(base) I clepe hym so by Seint Denys of France
(base) To han the moore cause of aqueyntance
(base) Of yow which I haue loued specially
(base) Abouen alle wommen sikerly
(base) This swere I yow on my professioun
(base) Telleth youre grief lest that he come adoun
(base) And hasteth yow and goth awey anon
(base) My deere loue quod she o my Daun Iohn
(base) Ful lief were me this conseil for to hyde
(base) But out it moot I may namoore abyde
(base) Myn housbonde is to me the worste man
(base) That euere was sith that the world bigan
(base) But sith I am a wyf it sit nat me
(base) To tellen no wight of oure priuetee
(base) Neither abedde ne in noon oother place
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) God shilde I sholde it tellen for his grace
(base) A wyf ne shal nat seyn of hir housbonde
(base) But al honour as I kan vnderstonde
(base) Saue vnto yow thus muche I tellen shal
(base) As help me god he is noght worth at al
(base) In no degree the value of a flye
(base) But yet me greueth moost his nygardye
(base) And wel ye woot that wommen naturelly
(base) Desiren thynges sixe as wel as I
(base) They wolde that hir housbondes sholde be
(base) Hardy and wise and riche and ther to free
(base) And buxom vnto his wyf and fressh abedde
(base) But by that ilke lord that for vs bledde
(base) For his honour myself for to arraye
(base) A Sonday next I moot nedes paye
(base) An hundred frankes or ellis am I lorn
(base) Yet were me leuere that I were vnborn
(base) Than me were doon a sclaundre or vileynye
(base) And if myn housbonde eek myghte it espye
(base) I nere but lost and therfore I yow preye
(base) Lene me this somme or ellis moot I deye
(base) Daun Iohn I seye lene me thise hundred frankes
(base) Pardee I wol noght faile yow my thankes
(base) If that yow list to doon that I yow praye
(base) For at a certeyn day I wol yow paye
(base) And doon to yow what plesance and seruyse
(base) That I may doon right as yow list deuyse
(base) And butI. do god take on me vengeance
(base) As foul as euere hadde Geneloun of France
(base) This gentil Monk answerde in this manere
(base) Now trewely myn owene lady deere
(base) I haue quod he on yow so gret a routhe
(base) That I yow swere and plighte yow my trouthe
(base) That whan youre housbonde is to Flandres fare
(base) I wol deliuere yow out of this care
(base) For I wol brynge yow an hundred frankes
(base) And with that word he caughte hire by the flankes
(base) And hire embraceth harde and kiste hire ofte
Goth now youre way quod he all stille and softe
And late vs dyne as sone as eủere we may
For by my khilendere / it is pⁱrime of the day
Goth nowe / and beth as trewe as I shal be
Nowe ellis / god forbede sire quod she
And forth she goth / as ioly as a pye
And bad the Cookes / that they shulde hem hye
So that men myghte dyne / and that anoon
Vp to hir husbond / is his wyf goon
And knokketh at his countour boldely
One la quod he / Peter it am I
Quod she / what how longe wol ȝe fast
Howe longe tyme / wil ȝe rekne and cast
Ȝoure sōmmes / youre bokes / and youre thinges
The devel have part / on al suche rekenynges
Ye han ynowe ꝑparde of goddes sonde
Come doun to day / and late youre bagge stonde
Ne be ȝe not ashamed / that Daun Iohn̄
Shal fastyng / al this day elenge gon̄
What lat vs here masse / and go we dyne
Wyf quod this man / evel caust thou devyne
The curious bysynesse / that we have
For of vs Chapmen / so god me save
And by that lorde / that called is seins Iue
Scarcely amonge xii / tweyne shul thryve
Continuelly lastyng / vnto oure age
We may wel make chere / and good visage
And dryve forth the worlde / as it may be
And kepen oure estate in privete
Til we be dede / or ellis that we play
A pilgrymage / or go out of the way
And therfore / have I grete necessite
Vppon this queint worlde / to avise me
For evermore / we moot stonde in drede
Of happe and fortune / and oure chapmanhede
To Flaundres wil I go / to morn at day
And come aȝein as sone / as eủere I may
For which my dere wif / I the biseche
As to be to eủery wight / buxom and meke
And forto kepe oure good be curious
And honestly / gouern wel youre hous
Thow hast ynowe / on eủery man̉ere wise
That to a thrifty huswyf / may suffise
The lakketh noon aray / ne no vitaile
Of syluer in thy purs thou maist not fayle
And with that worde / his countre door he shette
And don̄ he goth / no lenger uolde he lette
But hastely a masse / was ther sayd
And spedely the tables were ylayde
And to the dyner / fast they hem spedde
And richely this monk / the chapmon fedde
And after dyner / daun Iohn̄ sobrely
This chapman tooke aparte / al pryvely
He saide hym thus Cosyn Cosyn it stondith soo
Thal wel I see / to Brugges wol ye goo
God and seynt Austyn / spede you and gyde
I pʳᵃy you Cosyn / wisely that ye ride
Gouerneth you also / of youre dyete
And temꝑperlly / and namely in this hete
Bitwix vs twoo / nedeth no stronge fare
Fare wel Cosin / god kepe you from care
Ȝif eny thyng / therbe / by day or by nyght
If it ligge in my pouer and my myght
That ȝe me wol cōmmaunde in eny wise
It shal be done / right as ye wil devise
On thyng / er that ye goon / if it may be
I wil praye you / forto lene me
An C Frankes / as for a weke
For thynges I most bie / and bestes eke
To store wᵗith a place / that is oures
God helpe so / I wolde / that it were youres
I shal not faylle / sewerly of my day
Nought for a thousand Frankes / a myle way
But lat this thing be secre / I you prey
I wol non wite of it / but we twey
And fare nowe well / myn owne Cosyn dere
Graunt mercy for youre cost / and for youre chere
This noble Marchaunt / gentilly anoon
Answerde and seide / O Cosyn Daun Iohn̄
Nowe sikerly / this is a smal requoste
My golde is youres / whan that you leste
And not only my gold / but my chaffare
Take that you lest / god shelde ye spare
But oo thing is / ȝe knowe it wel ynowe
Of Chapmen / that her money is hir plowe
But goldelees forto be is no game
We may creaunce / while we haue a name
Paie it aȝein / whan it lith in youre ese
After my wit / ful fayn wold I you plese
Thise C frankes / he fett forth anoon
And pryuely toke it to Daun Iohn̄
No wight of al this worlde / wist of this lone
Savyng this Marchaunt / and Daun Iohn̄ allone
They dronken and romed / forto pley
Til that Daun Iohn̄ / rideth to his Abbay
The morn cam / and forth this Marchaunt rideth
To Flaundres ward / his prentys wel hym gideth
Til he come into Brigges / meryly
Now goth this Marchaunt fast and bysyly
Aboute his nede / and bieth and creanseth
He neither pleieth / at the dys ne daunseth
But as a Marchaunt / shortly forto telle
He lad his lyf / and ther I lete him dwelle
The sonday next / the Marchaunt was agon̄
To seynt Denys / ycomen is Daun Iohn̄
With croune and beerd fressh / and newe yshave
In al the hous / ther was so lusty knave
Ne no wight ellis / that he nas fayn
For that my lorde / Daun Iohn̄ was come agayn
And shortly to her poynt forto gon
This faire wyf accordeth to Daun Iohn̄
And for his C Frankes / he shuld al nyght
Have her in his armes / bolt vpright
And this accorde / ꝑparformed was in dede
In myrth al nyght / a besy lyf they lede
Til it was day / that Daune Iohn̄ went his way
And bad the mayne / fare wel / have good day
For noon of hem / ne no wight in the toun
Hath of Daun Iohn̄ / right no suspeccion
And forth he rideth / hoom to his Abboy
Or wher hym luste / no more of him I sey
This Marchaunt / whan that ended was the faire
To seint Denyse / he gan forto repaire
And wᵗith his wyf he maketh m̉erthe and chere
And telleth here / that chaffare is so dere
That nedes he most make a chevisance
For he was bounden / in a reconysance
To paie xxᵗⁱ Mˡ sheldes / anoon
For which this Marchaunt is wente to gon
To borowe / of certeyn frendes that he hadde
A certeyn frankes / and some wᵗith him he ladde
And whan that he was come / into the toun
For grete chierte / and grete affeccioun
Vnto Daun Iohn̄ / he first him goth to ploye
Nought forto borowe of him / no moneye
But forto wete and see / of his welfare
And forto tellen him / of his chaffare
As frendes done / whan they be mette yfeere
Daune Iohn̄ him maketh feestꝭes and mery chere
And him tolde / ayein ful specially
Howe he had bought / ful wel and gᵃraciously
Thonked be god / al hool his marchandise
Saue that he most / in al maner wise
Maken a chevisaunce / as for the beste
And than he shulde be / in ioye and in reste
Daun Iohn̄ answerde / certes I am fayn
That ye in hele bene cōmmen home ageyn
And if I were riche / as I have be er this
Of xxᵗⁱ Mˡ Sheldes / shulde ȝe not mysse
For ye so kyndely / this other day
Lent me golde / and as I can or may
I thonke you / by god / and by seint Iame

div.l: (base) But nathelees I took vnto oure dame
(base) Yowre wyf at hom the same gold agayn
(base) Vpon youre bench she woot it wel certayn
(base) By certeyn toknes that I kan yow telle
(base) Now by youre leue I may no lenger dwelle
(base) Oure Abbot wol out of this town anon
(base) And in his compaignye moot I gon
(base) Greet wel oure dame myn owene Nece swete
(base) And fare wel deere cosyn til we meete
(base) This Marchant which that was ful war and wys
(base) Creanced hath and payed eek in Parys
(base) To certeyn lombardes redy in hir hond
(base) The somme of golde and gate of hem his bond
(base) The somme of gold and gat of hem his bond
(base) And hoom he gooth murye as a Papyniay
(base) For wel he knew he stood in swich array
(base) That nedes moste he wynne in that viage
(base) A thousand frankes abouen al his costage
(base) His wyf ful redy mette hym at the gate
(base) As she was wont of old vsage algate
(base) And al that nyght in myrthe they bisette
(base) For he was riche and cleerly out of dette
(base) Whan it was day this Marchant gan embrace
(base) His wyf al newe and kiste hire on hir face
(base) And vp he goth and maketh it ful tough
(base) Namoore quod she by god ye haue ynough
(base) And wantownely agayn with hym she pleyde
(base) Til at the laste this Marchant seyde
(base) By god quod he I am alitel wroth
(base) With yow my wyf althogh it be me looth
(base) And woot ye why by god as that I gesse
(base) That ye han maad a manere strangenesse
(base) Bitwixen me and my cosyn Daun Iohn
(base) Ye sholde han warned me er I had gon
(base) That he yow hadde a hundred frankes payed
(base) By redy tokne and heeld hym yuele apayed
(base) For that I to hym spak of cheuyssance
(base) Me semed so as by his contenance
(base) But nathelees by god oure heuene kyng
I thoght not to axe / of him no thyng
I pʳᵃy the wyf / do no more soo
Telle me alway / er that I fro you goo
If eny dettour / hath in myn absence
Y paied the / lest thorgh thyir negligence
I myght him axe a thing / that he hath paied
This wyf was not aferde ne affraied
But boldely she seide / and that anoon
Mary I desie / that fals Monk Daun Iohn̄
I kepe not of his tokens / neủere a dele
He toke me certeyn gold / this wote I wele
That evel thedam / on his monkes snowte
For god it woot / I went with oute doute
That he had ȝeue it me / by cause of you
To do ther with myn honoure and my prou
For cosynage / and eke for beel chere
That he hath had / ful often tyme here
But sithen I see / I stonde in such disioynte
I wol answere you / shortly / to the peynte
Ȝe have mo stlakker dettours / than am I
For I wol paie you / wel and redely
From day to day / if so be I faile
I am youre wyf / score it on my taile
And I shal paie / as sone as eủere I may
For by my trouth / I have on myn array
And nought oon wasted / but bistowed euery dell
And for I have bistowed it so well
To youre honoure / for goddes sake I seie
As be not wroth / but lat vs laugh and pleye
Ye shullen my ioly body / have to wedde
By god I nyl not pay / you but abedde
For ȝeue it me / myn owne spouse dere
Turneth hiderward / and maketh better chere
This Marchaunt seigh / ther was no remedie
And forto chide / it nere but folye
Sithens that the king / may not amended be
Now wyf he seide / I for yeve it the
But by thy lyf / ne be no more so large
Kepe bette my good / this yeve I the in charge
Thus now endeth my tale / and god vs sende
Taillyng ynowe / onto oure lyues ende
¶ Here endeth the Shipmanes tale /
¶ And here bigynneth the prologe of the priores
We seide by corpus dominus / seide oure oste
Nowe longe mote thou seille by the see coste
Sir gentil Maist̉er gentil Marynere
God ȝeve the Monk / a thousand last quade yere
A ha. felawes / beth war of such a Iape
The Monke putte / in the mannes hode an ape
And in his wyves eke / by seynt Austyn
Draweth noo monkes / moor into youre Inne
But now passe over / and late vs seke aboute
Who shal now telle / first of alle this route
Another tale / and with that worde he saide
As curteisly / as it had bene a mayde
My lady Prioresse / by youre leve
So that I wiste / I shulde you not agreve
I wolde deme / that ye telle sholde
A tale next if so were / that ye wolde
Now wol ȝe vouche sauf / my lady dere
Gladly quod she / and seide as ye shal heere
¶ Thus endeth the prologe /

And here bygynneth the
Prioresses tale / of Alma redemptoris Mater /
O lorde oure lorde / thy name how m̉ervelous
Is in this large worlde / ysprad quod she
For nought only / thy loude p̉recious
Performed is / by men of dignyte
But by mouthe / of children / thy bounte
ꝐPerformed is / for in the brest soukyng
Somtyme shewen they / thine heryinge
¶ Wherfore in laud / as I can best and may
Of the / and of thi wit lily floure
Whiche that ye bare / and is a maide alway
To telle a story / I wol do my laboure
Nought that I may / encrece here honoure
For she here self / is honoʳe / and thereto Roote
Of bounte / next her sone / of soules boote
¶ O moder maide / o moder free
O bussh vnbrent / bennyng in Moyses sight
That ravisshed doun / from the deite
Thurgh thyn humblesse / the gost that in the light
Of whos vertue / whan he in thyme herte alight
Conceyued was / the Faders sapience
Helpe me to telle it / in thyne reủerence
¶ Lady thy bounte / and thy magnificence
Thyne vertue / and thy grete humylite
Ther may no tonge expresse in no science
For some tyme lady / er men preye to the
Thou gost biforn of thy benignite
And getest vs to light thorgh thy preyere
To gyden vs vnto thy sone so clere
¶ My conyng is to wake / o blessful quene
Forto declare / thy grete worthynesse
That I ne may / the weght not sustene
But a childe of xii moth eelde or lesse
That can vnnethes eny worde exp̉resse
Right so fare I and therfore I you preye
Gydeth my songe that I shal of you seye
Ther was in Asie a grete Citee
Amonges cristen folk a Iurie
Susteyned by a lorde / of that contre
For foule vsure / and lucre of vilanye
Hatful to crist / and to companye
And thorgh the strete / men myght ryde ⁊and wende
For it was free / and open at euery ende
¶ A litel scool of cristen folk / ther stode
Doun at the ferther ende / in whiche there were
Children an hepe ycome / of cristes bloode
That lered in that scole / ȝere by ȝere
Suche man̉ere docctryne / as men vsed there
This is to say / to syngen and to rede
As smale children don / in her childhede
¶ Amonge thise childrene / was a wydowe sone
A litel chergeon vii ȝere of age
That day by day / to scole was his wone
And eke also / where he segh the ymage
Of cristes moder / he had in vsage
As he was taught / to knele adon ⁊and seie
His aue marie / as he goth by the weye
¶ Thus hath this widowe / hire litel childe taught
Oure blisful lady / cristes moder dere
To worship ay / and he forgate it naught
For a sely childe / wil al day sone lere
But ay whan I remembre me on this matere
Seint Nicholas stant / euer in p̉resence
For he so yonge / to crist did reủerence
This childe / his litel boke lernynge
As he satte in the scole / at his prymere
He Alma redemptoris / herde synge
As Children lered / her antiphonere
And as he durst / he drough him nere ⁊and nere
And herkeneth ay / the wordes and the note
Til he the first vers couthe / al by rote
¶ Noght wist he what the latyn / was to sey
For he so yonge / and tender was of age
But on a day / his felawe gan he prey
To expownen him / this song in his langage
Or tellen him / why this songe was in vsage
This preide he / him to construe ⁊and declare
Ful often tyme / vppon his knees bare
¶ Hes Felawe / which that elder was than he
Answerde him thus / this songe I haue herde seie
Was made of oure blessed lady free
Hir to saluwe / and hir eke eke forto preie
Toben oure helpe / and socour whan we die
I can no more expounde / in this matere
I lerne songe / I can but smal gᵃmere
¶ And is this songe / ymade in reủerence
Of Cristes moder / seide this Innocente
Now certes / I wol do my diligence
To conne it / er cristemasse be wente
Though that I for my primere shal be shent
And shal be beten / thries in an houre
I wil it conne / oure lady forto honoure
¶ His felawe taught him homward priuely
Fro day to day / til he couthe it by rote
And thane he songe / it wel and boldely
From woorde to worde / accordyng to the note
Thrise on a day / it passed thorgh his throte
To scoleward and homward / whan he went
On Cristes moder / sette was his intent
¶ As I have seide / thorgh out þe Iuery
This litel childe / as he come to and froo /
Ful meryly / than he wolde synge ⁊and cry
On Alma redemptoris / euermoo /
The swetnesse hath his herte / perced soo
Of cristes moder / that to her to preie
He can not stint / of singging by the weye
¶ Oure first foo / the serpent Sathanas
That hath in Iwes / the waspes nest
Vpswal and seide / O Ebraik puple allas
Is this a thing to you / that is honeste
That suche aboy / shal walken as hym leste
In youre despite / and singen of such sentence
Which is aȝeins / youre lowes reverence
¶ From than forth / the Iewes han conspired
This Innocent / out of this worlde to chace
In homycide therto / han they hired
That at an Aley / in a pⁱriuey place
And as the childe gan forby forto pace
This cursed Iewe him hent / and helde faste
And kitte his throte / and in a pyt him caste
¶ I sey that in a warderope / they him threwe
Wher as Iewes / purged her entraile
O cursed folk / of herodes al newe
What may youre evel intent you avayle
Mordre wil oute certeyn / it wol not fayle
And namely ther the hounre of god shulde sprede
The blood out crieth / on ȝoure cursed dede
¶ O Martir sounded to virgynyte
Nowe maist thou sing folowyng eủere in oon
The white lambe / celestial quod he
Of which / the grete Euᵃaungelist seint Iohn̄
In Pathmos wrote which sore they that gon
Bifore this lambe / and sing a songe al newe
That never flesshly woman / that knewe
¶ This pore widowe / wayteth al that nyght
After this litel childe / but home come he nought
For whoom as sone / as it was dayes light
With face pale / for drede and hevy thought
She hath atte scole / and ellis where him sought
Til fynaly she gan so ferre aspie
That he was sene last / in the Iewerie
¶ With moders pite / in her herte enclosed
She goth / as though she half were out of mynde
To euery place / where she hath supposed
By liklyhede / hir childe to fynde
And euer on cristes moder / meke ⁊and kynde
She cried / and atte last thus she wroght
Amonge the cursed Iewes / she him soght
¶ She freyneth / and she pᵃraieth pitously
To euery Iewe / that duellith in thilke place dwelleþ in þilk place
To telle hir of hir childe went hym by
They seiden nay / butIħcIhesu of his gᵃrace
Ȝaf in her thought / within a lytel space
That in þᵗat place / after herr sone she cried
Ther he was cast / in a pytte beside
¶ O grete god / that ꝑperformest thy laude
By mouth of Innocence / lo here thy myght
This Gmme of Chastite þis Emerawde
And eke of Marterdome / the ruby bright
Ther he with throte / ycorve lay vpright
He Alma redemptoris / ganto syng
So loude /that al the place gan to ryng
¶ The cristen folk / that throwe the street went
In cāmen / forto wondren on this thinge
And hastely / they for the prouoste sent
He come anoon / wᵗith oute taryinge
And herieth crist that is of heuene kynge
And eke his Moder hounre of mankynde
And after that / þᵉ Iwes / he lete bynde
¶ This childe wᵗith pitous lamentacion
Vp taken was / syngyng his songe alway
And with honour / and grete ꝓprocession
They carien him / to the next Abbay
His Moder swonnyng by the beere lay
Vnnethes myght the puple / that were there
This newe Rachel / bryng fro his bere
¶ With torment and with shamful deth ilkon
This provoost / doth the Iewes forto sterue
That of this mordre / wist and that anon
He nolde non suche cursednesse obserue
Evel shal have / that evel wil deserue
Therfore with wolde hors / he dide hem drawe
And after that / he henge hem by the lawe
¶ Vppon this Beer / ay lith this Innocent
Biforn the cheef Auter whilis masse last
And after that / the Abbot wᵗith his couent
Had sped ham / forto bury him fast
And whan they holy water / on him cast
Ȝit spak the childe / whan spreint was the holy water
And songe oo Alma redemptoris mater
¶ This Abbot / which that was an holy man
As monkes ben / or ellis oughte to be
This yonge childe / to cōmuire he bigan
And seide o dere childe / I halse the
By vertue of the holy Crynyte
Telle me / what is thy cause forto singe
Sithen thy throte is kitt / at my semynge
¶ My throte is kitte / vnto the nek bone
Saide this childe / and as be way of kynde
I sholde have deide / ȝe longe tyme agone
But IħuIhesu crist / as in bokes fynde
Wil that his glorie / last and be in mynde
And for the worship of his moder dere
Ȝit may I synge / o Alma loude ⁊and clere
¶ This welle of m̉ercy / crites moder swete
I loued alway / as after my cōmnynge
And whan that I / my lyf shulde lete
To me she come / and bad me forto synge
This Anteme verely in my deyinge
And as ȝe han herde and whan that I had songe
Me thought she leide / agreyn vpon my tonge
¶ Wherfore I synge / and synge moot certeyn
In hounre of the blesful martrer fre
Til of my tonge / taken is the greyn
And after þat þus seide she to me
My litel childe / nowe wil I fecche thee
Whan that the greyn / is from thy tonge take
Be not agast / I wil the not forsake
¶ This holy monke / this Abbot him mene I
His tounge out kaught / and toke awey the greyn
And he ȝaf vp the goost / ful softely
And whan the Abbot / had this wonder seyn
His salt teres / striked doun as reyn
And gruff he felle / alle plat to the grounde
And stille he lay / as he had bene ybounde
¶ The Couent eke lay / vppon the payment
Wepyng and heriyng / cristes moder dere
And after that /they rise and forth bene went
And toke away this Martir / fro his bere
And in a tumbe of Marbel stonys clere
Enclosen they / his litel body swete
Ther he is nowe / god leue vs forto mete
¶ O younge hewe hewe of lyncoln slayn also
With cursed Iewes / as it is notable
For it nys / but alitel while a goo
Prey eke for vs / we synfull folk vnstable
That of his m̉ercy / god so m̉ercyable
On vs his grete m̉ercy multiplie
For reủer ence of his moder / swete Marie /
¶ Here endeth the Prioresses tale / ⁊etc̉etera
¶ And here bygnneth the prologe of ʆser Thopas / for Chaucers
Whan tolde was this tale / eủery man
As sober was / that wonder was to see
Til that oure host / Iape to bigan
And than at erst / he loked vppon me
And seide thus / what man art thou ꝙquod he
Tho lokest as thou wold fynde an hare
For euer / vppon the grounde / I se the stare
¶ Approche nere / and loke meryly
Now war you sires / and lat this man have place
He in the wast is shapen / as wel as I
This were a popet / in Armes to enbrace
For eny woman / smal and faire of face
He semeth elvissh / by his contenᵃnce
For vnto noo wight / doth he daliaunce
¶ Say nowe some what / sithens other folk / han seide
Telle vs a tale of myrth and that anoon
Host quod I / ne beth not euei apaide
For other tale / certes can I noon
But of a ryme / I lerned longe agoon
Ȝe that is good / quod he / nowe shul we here
Some deinte thyng / me thenkith by thy chere /
¶ Here bigynneth the tale of Chaucers of ʆser Thopas
Lesteneth lordes in good intent
And I wil telle verement
Of a myracle and of solace
Al of a knyght / was fair ⁊and gent
In bataille and in tornement
His name was ʆser Thopace
Yborn he was in fer countree
In flaundres al byȝonde the see
Alt poperyng in that place
His Fader was a man ful fre
A lorde he was of that contree
As it was goddes gᵃrace
Sir Thopas was a doughty swayn
White was his face / as Paynemayn
His lippes rede as rose
His rud is like scarlet in greyn
As I you telle in good certeyn
He had a semely nose
Hes heer his berde / was like safron
That to his girdel / come adon
His shoon of cordewayn
Of Brugges were his hosyn broun
His Robe was of Ciclatoun
That coste mony a Iayne
He couthe hunte at wilde dere
And ride on haukyng for the Ryvere
With grey Goshauke on honde
Therto he was a good Archier
To wrastlyng / was ther noon his pere
Ther eny man shold stande
Ful many a maide bright in boure
They morne for him ꝑparamoure
Whan they were bet to slepe
But he was chast and no lechour
And swete / as is the bramble flour
That bereth the ryde hipe
And so bifell on a day
For soth as I you telle may
Sir Thopas wolde out ryde
He worþ vppon his stede grey
And in his hand / a launcegey
Alonge swerde by his syde
He priketh thorowe a faire Forest
Ther Inne is mony a wylde best
Ȝe bothe buk and hare
And as he priketh norght and este
I telle you / him had almeste
Ytid a sory care
Ther spryngeth / herbes grete and smale
The licorice / and the setuale
And mony a clowe Gillofre
And notimiges yput male
Wheder it be moyst or stale
Or forto ley in Coffre
The briddes synggen it is no nay
The Sperhauke / and the popyniay
That ioye it was to here
The throstelcok made eke his lay
The wode dove / vppon the spray
She songe ful loude and clere
Sir Thopas felle in loue longynge
And whan he herde / the throstel synge
He pricked / as he were wode
His faire stede in his prickynge
So swette / that men myght him wrynge
His sydes were alle bloode
Sir Thopas eke so wery was
For prickyng on the soft gras
So fers was his corage
That doun he laide him in that place
To maken his stede some solace
And yaf hym good forage
For he was so sauage
O seint Marie benedicite
What eileth thus loue at me
To bynde me so sore
Me dremed al this nyght ꝑparde
An Elfe quene / shuld my lemman be
And slepe vnder my gore
An Elfe quene wil I loue ywis
For in this world no woman is
Worthy to be my make in ton
All other women / I forsake
And to an Elfe quene / I me bitake
By dale and eke by don
Into his sadel he come anon
And priketh ouer style and ston

A yong man whylom called Melyby myghty and ryche

and thorowe hardynesse of hym self / hath so grete p̉resumpcioıı̄un hym
shal evel betyde /

¶ That shul ye euermore encounterwayte / enbussh
mentes / and all espialle /
¶ For as seith the wise man̄ /

he ne falleth
into ꝑperiles / that ꝑperiles escheweth /

¶ And al be it so / that thou seme
that thou be in secre place / yet shalt thou alway done thi diligence
in the kepyng of thy ꝑpersone /

not only from thy grettest enemye /
but onely from thi lest enemye /.

¶ Senek seith / a man that ys wel ¶ Seneca
avised / he dredeth his lest enemye /

¶ Ovide seith / that the lytel
wessell wol slee the grete Bolee / and the wilde herte /

And the pro
verbe seith / that the lytel thorn̄ may greve a kyng full soor / and a
¶ The tale
lytell hounde will holde the wilde Boor /

But nathelees I say not thou
shalt be so couard / that thou doute / wher as is no drede /

¶ The
boke seith that sōmme men have grete lust to disceyue But yit they
drede to be disceyued /
and kepe the from the compayne of scorners

For the boke seith / that sōmme men̄ han grete lust to scorne / to
suche ne make thou no compayne / but fleeth heer wordes as
venym̄ /

¶ Now as to the secounde poynt / wher as youre counseilloᵘurs
counseilled you to warnistore youre houses / with grete diligence

I wold fayne knowe / how that ye vnderstande / thilk wordes / and
what is youre sentence /

¶ Melibius answered and seide Certes
I vnderstande in this wise / that I shal warnistore my hous with
Toures / suche as Castels han / and other man̉er edifices / and armure
and archers

bitwene which thynge if I may my ꝑpersone and myn̄
hous so kepe / and defende / that myn̄ enemyes shullen be in drede
my hous forto aproch /

¶ To this sentence answered Dame
prudence / ¶ warmyshyng quod she / of hie edefices / and of hie tours
apꝑperteneth sōmme tyme to pride /
¶ And eke men̄ make hie Toures

and
vnderstande well / that the grettest / and the strengest garnsoıı̄un / that
riche men may have / as wel to kepe here ꝑpersones / as here goodes /
is
that he be biloued with his subiettes / and wᵗith his neghbours /

For thus seith Tullius / ¶ That ther is a maner Garnysoıı̄un / that ¶ Tullius These marginal notes are again partially trimmed.
no man̄ may venquenchen / ne discomfeten / ¶ And that is

a lorde to
be biloued of his Citeseyns / and of his puple /

¶ Now sir / to the
iij poynt / wher as youre olde and wise counseilloᵘurs seiden̄ / ¶ That
ye ne ought not sodenly ne hastely proceden in this nede /

But that
ye oughten̄ purvey and apparaille you in this caas / with grete
diligence / and wᵗith grete delib̄eracioıı̄un /

¶ Trewely I trou / that they seiden
right wisely / and right soith /

¶ For Tullius seith in eủery nede ¶ Tullius
or thou bygynne it / Apparaile the wᵗith grete diligence /

¶ Then saie
I that in vengeance takyng in werre in bataille / and in warnistoryng

or thou bygynne / I rede that thou apparaile the therto / and do it
wᵗith grete delib̉eracioıı̄un /

¶ For Tullius seith that longe apparaillyng ¶ Tullius
to forn the Bataille / maketh short victorie /

¶ And Cassidorus ¶ Cassidorus .
seith / the garnysoıı̄un is strenger whan it is longe tyme avised

But
let vs speke of the counsell / that was accordet by youre neghbours
suche as don̄ you reủerence withoute loue /

youre olde enemyes recon
siled / ¶ youre Flaterers

that counseilled you certeyn̄ thynges
pⁱrively / and openly counseilled you the contrarie /
¶ The yonge folk also that counseilled

¶ Of Meliby
the deth /

¶ But yet for the grete goodnesse / and debonairte / that alle
the world witnessith of youre ꝑpersone / ¶ we submytten̄ vs to the excel
lence / and benygnyte of youre gᵃraciouse lordeship̄ /

and bene redy to obeie
to all youre cōmmaundementes / Bisechyng you / that of youre m̉erciable
pyte /

ye wolne consider / oure grete repentaunce / and lowe submyssioıı̄un
and to gᵃraunte vs foryeuenes / of oure outrageous trespasse / and offence /

For wel we knowe / that youre liberal gᵃrace / and mercy strecchith further
into goodnesse /

than̄ done other outᵃrageous giltes / and trespaces / into wic
kedenesse / Al be it / that cursedely and dampnably we han gilt ayeinst
youre high lordeshup̄ / that trewely we han̄ deʆserued the deth /

¶ Then
Meliby toke hym vp from the grounde / ful benygnely /

and resceyued
here obligacions / and her landes / by here othes vppon̄ here plegges

⁊and
assigned hem a c̉erteyn̄ day / to retourne vnto his Courte /

forto accepte
and resceyue the sentences / and iugementes / that Meliby wolde cōmman
de to be doon̄ on hem by the causes afornsaide /

¶ which thynges ordeyned
eủery man retourned to his hous /

¶ And whan that Dame prudence
segh hire tyme / she feyned / and axed here lorde Meliby

what venge
aunce he thought to take / on his Adủersaries /

¶ To whiche Meliby ans
wered and seide / ¶ Certes quod he / I thenke and pᵘurpos fully

to dishe
rite hem / and al that they han / and forto putten hem in exile for ever /

¶ Certes quod Dame prudence / this were a cruel sentence / and
moche ayenst reson̄ /

For ye bene riche ynowe / and han̄ no nede to an
nother mannes good /
and ye myght lyghtly gete you a coueitous name
which is a vicious thyng / and ought be eschewed of eủery man /

¶ For
after the sawe of the Apostell / Coueityse is Roote of all harmes /

¶ And therfore it were better to lese so mochel good of youre owne
than̄ forto take of here good in this maner

For better it is to lese good
with worship̄ / than it is goode to wynne with vilenye and shame /
And eủery man̄ ought to doon̄ his besynes to geten hym a goode name
¶ And yet shal he not only kepen hym in kepyng his goode name /

But he shal also / enforcen hym alway to do sōmme thyng / by which
he may renovel his goode name /

¶ For it is ywreten / that the olde
goode loos or goode name / of a man̄ is sone gon̄ and passed / whan
it is noght newed ne renoveled /

and as touchyng that ye seien / that
ye wil exile youre aduersaries /

that thenkith me mochel ayeinst reson
and out of mesure /

¶ Considereth the power / that they haven yeven
you vppon hem self /

and it is wreten / that he is worthy to lese his
previlage / that mysuseth the myght / and the power / that is yeven hym
¶ The tale /

¶ And I sett caas / that ye myght annoye hem / that peyne by right and
by lawe /
whiche I trowe ye may noght do

I say / ne myght not put it to
execucioıı̄un ꝑparaventure /

and than̄ were it lykly to retourne to werre / as
it was byforn̄ /

¶ And therfore if ye wil / that men do you obeisaunce
ye most done more curteisly /

this is to seine / ye most yeve more
esy sentence and Iugementes /

For it is wreten̄ / that yhe ye he / that most
curteisly cōmmaunden / to hym most obeien̄ /

¶ And therfore I pᵃray / that
in this necessite / and in this nede / ye casten therfore to ouercome
youre herte /

¶ For Senec seith / ¶ He that he that oủercometh his herte ¶ Seneca
ouercometh twies /

¶ And Tullius seith / Ther is no thynge so cōmmen ¶ Tullius
dable in a grete lorde /

as whan he is debonaire and meke / and appe
sith hym mekely

And I pᵃray you / that ye wil forbere nowe to do venge
aunce

In suche a maner / that youre goode name / may be kept and
conserued /

and that men may have cause and mat̉er / to praise you of
pite and of m̉ercy /

and that ye have no cause to repent you of thyng
that ye doon̄ /

¶ For Senec seith / ¶ He ouercometh in evil maner ¶ Seneca / These marginal notes are again partially trimmed.
that repentith hym of his victorie /

wherfore I pᵃray you / lat mercy
bene in youre herte /

to the effecte / and the entent / that god almyghty
have m̉ercy vppon you / in his last Iugement

with oute mercy / shal be
to hym / that han no m̉ercy of a nother wight /

¶ Whan Meliby had herde
the grete skilles and resons / of Dame prudence / and of wise informacions
and techynges

his herte gan̄ enclyne / to the wil of his wiff / consideryng
to the trewe entent /

confoᵘurmed hym anoon̄ / and assented fully to wir
chyne after hure counsell /

and thonked god / of whom procedith alle
goodenesse / that hym sent a wiff of so grete discrecioıı̄un /

¶ And whan̄
the day come / that his adủersaries shulden appere in his p̉resence /

he
speke to hem ful goodely / and seide to hem in this wise /

¶ Al be it
so / that of youre pryde by p̉resumpcioıı̄un / and folie / and of youre necli
gence / and vnkonnynge /
ye have mysborn̄ you / and trespassed to me /
¶ And for as moche / as I see / and biholde youre grete humylite /

and
that ye bene sory and repentant of youre gyltes /

it constreyneth me
to do you gᵃrace and m̉ercy /
Wherfore I resceyue you / to my gᵃrace /

and forye
ven you intierly alle the offences / Iniuries and wronges / that ye han̄
don̄ ayeinst me and myn̄ /

to this effecte / and to this ende / that god
of his eendeles m̉ercy

wil at the tyme of deyinge / foryeve oure giltes
that we have trespassed vnto hym in this wrecched world /

for doutles
if we be sory and repentant of the synnes and gyltes / in the whiche
we han trespassed / in the sight of oure lord god /

he is so free and so
¶ Of Meliby /
mercyfull /
that he wil foryeven vs / oure giltes

and bryngen vs
to thillk blisse / that never hath ende /

To whiche blisse / he vs brynge
that blood on Croys for vs did Sprynge / Qui cum deo patre ⁊et c̉etera
Here endeth / Chaucers his Tale / of Meliby /

div.l: And here bygynneth the prolog of the Monke his Tale /
I Wil be weille in maner of Tregedie /
The harme of hem / that stonden in high degre
And fallen so that ther nys no remedie
To bryng hem out of her aduersite
For certeyn̄ whan that fortune lust to flee
Ther may no man̄ of here the cours witholde
Beth ware / by these ensamples / yonge and olde /
At lucifer thogh he an Angell were /
div.note: ¶ Pᵒrimo De Lucifero
div.l: And noght a man̄ / at hym I wil begynne
For though fortune / may non̄ Angel dere /
From high degre / yet felle he for his synne
Doon into helle / wher as he yit is Inne /
Of lucifer / brightest of Angelys alle /
Now art thou Sathanas / that maist not twynne
Out of myserie / in which thou art falle in
¶ Lo Adam whiche oure foᵘurme fader was
div.note: ¶ De Adam
div.l: Begeled was thorwe fendes tysynge /
Wherthorugh we alle myghten seien allas
Ne hadde be the birth / of our lordes comynge
Wherfore alle gan to sprynge /
Amonge the puple / thorgh vertue of his birth
For that we mowe in herte singynge /
Both maken ioie gladnesse and myrth
¶ Lo Sampson which was anunciate
div.note: ¶ De Sampson̄
div.l: By the Angel longe er his natyuyte
And was to god almyghty consecrate
And stoode in noblesse / whiles he myght se
Was never such another as was he /
To speke of strenght / and therto hardynesse
But to his wiffes told he his secre /
Thorgh which / he slowe hym self for wrecchednesse /
Sampsoıı̄un this noble and myghty Champioıı̄un
Withoute wepen / sauf his handes tweye /
He slowe and alto rent the lioıı̄un
Toward his weddng / walkyng by the weye /
His fals wif couthe hym so plese and preye /
Til she his counseil knewe / and she vntrewe
Vnto his foos his counsell gan by wreye
And hym forsoke / and toke another newe /
An hundred foxes toke Sampsoıı̄un for Ire
And here tailles alle / he to geder bounde
And sett the foxes tailes al on a fire
For he in euery tayle had putt a bronde
And they brent alle / the cornes in that lande
And all here Olyues / and here vynes eke
A mˡthousand men he slough eke wᵗith his hande
And had noo wepen̄ / but an asses cheke
Whan they weren slayen̄ so thrested hym that he
Was wel nygh lorn̄ / for whiche he gan to preie
That god wold of his peine have pyte
And sende hym drenke / or ellis most hym deie /
And of his asses cheke / that was so dreye /
Out of a wang toth / spronge anon̄ / a well
Of whiche he dranke ynowe shortly to seye
Thus holpe hym god / as Iudiciūm can̄ telle /
By verrey force at gasoıı̄un on a nyght
Maugre philistiens of that Cite
The gates of the Toune he hath up plight
And on his bak ycaried hem hath he
Hegh on a hille / wher as men myght se /
O noble and myghty Sampson lief and dere
That so stronge so noble and myghty hast be
In al this world ther nas never thy pere /
This Sampson̄ / never sider dronke ne wyne /
Ne on his heved come rasour non̄ ne sheer
By p̉recept of the massager devyne
For al his strengħt was in his heer
And fully twenty yere by yere
He hadde of Israel the gouernance
But after soon̄ shaƚƚ he wepe mony a teere
For wōmmen shul brynge hym to myschaunce /
Vnto his lemman Dalida he tolde
That in his heeres al his strengtħ lay
And falsly to his foomen / she hym solde
And slepyng on hir barme vpon̄ a day
She made to clippe or sheere his heer away
And made his foomen al his craft espien
And whan that they hym founden in suche aray
They bounde hym fast and put out his eyen
But or heer were iclipped or Ishave
Ther was no bonde that mygħt hym bynde /
But nowe is he in prison put in a kave /
Wher as they made hym at the querne grynde
O noble Sampson̄ strengest of mankynde
O whilom Iuge in glorie and richesse /
Thou maist now wepe / wᵗith thyin yen blynde
Setħ thou art from wele fallen into wracchednesse /
The ende of this Catif / was as I shal saye
His foomen made a fest vpon̄ a day
And made hym as here fool biforn̄ hem pleye
And this was at the temple of grete Aray
But at the last / he made a foule affray
For he two postes shoke / and made hem falle
And doune fille temple / and al ther it lay
And slougħ hym self / and eke his foomen alle /
This is to seien the prynces eủerychon̄ /
And eke a Mˡ bodies were there slayn̄
Witħ falleng of the grete temple of ston̄
Of Sampson̄ ne wil I no more saien̄
Betħ ware of thise ensamples olde and pleyn̄
That no man̄ tel here counsel to her wyves
Of suche thynge / as they wolde have secre fayn̄
If that touche hir lymmes or hir lyves /
Of hercule the soủeraigne Conqueroᵘur
Syngen his werkes higħ and lowe / renon /
For in his tyme of strengtħ he bere the floᵘur
He slougħ / and raft the skyn fro the lyon̄
He of Sentawers leide the boost a don̄ /
He Arpies slougħ / the cruel briddes felle
He golden apples / raft the dragon̄
He drowe out Serberois the hounde of helle /
He slougħ the cruel tyraunt Buserus
And made his hors to frete hym flessħ and bon̄
And slougħ the verray serpent venemous
Of Achilles / two hornes / he breke on̄
And he slougħ kacus in a kaue of ston̄
He slougħ the geant Anteus the stronge
He slougħ the grisly Boor / and that anon̄
And bare the hede vpon̄ his nek longe /
Whas never wigħt sithe the world bygan̄
That slougħ so mony monslers as did he /
Thorgħ out the world / his name ran̄
What for his strengħt / and for his bonte /
And euery Reme / went he forto see /
He was so stronge / that no man̄ mygħt hym lett
And bothe the worldes ende saitħ Trophe /
Instede of Bondas / he a pilere sette /
A lemman had this noble Campion̄
That higħt diamyre / fresche as may
And as Clerkes maken mension̄ /
She hatħ hym sent / a shert fressħ and gay
Allas this sherte / and wel away
Envenymed was subtelly witħ aƚƚ
That er he had wered it half a day
Hit made his bones from his flessħ falle
But nathelees some clerkes hir excusen ·
By oon that higħt Nessus that it maked
Be as be may I wil hir not excusen
But on his bak tho shert he wertħ al naked
Til that the Flessħ was for the venym blaked
And whan he segħ noon other remedye
In hote cooles he hatħ hym self raked
For wᵗith no venyme / deyned he to deye /
This starf this worthy myghty Ercules
Loo who may trest on fortune eny throwe
For hym that folowetħ / al the world of prees /
Er he be ware / is oft yleide ful lowe /
Ful wise is he / that hym self can knowe /
Be ware / for whan̄ that fortune list to glose
Than waitetħ she hur man don̄ throwe
By suche a way / as he wolde lest suppose /
The myghty Trone the p̉recious tresour
The glorious scepter and real mageste
That had the kynge Nabugodonosor
Witħ tonge vnnetħ may discrived be
Hie twies nam Ierusalem the cite
The vessel of the temple he wᵗith hym ladde
At Babiloyne was his souerayne See
In whiche his glorie and his delite he hadde
The fairest Childer / of the blood Roiaƚƚ
Of Ierlm̄Ierusalem he did do geeld anon̄
And made eche of hem to bene his thraƚƚ
Amonge al other Danyel was oon̄ ·
That was the wisest child of eủerychon /
For he the dremes of the kyng expouned
Wher as in Calday / Clerk was ther non̄
That wist to what fyne / here dremes souned
This proude kyng lett make a stature of gold
Syxty cubytes longe / and vij in brede
To whiche ymage / bothe yonge and olde
Comaunded he to loute / and have in̄ drede
Or in a fourneis ful of flammes rede
He shal be brent / that wol not obeye
But never wolde assent / to that dede
Danyel ne his yonge felowes tweye
This kyng of kynges proude and Elate
He wend god / that sute in Magistee
Ne mygħt hym not bireve of his estate
But sodenly he lost his dignytee
And like a beest him semetħ forto be /
And eete hay as an Oxe / and lay therout
In reyne witħ wilde bestes walked he
Tyl certeyn̄ tyme / was come about
And ilike an Egles fethers were his eeres
His nayles lyke to clowes of briddes were
God releued hym at certeyn̄ yeres
And yaf hym witte / and than̄ wᵗith mony a tere
He thonked god and ever his lif in fere
Was he to don̄ amys / or moor t̉respasse
And or that tyme ileide was on his bere
He knewe weƚƚ / that god was ful of mygħt and gᵃrace /
¶ His sone whicħ that higħt Balthasare
That heelde the Beaume after his Fader day
He by his fadere coutħ not be ware
For proude he was of herte / and of aray
And eke an ydolatre was he aye
His highe estate assured him in pride
But fortune cast hym don̄ / and ther he lay
And sodeynly his regne gan devyde /
A feest he made vnto his lordes alle /
Vppon a tyme / he made hem blitħ be
And than his Offic̉ers gan he calle
Gotħ bryngetħ fortħ the vessels quod he
Whicħ that my Fader in his ꝓprosꝑperite
Out of temple of Ierlm̄Ierusalem byrafte
And to oure goddes thonke we
Of honours / that oure elders witħ vs lafte
His wif his lordes / and his Concubynes
Ay dronken / the whiles her appetit laste
Out of thise noble vesselles sondry wynes
And on a walle / this kyng his eyen̄ caste
And segħ an hande Armelees that wrote ful faste
For feer / of whicħ he quoke / and sighed soor
This hand / that made Baltazar so soor agaste
Wrote Mane techel phares / and no more
In al that lande / Magicien was ther non̄
That couthe expoune / what this letter ment
But Danyel expouned it anon̄
And seide kyng / god / thy Fader sent
Glorie and honoᵘur regne tresour and rent
And he was proude / and no thyng god ne dradde
And therfore / god grete wreche vppon hym sente
And hym biraft the regne / that he hadde /
He was out · cast / of mannys companye
Witħ asses / was his habitacion̄
And eete hay as a best in wete and drye
Tyl that he knewe by grace / and by reson̄
That god of heven̄ hatħ domynacion̄
Ouer euery regne / and euery creature
And than had god / of hym compassion̄
And hym restored his regne / and his figure /
Eke thou thart his sone / art proude also /
And knowest aƚƚ thise thynges prively
And rebelle to god / and art his Foo /
Thou dronke eke / of his vessellis boldely
Thy wiff eke / and thy wenches sinfully
Dranke of the same vesseƚƚ sondry wynes
And heried fals godes cursedly
Therfore to the shapen grete peyne is
This hande was sent fro god / that on the walle
That wrote / Mane techel phares / trest me
Thy regne is don̄ / thou weiest not at alle /
Devided is the regne / and it shal be
To medes and parses / yeven quod he
And thylke same nygħt / the kyng was slawe /
And Darius occupyetħ his degree
They he therto nad nother rigħt ne lawe
Lordynges her by ensample may ye take
How that in lordshyp̄e nys no sikernesse
For whan̄ fortune wil a man̄ for sake
He beretħ a way his regne / and his richesse
And eke his frendes / bothe more and lesse
And what man̄ hatħ frendes / thorgħ fortune
Mishappe wil make hevynesse I gesse
This ꝓproverbe is ful sotħ / and ful comune
Cenobia and palimer the Quene
As writen ꝑperisience of here noblesse
So worthy was in armes / and so kene
That no wigħt / passed here in hardynesse
Ne in lynage / ne in other gentilnesse /
Of kynges blood of percy / es she descended
I sey that she made is not most of fairenesse
But of shap / she mygħt not be amended
From hir childhode / I fynde that she flodde
Office of wōmmen / and to the wode she wente
And mony a wilde hertes blood she shedde
Witħ arowes brode / that she to hem sente
She was so swift / that she anon̄ hem hente
And whan̄ that she was elder / she wolde kylle
Lyons / leoperdes / and beeres alto rente /
And in heere armes / welden hem at here wille /
She dorste wildes beestes Dennes seke
And renne in the mounteyn̄ al the nygħt
And slepen vndre the bussħ / and coutħ eke
Wrastel by verray force / and verrey mygħt
Witħ eny yonge man / wher he never so wigħt
Ther mygħt no thyng in her armes stonde
She kept hire maidenhode fro eủery wigħt
To no man deyned she to be bounde /
But at the last / here frendes han here maried
To Odonake a prince of that countre
Al were it so / that she hem longe taried
And ye shul vnderstande / how that he
Hadde suche fantasies / as hadde she
But nathalees / whan they were knyt in fere
They leved in Ioie / and in felicitee
For eche of hem had other lief and dere /
Sauf oo thynge / that she nolde never assent
By no way / that he shulde by here lye /
But ones / for it was hir pleyn̄ entent
To have a childe / the worlde to multiplie
And also sone / as she mygħt espie /
That she was not witħ childe wᵗith that dede
Than wolde she suffre hym doon̄ his fantasie
Eft sone / and nat but ones out of drede
And if she were witħ childe in thilke caste
No more shulde he pleye thilke game
Til fully xl daies were paste
Than wolde she / ones do suffre hym the same /
Al were this Onedak wilde or tame
He gate no more of hure / but thus she seide
It was to wyves leccherie and shame
In other caas / if that men witħ hem pleide /
Twoo sones by this Odenak had she /
The whiche she kept in vertue and in letterure /
But nowe vnto oure tale turne we
I say that wirshupful creature
And wys ther witħ / and large wᵗith mesure
And pesebly in the werre / and curteise eke
No more labour mygħt in werre endure
Was non̄ / thougħ al this world men shulde seke /
Here riche array mygħt not be tolde
As wel in vesseƚƚ / as in clothynge
She was al clad in perry and in gold
And eke she laft not for non̄ huntenge
To have of sondry tonges folk knowynge
Whan she leiser hadde / and forto entende
To lerne bookes / was al here likynge
How she in vertue / mygħt hir lyf dispende /
And shortly of this storie forto entrete
So doughtely was he husbonde as she /
That they conquered mony regnes grete
In the orient witħ mony a faire Citee
Apꝑpertenent vnto the mageste
Of Rome / and witħ stronge heelde hem faste
Ne never mygħt hir foomen doon̄ hem slee
Ay whiles that Odenak daies laste /
Her batailles who so lust hem forto rede /
Ageyn̄ Sapor the kyng and other moo /
And how that al this prossesse fille in dede
Whi she conquered / and what title had therto
And after of hir meschief and her woo
How she was byseged / and itake /
Lat him vnto my Maist̉er petrak goo
That writ ynowe / of this I vnderstande /
Whan Odenake was dede she mygħtely
The regnes heelde / and wᵗith here ꝓpropre hande
Ayenst hir foos / she fougħt trewely
That ther nas kynge ne prynce in al that lande
That he nas glad / yf he that gᵃrace fande
That she ne shulde vppon hem werrey
With hire they maden aliaunce by bounde
To bene in̄ pees / and let here ryde and pley
The Emꝑperoᵘur of Rome Claudius
Ne hym byforn̄ the Romayne galien̄
Ne durst never be so coragius
Ne non̄ hermenye / ne non̄ Egipcien̄
Ne Surreyne ne none Arabyene
Witħ Inne the feelde / that durst wᵗith hire figħt
Lest that she wolde / hem witħ here handes sleen
Or witħ here mayne / putten hem to flygħt ·
In kynges Abyte went her sones twoo
As heires of here regnes alle
And hermanno / and thymalao
Here names were / as ꝑperisience hem calle
But fortune hatħ ay in here hony galle /
This myghty Quene / may noo while endure
Fortune out of hure regne made hure falle
To wrecchednesse / and to Misauenture /
Aurelion whan̄ that / þᵗat the goủernᵃaunce
Of Rome / come into his handes tweye /
He shoop vppon̄ this Quene to do vengeance
And witħ his legioıı̄uns he toke his weye
Toward Qenobie / and shortly forto seye
He made her flee / and at the laste here hent
And fettred here / and eke hir childern̄ tweye
And wan̄ the londe / and home to Rome he went
Amonge thise other thynges that he wan̄
Hure Chare / that was witħ golde wrogħt and perry
This grete Romayn̄ / this Aurelian̄
Hatħ witħ hym lad / for that men shuld see
Biforne his Trihumphe walked shee
Witħ gilt Chaynes or here nek hanginge
Corowned she was as after here degre
And ful of perry charged her clothynge /
Allas fortune / she that whilom was
Deedfuƚƚ to kynges / and to Emꝑperours /
Nowe gauretħ aƚƚ the puple on hire allas
And she that helmed was in stark stoures /
And wan by force / Townes stronge and Towres
Shal on here hede / nowe bere a vitremyte
And she that bere the Septer ful of Floures
Shal bere a distaf / he cost forto quyte /
¶ O noble worthy petir glorie of Speyne
Whom fortune heelde so higħ in Mageste
Wel ougħt men / thy pitous detħ compleyne
Thy bastard brother / made the for flee
And after at a Sege by subtilite
Thou were bitrayed / and lad vnto his Tent
Wher as he witħ his owne hande slowe the /
Succedyng in thi regne and in thy rent
¶ The feelde of snowe / witħ the Egle blak ther ynne
Caugħt witħ the lymrode / colours as the glades
He brewe this cursednesse and al the synne
The wicked nest was wirker of these nedes /
Nougħt Charles Olypher / that ay toke goode hede
Of troutħ and honour / but Armorek
Genylon Oliuer corrupt for mede
Broughtest this worthy kyng in suche a brek
¶ Worthy petir kynge of Cipre also
That Alisaunder wanne by his maistrie
To ful many an hethen / thou wroghtest woo
Of whiche thyne owne legis had envie
And for no thynge / but for thy chyualrie
They in thy bed han̄ slayn̄ the / by the morowe
Thus can fortune gerien and gye
But out of Ioie / brynge men into sorowe /
¶ Of Meleyn̄ grete Barnabo vescounte
God of delyte / and scourge of lumbardie
Whi shuld not / I thyn̄ fortune acounte
Sithen in estate / thou clomben were so hye /
Thy Broder sone / that was thy double allie
For he thy neviwe was and sone in lawe
Withyn his prison̄ made the to die
And why ne howe wote I / that thou were slawe /
¶ Of the Erle hugelyn̄ / of pise the languour
Ther may no tunge telle for pyte
But litel out of pise stant a tour
In whicħ tour in prison put was he
And witħ hym / bene his litel childern three
The eldest scarsely v yere was of age
Allas fortune / it was grete crueltee
Sucħ briddes forto putte in suche a cage
Dampned he was to deye in that prison̄
For Rogger whicħ that bisshop̄ was of pyse
Hadde on him made a fals suggestion̄
Thorgħ whiche / the puple gan on hym aryse
And putt hym to prison in suche wyse
As ye han herde / and mete and drynke he hadde
So smal that it mygħt not suffise
And ther witħ al it was ful poor and badde /
